HEADLINE: 3 Papers' Unions Set Deadline

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11

 BODY:
In an effort to shift contract talks to economic concerns, unions representing workers have set a deadline of 5 P.M. Friday for strikes against The San Francisco Chronicle, The San Francisco Examiner and The San Jose Mercury News. The Conference of Newspaper Unions, representing 10 unions and 4,500 employees, took the action last week. Employees have been working without a contract since Feb. 2.

HEADLINE: New York City Is Hurt But Still Has Reserves;
The Law: A Difficult Year, But With Potential

BYLINE: By Stephen Labaton

 BODY:
After 20 years of nonstop growth, Manhattan's largest law firms are facing their toughest year in decades.
Largely because of the slump on Wall Street and the downturn in the financial-services industry, leading law firms are in creasingly dismissing lawyers -- a phenomenon virtually unknown until now.
And for the first time in years, there are jitters at law schools about whether jobs will be available -- especially at those firms that start new lawyers at $85,000 a year.
There are now more than 125,000 lawyers licensed in New York State and a majority of them do business in New York City.
Perhaps the best illustration of the industry's troubles is Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, Manhattan's largest firm, which hired away lawyers by the battalion from competitors. Skadden, Arps built a large national practice around its reputation as a premier Wall Street player. Now the firm has stopped hiring lawyers from other firms, frozen associates' pay at last year's levels and, some associates said, begun laying off dozens of junior lawyers.
 
The Boom in Bankruptcy
 Yet, there are some positive trends.
The law, more than most industries, finds profits in the hardships of the economy and is able to weather downturns somewhat better than other economic sectors. Litigation, for example, remains largely unaffected.
And bankruptcy practice, once disdained as a second-rate field relegated to has-beens and lower-rate practitioners, is now a hot practice and will likely remain so for some time. The larger bankruptcies, like those of Drexel Burnham Lambert and Eastern Airlines, require teams of lawyers to represent the companies, creditors and shareholders, and the cases can take years to resolve.
And, to the extent that large real estate developers like Donald J. Trump encounter significant difficulties, law firms can count on substantial business in attempting to keep their clients afloat.
Recognizing this, several leading firms, including Willkie, Farr & Gallagher; Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, and O'Melveny & Myers, have taken steps to bolster their bankruptcy practices.

HEADLINE: New York City Is Hurt But Still Has Reserves;
Health Services: Medical Industry Is Still Flourishing

BYLINE: By Josh Barbanel

 BODY:
While some sectors of New York City's economy appear to be shrinking, health care remains an important growth industry, generating 7,000 new jobs a year and more than $1 billion in construction. Still, some economists say that despite this growth, there are ominous signs of decay.
One of every 12 private-sector jobs in New York City -- or a total of about 250,000 -- is in health services. These jobs have been increasing at a rate of about 3 percent a year, said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "It has been one of the key growth engines of the economy throughout the 1980's," he added. "It continues to be the leading growth sector."
To Mr. Ehrenhalt, this job growth, financed in large part by government health insurance programs and insulated from the vagaries of the economy, has become a main source of employment for unskilled workers.
 
Problems Driving the Growth
 Others take a less sanguine view, pointing out, for example, that much of this growth has been driven by the city's worsening social and medical problems, including homelessness, drug addiction and AIDS. And the jobs are more likely to be for low-paid home health-care workers than for scientists.
"We don't have the kind of activity that is attracting future Nobel Prize winners," said Rae Rosen, an economist at the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York.
Though New York City still ranks second, after Boston, in Federal medical research grants, it is losing ground, several studies indicate. "We are just being increasingly outbid by other parts of the country that can put together better facilities, better research and living conditions, and it really hurts the city," said William A. Polf, a deputy vice president for external affairs at Columbia University.
Still, one of every seven patients at the private hospitals is drawn from beyond the city limits by the promise of better medical care. A survey by U.S. News & World Report found that seven of America's best hospitals were in New York City, more than in any other city. And at least $1.1 billion in hospital construction is under way, with another $2 billion in work expected to begin in the next year or two.

HEADLINE: New York City Is Hurt But Still Has Reserves;
Public Sector: Government Help, At Least for Now

BYLINE: By Richard Levine

 BODY:
Even in bad times, New York can count on prodigious public spending to help prop up its economy -- at least for a while.
Since the end of 1987, as industry after industry stumbled and private employment waned, jobs in govern ment rose by 23,000. That brought the total increase in government jobs for the 1980's to 95,000, or one of every four jobs created in the city's most prosperous decade since World War II. All of this increase was generated locally, because the small rise in the number of state workers was more than offset by a decline in Federal employment in the city.
No government can long continue to hire in the face of a declining economy, and Mayor David N. Dinkins said last week that he would eliminate about 5,000 positions this fiscal year and perhaps 20,000 more next year. But New York City still plans to spend nearly $4 billion a year on long-term projects, much of it on dilapidated public works.
In addition, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is spending huge sums. By 1992, it will have spent $16 billion in a 10-year effort to rehabilitate the commuter rail lines and the subways. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is spending $1 billion or so a year on its bridges, tunnels and airports. And the School Construction Authority will spend $4.3 billion over the next five years.
 
Powerful Stimulus for New York
 All this spending is a powerful stimulus even to an economy as big as New York's. The transportation authority's spending alone, for example, would keep more than 200,000 people employed for a year. And it is partially self-perpetuating, because it will generate $700 million in state and local taxes.
The drawback is that for decades, residents and businesses will be paying for this work in taxes and fees and fares. Mindful of the strain, the Citizens Budget Commission recommended somewhat regretfully that the city cut long-term spending, and the Dinkins administration has pushed back some projects and reduced others.
But Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist of the Port Authority, said she believes that now is not the time to make large cuts in such spending, in part because it helps the economy but also because the work is necessary. "Everything needs patching and repairing," she said.

HEADLINE: New York City Is Hurt But Still Has Reserves;
Banking: Many Questions About the Future

BYLINE: By Michael Quint

 BODY:
With their profits and stature at a low ebb, New York's largest banks are realizing that their size and traditions do not guarantee them a place at the top of the financial-services indus try in 10 years.
The banking industry prob ably faces more questions about its future than perhaps any other important segment of the New York City economy. Banking provides more than 170,000 jobs in the city, up by more than 10,000 in a decade. Still, banking employment has fallen by about 15,000 in the last three years.
Costly mistakes on loans to less-developed countries and real estate developers have so weakened the largest banks that they now lack the financial muscle to expand into new markets and businesses.
Still, demand for bank products is growing at a healthy rate, which is one reason why nonbanking companies like the General Electric Company have moved into areas like corporate lending and credit cards.
For now, the city's largest banks -- with the exception of J. P. Morgan & Company and the Bankers Trust Company -- are so strapped by bad loans that they are concentrating on cutting costs. But in the coming decade, bankers and analysts expect a wave of mergers, acquisitions and joint ventures.
 
Millions of Dollars in Savings
 The merger of any two big New York banks could raise their profits by hundreds of millions of dollars by eliminating duplicate branches, headquarters and executives.
Since Citibank, the nation's largest bank, has only about 15 percent of consumer accounts in the New York market, and Chemical, Manufacturers Hanover and Chase Manhattan, the next three, have a total share of only about 18 percent, some analysts see room for large-scale consolidation without any bank gaining monopoly power.
Thomas Labrecque, chairman of Chase Manhattan, said consolidiation need not be limited to banks. He noted that competitors like the mortgage unit of the General Motors Corporation often have lower costs. Chase would consider merging or creating joint ventures with such companies, he said.
Analysts are confident that a large banking industry will remain in New York City, but the organizations and even the names of banks are in question. The answers depend on whether banks are allowed and have the inclination to merge with each other or industrial companies, to develop nationwide branches, or to expand into securities and insurance.
New York City is likely to be headquarters for at least a few of the giant banks in the next generation, but many jobs will be elsewhere. A number of large banks already have credit-card operations in states like Delaware and South Dakota, where taxes and labor costs are lower.

HEADLINE: New York City Is Hurt But Still Has Reserves;
The Media: Growing Trouble For the Networks

BYLINE: By Bill Carter

 BODY:
Network television is in a steep downturn that has led to forecasts of reduced profits and possible layoffs. Cable television, on the other hand, is doing fine.
And these trends are not good for New York City.
The three big television networks have always had their headquarters in Manhattan. Last year ABC, CBS and NBC employed about 12,000 people in New York and generated a total of $10.8 billion in corporate revenues.
The cable industry, by contrast, has important power bases in Denver, the home of the largest cable operator, Tele-Communications Inc., and in Atlanta, the home of Ted Turner's cable empire, though several important cable channels, including HBO and MTV, are based in New York City.
Network revenues grew by only 2.5 percent last year from 1988. That was less than half the annual growth rate of 5.7 percent from 1985 to 1989, according to the investment firm of Veronis, Suhler & Associates.
Some additional growth is expected this year, but several analysts predict a flat year at best in 1991. The following year, with the Olympics and a Presidential election, could bring a revival of advertising, they say.
"We are surely in a trough for the network business," said John Reidy, an analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.
 
Problems for Publications
 The same advertising weakness is also affecting magazines and newspapers, which employ about 41,000 people in New York.
Several leading magazine publishers are based in New York, including the Time Inc. Magazine Company, Conde Nast and Hearst. In addition, The New York Times Company and Dow Jones & Company are based in Manhattan. All have been hurt by the advertising slump.
As a result, layoffs in the media industry seem to be likely. Mr. Reidy said layoffs were the only effective way to cut costs. But because the industry is so visible, he said, layoffs can create unfavorable publicity and contribute to the advertising slowdown.
Mitchell Moss, the director of the Urban Research Center at New York University, said he thought the television networks could recover by becoming "idea exporters."
"What we do best here in New York is create ideas that are made into media products," he said. "The networks ought to be able to make television a global export."

HEADLINE: New York City Is Hurt But Still Has Reserves;
Advertising: Too Many Ties To Walk Away

BYLINE: By Kim Foltz

 BODY:
Like it or not, the advertising industry is stuck in New York City. As long as the city remains a mecca for the arts and the media, advertising will stay close by.
"We've looked at the possibility of moving the agency outside New York, and right now it just can't effectively be done," said Graham Phillips, the chairman and chief executive of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide. "The most creative people want to live in New York. They need the stimulus of things like the theater or simply the conversation at popular restaurants."
The New York anchor to the commercial-production industry also seems firmly in place. Because an advertising campaign can change many times before the final version is set, many advertising executives said, agencies still need to remain near production houses so alterations can be made quickly.
But while many production companies are still in New York, they are increasingly doing the filming in locations like Canada or Australia, where the work costs less.
Currently, half the people in advertising in the United States work at New York agencies. But the total number of people working in the industry in New York has declined to 39,000 from a peak of 41,800 in 1985.
The industry is in the midst of a slowdown. Many clients are cutting their budgets and the overall rate of increase in advertising spending has fallen drastically during the last few years. This trend is expected to continue for at least another year.
 
'The Next Logical Move'
 "Agencies are being squeezed by rising rents and taxes and falling compensation from clients," said John O'Toole, the president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies. "To cut costs, most agencies have moved from their expensive Madison Avenue locations to offices on the West Side and downtown. The next logical move will be out of Manhattan."
During the next 5 to 10 years, some large agencies will probably relocate operations like accounting, but many agency executives think New York will continue to be an advertising center.
The hundreds of small and medium-size agencies seem eager to stay in the city. "Smaller agencies tend to attract more adventuresome people," said Marty Weiss, the co-chairman of Weiss Whitten, one of the little companies. "Sure, New York is frightening, but that is part of what makes it creatively exciting."

HEADLINE: New York City Is Hurt But Still Has Reserves;
Retailing: Big-Name Stores Strive to Survive

BYLINE: By Isadore Barmash

 BODY:
Sweeping changes in New York City's retailing and apparel industries seem inevitable, because of changing consumer tastes, in creasing competition and ever-growing finan cial pressures. Some big retailers may change ownership, and many are expected to close some larger stores, open smaller ones and, in general, have a tough time surviving.
Department stores, specialty shops and other retailers are among the largest employers in New York City, with nearly 260,000 workers, down slightly from 1989.
For more than a year, retail sales in New York and its suburbs have barely kept pace with inflation. In part, this trend reflected the layoffs on Wall Street and elsewhere in New York. It is also a reflection of the downturn in the national economy.
Indeed, sales at department stores in the New York metropolitan area declined by 4.1 percent in 1989, in contrast to an annual growth rate of 8.7 percent from 1982 to 1987.
 
Financial Pressures
 Perhaps more than anything else, the financial pressures created by merger-induced bankruptcies at the parent company of Bloomingdale's, at Abraham & Straus and at Stern's, and the debt-laden position of R. H. Macy & Company have raised questions about the future of these famous stores.
B. Altman closed its doors for those reasons in January, joining other failed New York retailers like Gimbels, Ohrbach's, Korvettes, J. W. Mays and S. Klein.
Some industry executives believe the major retailers will survive these difficulties. "Bloomie's and Macy's will still be around because of their unique position, while A.& S. and Stern's will continue to occupy the middle ground," said Thomas Rauh, regional director of retail services for the accounting firm of Ernst & Young.
Others have doubts. "I cannot say positively that Macy's and Bloomingdale's will survive," said Helen Galland, a marketing consultant and former president of Bonwit Teller. "They are too highly leveraged."
Reflecting much of the same consolidation and financial pressures, the garment industry is expected to be whittled down as retailers move more toward large suppliers with out-of-town or overseas manufacturing.
As in retailing, the trend to bigger but fewer companies will create opportunities for small and medium-size fashion designers and garment makers to provide more specialized merchandise. But these companies will have to be highly creative to survive.

HEADLINE: New York City Is Hurt But Still Has Reserves;
Blue-Collar Workers: Industries Fading, But Not the Jobs

BYLINE: By Richard Levine

 BODY:
Once the bedrock of New York City's economy, the manufacturing industries that historically provided many blue-collar jobs have been leaving the city for years. Even during the prosperity of the 1980's, the city lost about 150,000 factory jobs.
But to the surprise of some labor economists, blue-collar workers are not disappearing. In fact, despite the lost factory jobs, the overall number of blue-collar workers increased by 140,000 from 1983 to 1989, bringing the total to 740,000 last year. Blue-collar jobs of all types now account for about a fifth of the city's work force.
Still, in a city that has become increasingly dominated by what Mr. Ehrenhalt of the Bureau of Labor Statistics calls knowledge-based industries, many of these blue-collar jobs require more training and more skills than the usual entry-level, industrial jobs. Workers who once might have worked on carburetors are now expected to care for computers and other sophisticated electronic gear.
This problem is a worrisome one in New York City, where already perhaps half a million working-age people are not looking for work, because they are held back by lack of education or skills. Indeed, only 25 percent of the city's young people have jobs or are looking for them, about half the rate of their counterparts in Houston or Los Angeles.
Construction work has been a quick route to the middle class, especially for many people just starting their work lives. But that industry, which had surged in the 1980's real estate boom, is now experiencing a sharp decline that has idled as many as 25 percent of the workers in some trades.
"The more demanding jobs structure and an education system with a 38 percent dropout rate are on a collision course," Mr. Ehrenhalt warned.

HEADLINE: Finally, a Little Courage on Trade

 BODY:
After years of intransigence, and only weeks before the Uruguay Round of international trade talks is scheduled to end, the European Community offered last week to trim its protectionist farm policies. The European leaders did not offer much in the way of concessions. But the proposal will at least keep the trade talks alive.
Third world exporting nations threatened to pull out of the talks if industrialized nations refused to let in more food and textiles. In exchange for greater access, the third world would negotiate new rules -- important to the developed nations -- governing trade in agriculture, services and intellectual property. Until last week, the European leaders -- primarily at the insistence of the French and Germans -- had refused to budge. 
 Despite the new proposal, the negotiators remain far apart. If a deal is to be struck before the December deadline, President Mitterrand, Chancellor Kohl and President Bush will have to take charge, and soon.
The E.C. proposal would cut farm subsidies by 15 percent from current levels. That's a far cry from the demand of the United States and a group of 14 agricultural exporting nations, to cut price supports by 75 percent and export subsidies by 90 percent. And the proposal includes an objectionable provision that would, in effect, allow the E.C. to increase tariffs on American soybeans and some other products.
The Europeans are not the only obstinate leaders. The Japanese won't agree to import rice; and the U.S. proposes to exempt telecommunications, aviation and shipping from the new regulations governing service industries.
The common thread in these difficulties is the willingness of government leaders to sacrifice the well-being of the vast majority of their citizens to protect the economic privileges of politically powerful industries.
European taxpayers pay huge sums, more than $100 billion each year, to support a handful of inefficient family farmers. Yet President Mitterrand and Chancellor Kohl, who faces an election early next month, fight to preserve these outrageous subsidies. To its credit, the Bush Administration seems willing to stand up to farm and textile interests. But it has caved in to the shippers, undermining a clean U.S. bargaining position.
The economic gains from an international trade agreement would be enormous, adding perhaps $1 trillion to the U.S. economy alone. To reap these benefits, the Western leaders will have to stare down the special interests.

HEADLINE: Socialist Vows to Be Capitol Outsider

DATELINE: BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 8

 BODY:
Twenty years ago, many Vermont residents saw Bernard Sanders as little more than a political hippie.
He was an outspoken advocate of social causes who called himself a socialist and called for taxing the rich, caring for the poor and building a truly progressive political party in America. 
 Now, irked by flip-flopping politicians and the legacy of Reaganomics, voters in this increasingly liberal state have ousted their Congressman and are sending Mr. Sanders to Washington in his place.
Mr. Sanders, the former Mayor of Burlington, identifies himself as a "democratic socialist," but he ran for Congress as an independent, defeating the state's lone Representative, Peter P. Smith, a Republican, by 17 percentage points on Tuesday. Mr. Sanders is the first truly independent candidate elected to Congress since Henry Frazier Reams, a former Democrat, was elected to the House in 1952.
"If timing is everything in politics, this was perfect timing for his campaign," said Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin, who like other New England Governors is seeing her state slide into recession. "Now the question is whether a man who has made his career fighting the system will be able to be an insider and an outsider at the same time."
And while Mr. Sanders admits he has learned how to make short-term compromises, the 49-year-old Brooklyn native said his unequivocal answer to the insider-outsider question was "no."
His credentials as a socialist date to his membership in a Socialist party at the University of Chicago. In 1980 he was one of three electors for the Socialist Workers' Party, and then helped formed a new Vermont party, the Burlington Progressive Coalition.
In his victory speech Tuesday night Mr. Sanders said Vermont was "leading the way for the fight for a political revolution which would take power from the wealthy and return it to the people."
Sitting at his campaign headquarters here, surrounded by crudely written cardboard "Bernie" signs, and biting into a McDonald's pastry, Mr. Sanders said: "I'm not an insider. I know who I am. I know where I came from. I don't need to get down on my knees and ask rich people for their help. The point of this is to show the nation that we, here in Vermont, have given people a real political alternative."
His victory, he added, is evidence that working-class people can "fight against the establishment."
Mr. Sanders, who came to Vermont in 1968, has long been a renegade in a state that was once the most Republican in the union. After running unsuccessfully in four statewide races as a Liberty Union Party candidate, Mr. Sanders stunned established politicians in 1981 by defeating Gordon H. Paquette, Mayor of Burlington for five terms. His winning margin was 10 votes.
Mr. Sanders was elected to four consecutive two-year terms. Since leaving office in 1989, he has taught at Hamilton College in Clinton, N.Y., and at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. He has been praised for pushing through progressive programs in Burlington: an after-school program for youths, city-subsidized child care, a community boathouse, a city arts office and a youth council.
Mr. Sander's Congressional campaign, supported by an extensive grass-roots organization, was propelled by a backlash against Mr. Smith, a freshman Representative who seemed to change positions on two pivotal issues: gun control and the Federal budget.
Even though Mr. Sanders supports gun control, the National Rifle Association endorsed him after Mr. Smith voted for controls on semiautomatic assault-type weapons after earlier promising to oppose such measures.
In a campaign appearance by President Bush, Mr. Smith was critical of the final form of the budget, although he had voted for the preliminary Congressional budget package that would have cut $60 billion in Medicare spending and raised taxes on gasoline and home heating oil.
The Democrat in the House race, Delores Sandoval, trailed badly after announcing a proposal for "controlled legalization" of drugs.
Mr. Sanders says his agenda in Congress will include lower limits on campaign spending, a steeply progressive income tax, a national health care program, support for education, affordable housing and 50 percent cuts in military spending over the next five years.
Mr. Sanders said that he hopeds to join the Democratic Caucus in the House and would support the Democratic committee appointments but that he would not change his independent status to do so. "We are causing them a good deal of consternation I realize," Mr. Sanders said with a smile, "but I'm optimistic things will work out."
Speaker Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, has said Mr. Sanders's membership would be subject to a caucus vote on Dec. 3. Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, chairman of the Democratic group, said he would wait to comment until the vote.
But Representative Charles Wilson, Democrat of Texas, expressed reservations about the newcomer. "The Democratic Caucus is for Democrats," Mr. Wilson said. "I'm sure the more liberal members of the caucus will welcome him in. But to many of us from the South, it is going to be hard when our opponents start saying that the Democrats and the socialists have all gotten together."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bernard Sanders, the Representative-elect from Vermont, in Burlington last week. He identifies himself as a "democratic socialist." (Paul O. Boisvert for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD;
Syphilis Fools a New Generation

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, M.D.

 BODY:
SYPHILIS, which is known as the great imitator because it mimics so many other diseases, is making its strongest comeback in 40 years in the United States. And it is fooling a generation of doctors who have rarely, if ever, seen a case.
Many doctors are scurrying to textbooks and flocking to lectures to learn about the unusual ways the bacterial infection can damage organs at any age, from newborns to the elderly. 
 Specialists from pediatricians to pathologists have mistaken the sores of syphilis for cancers, abscesses, hemorrhoids, hernias and other conditions. Pediatricians have mistaken the sniffles than can result at birth from congenital syphilis for the flu. Other doctors have also mistaken different forms of syphilis for dizziness from Meniere's disease and multiple sclerosis.
Dr. William Schaffner 2d, who heads the department of preventive medicine at Vanderbilt University, described a case that mystified several specialists in Nashville.
A young man with a painless sore on his penis went to a doctor who, believing the man had cancer, took a biopsy that he sent to a pathologist for identification under the microscope. The pathologist was stumped and he sent the biopsy to a colleague: he diagnosed syphilis.
Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spiral-shaped bacterium known as a spirochete. The microbe is most commonly spread by sexual contact, and the disease appears in three stages.
The first stage is characterized by a painless sore, a primary chancre, that usually appears 21 days after exposure. The edges of the sore are hard, like cartilage, and can appear anywhere there has been sexual contact, such as the penis, vagina, cervix, tongue and anus.
Untreated syphilitic sores disappear after two to six weeks. From six to eight weeks later, the spirochete spreads silently through the blood to cause the second stage. It often appears as a rash that may be accompanied by swollen lymph nodes throughout the body, a sore throat, weight loss, malaise, headache and loss of hair. The second stage of syphilis can also damage the eye, liver, kidney and other organs.
If untreated, the second stage of syphilis heals within two to six weeks. Then years to decades later it can damage the heart, aorta, bones and cause paralysis and dementia.
The symptoms from syphilis not only are transient but can vary greatly, which explains its reputation as the great imitator. And if a doctor misses the early stages, Dr. Schaffner said, "the patient becomes a biological time bomb waiting to develop tertiary syphilis."
Syphilis can also harm newborn babies through transmission of the spirochete from the mother to the fetus in pregnancy. A baby born with syphilis often has a runny nose and can have a rash and other symptoms that resemble an adult's secondary stage. Congenital syphilis can cause deafness, anemia and permament damage to the bones, liver and teeth.
But prompt and adequate treatment of the syphilitic mother with antibiotics usually prevents damage to the unborn baby, and treatment of an infant with syphilis generally prevents permanent damage.
Dr. Harold Neu said the infectious disease team he heads at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York had recently found a number of mothers whose blood tests showed no evidence of syphilis yet who gave birth to babies with the disease.
The doctors found that the mothers had such a heavy infection that standard testing methods were unable to detect it. The problem was solved by modifying the laboratory technique, Dr. Neu said.
New cases of syphilis are at the highest level since 1949.
Dr. Willard Cates Jr., an expert at the Federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, said the centers expected about 50,000 cases to be reported in 1990, as against 41,942 in 1949. The reporting of syphilis is the most reliable of all the sexually transmitted diseases.
The surging number of cases reflects social and economic factors like changing sexual habits; drug abuse, particularly trading sex for crack; rising rates of pregnancy among teen-agers who do not use contraceptives to protect against infection and declining support for public health services, which has limited tracing some cases.
Some epidemics occur because a microbe develops resistance to antibiotics, but the spirochete that causes syphilis is still killed by penicillin, the drug that has been used to treat it since World War II.
In New York State, "a booming syphilis epidemic" is occurring, says Dr. David Axelrod, the Health Commissioner. Testing for syphilis of all patients 15 to 45 years old who are admitted to hospitals and treated in emergency rooms is the current standard of medical care, Dr. Axelrod said. This practice was dropped in the years when the number of syphilis cases reached record lows. No other state has adopted a similar measure, though pregnant women are often tested in other states.
The surge is primarily among black and Hispanic heterosexual men and women in cities. A primary factor is the trading of sex for drugs. Women who give birth to babies with syphilis are more likely to have used crack while pregnant and less likely to have received prenatal care.
Health officials are also deeply concerned about the links between syphilis and AIDS. The open sores of syphilis are belived to make it easier for the AIDS virus to enter the body.
A rule among public health workers in past years was to not let the sun set on an untreated case of syphilis. But that goal is now often impossible because budget cuts have strapped the public clinics where most syphilis and other sexually transmitted diseases are diagnosed.
"What happens is that clinics become backed up at 11 A.M. when they used to take new patients until 4 P.M. and some clinics have to stop accepting new patients before noon because they cannot handle the load," said Dr. King K. Holmes of the University of Washington in Seattle, an expert on sexually transmitted diseases.
The delays translate into additional cases of syphilis because untreated patients pass the infection on to sex partners and babies. Health workers who trace sexual contacts of syphilis patients have found that about one of two people named as contacts are also infected.
Until the recent resurgence, syphilis was not a research priority, said Dr. Edward W. Hook 3d, an expert in sexually transmitted diseases at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore. "It was a hard organism to work with, time consuming, expensive, and people viewed it as a minor and declining problem," Dr. Hook said. "Now we find ourselves knowing so little about it."
Health workers cannot be blamed for ailments of patients who do not come for care, but Dr. Laurene Mascola of the Los Angeles County Health Department said that if she were a lawyer, she "would put society and health departments on trial for allowing the escalation of congenital syphilis cases in the era of penicillin."

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By WOODY HOCHSWENDER

 BODY:
But Is It a Business?
 Profit does not seem to be the point at Romeo Gigli 's new Manhattan store, which opened a week ago. With its Venetian-glass chandeliers, mosaics, Fornasetti screens, outdoor garden and gallery, the store is definitely unusual. But is it a business?
Takashimaya , a Japanese retail company that financed the Gigli boutique in Paris, bought the building, at 21 East 69th Street. The first three floors, where the men's and women's clothing are sold, are a joint venture of Takashimaya and Mr. Gigli. Mr. Gigli (whose name is pronounced ZHEE-lee) leases the fourth floor, which is a gallery, and the fifth, which is used for offices. Plans call for sales of $1.8 million in the first year. The first week, the store took in $20,000, which is off the pace, but boutiques often do better as time goes by.
The least expensive item is a pair of socks, for $35. Some of the coats, almost ecclesiastical in their embroidered finery, cost more than $30,000.
"In our business, image is No. 1," said Ellen Carey, who is, appropriately, the image director of the company in New York. "We really want to show the most creative pieces, even if they don't sell."
But more reasonable merchandise is on its way. Mr. Gigli's resort collection, which begins arriving this week, includes cotton-Lycra tops, skirts and pants in the $300 to $550 range. Next year there will be a lower-priced collection called G. Gigli, for both men and women. This more casual sportswear line is being created primarily for the American market.
"It will have all of his best shapes," Ms. Carey said, "all the pieces that everyone else has been knocking off."
The reason Mr. Gigli is doing a secondary line, apparently, is that everybody else seemed to be doing one.
 
Samples of the Time
 A sign of the current state of fashion retailing: the rise in sample sales. Historically, these allowed companies to clear out showroom samples and undelivered or mismatched shipments.
But Seventh Avenue manufacturers are now using showroom sales as a way of offsetting poor retail performance, said Elysa Lazar, the president of The S & B Report, a consumer guide to unadvertised showroom and sample sales.
Ms. Lazar said there had been 50 percent more sample sales this fall than in the same period last year. The November 1989 issue of The S & B Report listed 100 companies holding such sales; this year it has 150.
The depth and variety of merchandise at recent sample sales also suggest hard times. Instead of a few sizes and styles, there is a lot of everything, some below wholesale, compared with straight wholesale last year.
 
Toning It Down
 Charivari , the Manhattan-based retailer, is weathering the downward turn by expanding wholesale operations. The company recently introduced a more casual version of its private-label collection Sans Tambours ni Trompettes. (The name is French for "without fanfare," the opposite of Charivari, "din.")
The new line, STNT for short, is mostly men's wear costing $50 to $200. The line has been ordered by such stores as Bloomingdale's, Saks Fifth Avenue and I. Magnin.
 
By the Numbers: Color
 Reinforcing the folk wisdom that color is the best antidote to gray economic times, designers have been choosing brighter hues, according to Pantone Inc., whose swatch cards are used by clothing and textile manufacturers.
Black, which was No. 1 in 1989, has slid to 24th in Pantone's sales. That means yellow-green, or chartreuse, so popular in recent seasons, has also faded out of favor. The leading three colors this year are all variations on navy blue, followed by antique white and burgundy.

HEADLINE: Plant Lovers' Ambitious Goal Is No More Extinctions

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE Malheur wire lettuce, an unprepossessing but rare plant that grows only in hot, dry central Oregon, appeared to have lost its struggle for survival.
The few existing populations of the plant that managed to cling to life in its inhospitable ecological niche were gradually erased by the hoofs of cattle, foraging by jack rabbits, fire and an invasion of Asian cheat grass. By the early 1980's there were no plants of the species known to be alive. 
 But Dr. Leslie D. Gottlieb, a professor of plant genetics at the University of California at Davis who discovered the plant in 1968, had stored a large number of its seeds. They were propagated at the Berry Botanic Garden in Portland, Ore., and the seedlings were planted on land managed by the Bureau of Land Management in Oregon. The extinct plant was returned to life.
 
Efforts Are Paying Off
 The resurrection of the Malheur wire lettuce is one of a growing number of successes of a nationwide cooperative effort among scientists, botanical gardens, state and Federal governments, and the Nature Conservancy and other private conservation groups to preserve the nation's endangered flora.
Don Falk, executive director of the Center for Plant Conservation, one of the groups leading the effort, said he believed that there need be no further losses of native plants.
"We have set as a realistically attainable goal preventing from this point on any further extinctions of American flora," Mr. Falk said in a telephone interview.
Saving every American plant would be a formidable task. There are about 25,000 native plants, of which 3,000 are considered in some danger of extinction. The Center for Plant Conservation has estimated that more than 700 plants will disappear in the next 10 years if strong measures are not taken to save them. More than a third of these could be wiped out in five years.
While there are many sources of danger, the chief cause of extinction is the destruction of the plants' limited habitat by housing, industry or other human activity.
"We are talking about protecting plant diversity on a continental scale and that is not a trivial exercise," said Mr. Falk. But he added: "This is not something we have any choice about. The consequences of not attending to the diversity of plant life would be felt fairly quickly as ecological communities deteriorate."
 
Role as Food and Drugs
 Little is known about most of the rare endangered plants, but many of them are genetically related to food crops, including grains, vegetables and fruits. Many could have pharmaceutical value and many others should be saved for their beauty, Mr. Falk and others engaged in the rescue effort contend.
As an example of the value of saving rare plants, Mr. Falk pointed to a Texas wild rice, Zizania texana, whose habitat is now reduced to a single stream in central Texas. The genetic characteristics that enable it to live in a hotter, drier climate could be used to extend the growing range of wild rice in the United States, where it is now generally limited to the North Central states.
Even more important, he said, is the value of the wild rice's genes as insurance against a significant warming of the earth over the next century as a result of the greenhouse effect. If, as many scientists expect, rising global temperatures make the nation's interior hotter and drier, crops that can grow under such conditions would be urgently needed.
"We are talking about a survival issue for Homo sapiens," Mr. Falk said.
Last month the Center for Plant Conservation announced that to strengthen its efforts to preserve species, it was moving from Boston to St. Louis to affiliate with the Missouri Botanical Garden, a leading institution for plant research. The botanical garden is coordinating the preparation of a 12-volume "Flora of North America," which will be the first comprehensive listing and description of the plants of the United States, Canada and Greenland.
Peter Raven, the director of the Missouri Botanical Garden, said his institution's wide and growing storehouse of information about native plants would fit directly into the Center for Plant Conservation's efforts to identify and collect plants that are in danger of disappearing.
 
Returning Plants to the Wild
 The next step after finding and collecting those endangered plants, he said, is reintroducing them into the wild. Preserving seeds or a few plants in botanical gardens does not permanently protect plants because their survival depends on money and continuing care by people that could be cut off. Only re-establishing plant communities in their natural setting can save them over the long run, he contended.
Mr. Falk agrees. "A botanical garden is a holding pattern -- an ark," he said. "We have to find a place for the ark to land. Plants need to live in an ecological community with pollinators and symbiotic organisms such as fungi. Our objective is to restore species to a fully functioning existence in their ecological setting so that they can continue on their evolutionary pathway."
But before endangered plants can be reintroduced into the wild, they must be found and collected. This task is shouldered in large part by natural heritage programs run by state governments in cooperation with scientific institutions and cultural groups. The Nature Conservancy, a private nonprofit group based in Arlington, Va., plays a major role in this program, providing technical support and a data base for state programs.
Members of the the state programs meet at least once a year with the Center for Plant Conservation, representatives of botanical gardens, university scientists, Federal land managers and private conservation groups to discuss the status of the most critically threatened species and to determine which must be collected to assure their safety.
Plants identified as being in trouble are collected, their seeds stored, and individual plants propagated and studied. "If you have only a few populations of a plant left, you don't dare mess around with it," said Robert E. Jenkins, vice president for science programs of the Nature Conservancy. "You have to study it in the greenhouse to find out how much sun it likes, whether or not it should be fertilized and watered. Only then can you think about reintroducing it into the wild."
 
Some Are Skeptical
 Not all botanists think the goal of saving all native flora is realistic. Dr. Gottlieb of the University of California, for example, called the notion of zero losses of American plants romanticism. It would be a mistake to try, he said.
"We must save those species we know are very important and, if we have the time and the money, save the rest," he said, adding that there are not enough money or scientists or other workers to save every plant in danger of extinction.
He recalled that he had urged the California Fish and Game Commission, which decides which plants and animals to list as threatened or endangered, to try to save a plant called Oryctes nevadensis, a small annual herb in the tomato family that grows only in a few populations in the Owens Valley of California.
The plant belongs to a family "of supreme economic importance" because its genetic structure is related to tomatoes, potatoes, tobacco and petunias, Dr. Gottlieb said. But the commission turned down his petition and spent its resources on what he said were much less important plants.
At the time of the commission's action in 1989, one member of the panel was quoted by The Sacramento Bee as saying, "Here's a very weedy looking plant, and what I'm really wondering is, why are we worrying about it?' " The paper did not identify the member.
Although Dr. Gottlieb calls for scientists to be selective in deciding which plants to rescue, many say virtually all native plants could be saved.
"It is a lot easier to save plants than it is to save, say, spotted owls," said Bruce MacBryde, a botanist for the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.
Mr. Falk says he is confident that his goal can be achieved. "Like any good doctor, I should never say never," he said. "But I really think we can pull it off -- that we will not lose a single native plant. We have a system now we believe will enable us to prevent anything from slipping through the cracks."
 
Zizania texana
 
Texas wild rice, which grows in a single stream in Texas, tolerates heat and dryness and could extend the growing range of wild rice.
 
Dicerandra christmanii
 
Found three years ago, this scrub mint grows only in three places in one Florida county. Drought-tolerant and menthol-scented, it is being cultivated.
 
Polygala smallii
 
Tiny polygala, an herb with small yellow-green flowers, grows in open sandy spots in the coastal pinelands of Florida. Only a few individual plants exist.
 
Stephanomeria malheurensis
 
Malheur wire lettuce became extinct
in the wild; it was propagated from saved seeds.
 
Torreya taxifolia
 
Once an abundant tree up to 60 feet tall, the Florida torreya has resinous wood widely used for fence posts. Only seedlings remain in the wild; it is being cultivated.
(Sources: Center for Plant Conservation; Missouri Botanical Garden; Berry Botanic Garden; Systematic Botany; SIDA)

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Lebanese Split on Potential for Peace

BYLINE: By ALI JABER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 12

 BODY:
This country long riven by factional and sectarian strife is now torn between hope and pessimism as militia fighters withdraw from the capital and the Government moves ahead with a plan to restore peace.
The country's legacy of failed cease-fires and peace plans has left its people so wary that many are not even bothering to remove sandbags from their homes and shops. 
 "We have seen the militias pull out before," said Mustapha Inja, a 56-year-old retired pilot. "In 1983 all crossing points were opened and even the devastated downtown district was restored. But at the slightest sign of trouble the militiamen popped up from nowhere, closed all passageways in no time and started fighting again.
"There are no guarantees this will not happen again," he said.
 
Best Chance in Years
 Despite such gloomy assessments, many politicians and analysts believe that Lebanon has its best chance in years to achieve a lasting peace.
"No one can stop spring from coming to Lebanon," said Ghassan Tweini, the publisher of the newspaper an Nahar.
Ahmad Ayash, a columnist at the paper, pointed to global developments, particularly the end of the cold war, as a major source of hope for Lebanon.
"Syria has shifted alliances and is now in the same ditch with the Americans in the gulf," he said, referring to the American led effort against Iraq. "The Palestine Liberation Organization is no longer a player in Lebanon's political game and, for the first time since the war started 15 years ago, the Christians agreed to give concessions to the Muslims.
"These factors alone form serious bases for a lasting solution here," he concluded.
 
Assault on Aoun Opened a Path
 The focus of the optimism and doubts is the progress that President Elias Hrawi has made toward peace since Oct. 13. On that day Syria, the dominant force with 40,000 troops in this country, decided to launch an all-out assault on the East Beirut stronghold of the Christian Gen. Michel Aoun. The general's two-year rebellion against the Government had prevented the carrying out of a comprehensive political settlement giving the country's growing Muslim population a greater share of power at the expense of the long-favored Christians.
More than 750 people died in the Syrian assault, and General Aoun was forced to flee to refuge in the French Embassy from the presidential palace he had occupied in Baabda.
In the aftermath of the assault, President Hrawi has ordered all militias to leave Beirut by Monday and offered to set aside Cabinet seats for the heads of the country's six main factions. The Government's goal is to establish a zone in and around the capital controlled by the Lebanese Army so that it can revive institutions and services and stabilize the economy.
It has a long way to go toward convincing many Lebanese that it can succeed. Most people here have little or no time to think about peace. They are too busy struggling to secure bread and butter and other basic needs as prices for food and gasoline soar and telephones, electricity and water remain cut off.
 
The Pessimists' View
 Ziad Kamal, a sociologist, described the situation as "hopeless." He said the war has bred a hateful generation accustomed to violence.
"The compromise that militiamen have accepted today may be rejected by their sons tomorrow," he said.
Akram Zuheiri, a close aide to the Druse militia chief, Walid Jumblat, said peace is still out of reach.
"They may kick out the militias from Beirut today, but their plan stops right there," he said. "They cannot force Israel to pull out from south Lebanon, therefore giving Syria the pretext to remain where it is now."
The Government's plan has been drawn from the comprehensive peace accord reached between Christian and Muslim members of Parliament last year in Taif, Saudi Arabia.
 
Phased Syrian Withdrawal
 The accord calls for the disbanding of all militias within four months and a phased Syrian troop withdrawal from Beirut beginning in September 1992.
So far about half of the estimated 10,000 Shiite militiamen under the mainstream Amal organization have left the capital with their weapons. The rest, according to Amal officials, stayed in Beirut but disarmed and returned to civilian life.
Druse sources said that as many as 7,000 Druse militiamen have been dismissed. About 1,000 were kept under arms, they said, but they are preparing to join the police force or army.
The hard-line Christian militia, the Lebanese Forces, which fought Muslim, Syrian and Palestinian forces throughout the civil war, began on Sunday to gather fighters and armor at in its headquarters in East Beirut in preparation for a move north.
 
Party of God Won't Disarm
 The Party of God, the Shiite Muslim fundamentalist group, has reportedly transferred its heavy arms and fighters and the 13 foreigners it has held hostage here to remote areas in eastern and southern Lebanon. Their spokesman said they would fight Israel from bases in the south, but he claimed his group had no intention of dissolving its military forces.
Already the plan to get the militias out of Beirut has begun to run into obstacles. Samir Geagea, the commander of the Lebanese Forces, told reporters that he would insist on control of a third the seats in the Cabinet. He said that since his militia was the only Christian militia invited to join the new Cabinet, the four main Muslim factions would otherwise have too much power.
In addition, the Party of God, the Shiite fundametalist organization linked to the kidnapping of Westerners, has indicated through its mentor, Sheik Mohamad Hussein Fadlallah, that it would not join the Cabinet. He said his group prefers to remain in the opposition.
Despite the deep pessimism born of years of dashed prospects for peace, the Government's current progress has encouraged many here to revive the once-famous landmarks of pre-war Lebanon.
 
Commercial District Patrolled
 Beirut's tumultuous Hamra commercial district, whose chic sidewalk cafes were often frequented by Arab intellectuals, during the war years became a dirty habitat for refugees and beggars.
Today, a police force maintaining round-the-clock surveillance of the street have removed vegetable vendors blocking the windows of haute couture shops and turned away beggers disturbing shoppers.
Elsewhere grimmer realities intrude and dampen expectations. Probably the most accurate indicator of stability here is the price of Lebanese pound against foreign currencies. The current value of the dollar, more than 700 Lebanese pounds, hardly indicates that peace is at hand. Its value before the civil war erupted in 1975 was a little less than three pounds.
Beirut has been living under a total blackout since January. Electricity from generators set up by entrepreneurs costs at least $60 a month, about half the monthly income of the average Lebanese.
 
'Accepting Terms of Surrender'
 Other Christians living in sectors of central Lebanon conquered by the Syrian forces on Oct. 13 are experiencing another kind of anxiety.
The once-bustling villages of Brummana and Beit-Meri east of Beirut have become virtually deserted, except for Syrian soldiers on patrols. Residents lock themselves indoors as soon as they come from work in the afternoon. "You cannot label what is going on as a peace plan," said Joseph Haddad,a 30-year-old businessman. "The Christians were simply defeated and are now accepting terms of surrender of their victorious rivals, the Muslims and Syrians," he said.
Still other Lebanese have arrived at what they call a realistic medium between the optimists' euphoria and the pessimists' depression.
Dalal Aoud, a 30-year-old journalist, said, "Enjoy peace while it lasts."

(Associated Press); Three generations of a Beirut family returned to their home, situated on the former Green Line, which had divided the city. HEADLINE: $18.2 Million for a Renoir From the Ford Collection

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
Renoir's "Cup of Chocolate," from 1878, was sold last night for $18.2 million -- the highest price in Sotheby's auction of artworks from the family and the estate of Henry Ford 2d. The sale brought many disappointments for the auction house: of the 36 works offered, 23 were sold for a total of $48.6 million, well below Sotheby's presale estimate of $66 million to $85.8 million.
"It looks as if they had a bit of a bath," said Desmond Corcoran, a London dealer. 
 Julian Agnew, another London dealer, said: "I think it went more or less as predicted. This market has still a way to go on the way down."
The room was packed with an international gathering of dealers and collectors as impressive as any seen at a sale in recent years. But most of those in attendance were spectators.
"It does show a change in the market," said David Nash, head of fine-art sales at Sotheby's. "More than anything, it is slightly confusing. Some things sold well; some things sold that we didn't expect would sell, and some things we expected to sell did not.
"There is no doubt that the events on the international scene, combined with the rather worrying economic predictions, have made people more cautious. Despite all this, there are people who really want to buy paintings at very strong prices and will compete for them."
The price paid by the unidentified Japanese collector who bought the Renoir was the second highest at auction for a painting by the artist, exceeded only by "At the Moulin de la Galette," which was sold in May in the same room for $78.1 million to the Japanese paper industrialist Ryoei Saito.
 
The 20th Century Sells
 Among the paintings sold by the Ford' estate was Paul Cezanne's 1880's painting of the Provence estate of the artist's father, Louis-Auguste Cezanne, for $7.2 million to an unidentified buyer. The price paid was within the house estimate and considerably more than Mr. Ford paid for it in 1966 at a New York City auction where it brought $350,000. Modigliani's 1918 portrait of the American artist Morgan Russell, which had been expected to bring $8 million to $10 million, did not sell.
Mr. Corcoran said the sale also showed that "what was selling the best were the 20th-century works." He left shortly after the sale of Picasso's sculpture "Glass of Absinthe," from 1914, for $2.53 million and Matisse's painting "Pewter Pot, Lemon and Armchair," from 1939, for $3.9 million. Those prices were among the highest prices in the sale.
Mr. Ford, who died in 1987, inherited the Renoir from his mother in 1976 and gave it to his three children -- Edsel, Charlotte Ford Downe and Anne Ford Scarborough -- who were the sellers last night.
Several dealers were critical of Sotheby's guarantee -- an agreed-upon price between the auction house and the seller -- on the 35 artworks from the Ford estate, which did not include the Renoir. The guarantee figure was not disclosed. Sotheby's became the owner of the 13 unsold lots.
"There is still a lot of sorting out in this market," Mr. Agnew said. "The massive influx of credit into this market since 1986 and 1987 has now gone into reverse. We have a sort of credit crunch, and banks are very nervous about making loans into fine arts and other markets.
"Maybe we have to go back to the prices of before 1987, to 1986, before van Gogh's 'Irises' was sold on credit. Maybe the auction houses will reconsider their policies on guarantees. The guarantee tonight was about $58 million, and last night they sold about $32 million for the estate."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "The Cup of Chocolate" by Renoir as it was being auctioned last night at Sotheby's. It sold for $18.2 million. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
The President's Mistake

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
President Bush made one profound mistake immediately after Iraq conquered Kuwait. Every day it becomes more important that he correct it before United States ground forces go into action against Saddam Hussein.
Mr. Bush failed to state the single most important reason for going to war against Iraq -- or even for organizing the worldwide embargo. That is to eliminate Saddam Hussein's power to cause more death and destruction. Other reasons do not justify the deaths of Americans -- or placing them in deadly jeopardy. 
 Perhaps Mr. Bush himself was reluctant to face it in the beginning. Certainly Presidential candor was not a happy prospect for Administration officials who designed and pushed the failed, disgraced policy of strengthening Saddam Hussein and appeasing him almost up to the hour of invasion.
If they really wanted to convince Saddam Hussein of American determination to oppose him at last, the resignation of Secretary of State James Baker and some of his top Middle East hands would have been one inexpensive, bloodless way of showing it.
Whatever the reason, Mr. Bush came up with war goals that simply do not satisfy a large part of the American public. The public support needed by the President and every soldier depends not so much on the length of a war but whether it sits well in the American stomach.
Mr. Bush told the country that one goal was to turn back aggression. Every American intelligent enough to fight is intelligent enough to know that the United States did not feel compelled to go into battle against other aggressions -- China against Tibet, the Soviet Union against the world of Eastern Europe, and Arab against Arab time and again. Why was was this one so important?
Americans were told that another objective was to restore the royal family of Kuwait. Name one American you know who thinks that is worth dying for, or even facing the possibility of death. Just one.
And Americans were told that the country could not allow a dictator with a proven taste for power and blood to stand astride much of the world's oil supply. That is an economic and political reality. But it is not convincing enough to Americans who know that there are steps the U.S. has not yet taken to preserve its oil independence. Among them: tougher conservation, higher gas taxes, real attempts to break the OPEC cartel with a Western Hemisphere consortium benefiting us and our neighbors.
So, with American men and women facing combat in the desert, the U.S. debates why they are there. Mr. Bush has done well preparing the country militarily for the possibility of war, but has failed to prepare it politically and spiritually.
He has not said the bone truth: Left in power, Saddam Hussein will use his missiles and chemical arsenal in the future as he has in the past. And if Israeli destruction of his nuclear plant in 1981 had not set him back a decade or so, Iraq would be a nuclear power today.
Does anybody truly believe that when he acquires them, Saddam Hussein will not use nuclear weapons as blackmail? Or never slip a few to some of his terrorist gangs and allies like Libya? Does anybody truly believe that he would not use nuclear power as a first resort or certainly a last if he ever again faces a strong coalition that threatens his rule?
Stop this man before he can kill millions. That is the only war goal worth putting before American soldiers as a reason for risking their lives. And it is the reason that U.S. and allied air power should have been used to destroy his arsenals before American armies were shipped abroad. It is the reason that air power should still be tried before they are sent into combat. The country and the President need matters of heart from each other -- trust, confidence and respect. But on the edge of war, he wasted his dignity and dwindling time by running around fighting local political battles.
When he decides he must send more hundreds of thousands of Americans into danger, he breaks the news to reporters at the White House, instead of telling the parents himself, in their living rooms.
He talks almost every day, but always gives the impression that he talks to be heard only by Saddam Hussein or the U.N. In the timetable of the Mideast crisis, the date that counts most is when the American President decides to address the American people in full openness -- rectifying the error he made, telling them that the reason to confront the power of Saddam Hussein is to end the power of Saddam Hussein.

HEADLINE: Son's Killing Leaves Family An Angry, Painful Legacy

BYLINE: By DON TERRY

 BODY:
On Thursday, Kimson Russell was supposed to celebrate his 17th birthday. His unemployed mother had even scratched together enough money to buy him a much wanted new coat with the Los Angeles Raiders football team logo stitched across the back.
"I have the money hidden in a suitcase," she said yesterday.
But instead of celebrating on Thursday, Mr. Russell's family and friends will gather for his funeral. Any extra money will cover burial expenses. 
 The teen-ager, who dreamed of becoming a professional football player, was shot to death on Saturday night on a street corner in the East New York section of Brooklyn, about a block from his home in the Cypress Hills public houses.
He had been returning home from an errand for his grandmother.
"When they lifted him up to take him to the morgue, he was lying on the bread I sent him just thought he was going for bread. That's all, bread."
Why the teen-ager was killed was uncertain late yesterday. "As far as we know, we don't have a motive," said a police spokesman, Officer Ralph Saint Just. "He's just a victim at this part of the investigation."
His mother, Veberly, said yesterday that she was determined not to let her son becomejust another statistic, just another brief story about a poor boy gunned down in a struggling and neglected neighborhood.
By yesterday, Ms. Russell's tears had turned to resolve.
"I want my son's death to make a difference," she said. "I can't sit up here crying. I have to do something about these kids killing each other."
Tomorrow night, she hopes to hold a memorial for her son at a nearby community center and turn the mourning into what she called an "anti-violence teach-in" for the neighborhood's teen-agers and their parents.
 
'They're Just Frustrated'
 "There are tons of hard-working people around here," Ms. Russell said. "They want to do something. They're just frustrated. There are a whole lot of families who are suffering because their children died like Kimson."
She is trying to recruit radio and television hosts to speak at her son's memorial to help convince the young people that the path so many are following leads to death and unbearable heartache for those left behind.
"I want the kids to know, we're destroying ourselves," she said. "Nobody takes the time to talk to the kids. That's part of the problem. I'm not saying I'm going to change their minds. I just hope we stir them up, to make them start thinking about what they're doing."
As she talked, her brother, Renaldo Russell, a 31-year-old accountant for Merrill Lynch, sat across the living room shaking his head.
"Depending on where you walk around here, you take your life in your hands," he said. "The kids with guns aren't kids anymore. They're murderers."
"They are still kids, Renaldo," Ms. Russell, 41, said. "You are very bitter." "I'm not bitter," Mr. Russell said. "I'm realistic."
Later, looking over his nephew's baby pictures, Mr. Russell admitted, "Yes, I'm bitter."
"I'm bitter that I have to call here every day to make sure that they're all right," he said. "I'm bitter that it's always on my mind. I'm bitter that I have to tell my mother to be careful when she goes to the store and not to go out at night. Yeah, I'm bitter."
For years, Mr. Russell has been trying to convince his mother and sister to leave the Cypress Hill Houses, their home for almost 20 years.
He only visits the project on weekends and during the day. "When it starts getting dark, I leave," he said. "Whenever I'm over here, I hear pop, pop coming from the street."
Gunfire was more than just a sound on the street for the Russell family even before Saturday night. In April, Ms. Russell's daughter, Ronelle, 21, was shot when a teen-ager shooting at another youth hit her by mistake as she ran into a building in the project. She lost her left kidney.
"I was lucky," she said yesterday.
 
Many Are Shot and Live
 In September, 12-year-old Laykama Taylor, who also lived in the project, was not lucky. She was shot and killed while in a playground braiding a friend's hair. Ms. Russell said she knows of at least a half-dozen young people who have been slain in the area in the last two years.
"And if you ask how many kids were shot and lived, the number is about 40," she said.
Her brother said he believed that his nephew had been gunned down by drug-gang members trying to intimidate the neighborhood by killing someone, anyone who came along.
"I went to the morgue today to identify Kimson," Mr. Russell said. "It's hard, real hard. I used to change his diapers."
The police said the teen-ager was shot twice by someone in a car as it drove past 1260 Sutter Avenue shortly after 9 P.M. Another teen-age boy with him was shot and wounded in the leg.
 
'I Used to Tease Him'
 Kimson Russell's family and friends said he had avoided the rougher elements in the neighborhood. He still sucked his thumb, his uncle said.
"I used to tease him about that," Mr. Russell said.
The teen-ager played video games and football and looked for girls, said his best friends, Infinite Berry, 14, and Anthony Rosa, 15.
"If he was here, we'd be outside playing right now," Mr. Berry said.
"There ain't no bringing him back," Mr. Rosa said. "I'm going to miss him going to practice with me."
 
'She Doesn't See His Face'
 Kimson Russell had a baby daughter with his girlfriend, Melissa Gibbons, 17. Yesterday, as his family's apartment filled with relatives and friends, the baby, Christina, who will be 1 on Christmas, played with a rattle and crawled from one sad-faced adult to another.
"She must wonder where Kimson is," said her aunt, "because she doesn't see his face."
The telephone in the apartment rang constantly yesterday, and several callers pleaded with Ms. Russell to pack up and leave East New York.
She said, "I won't be run out of here."
"I really love East New York," she said. "I believe I can make a difference. I just had no idea I was going to lose my son."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Friends of Kimson Russell, a 16-year-old who was killed Saturday in Brooklyn, gathered yesterday at his family's apartment. From left were, Melissa Gibbons, holding their daughter, Christina, Anthony Rosa, at the window, and Infinite Berry. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Beijing Journal;
Little Whispers, the Big Lie and China's Future

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 12

 BODY:
For Americans, the campaigning and the mud-slinging are over for a while. For Chinese, they never end.
For most of the last four decades China has been embroiled in campaigns: to wipe out prostitution, to kill sparrows, to make steel in backyard furnaces, to attack "stinking" intellectuals, to denounce Deng Xiaoping, to hail Deng Xiaoping. 
 Those were one-sided campaigns, but now a bitterly contested one -- not entirely different from the campaign Americans have just endured -- is under way for the future of China.
This campaign will not end in an election; indeed, no one is sure how it will end. But all sides seem to believe that public opinion will matter, at some point, in some degree, particularly after the death of the octogenarians like Mr. Deng who are now in charge. That is why the leadership is not relying on force alone, but is also trying desperately to cultivate popular support.
"Everything here seems like one long campaign," said a Western diplomat in Beijing. "It's the way they do business. It's the only way they have to energize their vast apparatus."
 
Incumbency Helps
 The hard-liners have the enormous advantage of incumbency, which is an even greater benefit here than in the United States. In China, incumbents not only sling mud at their opponents, they also imprison them, or send them into internal exile, as the Government has done with Liu Qing, an advocate of democratic change who was expelled from Beijing to distant Shaanxi Province.
Moreover, the Communist Party treats all the nation's newspapers and television broadcasts as advertising space to celebrate the glories of Communism.
But critics of the Government have come up with their own makeshift campaign techniques, like rumors, to discredit the Government. It helps that the opposition has millions of "precinct workers": ordinary men and women who were outraged at the military crackdown on the democracy movement, as well as by corruption and economic mismanagement, and who are glad to pass on gossip about the leaders' reported Swiss bank accounts.
"Do you know about the Asian Games insignia?" a disgruntled young Chinese worker asked a foreign friend the other day. "It was designed so that if you look at its mirror image, it's a spot of blood and a 6 and a 4" -- an allusion to the 6-4 incident, as the killing of protesters on June 4, 1989, is known.
The insignia arguably does include a backward 6 and 4 and a red glob, so many young Chinese gleefully assert that the design is evidence of continuing resistance. There is no evidence that this is true, but if enough people believe it then it succeeds in making the Government look foolish.
 
Whispers About an Earthquake
 To foreigners, it sometimes seems a battle between the Big Lie and Little Whisper techniques, in which each side is constrained only by the limits of its imagination. One of the Little Whispers now going around is that a big earthquake will strike China in December, showing what the heavens think of Communism.
So who is winning the campaign? Conversations with a variety of Chinese as well as with foreign diplomats suggest mixed results.
The Government seems to be winning some support among older and middle-aged cadres, who have already devoted their lives to the Communist Party and are reluctant to believe ill of it. The Government's campaign theme -- that China needs stability above all -- also has some appeal in this constituency, which has bitter memories of the Cultural Revolution or even of the pre-Communist era.
The leadership also appears to be doing well in some rural areas, particularly those with television but no alternative source of information. In cities, people rely on rumors and on Voice of America.
Even in the cities, the overwhelming repetition of the official version of events has some effect. A woman who grew up in China but now lives abroad said that when she returned for a visit recently, she was surprised that several of her former neighbors in Beijing were skeptical about whether there really had been much killing during the crackdown.
"They asked if it was really true that students were killed, and whether I had seen videos of it with my own eyes," she said. And a worker in her 40's, who is fundamentally hostile to the Government, said she now believed that the student demonstrators had been used and misled by a small group of anti-Government conspirators.
 
Contempt for Propaganda
 But over all, the Government is losing ground, diplomats and many Chinese say. Particularly among intellectuals and younger people -- the three-quarters of the population who were born after the Communist revolution -- propaganda arouses mostly contempt, and there is a deepening desire "to throw the rascals out."
Pocket-book issues are still most important, although continuing irritation with family planning restrictions is a major issue in rural areas. Chinese are worried by the economic slump in which they find themselves and embittered by the general inefficiency and poverty in which they live, especially compared with the affluence that they know exists in Hong Kong and Taiwan.
The public's bitterness has been compounded lately by increases in the fixed prices for daily necessities like sugar, coal and gas for cooking. Economists say the increases are necessary, but they go over about as well as a tax increase does with American voters.
The Government has tried to win support with a widely publicized drive against corruption, with hagiographies of particularly dedicated Communist cadres and exposes of the problems in Taiwan and the United States.
"In Washington and New York, you see beggers and homeless vagabonds," Beijing Evening News reported in a recent front-page article. "With their sons and daughters in tow, they spread their old and dirty clothes on the ground and lie down to sleep."
Such articles seem to have minimal effect, however, because few Chinese read the newspapers these days and even fewer seem to believe what they read.

China seems to always be embroiled in a campaign, though no one ever votes. "Everything here seems like one long campaign," said a Western diplomat in Beijing. (Fumiyo Asahi for The New York Times)
