HEADLINE: F.B.I. Investigates Groups of Zealots Who Praise Kahane Slaying

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES

 BODY:
The Federal Bureu of Investigation is scrambling to investigate the Muslim groups associated with the Masjid al-Salam mosque in Jersey City, where El Sayyid A. Nosair, the man accused of killing Rabbi Meir Kahane, worshiped, according to high-level law-enforcement officials.
Although the New York City police say they believe Mr. Nosair acted alone, one law-enforcement official said the investigation into Rabbi Kahane's death had opened "a window" into several radical fundamentalist groups. Besides looking at possible links between these groups and the shooting of Rabbi Kahane last week at a Manhattan hotel, the F.B.I. fears that these groups may be capable of terrorist activities at a time of heightened tensions in the Middle East, thehigh-level officials said. 
 One group under investigation, the officials said, is the Muslim Brotherhood, an Egyptian-based group that has engaged in violent campaigns against the Egyptian Government and has given rise to many radical splinter groups that have taken responsibility for political assassinations and terrorist attacks. The officials said Mr. Nosair had contacts through the mosque withthe brotherhood and other radical groups, which they did not identify.
Officials at the mosque yesterday praised the killing of Rabbi Kahane, a leader of a far-right political group that called for the expulsion of Arabs from the occupied territories in Israel. But they denied any connection to the murder and said the mosque, at 2824 Kennedy Boulevard, was only a place of worship.
 
A Largely Hidden World
 Mr. Nosair, who is now recovering in the Bellevue Hospital Center from a gunshot wound received after the Kahane slaying, rose from this insular world of radical Muslims who have established storefront mosques and schools in Brooklyn and Jersey City.
It is a hermetic world, distrustful of outsiders and rooted in the belief that Islam is the absolute truth in an alien and godless society. It is a world largely unknown to authorities, composed not only of operatives for the Palestine Liberation Organization, but also Muslim fundamentalists who sanction violence to further the cause of Islam.
These Muslims decry the moral degeneration of Americans and Western society. They have attracted disenfranchised Americans and Arab immigrants. And as these people suffer economic deprivation and often social ostracism, they cling to their religious tenets like shipwrecked sailors to a raft.
It was out of this world that Mr. Nosair, a 34-year-old maintenance worker at the Criminal Courts Building, at 111 Centre Street, rose to shoot Rabbi Kahane as he addressed a group of followers last week in a midtown hotel, the police say.
One of the 300 to 400 worshipers at the mosque is Sultan Ibraham El Gawli, an Egyptian-born travel agent and grocery store owner, who was convicted of attempting to smuggle 150 pounds of explosives, 100 blasting caps, remote detonators and a 9-mm automatic weapon silencer to the P.L.O. for use in Israel.
Mr. El Gawli and Mr. Nosair both come from Port Said in Egypt and have close family ties, according to several people who know the two men.
 
Killing Viewed as Legal
 Imam Shaker El Sayed, the principal of the Al-Ghazly Islamic School in Jersey City, where Mr. Nosair sent his children until the beginning of 1989, and many Muslims argue that the killing of Rabbi Kahane was not in violation of Islamic law.
The rabbi founded the Jewish Defense League in New York and led the far-right political Kach Party in Israel until it was banned for racism. He often sanctioned violent attacks against Arabs, and his followers were accused of carrying out several violent attacks in the West Bank and Gaza strip.
Discussing how some Muslims view the killing of the rabbi, Imam Shaker said: "It was not a violation, in the sense that Kahane adopted a position against all Arab and Muslims. He put himself in that category."
In the third-story mosque in Jersey City, Mr. Nosair, described as a quiet, introspective man, has become a hero.
 
Slaying 'a Great Thing'
 "He has done a great thing," said an Arab-American, who would not give his name but who said he managed a fast-food outlet. "If I had had the chance, I would have killed Kahane, too."
Debra Ragab, an American convert who lives in Jersey City at 143 Highland Avenue, where Mr. Nosair and his family once lived, said, "Our job now is to take care of his family."
Mrs. Ragab, 39, like many of the converts who refer to themselves as reverts, arguing that every child is born a Muslim, sees in Islam moral and ethical certainty. She said she became a Muslim after reading about Islam. Her conversion led her to seek an Muslim husband, to cover her head and to raise her three children in an Islamic household.
"I turned to Islam first, then I met my husband," she said. "I was interested in the religion first."
 
Religious Law Followed
 The world of devout Muslims is ruled by Islamic law, in much the same way Hasidic Jews rigorously follow precepts drawn up by Talmudic scholars for their daily affairs. The imam, during a recent conversation, for example, refused to shake the hand of a woman who was visiting. Alcohol is forbidden, and everyone must pray five times a day, a practice Mr. Nosair carried out in the Criminal Courts Building, according to fellow workers.
Many followers who feel powerless and alienated in American society come to believe that they, as devout Muslims, are carrying out the will of God.
"We are His agents," said a teacher at the Jersey City Islamic school. "We must implement and carry out His mission because we will be asked about it."
"Our short-term role is to introduce Islam," said this bearded teacher. "In the long term, we must save American society. Allah will ask me why I did not speak about Islam, because this piece of land is Allah's property."
When asked about the religion, Mrs. Ragab said, "Islam is truth."
 
Coptic Christians Concerned
 The large community of Coptic Christians who live in Jersey City, many with small, blue indigo crosses tattooed on their hands or wrists, are wary of the radical Muslims.
"They want to destroy America," said one Coptic shopkeeper from Egypt as he looked out a window toward the mosque. "They are a bad group."
Imam Shaker sees it differently. "Islam offers a comprehensive vision and understanding of life, death and suffering," he said. "The problematic paradoxes of life have answers that are convincing and simple."
"Compare," he said, "the American reality to the Islamic dream."

The mosque is on the third floor; a check-cashing establishment is on the second floor. (F.N. Kinney for The New York Times) (pg. B4)

HEADLINE: After the Cold War: Frozen Chaos?

 BODY:
Food. Fuel for heat. Pharmaceuticals. Boots. Winter winds have just started blowing across the steppes but some necessities are already in short supply in Soviet cities. Unless the Soviet people get help from abroad, they could take to the streets of Moscow, Leningrad and Sverdlovsk in protest.
Chaos won't advance the prospects for democratic and economic reform -- a matter of grave concern for the U.S. as well as the Soviet Union. Simple humanity, as well as prudence, argues that the U.S. prepare and coordinate Western emergency aid efforts now, before it's too late to help. 
 The reasons for Soviet shortages are many. An economy that had trouble delivering the goods in the best of times is breaking down. Bumper crops rot in the fields as farmers, with few incentives to bring goods to market, ignore orders from above. Strikers disrupt mining and oilfields.
Meanwhile factory managers hoard, waiting for new and higher prices sure to come. Neither the Soviet leadership nor public seem able to cope with the confusion and contradictions of an economy in limbo between state control and functioning markets. Road and rail networks, never adequate, have been deliberately disrupted. Reportedly, angry nationalists blockade some trucks and trains and hijack others. Republics, farmers and managers withhold goods from the market -- and Communism begins to look like the shortest road from industrial revolution back to feudalism.
The temptation is to blame the victim. That's not only inhumane; it's dangerous. Americans have a huge stake in nurturing stable Soviet change. As the Soviets move to markets and as democratic forces gather strength, it's important not to starve these heartening developments. Just as Europeans have never forgotten what U.S. help meant to their war-devastated countries, so the Soviet people will remember that Americans helped them through hard times with food, fuel and other necessities.
Washington needs to prepare now. A high-level fact-finding team can be dispatched to determine what the Soviet people need and how best to supply it. Meeting with Moscow is essential to expedite aid shipments and avoid undermining its reformist leadership. The visitors would do well also to meet with local authorities, who can assure that aid reaches those who most need it.
The U.S. cannot and should not try on its own to meet Soviet emergency needs. Other Western countries can participate, in ways that use aid shipments to promote the development of private enterprise in Soviet retailing, transportation and food processing. Together, outside powers can help take the edge off the winter wind, and show the desperate Soviet people that they have the heart, and head, to help.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Job Fair Is Bleak Portrait of Economic Mood

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
Armed with resumes, years of experience and tenuous hopes for employment, thousands of people stood for three hours or more yesterday, waiting to enter a job fair and gain the attention of receptive industry recruiters.
As a sign of the current economic climate, the event, which was held at the Roosevelt Hotel in Manhattan by a private job fair organizer called National Career Centers-USA Inc., offered a bleak snapshot of New York City's economic mood. Recent college graduates rubbed elbows with jaded longtime jobholders who had either been laid off or who feared the prospect was imminent. Along a line that snaked around four city blocks from Madison to Vanderbilt Avenues on East 45th and 46th Streets, well-dressed people carrying attache cases talked of recesssion, of months without income, of dreams scaled down. Billing the event as a minority professional recruiting center, advertisements said the focus would be on "women, African-American, Asian, Hispanic, American Indian, over-40, veteran and disabled professionals," and indeed the crowd seemed diverse, although there seemed to be few people over 50 years old in attendance. 
 Once they gained entrance to a second-floor exhibition room inside the hotel -- where tables had been set up by three dozen companies, including I.B.M., Campbell Soup, Home Box Office, Bear Stearns, Colgate-Palmolive, Xerox, Continental Grain, Brooklyn Union Gas and Walt Disney Imagineering, as well as the National Transportation Safety Board, and the Planned Parenthood Federation -- the job seekers found more lines and, in some cases, no positions in the specialties they were pursuing. Recruiters acknowedged that some of the positions were "in the proposal stage" and not yet established. But though many people expressed qualms about the way the fair was run, they left their resumes, hopeful that someone would single them out of the pile.
"This is an unusually large crowd," said Rob Imlay, regional director of the company that organized the fair, who estimated that 8,000 people would attend by the day's end. "It has to do in part with the fact that more companies are being more aggressive about affirmative action, and in part with the downsizing going on in New York. A lot of people here don't know what the future of the job they now hold is."
Entrants to the fair did not have to pay admission. It was subsidized by fees charged to the companies participating, but neither Mr. Imlay nor officers at his company's headquarters in Fayetteville, N.C., would divulge how much those fees were.
 
'It's Human Nature'
 One of the advertisements cited the possibility of "Salaries/Compensation to $250,000," but many people leaving the fair complained that the jobs seemed limited to sales and did not include other categories of work suggested in the advertisment. Mr. Imlay denied this was true.
"Just look at the brochure," he said, leafing through the fair's guide, which listed acounting, finance, information, services, consulting and administration among the possibilities. He dismissed the disatisfaction, saying, "It's human nature to complain if you don't get a job on the spot."
Still, even as people outside on the line learned of the complaints, few, if any, gave up, nor were they dissuaded by the length of the wait. "I'm not surprised by the line, I was prepared for it," said Raymond Robinson, a Jersey City resident who took the day off from his job on Wall Street as a retail securities and commodities broker.
"The retail brokerage business is lousy and I want to get into institutional brokerage," he said. "My entire career has been on Wall Street, and that is scary, so I would stand here another week if I had to. When Wall Street stops, everything else does, too."
 
'Means Nonemployed'
 Waiting behind Mr. Robinson, an architect who would not give his name said, "I have been self-employed, which means nonemployed, because I work in the luxury area, designing residences on Long Island." Business evaporated, he said, adding that "people are not doing the $150,000 renovations on the $1 million houses anymore."
Several teachers were in the crowd, among them Michael Prince of Manhattan, an elementary school mathematics teacher. "I'm fearful about the layoffs of teachers in the city, so I am trying to switch into sales," he said.
Masud Ahmed, who came to Astoria, Queens, from Bangladesh and is a graduate student in environmental science at Staten Island College, said he had been selected by the city for an assistant geologist position, and then that job was frozen. "So I'm here looking for something in hazardous waste," he said from his vantage point at the rear of the line.
"Sure I'm nervous, this is a recession," said Vasunder Bhashyam of Bronxville, N.Y., a father of two children who said he was laid off after 10 years as a computer engineer with a photocopy company in Stamford, Conn. "Twenty percent of the company was let go."
 
Sharing War Stories
 Most people seemed resigned to the travails of unemployment and were sharing war stories. But Yanick Dominijanni of Forest Hills, Queens, was angry as she looked across the street at the office of her former employer, the Manufacturers Hanover.
"They started laying off people on Oct. 18," she said. "As I was the oldest one there -- 49 -- and had 10 years on the job in liaison in corporate banking operations, I should have had seniority. But I was told I didn't fit the company and was forced to resign. How could I not fit after 10 years? I am a single parent; I have a son in his freshman year of premedical studies at New York University. I'm here to save my son from being kicked out of school and because of the need to support myself."
In direct contrast was the equanimity expressed by Mihaeli Mihai, a mechanical engineer who came to New York from Bucharest a year ago. She had stood in line for more than two hours.
"This is nothing, she said. "In Romania, you stand in line longer for food."

HEADLINE: No Wonder Fewer and Fewer Want to Accept Public Office

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your disingenuous, innuendo-laden report on "a computerized study conducted by The New York Times of the approximately $20 million in contributions" received by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York (Nov. 1) takes outrageous liberties with several case studies -- including mine. 
 Offering no evidence (because there is none), you hint that as a result of my contributions to Governor Cuomo's campaigns, I had bought myself a coveted government position, in which I award lucrative contracts to others. Absolutely wrong on both counts.
For one thing, I never contributed with an eye toward joining public service. I was happy and successful in private life, and joined the administration only after being invited by the Governor. I do love my work -- and I think I've made a difference -- but to suggest I longed for the chance to forfeit millions of dollars in potential income in return for my job title would make me laugh if the mere thought of it didn't move me to tears.
As for the "contracts" I allegedly dangle in front of others, no chairman of the Urban Development Corporation, including me, is empowered to make such decisions alone. Contracts are considered at monthly meetings open to the public and voted in public by a seven-member board. I couldn't make large contract awards if I wanted to.
Besides, what are these "contracts"? Clearly, you have tried to suggest something tawdry. Do you mean contracts to establish day-care centers at companies we help attract to or expand in New York? Contracts to increase productivity and retrain workers in aging plants? Contracts to incubate high-tech industries?
Or do you use the word loosely to include the incentive programs we created to lure companies to New York from other states -- to attract foreign investment and open foreign markets -- or to establish opportunity zones in the state's most distressed areas?
We hardly need apologize for the programs or the results: more than a million new jobs in seven years and hundreds of millions of dollars in investment in poorer communities.
Citizens who justifiably demand that their governments hire the best and the brightest shouldn't be surprised to learn that fewer and fewer are willing to give up the opportunities of private enterprise to share a goldfish bowl with the piranha of a biased press.
I contribute my time (I donate my entire salary to charity) because I admire and respect Mario Cuomo -- because I think he makes a difference. I contribute to his campaigns because I believe in him, because I can afford to and because the system under which we elect leaders today makes ridiculous financial demands on all candidates. As the Governor likes to say, any jackass can kick down a barn. It takes good people to build one.
 
VINCENT TESE
Chairman, New York State
Urban Development Corporation
New York, Nov. 1, 1990

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL
A European proposal to cut farm subsidies has been rejected by nations that export farm goods, who say it is too small. Talks to liberalize trade are deadlocked and could collapse. [Page A1.]
As he undertook Europe's largest real estate development, Paul Reichmann said he was prepared to live through at least two downturns in London. He is going through the first slump now. [D1.]
 
THE ECONOMY
U.S. officials knew as long ago as 1988 that preferential treatment was being given to some troubled savings and loans whose senior executives also served on Government regulatory boards, documents show. [A1.] Five Senators are preparing to go before the Ethics Committee for hearings on their links to Keating. [A22.]
Oil companies' response to higher oil prices is to sit tight and hope prices do not crash after the crisis ends. [D1.] Officials in Santa Barbara, Calif., denied permission to a Chevron-led consortium to use tankers to ship oil from a field off the coast. [D8.]
More foreign tourists are coming to New York, spurred by the precipitous fall in the value of the dollar. [A1.]
The apple industry is as profitable as ever, two years after the scare about spraying with Alar. [A28.]
 
MARKETS
Stock prices moved sharply higher for the second straight session. The Dow closed at 2,540.35, up 51.74. [D1.]
Oil prices fell $2.02, to $31.87 a barrel, as rising supplies appeared to have a greater impact than the threat of war. [D8.]
Treasury securities prices moved higher in Europe. Because of Veterans Day, there was no trading in the U.S. [D19.]
Gold and silver futures prices declined in light trading highlighted by a consensus that war is not imminent. [D20.]
The dollar fell broadly in sleepy trading, largely on the expectation that the Fed would move this week to lower rates. [D20.]
 
COMPANIES
Nineteen days into the Daily News strike, the struggle between management and unions stays in the streets. [A1.]

HEADLINE: Big-City Mayors Focus On Problems and Goals

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Joined by his counterparts from nearly three dozen big cities around the nation, Mayor David N. Dinkins played host yesterday to an "urban summit" in which they conferred, conversed and otherwise hobnobbed on how best to make their cities' case to Washington and the world.
"Today we come from many different types of cities to step back, to reflect, to discuss and to set goals," Mr. Dinkins told the group, which arrived on Sunday for two days of mostly private sessions that are to end today. "Because, as we all well know, if our cities do not survive, our country cannot survive." 
 While mayors meet regularly in a number of national organizations, Mr. Dinkins proposed this conference last spring as a way for the leaders of cities with more than 200,000 people each to talk about their particular problems and to plan alliances to lobby for more Federal aid, international trade and public support for urban needs.
Just how well the mayors' requests will fare amid a competing horus of national demands remains to be seen. Yesterday, the 35 of them, including Mr. Dinkins, conducted their business in private, holding closed seminars at the Sheraton Centre hotel in Manhattan on topics from "Fiscal Challenges" to "The Global Economy."
 
'The Important Thing'
 "The important thing for me so far is the opportunity to meet and talk and strategize with some 30-odd people who have probably the most unique job in American politics," Mayor Art Agnos of San Francisco said in a break between sessions. In other mayors' meetings, which include leaders from small towns to huge cities, he said, "there isn't the opportunity to focus with this kind of intensity."
Mayor Sidney Barthelemy of New Orleans said one goal was to make a statement to national leaders and residents of rural and suburban areas: "Guess what? Cities are important to your survival and my survival, and you and I need them."
Whatever else it was, yesterday's gathering was a splendid junket, an opportunity for the mayors to bask in radio and television coverage in the country's media capital, and, in some cases, coverage by hometown journalists who followed them here. On an icy clear fall evening, they dined at Windows on the World in lower Manhattan.
 
Gun Control and Housing
 It was also a chance for Mr. Dinkins, who has had his share of troubles lately, to forget them for a moment, or at least to compare them with others grappling with crime, drugs and fiscal headaches. Mr. Dinkins, who persuaded various local businesses to donate hotel rooms and other services, pressed issues dear to his heart, from stricter national gun control to more Federal funds for housing.
"Cities are the engines that drive every one of the regional economies in the nation," said Mayor Bob Bolen of Fort Worth.
"We are the best that America has to offer" in commerce, culture and social commitment, Mr. Bolen said. But, he added, cities must fight harder to get their share of Federal aid.

HEADLINE: Chevron Turned Down On Tankers

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEV, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12

 BODY:
County officials in Santa Barbara, Calif., voted today to deny permission to a consortium led by the Chevron Corporation to use tankers to ship oil from a large field off the Southern California coast to three Los Angeles area refineries.
The decision by the Santa Barbara County Board of Supervisors means a longstanding dispute between the Chevron group and government officials in California will continue to simmer. For nearly three years, Chevron and 17 partners have been ready to begin extracting oil from the Santa Maria basin off Point Arguello. But the companies have been stymied by local and state opposition to the $2.5 billion project, which remains in mothballs. Santa Barbara officials have wanted Chevron to use a pipeline instead of tankers because they view that method of transporting oil as safer, but the two sides have been unable to agree on a plan.
 
Issue in Larger Debate
 The dispute over oil transporation in Santa Barbara has become the focus of national debate over the correct balance between energy needs and environmental concerns. The issue has become more prominent only since the Persian Gulf crisis erupted in August and questions about the nation's reliance on foreign oil have been asked more frequently. 
 The decision, a 4-to-1 vote by the Board of Supervisors, followed a recommendation from the Energy Division of the Santa Barbara County Resource Management Department that said an existing pipeline system that reaches from Santa Barbara to Los Angeles is a viable alternative. Chevron has strongly disagreed, saying that given the low quality of the Arguello crude, such an alternative is economically and technically impractical.
The permit would have allowed Chevron to use double-hull tankers for four years to move oil to three Los Angeles area refineries while it built a new pipeline. Chevron has conducted preliminary studies on building a $200 million underground pipeline along land owned by the Southern Pacific railroad.
G. Michael Marcy, a Chevron spokesman, said that the company would consider appealing the decision and taking legal action.
 
300 Million Barrels
 Today's vote was the latest in a string of victories for environmentalists and disappointments for Chevron, which has been waiting since December 1987 for permission to tap into what is the largest domestic oil field to be discovered since Prudhoe Bay in Alaska in 1969. Oil experts say the field, with more than 300 million barrels of recoverable reserves, could produce nearly 100,000 barrels a day.
Chevron originally tried to build a pipeline to Los Angeles but gave up in 1987 because of political opposition from Los Angeles and other cities along the pipeline route. The company then asked Santa Barbara County for an interim permit to move oil by tanker. That was approved in May 1989 but was revoked on appeal by the California Coastal Commission, a state agency, on the ground that the oil companies involved in the Point Arguello project had not made adequate precautions to clean up any spills.
The Board of Supervisors had supported Chevron's permit last year on the basis that Chevron would have switched to a pipeline within a short time.

HEADLINE: Oil Industry Shows Caution In Spending Sudden Profits

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 12

 BODY:
The American oil industry's response to the surge in oil prices in recent months is to sit tight and hope prices do not crash after the crisis in the Persian Gulf ends.
Chief executives of several oil companies, here for the annual meeting of the American Petroleum Institute, said in separate sessions today that higher prices were giving some of them a windfall. But these gains cannot be turned into huge investments to find more oil, they said, because money spent on exploration and production is slow to earn a return, and the higher prices are unlikely to last. In fact, several experts said, prices may plunge with a vengeance. 
 "This is a long-term business," said Lawrence G. Rawl, the chairman of the Exxon Corporation. "You don't turn the money on because the oil price spikes, and turn it off because the price goes down. Every time someone clears his throat in the Middle East or elsewhere, the price goes up and down."
Exxon's capital budget this year is $8.5 billion, Mr. Rawl said, and next year's will be higher, "but not by a whole lot."
As he emerged from the institute's board meeting here, Mr. Rawl told reporters that making investment decisions was difficult amid the uncertainty. "When prices go up and down like a window shade, it creates problems, not just for you, but for anybody in a long-term business," he said.
Executives of other companies made similar comments. Texaco Inc. will raise its capital budget to $3.1 billion in 1991, from $2.9 billion, said James W. Kinnear, president and chief executive officer. But, he added, "we try not to run up and down with the morning newspaper."
The price of oil has fallen in recent days, to $31.87 a barrel. But it closed over $40 in mid-October, and is still nearly 40 percent higher than the level at which it was trading when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.
The expectation that prices will plunge from this level is in marked contrast to the oil crises of 1973 and 1979, said Thomas A. Petrie of Petrie Parkman & Company, a Denver brokerage that specializes in oil stocks. "There is no excess of optimism or expectation," he said. "It is important to maintain a sober attitude, but not to block well-crafted reinvestment plans for the cash flows now being generated."
Mr. Petrie said the stock market shares an assessment that high prices cannot last. When Iraq invaded Kuwait and the price of crude oil took off from the low $20's it was trading at then, oil company stocks outperformed the market. But when the price got above $30 a barrel at the end of August, the market soured on the stocks. Stock prices of five of the six biggest international oil companies have since fallen, as have 10 of the 11 big domestic companies, while one is unchanged.
Independent oil producers are not burdened with refining or marketing operations that can become unprofitable in times of rising crude prices, but even among that group the stocks of 21 of 30 companies have declined.
The market's reading, Mr. Petrie said, is that "this is too much of a good thing, and in fact could be described as a bad thing."
 
Potential for a Glut
 The potential has emerged for a glut of oil once the Persian Gulf crisis ends, with any post-embargo exports by Iraq and Kuwait likely to end up as a surplus on the world market.
"If production from Iraq and Kuwait comes back, which is a real possibility, OPEC will be back in the problems very similar to what they had early this year, except there has been a change in OPEC," said John B. Boatwright, an economist with Exxon.
Oil analysts presume that after the crisis ends, Iraq will no longer be in a position to enforce production limits by bullying its neighbors. As a result, Mr. Boatwright said, "a future production agreement would be even more difficult."
 
Finely Balanced Market
 Even without an end to the standoff over Kuwait, production will eventually outstrip demand, experts here said. Several described the current market as finely balanced, with oil production and especially refining capacity strained to the limit. But Mr. Boatwright said that by next summer "demand will be 1.5 million barrels a day less than OPEC capacity."
"You can make your own conclusion about what that will do to prices," he added.
James H. Ross, the president and chief executive of BP America Inc., the United States subsidiary of the British Petroleum Company P.L.C., said demand for OPEC oil in the first quarter of next year would run 20.5 million barrels a day, while production is now 22.5 million barrels a day and Saudi Arabia is planning to pump even more. Prices will stay high while there is a fear of war, he said, but if the perception took hold that the price would plunge, that is exactly what would come to pass, because purchasers would delay buying to wait for a bargain, demand would fall and prices would drop in response. "OPEC needs to get its act together, whoever OPEC is," Mr. Ross said.
 
The Role of Iraq
 The chief economist of the Amoco Corporation, Theodore Eck, said, "Everyone knows Iraq's going to come back into the market, and clearly Saudi Arabia's going to make a place for them, but how it fits together I don't know."
Discussing the difficulty of predicting future market conditions, an executive of one big oil company said that every year he presents his board with a proposal for capital spending, prefacing his remarks by saying, "We face an uncertain situation." This year, he said, he would say the same thing but would pound the table as he said it.

HEADLINE: Dow Soars; Cut by Fed Is Expected

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
A relaxation of war nerves coupled with expectations that a reduction in interest rates could come as quickly as today or tomorrow helped push stock prices sharply higher yesterday for the second straight session.
Trading on higher ground for most of the day, the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,540.35, up 51.74 points, in a fairly busy session. With Friday's increase of 44.80, the Dow has gained more than 96 points in just the two days.
 
 The surge led some analysts to forecast further gains -- particularly because a cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve is now viewed as practically a sure thing.
 
Blocks of New Money
 Laszlo Birinyi Jr., president of Birinyi Associates, the Wall Street research firm, said that $343 million in new money came into the stock exchange yesterday in big blocks of 10,000 shares or more and that $195 million entered in smaller trades.
That means, he said, that "the little guy, the big guy, the institutions, they were all active."
Asked what helped the market, Philip J. Roth, chief market technician for Dean Witter Reynolds, said, "It was obvious today: lower oil prices and the expectation of lower interest rates by the Fed."
With the possibility of war in the Persian Gulf fading into the coming year, oil tumbled again. After falling $1.64 on Friday, prices fell $2.02 a barrel yesterday, to $31.87. [Page D8.]
 
Debate on Move to War
 A national debate has begun to unfold in the last few days among political and government leaders and prominent academics over whether the United States has been moving too quickly down the road to war. And yesterday, seeking to calm the critics, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said, "We don't want to go to war." Like many Congressman, President Bush, he added, prefers to "be cautious."
As for the rate cut, Mr. Roth noted that under Alan Greenspan as chairman, the Fed's policy had been to cut rates a quarter-point at a time. A new cut, prompted by mounting evidence that the economy may have slipped into a recession, is expected shortly after the Fed's Open Market Committee discusses monetary policy today,
The New York Stock Exchange, which intervenes whenever the index moves 50 points or more in either direction, stepped in yesterday at 3:41 P.M. after the average had risen that far. For the remainder of the session, to help stabilize prices, orders by index arbitragers to buy stocks could not be executed at prices higher than the previous sale price. Index arbitrage is a form of program trading in which traders try to profit from the difference between the prices of stock index futures contracts and the underlying stocks.
Program traders were a big factor in the market's advance, Mr. Birinyi said, with three waves of buying lifting the Dow more than 19 points.
Activity rose to a relatively strong 161.4 million shares, from 145.2 million shares on Friday. The new money helped 1,163 stocks advance, while only 381 declined; 14 rose to new highs while 38 fell to new lows.
The sharp rise in stock prices, which raised the Dow blue chips a little more than 2 percent, also spilled over into the smaller over-the-counter stocks, with the Nasdaq composite index rising close to 3 percent. The Amex market value index, representing other small stocks, trailed the blue chips.
Traders took heart in the strong leadership of I.B.M., the Joe Montana of the stock market. I.B.M. rose 2 3/4 on Friday, to crash through $110, and yesterday jumped another 2 3/4, to 113. It topped the Big Board's most-active list, with 3.5 million shares changing hands.
Other high-tech stocks that followed its lead were Motorola, up 2, to 57 5/8; Compaq Computer, up 2 1/4, to 51 3/8; Honeywell, up 1 3/4, to 91 3/8, and Digital Equipment, up 1 7/8, to 51 1/4.
Noting that financial stocks were exceptionally strong, Mr. Birinyi said that that suggested "rates really are going to be cut."
American Express, the second-most-active Big Board stock, rose 2, to 21 5/8, on nearly 3 million shares; Fannie Mae rose 1 1/2, to 32, on 2.6 million; BankAmerica climbed 1 1/2, to 23 3/4; Citicorp rose 1, to 13 1/4, and General Electric gained 1 5/8, to 55 3/8.
Airlines yesterday were a big beneficiary of the oil-price slide. The Dow transportation index jumped nearly 4 percent, led by AMR, up 1 7/8, to 48 1/8; Delta Air Lines 2, to 57 3/8, and UAL 4 5/8, to 100 1/4, although part of the UAL rise seemed related to takeover developments. UAL agreed earlier to buy Pan Am's London-New York routes.
 
Tokyo Stocks Climb
TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 13 (REUTERS) -- Stocks in Tokyo were sharply higher at midday today, helped by a stronger yen and weaker oil prices. At the end of the morning session, the 225-share Nikkei index was up 773.04 points, or 3.4 percent, to 23,704.84.

LENGTH: 1524 words

HEADLINE: FREE-TRADE TALKS IMPERILED BY FIGHT ON FARM SUBSIDIES

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Talks to liberalize world trade were threatened with collapse today in an impasse over the subsidies that the European Community gives its farmers.
The community made an offer to reduce those subsidies, but the United States, Australia and other countries that depend on farm exports said the proposal was too meager to talk about. These nations contend that for domestic political reasons, Germany and France in particular subsidize inefficient small farms and encourage them to dump their products on world markets and preserve home markets for themselves. 
 Trade officials in Geneva, where the talks are taking place, said the four-year round of negotiations had reached a standstill and that plans to complete the talks early next month were in jeopardy.
 
Situation Called Grave
 "We are now in a very grave situation," said Arthur Dunkel, Director General of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the Geneva-based organization overseeing the talks. "Until and unless some major political decisions are taken, the negotiations will not move forward."
The deadlock could torpedo the whole round of negotiations, which seek to set liberal new rules in 15 sectors with trade totaling $1.5 trillion. The talks are intended to write new rules for sectors that are increasingly important in today's economy: investment, intellectual property and services, including banking, telecommunications and aviation.
If the talks succeed it could enable the United States and other low-cost food producers like Argentina to export more of their farm products. It would also make it easier for American banks to open branches and for publishers to have copyrights honored worldwide. Failure of the talks could result in more unilateral protective moves by many countries.
 
'Need Something to Change'
 Many countries that export farm goods asserted that the European Community's offer to cut agricultural subsidies by 30 percent over 10 years was too modest even to discuss. Rufus Yerxa, a United States deputy trade representative in Geneva, said in a telephone interview that the talks were "near collapse."
"We're in a very serious situation," he added, "and we need something to change to bring us out of it."
The final phase of the 105-nation talks, which are known as the Uruguay Round because they began in Punta del Este, Uruguay, in 1986, is scheduled to take place in Brussels Dec. 3 to 7.
After repeated failures to reach a common position, the 12 community nations agreed last week to propose the 30 percent cut over 10 years, dating from 1986. But the United States and the Cairns Group have proposed cutting farm supports by 75 percent over 10 years, with export subsidies cut 90 percent.
The Cairns Group of 14 nations that are exporters of farm goods is headed by Australia and includes Argentina, Brazil and Canada, which are seeking far deeper cuts in farm protection than those proposed by the Community. The group, whose other members are Chile, Colombia, Fiji, Hungary, Indonesia, Malaysia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Thailand and Uruguay, takes its name from the town in Queensland, Australia, where their representatives organized in 1986 in preparation for the Uruguay Round.
 
 Markets Viewed as Stolen
 Farm trade, which is not now covered by international trade rules, has become the linchpin of the talks since many nations that export farm goods have said they would not sign an overall accord without large cuts in farm protection like export subsidies, which they say steals their markets.
Today, about 2,000 French farmers blocked highways to protest the community's proposal. On Tuesday some 10,000 farmers are expected to demonstrate in Geneva.
 Trade officials hope there will be some narrowing of differences between Washington and Brussels on Tuesday when President Bush meets in Washington with Jacques Delors, the president of the community's executive commission, and Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy, which holds the community's six-month chairmanship.
 
 Threat of Walkout
 Officials from many countries that export farm goods say the talks could be doomed if the community treats its offer as final. Argentina and several other nations have even threatened to walk out unless the community agrees to consider deeper cuts in farm protection.
"Their offer falls far short of the mark," Julius Katz, a United States deputy trade representative, said in a telephone interview. "It is not yet clear that the community is prepared to go beyond its initial offer."
In a statement issued today in Geneva, Mr. Dunkel, who is the chairman of the talks, said that unless there were "some basic changes in present postions in the next few hours or at most the next few days I do not see how we will be able" to have a successful outcome next month.
He added that in the view of a number of participants the community's offer "does not constitute an adequate basis on which to conduct substantive negotations."
 
Lag on Services Criticized
 In his statement, Mr. Dunkel also criticized a lack of progress on liberalizing trade in services. The members of the European Community and other countries criticize Washington for dragging its feet on agreeing to a liberalization in shipping, aviation and telecommunications.
Because of the snags in negotiations over farm supports, some officials say the final phase of the talks may have to be postponed, a prospect American officials strongly oppose because of a deadline imposed by Congress.
Raymond MacSharry, the community's farm commissioner, today denied that the talks were falling apart because of the community's offer. He predicted that the negotiations would have a successful outcome once other countries "stop accusing the community of being the sinner."
"We've all been supporting agriculture," he said.
 
Cost of $250 Billion Seen
 The United States, Canada, Australia, Argentina and many third world countries argue that their farms produce at lower cost than the small farms of Europe. They add that cuts in agricultural protection would allow their farmers to capture a larger share of world farm trade. Economists say farm protectio costs the industrial world $250 billion a year in extra taxes and inflated food prices.
"We can't have a package without an agreement in agriculture," said one GATT official. "People say to the GATT secretariat, 'Wave a magic wand. There must be some magical way of doing this.' Well there isn't."
Last Tuesday, in their eighth attempt to adopt a common negotiating position, community ministers proposed cutting farm supports by 30 percent. But the community's proposal was ambiguous about making cuts in export subsidies, which Washington says are particularly insidious in distorting trade.
 
'Ridiculous and Incompetent'
 When the community's executive commission originally proposed a 30 percent cut, France and Germany opposed it as going too far. Britain, Denmark and the Netherlands were the only community nations pushing vigorously for less farm protection, with the British Agriculture Minister, John Gummer, saying that French and German opposition was making the community seem "ridiculous and incompetent."
The Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl opposes big cuts partly because, with elections set for Dec. 2, it is eager not to displease Germany's farmers. France, the community's leading exporter of farm goods, is hesitant to cut farm supports because the Government faced mass protests last summer in which many of its two million farmers demanded more aid to help them cope with drought and plunging beef prices.
The community's 10 million farmers, a potent political force, contend that the group's proposal goes too far, making it difficult for the organization to agree to greater cuts.
 
Reasons for German Assent
 European officials said Germany finally agreed to the executive commission's proposal for 30 percent cuts for two reasons: Germany is Europe's largest exporting nation, and it feared that it would be hurt in many non-farm sectors if the Uruguay Round fell apart over agriculture. Second, Germany won commitments that any income losses its farmers suffered because of reduced farm supports would be offset by, for example, direct income grants. Washington officials say grants would be preferable to price supports and export subsidies because they do not inflate production or distort trade flows.
Getting France to agree to the executive commission's proposal for 30 percent cuts was more difficult. France insisted on changes that American officials say have watered down the proposal, which most countries already said was inadequate.
Louis Mermaz, the French Agriculture Minister, insisted on omitting a paragraph that called for reducing the community barriers to imports of cheap food by 30 percent. The French also insisted on and won changes to make the language in the community's proposal far more ambiguous about how fast export subsidies should be reduced. Paris also had the community rule out making export subsidies a separate subject in the negotiations.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chip Indicator Is Unchanged

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Orders for computer chips rose slightly in the United States while shipments declined in October, but the semiconductor industry's leading indicator remained unchanged from September, a trade group reported today.
The Semiconductor Industry Association, based in San Jose, Calif., reported a book-to-bill ratio of 0.95 for the three-month period that ended in October, unchanged from September and down from a revised figure of 1 in August.
The book-to-bill ratio compares orders with shipments and is considered a leading indicator of the industry's performance. A ratio of 0.95 indicates that for every $100 worth of product shipped, $95 was ordered, indicating that demand has declined.
At $1.19 billion, three-month orders for October were up slightly from the period that ended in September, and 5.1 percent higher than the comparable figure last year, which was $1.14 billion.
Three-month average shipments for October totaled $1.26 billion, up seven-tenths of 1 percent from September at $1.25 billion. At $1.18 billion, United States market shipments for the month of October were down 13.8 percent from September's $1.37 billion.

HEADLINE: London Betting on Itself And on Canary Wharf

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
When Olympia & York Developments Ltd. decided in 1987 to undertake Canary Wharf, the biggest real estate development project in Europe, Paul Reichmann, the president of the family-owned company, said he was prepared to live through at least two downturns in the real estate market here.
The Toronto-based developer, which is staking nearly 4 billion ($7.86 billion) on Canary Wharf, is now going through the first slump -- and without too much difficulty considering that London is in the grips of the worst real estate downturn since the mid-1970's. 
 As the complex of buildings at Canary Wharf steadily rises above the Isle of Dogs, 2.5 miles to the east of London's financial district, rents are falling and vacancies are climbing in central London. Several developers have filed for bankruptcy protection or have liquidated. Others are believed to be on the ropes.
There is more at stake here than the performance of Olympia & York, one of the largest developers of commercial real estate in New York. How the project fares will largely determine the merits of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's ambitious plan to revive the Docklands, the derelict area surrounding the wharf that in the heyday of the British empire was the home port for much of the country's vast merchant fleet.
Mr. Reichmann remains optimistic about Canary Wharf and the assumption on which it was built. He is still betting that London will remain the dominant financial center of Europe after the end of 1992, when the European Community plans to have eliminated trade and commercial barriers among its 12 member nations.
For now, Olympia & York is trying to line up tenants for the 4.5 million square feet of office space in the nine buildings that make up the first phase of Canary Wharf. In an effort to lay off some of its risks to banks, the company is also trying to refinance the first phase of the project.
When completed in 1997 or so, the 71-acre site will include 26 buildings, with 10 million square feet of office space; up to 500,000 square feet of stores, restaurants and other leisure facilities; a 400-bedroom hotel, and parking for 6,500 cars.
Eight of the nine buildings in the first phase, including an 800-foot tower that will be the tallest building in Britain, will be largely completed by mid-1991. Olympia & York says it has pre-leased 54 percent of the office space.
While "obviously I would be happier if 75 to 80 percent were pre-let, I'm hopefu it will be at that level next summer," said Michael Dennis, the Canadian who is chief executive of Olympia & York Canary Wharf Ltd.
Smaller tenants will begin to move in next summer. The first major one, Morgan Stanley, will follow in the fall. And Texaco plans to take up residence in the ninth building in mid-1992.
 
A Change of Heart
 Others that have signed leases include Credit Suisse First Boston, American Express, Manufacturers Hanover, London Wall Holdings, a big British insurer; Ogilvy & Mather, the ad agency, and The Daily Telegraph, the British newspaper.
Real estate experts are impressed with the leasing effort. "They are doing remarkably well," said Roger Nield, an executive at Chesterton, a major real estate agency.
But Olympia & York has also suffered some setbacks. Two big prospective tenants -- Merrill Lynch Europe Ltd. and Saatchi & Saatchi Company, the advertising giant -- changed their minds about Canary Wharf. The European Bank for Reconstruction and Economic Development, which is being created to finance the rebuilding of Eastern Europe, is not even considering Canary Wharf for its headquarters.
Olympia & York executives acknowledge having to offer juicy enticements to attract tenants. Analysts say these include assuming tenants' existing leases. Olympia & York even bought The Daily Telegraph's building in the South Quay section of the Docklands.
While Olympia & York did not get burned when it used similar tactics to woo companies to New York's World Financial Center in the 1980's, the moves increase its bet on the London market. Besides Canary Wharf, the company has joint ventures in other areas of the Docklands and owns sizable minority stakes in two big London developers, Stanhope Properties P.L.C. and Rosehaugh P.L.C.
 
Disclosure on U.S. Portfolio
 The first phase of Canary Wharf is expected to cost 1.4 billion ($2.75 billion). So far, Olympia & York has invested more than 800 million ($1.57 billion) from internal funds, bank credit lines or money borrowed against its North American properties.
Now, the company is negotiating with banks to replace that with money secured by Canary Wharf buildings. Mr. Dennis said Olympia & York was on the verge of completing a 500 million ($982 million) general-project-financing deal and was beginning discussions about a 600 million ($1.18 billion) loan secured by the tower.
The refinancing efforts, and the disclosure last month that Olympia & York was peddling a 20 percent stake in its United States real estate portfolio to outside investors, touched off speculation that the company needed cash for Canary Wharf. But Mr. Dennis insisted that Canary Wharf had no cash problems and said that the refinancing followed a timetable announced at the beginning of the project in 1987.
While banks have become more skittish about real estate lending, Mr. Dennis said they should lend to the project "given the extent of the equity we have in the project, the fact it is nearing completion and the extent of the leasing accomplished."
But Mr. Dennis said he will worry if Britain's interest rates do not drop sharply in the next few months.
 
Vacancy Rate Up Sharply
 The British Government cut its base interest rate in October to 14 percent from 15 percent. But further easing is unlikely soon.
As a result, real estate experts do not expect the London market to begin recovering before the end of 1991. And their forecast assumes that the Persian Gulf crisis does not result in a major disruption in oil supplies and a significant deepening of the shallow recession that economists believe Britain is entering.
The vacancy rate in the City, as the financial district is known, has risen to about 12 percent, from about 2 percent in 1986, and is expected to hit 15 percent or more this year or next.
Meanwhile, rents for new leases in central London have dropped by 8 to 15 percent this year. Those for new buildings in prime locations in the City have fallen to about 55 ($108.05) a square foot, from about 64 last year, said Simon P. Ward, a partner at Jones Lang Wootton, the real estate appraisers and brokers. "Significant growth in rents, by which I mean a 5 to 10 percent annual rate, is unlikely before 1993 at the earliest," he said.
Whether the slump seriously hurts Canary Wharf remains to be seen. The economic slowdown could provide an incentive for cost-conscious companies to move there. Thanks to low land costs and Government tax breaks, Olympia & York can charge rents of 27 to 30 ($53.04 to $58.95) a square foot -- about two-thirds the typical rent in the City.
 
Modern Quarters
 In addition, Canary Wharf's buildings will be state of the art in everything from air-conditioing to their capability to house computer and telecommunications systems. The same cannot be said about much of the office space in central London: 45 percent predates World War II, 31 percent was built between the war and 1979 and 24 percent after that, according to Jones Lang Wootton.
This lack of modern office space was a major reason Paul Reichmann and his two brothers were willing to undertake a project as big as Canary Wharf. With a unified Europe bringing increasing competition and opportunities to the area, Mr. Reichmann argues, companies will become increasingly willing to move out of central London into these kind of quarters.
But the Reichmanns also decided that for Canary Wharf to compete with central London, it had to be a stand-alone business center.
In addition to the shops, offices and hotels, the plan calls for Canary Wharf to offer a transportation system that is vastly superior to London's, with roads, subways, a light railway, a catamaran river bus service on the Thames and proximity to two nearby airports. Olympia & York is contributing at least 500 million ($982 million) to help pay for all this. And the British Government has pledged 3 billion ($5.89 billion).
Real estate experts say that once these plans are completed, Canary Wharf -- and the Docklands -- will flourish. But that may not be until the mid- to late 1990's. In the meantime, Olympia & York faces the formidable task of wooing corporations to an area that looks more like a construction site than a place of work and that can be a nightmare to reach.
 
No Rush to the Top
 Although the first trees will be planted next month, many of the basic improvements and the expansions of the transportation system will not be completed until the end of 1992 or early 1993. And Olympia & York does not expect the extension of London's subway to Canary Wharf to be completed before the first half of 1996.
"Obviously we moved faster than the Government agencies working on various transportation improvements, who are trailing us by about a year," Mr. Dennis said.
Despite the challenges, he does not sound worried. Indeed, he seems in no rush to rent the top floors of the tower. While most of the deals in the tower have averaged about 30 (58.95) a square foot, he says the top section should command at least 10 ($19.65) more. "If we opened and had the top quarter of the tower left, it wouldn't dismay me at all," he said.
Nor does he consider the pullouts by Merrill Lynch and Saatchi & Saatchi to be a bad omen. Analysts agree, noting that both have suffered financial setbacks and are retrenching.
Yet even those real estate experts who are impressed by progress say it is not clear whether Olympia & York will make money on Canary Wharf. "It's far too early to tell," said John J. S. Coventry, a partner at Hillier Parker May & Rowden, a property agent and consulting firm.
Mr. Dennis says he has no doubts. "We expect the first phase to be a financial success and not to have to wait 10 years as some have suggested," he said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Treasury Securities Up Abroad

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prospects of a further easing in monetary policy by the Federal Reserve Board pushed prices of Treasury securities higher yesterday in Europe.
Because of the Veterans Day holiday, trading did not take place in the United States. And financial markets were closed in Tokyo as Emperor Akihito was enthroned. 
 Speculation that the Fed may decide to push a key short-term interest rate down another notch has heightened in advance of today's meeting of the central bank's policy-making Open Market Committee.
Despite lingering concerns about inflation, most credit market analysts said that signs of deepening economic weakness would prompt members of the committee to approve a quarter-point cut in the overnight Federal funds rate, to 7.50 percent from 7.75 percent.
"The Fed could move this week, or they could put it off for a few more days," said James Fralick, senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "Dealers certainly anticipate another ease in policy, and are willing to hold the securities they bought at last week's Treasury refunding auctions."
 
Futures Prices in Bonds
 Prices of Treasury securities of all maturities advanced in London, with the biggest gains recorded among longer-dated notes and bonds. Bond futures prices posted strong gains on the Chicago Board of Trade.
In the cash market, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 102 7/32 in London yesterday, up 27/32, to yield 8.54 percent. Late Friday in New York, the Treasury's benchmark bond was offered at a price to yield 8.61 percent.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 21/32 in London, up 12/32, to yield 8.40 percent. And the 7 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 101 3/8, up 3/32, to yield 7.53 percent.
Rates of short-term Treasury bills dipped slightly.
During London trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.03 percent, down 5 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell 3 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.01 percent.
Because of the Veterans Day holiday, the Treasury's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills, normally held on Mondays, was scheduled for today.
In Chicago, the nearby Treasury bond contract rose by 29/32, to 93 14/ 32. Trading volume in bond contracts at the Board of Trade was heavy.
Activity in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and tax-exempt municipal bonds was extremely light. Dealers said prices of widely quoted issues were little changed.

HEADLINE: Survey Sees Recession

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
The majority of top economists in a monthly survey believe a recession will begin before the end of the year, but most predict it will be brief and relatively mild, a prominent economic newsletter reports.
The publication, Blue Chip Economic Indicators, said in its latest report that 80 percent of the 55 economists in its survey thought a downturn would start before the end of 1990. Another 5 percent said the slump would start in 1991.
"It now seems very likely that America's longest peacetime expansion is about to come to an end," wrote the Blue Chip editor, Robert J. Eggert of Eggert Economic Enterprises Inc. in Sedona, Ariz.
The Blue Chip survey found three-fourths of the respondents expected any downturn to last no more than two or three quarters. "An even larger majority -- 82 percent -- anticipate that the recession will be relatively mild," the newsletter said.
The survey participants represent many of the nation's top banks, brokerage companies, corporations, economic forecasting organizations and universities.

HEADLINE: Debate on Persian Gulf Enlivens Bishops' Meeting

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
The nation's Roman Catholic bishops, gathered here for their fall meeting, strongly backed an appeal today for American restraint in the Persian Gulf.
The gulf question injected a surprise into what had promised to be a rather routine meeting, more concerned with institutional housekeeping than any of the conflicts sharply dividing Catholics. 
 By a vote of 249 to 14, the bishops supported a letter that Archbishop Roger M. Mahony of Los Angeles, chairman of the bishops' international policy committee, sent last week to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d.
Outside the Omni Shoreham Hotel, people who favor admitting women to the prieshood blessed varieties of bread, from sourdough loaves to saltines and bran muffins, and drink in what they called a women's eucharist.
 
Dissent on Other Issues
 A group of lay people calling for democratic changes in the church held a parallel conference in Silver Spring, Md. And conservative Catholics complained that the bishops were departing from church teaching by considering a document authorizing sex education in Catholic classrooms.
The letter on the gulf outlined the limits that Catholic teaching considers essential for warfare to be considered moral, including a just cause, the exhaustion of peaceful alternatives and discrimination between military targets and civilian centers. While not ruling out military action, Archbishop Mahony suggested that there was a great danger of gravely violating these limits if war broke out.
The uneasiness among the bishops over the Bush Administration's policy in the gulf was further indicated by the debate in what was almost the first order of business at the meeting, which will run through Thursday.
Even the endorsement of Archbishop Mahony's letter left many of the prelates unsatisfied that they had sufficiently addressed the gulf question, and what might what might have been a routine vote turned into a full-scale discussion.
 
More Discussion Is Set
 Bishop Michael H. Kenny of Juneau, Alaska, protested that the bishops "would discredit our credibility" if they did not offer Catholics specific "moral directions" on the gulf crisis.
"It seems to me that we don't hesitate to tell people what to do in regard to abortion or in regard to use of a condom," he said. "Are we willing to be so clear in reference to weapons of incalculable destruction?"
The bishops then voted by more than two-thirds to revise their agenda so that the gulf policy could be discussed more fully at a closed session on Wednesday afternoon. Archbishop Mahony expressed disappointment at the decision to discuss the gulf crisis in closed session. "I think this kind of discussion is better held in open forum," he said later.
 
Statement by O'Connor
 This morning's debate and vote showed that concern about recent American steps in the gulf extended well beyond those bishops who are frequent critics of American diplomacy and military policy.
John Cardinal O'Connor of New York said he felt "anxieties even apart from the dangers of war." He raised the question of expenditures overseas at a time of economic hardship in the United States.
Apart from the gulf discussion, the mood in the conference was one of business as usual. The bishops listened calmly to reports on the recent synod in Rome dealing with the training of priests, on Vatican finances, on ministry among Hispanic Catholics and on new guidelines for approving biblical translations, religious educational materials and sex-education programs.
"It looks like a tame meeting," said Bishop John S. Cummins of Oakland, Calif.

During yesterday's conference, the bishops expressed uneasiness over the Bush Administration's policy in the Persian Gulf. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Encinitas Journal;
Accident of Geography Prompts Local Protest

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ENCINITAS, Calif., Nov. 10

 BODY:
The bill to the Fed eral Government, for $225,356.20, covers items like the policing of migrants' campsites and the establishment of a hiring hall for day laborers. But as much as anything it is a cry of protest over an undeniable fact of geography.
Because the citizens of this small, affluent city live just 38 miles from the Mexican border, they face a daily reminder, in the presence of the migrant workers, of the poverty in which many of this country's neighbors live. 
 "It sort of pricks their conscience," said Ozzie Venzor, an advocate for immigrants rights, speaking of the city's residents. "If you just put these guys on balloons after work and they just disappeared so people would not have to see them, then the problem would go away."
But Mr. Venzor said he agreed with the contention of Mayor Pam Slater, who sent the bill to Washington, that because Encinitas is at the end of the first leg of the immigrants' journey, the city is left to deal with what is in essence a Federal problem.
"My feeling is that we have been dumped on by the Federal Government," Mrs. Slater said. "They've said, 'O.K., we're not going to enforce the border and we are not going to take charge of immigration, but it's up to your local hospitals, your local schools, your local social service agencies to provide for the needs of these indigent people.' "
 The bill, which was sent to Washington on Sept. 27, is the latest protest by communities in San Diego County over a border situation that has left the communities to deal with a growing influx of both legal and illegal migrants.
All sides generally agree that after an initial slowdown soon after the passage of the 1986 immigration law, which provided amnesty to some illegal aliens, illegal immigration has again surged.
There have been continuing complaints from local communities that increasing proportions of their budgets for law enforcement, health care and other services go to cover the needs of migrants.
The residents do not always deal with the situation well, and there are constant reports of harassment and violence against the migrants. Advocates like Mr. Venzor, who heads a group called Friends of the Immigrant Workers, say protests like the Encinitas bill to Washington carry a taint of racism.
Other such protests have included the declaration by Encinitas of a "local emergency" in which the City Council discussed its complaints about migrant workers.
Mrs. Slater's bill, which was addressed to the Comptroller General in Washington, warned of an escalation in "the problems of illegal encampments, open fires, increase in crime, exploitation of workers and increased community tensions."
The Mayor said she had not received an answer from the Federal Government. But she added that even without reimbursement the bill served a purpose in calling attention to the problem. "This is one more attempt on our part to ask for Federal assistance in dealing with what is a national and international problem far beyond the capacity of a city of 55,000 people to deal with," she said.
 The bill was accompanied by a copy of the emergency declaration of last April, which detailed some of the city's concerns.
According to that statement, more than 350,000 people were detained and later deported by the Border Patrol in the San Diego region in the fiscal year 1989. Some 13,250 illegal immigrants were arrested last year in Encinitas, it said.
The city says the number of homeless migrants here ranges from 800 to 1,500, of whom are 150 legal aliens registered with the job center. Mr. Venzor said he believed the figure to be considerably smaller.
The city's statement also estimated that $175,000 in public money had been spent last year to control and keep clean about 20 illegal campsites, and another $30,000 to run its jobs center.
But more than the costs themselves, it seemed that the very presence of the migrants was taking its toll on the residents of Encinitas.
"A lot of retired people have chosen to live here," Mrs. Slater said. "And now suddenly all those senior citizens are looking out their windows and seeing people going across their property and using their water and performing all their bodily functions right out there. It's caused a tremendous problem."

HEADLINE: New York City Gains As Low Dollar Lures The Foreign Tourist

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
Guests at the Ritz-Carlton, one of New York City's more traditional hotels, can have bacon and eggs for breakfast in the Jockey Club restaurant for $14.50. Or they can have miso soup, grilled fish and rice for $18.
While New York has always catered to foreign travelers, the addition of the customary Japanese fare to the breakfast menu at the Ritz and other New York hotels reflects the increasing importance of foreigners to the city's tourist industry. 
 The number of Americans visiting New York City dropped 5 percent in 1989, compared with 1988, but the number of foreigners staying at least one night increased 9 percent, according to the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau. In fact, the bureau estimates that almost a third of the city's 16 million annual tourists are foreign.
 
Dollar Falls, Visits Rise
 The boom in foreign tourism has been spurred by the precipitous fall in the value of the dollar compared with foreign currencies in the last few years, which makes the United States a bargain for prosperous Western Europeans, Japanese and others. As a result, for the first time, foreign tourists spent more in the United States last year than Americans spent abroad, and the spending gap is expected to increase, according to the United States Travel and Tourism Administration.
"A few years ago, the dollar was worth 10 francs, and now it's five," said Sylvain Macrez, of Lille, France, who returned to New York recently for the first time since he was a student in America 24 years ago. "So things don't seem so expensive."
Erika Kloapfar, a first-time visitor from Vienna who came for a 10-day vacation, said: "We heard that New York was dirty and dangerous, but it's really not so bad. And with the dollar so low, it's good for us to shop."
A German tourist coming to New York last November would have had to spend about 1,470 marks for four nights in a $200-a-night hotel room. But that same tourist arriving this week would find that those 1,470 marks would now buy five nights in the same hotel.
One-quarter of the foreign tourists in New York in 1989 were Canadians, and a third were from Britain, Japan, Germany, France or Italy. But other, non-European countries like Brazil, Australia and South Korea are also sending increasing numbers here.
The United States Travel and Tourism Administration has not yet compiled statistics for foreign visitors to New York this year, but it has projected that overall foreign tourism to the United States will rise 11 percent in 1990, to 40.6 million.
By all indications, foreign tourism to New York has continued to increase this year. Tourism and hotel officials say that the number of visitors from abroad has shot up even in recent months.
In the first six months of this year, the number of international travelers arriving at all three New York area airports went up 5.2 percent over the first half of 1989, to 10.6 million, said Amos Ilan, an economist for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Although this includes Americans returning from abroad and foreigners passing through New York, it nonetheless strongly reflects an increase in foreign visitors coming to the city, he said.
The influx of foreign travelers has been one of the few bright spots in the region's troubled economy. Although the increase from abroad has not completely offset the decline in domestic tourists, it has at least reduced the impact of that decline for New York businesses that depend on tourist dollars.
While foreign tourists this year will account for nearly one in every nine tourist dollars spent in the United States, in New York, one-third of the $10 billion in tourist expenditures is by foreigners, according to Ruth Nadler, a market research analyst for the Convention and Visitors Bureau. The proportion of foreigners patronizing various New York attractions ranges from about 10 percent of Lincoln Center and Broadway concert- and theatergoers, to 30 percent of visitors to the Museum of Modern Art and 50 percent of tourists at the Statue of Liberty.
 
'The Hub of America'
 "Foreigners are especially interested in coming to New York, because it's perceived around the world as the hub of America," said Daniela Marino, the regional tourism director for the New York State Department of Economic Development.
Leaders of New York's hotel, restaurant, retailing and tourist industries say that sharply increased revenues from foreign tourism have helped at a time when overall spending is down. They also have stepped up efforts to attract foreign tourists with new overseas marketing efforts, and by introducing a range of new services.
New York State has begun selling itself abroad in conjunction with Pan Am and Japan Airlines, and many hotels have established their own international sales offices from Frankfurt to Hong Kong.
With occupancy rates dropping for New York's 65,000 hotel rooms, hoteliers are competing for the lucrative foreign market. Hotels like the Marriott Marquis, Parker Meridien and Ritz-Carlton have hired more multilingual employees. They have added traditional Japanese dishes to their menus, and their newsstands feature Le Monde, the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, Yomuri Shinbun and Corriere Della Sera.
"In the past, only English was spoken in hotels, with maybe a sprinkling of Spanish and French," said Joseph E. Spinnato, president of the Hotel Association of New York City, "but now many hotels have Japanese signs and can accommodate most major languages."
Museums, sightseeing attractions and other tourist businesses are also beginning to cater to visitors from abroad. The Metropolitan Museum of Art, which draws nearly one-third of its four million annual visitors from abroad, began offering brochures in Japanese, German, French, Italian, Spanish and Chinese last year, and Central Park is about to follow suit with its first multilingual map.
City Guide, a weekly publication distributed in hotels, began a 40,000-copy Japanese-language edition two years ago. Tiffany's claims to have employees who can help customers in 50 languages, and Gray Line has increased its city bus tours in German, French, Spanish, Italian and Japanese.
 
Obstacles Remain
 Such efforts are particularly noteworthy since the United States has traditionally done less to cater to foreigners than most European countries.
Many attractions still lack even rudimentary services for non-English-speaking tourists. At the Empire State Building, where half of the 2.5 million annual visitors are foreign, there are no foreign-language brochures.
Compared with other countries, there are fewer foreign-language hotel concierges, tours and brochures in the United States, and tourist-information centers and places to exchange money are comparatively rare.
 
Informed but Not Scared
 Another obstacle to tourism is the impression of the United States, and New York in particular, as dangerous.
Nonetheless, many tourists, like Wolfgang Grollmuss, from Hildesheim, Germany, are not deterred by news stories about New York crime. "Crime may be going up, but I'm not afraid," he said. "New York sometimes seems decadent and dirty, but it also has more culture and is more fun than other American cities."
And many tourists say that they would visit regardless of crime rates or currency-exchange rates. Guy Lemaire, a dentist and former deputy mayor of Cannes, France, brought his two grandchildren to New York "so they know about life in America not only from TV and the movies," he said.
"With the dollar so low, it's an added benefit, but I would have come at any cost," he added.
