HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
When to Threaten Iraq?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
To critics who ask why the United States should not wait a year or more to see if economic sanctions force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, Administration officials say they have valid reasons for threatening a war this winter.
 President Bush's decision last week to nearly double the American military force in the Persian Gulf and to cancel troop-rotation plans, they say, was based on the assumption that only the threat of early war can persuade President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to withdraw his forces from Kuwait. 
 In addition, said a senior Administration official who would not be further identified, the White House is worried that keeping a large number of American soldiers in the Persian Gulf region for a prolonged period may provide a political target for Arab nationalists and contribute to the destabilization of Saudi society.
American soldiers might also lose their fighting edge if the crisis went on too long, and some specialists note that the coming winter are better fighting weather than the broiling summer.
 
No War Decision at This Time
 In the end, the President can turn away from a military confrontation and look for other ways to end the crisis. His aides say Mr. Bush has not decided whether to go to war. But they acknowledge that it will be difficult to sustain the large deployment of American forces in the Persian Gulf for a longperiod and would be politically embarrassing to withdraw them without having achieved the Administration's objectives.
Mr. Bush's troop decision has led to the first serious challenge to his policy from some leaders in the political mainstream, like Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia and chairman of the Armed Services Committee. They say that the White House is moving too quickly toward the use of force.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, asserted today that the Bush Administration was poised to go to war without either a genuine effort to see if the economic sanctions would be effective or to provide a thorough explanation to the American public.
"Why not stay the course we started?" Senator Moyhihan asked. "If ever a blockade might work, it's here."
Mr. Bush is "not preparing Americans for what's happening," he declared.
Mr. Moynihan, speaking on the ABC television program, "Good Morning America," added: "He will wreck our military; he will wreck his Administration, and he'll spoil a chance to get a collective security system working. It breaks your heart."
 
Lugar Moving on His Own
 Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, senior Republican on the Foreign Relations Committee, is expected to recommend on Tuesday that President Bush call Congress back into session to debate a declaration of war, acccording to an offical familiar with the Senator's thinking. Mr. Lugar has scheduled a news conference for Tuesday morning, but is not among the bipartisan Congressional leadership group that will meet President Bush to discuss the Persian Gulf.
The official said that Mr. Lugar was acting on his own and had not sought a consensus of Republican leaders.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, has discussed with President Bush the possibility of calling Congress back into session, but according to a senior Dole aide, the Senator is not prepared to recommend that such a session be used to debate a declaration of war. The aide said that Mr. Dole's chief concern at the moment is that lawmakers have been able to criticize Mr. Bush's strategy in the gulf without having to formally break with the President.
Mr. Dole, who is scheduled to have lunch with the President on Tuesday, has told Mr. Bush that Congress should be forced to commit itself, through votes rather than speeches, on a position for or against the additional troop deployments the President announced earlier this week.
Senator Nunn, reflecting the wariness of some American military commanders, says that war in the Persian Gulf would be bloodier than Bush Administration policy makers seem to anticipate and that economic sanctions may work, dispensing with the need to put American servicemen and women at risk.
Seeking to contain the growing debate, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said today: "We don't want to go to war. President Bush will say the same things these Congressmen are saying -- be cautious, follow the policy, support the U.N. resolutions, consult with Congress."
But Mr. Fitzwater's statements, while apparently aimed at quieting the critics, did not provide a public explanation for the Administration's speeded-up timetable for resolving the gulf crisis.
A senior Administration official in private did not hesitate to explain that the White House has put its political and military campaign to evict Iraqi troops from Kuwait on a fast track.
"There is some doubt as to how long we keep our forces there. This is not Germany," the official said, suggesting that the longer American forces remain in Saudi Arabia, the greater the possibility that the foreign presence might undermine the conservative traditions of Saudi society and even lead to instability.
 
How Vulnerable?
 He said the presence of large numbers of American troops in Saudi Arabia "is a point of vulnerability" for the Saudi leadership that Iraq has tried to exploit. "How much of a vulnerability we do not know," he added.
The senior Administration official also said that "American troops are out there in the most forbidding terrain and may loss their edge," a concern that must be balanced by the apparent desire of some senior military commanders to avoid a rush to war.
The senior official argued further that Eastern Europe nations and other countries were being seriously hurt by the oil-price rises, adding to the need to resolve the gulf crisis soon.
Finally, the official explained, the White House was concerned that Mr. Hussein was simply not taking the United States seriously because Iraq had continued to build up its forces in Kuwait and was continuing to plunder the country. Mr. Hussein, this official said, was still trying to drive a wedge through the alliance and appeared to believe that time is on his side.
 
Achieving the New Order
 Critics have raised other important questions:
Is the "new world order" that Mr. Bush seeks best established by a decisive defeat of the invading Iraqi forces at the hands of the American military, or by waiting to see if economic sanctions take their toll?
Is the threat of war this winter a shrewd application of shock therapy against a recalitrant Saddam Hussein, or does it reflect a lack of confidence in the multinational coalition to hang together in its opposition to Iraq's taking of Kuwait?
The developing debate is a far cry from August, when the Bush Administration decided to send American forces to Saudi Arabia to defend the West's oil supply against an Iraqi attack. The stated mission of the American military at that time was to "deter and defend," a mission that has since been accomplished, and the Administration received broad backing from members of both parties.
 
And Now, a Milestone
 President Bush also stated at the time that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait would not stand, and pointedly noted that no military options had been excluded. But the Administration emphasized that it was relying primarily on worldwide economic sanctions to persuade Mr. Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait. Echoing this line, Administration officials repeatedly argued that time was on Washington's side.
President Bush's decision to send more than 150,000 fresh troops to the gulf area, bringing the total to nearly 400,000 by early next year, marked a milestone in the Administration's handling of the gulf crisis because it appeared to be based on the calculation that either economic sanctions would not force Mr. Hussein to withdraw or that Washington could not afford to wait to see if they did.
Making a comprehensive public case for its decision to accelerate the timetable for resolution of the crisis may not be easy for the White House, which clearly does not want to highlight concerns it may have over the endurance of the multinational coalition or Saudi sensitivities to a long-term American troop presence there.

HEADLINE: Latin Meeting on Oil Policy

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Spurred by the Persian Gulf crisis, ministers from 24 Latin American and Caribbean nations met today to formulate a joint energy strategy that could help save the region's shaky economies from another oil shock.
Although Latin America contains the world's biggest reserves of crude oil outside the Middle East as well as immense gas, coal and hydroelectric resources, the wealth is spread unevenly.
Big importers like Brazil are unhappy at having to depend on volatile Middle Eastern nations for crude oil supplies while leading exporters in the region like Mexico and Venezuela sell their crude to the United States and Europe.
"It is no longer right that Latin America, which is so rich in energy, should see its development compromised by external factors over which it has no control," Brazil's Infrastructure Minister, Ozires Silva, said at the opening of the conference.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls in Slow Trading On Expectation of Fed Move

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell broadly in sleepy trading on world currency markets yesterday, largely on the expectation that the Federal Reserve would move this week to lower interest rates.
Trading was extremely light with many bank trading floors closed in observation of Veterans Day. Lack of news indicating increased volatility in the Middle East kept investors focused on what the Fed might do after today's meeting of its policy-making Open Market Committee. 
 Lower interest rates generally diminish the value of the dollar.
"With the war specter off the horizon and with rumors that the Fed will drop rates by tomorrow, there's nothing positive for the dollar at the moment," said Michael McGuinness, a vice president of the Harris Trust and Savings Bank.
 
Aided by Oil Slide
 Also driving down the dollar's value against foreign currencies was a slide in prices of oil futures. Traders were discouraged by a $2.02 drop in the December contract for crude oil, to $31.87 a barrel.
The oil drop added strength to the yen because traders read it as a favorable sign for Japan's oil-dependent economy. The dollar fell against the yen in New York, closing at 128.30 yen, down from Friday's 129.70. In overnight trading in Tokyo, the dollar traded at 130.50 yen, unchanged from Friday's close, and in London, it fell to 128.80 yen.
The British pound also strengthened, to $1.9660, from $1.9655 late Friday. In earlier London trading, the pound traded at $1.9627, compared with $1.9670 late Friday.
Against the German mark, the dollar fell one pfennig, to another postwar low, at 1.4770 marks, from 1.4870. It has been steadily declining against the mark since the beginning of the summer.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Friday's late rates, included: 1.2468 Swiss francs, down from 1.2499; 4.9700 French francs, down from 4.9940; 1,113.00 Italian lire, down from 1119.00, and 1.1664 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1683.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday: 1.4805 German marks, down from 1.4875; 1.2500 Swiss francs, up from 1.2495; 4.9755 French francs, down from 4.9940; 1.6700 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6775; 1,113.25 Italian lire, down from 1,119.50, and 1.1665 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1698.

HEADLINE: Pan Am's Fight to Survive on Its Own

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
The Pan Am Corporation has sold off its Park Avenue headquarters building, its Inter-Continental Hotel chain, its routes across the Pacific and now, in a deal on which final agreement could be reached tomorrow, its routes between New York and London. But despite years of trying, the company that used to symbolize the prestige of aviation has never succeeded in selling off itself.
So Pan Am is falling back on an alternative strategy: survival as an independent carrier. 
 Thomas G. Plaskett, Pan Am's chairman and chief executive, envisions building up Pan Am's Latin American operations, which have proved profitable, and regrouping the carrier's European flights around a large new hub, in Frankfurt. From there he hopes Pan Am can reap the new business that will come from German reunification and increased travel to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
Mr. Plaskett is also counting on higher traffic because of a marketing agreement, also up for approval tomorrow, under which Pan Am and United Airlines would coordinate schedules and reciprocate on their frequent-flier plans. And he is planning to increase the airline's fleet of fuel-efficient smaller planes and phase out many 747's.
On Sunday, Trans World Airlines Inc. and its chairman, Carl C. Icahn, offered to buy Pan Am, paying $100 million on Dec. 31 to keep it afloat while regulatory approval is sought. But Pan Am views the proposal as only a backup in case the deal to sell its Atlantic routes to United Airlines for $400 million fails. [Page D6.]
One way or another, Pan Am needs a lot of cash to survive another winter, a season when traffic is weak. In the first nine months of the year, Pan Am lost $268 million, and the airline has reported losses for years.
The New York-based carrier is reaching the limit on being able to bail itself out by selling assets. The only large asset left that could be disposed of readily is the East Coast shuttle that files to New York, Boston and Washington. While the company could also sell its routes to Latin America or Europe, it would shrink to the extent that it would be too small to compete against other big carriers.
 
One Analyst's Caution
 Julius Maldutis, an airline analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc., said Pan Am had shown a remarkable ability to survive crisis after crisis and thus its strategy could not be dismissed lightly.
"One should be very careful about saying it doesn't have a chance," he said, "because airlines are basically generators of cah and can quickly sell assets."
Pan Am, and the rest of the industry, must first get through the current problems caused by high fuel costs, a weak economy and the threat of war in the Middle East. "The airline industry is in a depression," Mr. Plaskett said in an interview.
He warned that the huge increases in the cost of jet fuel would lead to staggering losses for the airline industry and that some carriers could fail next year. If Pan Am and other airlines can pull through, he said, then Pan Am's strategy has a chance.
 
United Deal Is Critical
 Important to Pan Am's ability to go it alone, he said, is the marketing agreement with United included in the route-sale deal. Fliers from either airline could credit miles on each other's frequent-flier program. The route systems of the airlines barely overlap, and United fliers could cash in for trips to Europe on Pan Am while Pan Am fliers could get free trips on United to the Pacific.
Other alliances have shown they can generate traffic, including Continental Airlines' ties with the Scandinavian Airlines System.
United and Pan Am would also coordinate their flights at hubs like Miami to feed Pan Am's flights to Latin America.
Pan Am's Latin American routes are a bright spot, earning $10 million last year. Mr. Plaskett expects the routes, which generate 20 percent of the carrier's revenues, to do as well this year. Pan Am generates 12 to 13 cents a mile in revenues on the routes, compared with about 10 cents a mile on the more competitive trans-Atlantic routes.
"Miami is becoming the financial gateway to South America," Mr. Plaskett said, explaining the potential of Pan Am's Latin American operations. "A lot of South American companies have their local headquarters in Miami. There's a lot more business travel, rather than vacation people coming from New York."
 
Europe's Potential
 In Europe, Mr. Plaskett thinks a reunified Germany and sweeping changes in Eastern Europe will make Germany the economic center of Europe. He said Pan Am would build up flights to Frankfurt, offering nonstop 747 service from Los Angeles and San Francisco next year, and would increase service from Miami.
The carrier will also increase service from such hubs as Dulles International Airport outside Washington, where United now has about 125 flights.
Meanwhile, Pan Am will eliminate most of its feeder flights. Such flights do not pay for themselves. Mr. Plaskett said, for example, that the airline received only about $30 a passenger in revenues on its daily flight from Cincinnati to Kennedy International Airport in New York.
He said Pan would phase out many of its 747's, with five being retired this fall alone, because they were less fuel-efficient and held more passengers than was needed on many Pan Am routes.
 
Lighter Planes
 At the same time, the carrier will try to build up its fleet of Airbus A310's, which have two engines, are more fuel-efficient and are flown by two crew members. Also, the planes carry about 196 passengers, a number more appropriate for Pan Am's European destinations than the 747's, which can carry up to 412.
Pan Am now has 21 A310's, with 2 more scheduled to be delivered next year, and is looking for more.
As part of his offer made on Sunday, Mr. Icahn wants Pan Am to end its agreement with United, which Pan Am said it would not do. If Mr. Plaskett broke the United agreement and accepted Mr. Icahn's bid, their overlapping routes across the Atlantic would raise antitrust concerns at the Transportation Department.
But the department might approve a combination if the carriers convinced the agency that they needed it to survive.

HEADLINE: FAVORITISM FOUND IN SAVINGS CASES

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Senior officials in Washington knew as long ago as 1988 that preferential treatment was being given to some troubled savings and loans whose senior executives also served on Government regulatory boards, newly disclosed documents show.
Congressional investigators said the failure to make such conflicts of interest public, along with other serious regulatory lapses, discouraged local examiners from being more aggressive. This in turn slowed recognition of difficulties at savings and loans, adding billions of dollars to the costs of bailing out the industry.
 
$1.5 Million Mortgage
 In one case a director of the Federal Home Loan Bank in Dallas who was also a savings executive received a $1.5 million mortgage loan from a troubled institution at the same time that local examiners were being "influenced improperly by senior officials" of the home loan bank. 
 In another instance, local examiners removed one auditor who questioned a senior executive at an Arkansas institution who was also a director of the Home Loan Bank in Dallas and who had been accused of defrauding the institution's shareholders. Rather than remove the official, the documents show, "the F.H.L.B. of Dallas had been more interested in helping a fellow director."
The newly disclosed documents -- reviews conducted from 1986 to 1989 by outside Government examiners at 10 districts of the Federal Home Loan Bank system -- show that senior regulators at the bank board knew that in three of the larger districts "losses were deliberately concealed by the thrifts with the approval" of local examiners.
The home loan banks had a dual role: they both lent money to savings institutions and were charged with overseeing them. The Federal bailout put into place last year transferred the regulatory functions of the home loan banks to the Office of Thrift Supervision.
"People have debated whether it was ascertainable in 1988 to know the extent of the savings and loan problem," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, "The reviews show that officials knew the real extent of the problem and there was a deliberate effort to conceal that information."
Mr. Schumer is the chairman of the House Task Force on Urgent Fiscal Matters, whose staff investigators discovered the reviews of local examiners' activities and reports, conducted by examiners from other districts. This procedure was set up in 1986 to keep the cost of savings failure under control. It was to provide Washington officials with a "detailed independent report of the currenct effectiveness" of the home loan banks. The investigators provided summaries of some of the reviews to The New York Times on the eve of a Congressional hearing about the documents. The contents of the reviews were confirmed by interviews with people who were officials when the reviews were prepared.
"The peer review team vigorously contested the rationalization that the failing economy had caused all the problems and pointed to incompetence, poor lending practices, insider abuse, inadequate supervision and oversight, and fraud," the Congressional summary of the Dallas review said.
 
 Rewards for Losers
 The findings include instances in which local regulators approved enormous compensation to savings executives managing institutions that were losing large sums of money.
One example cited a $5 million bonus and a commitment of more than $8.5 million that was given to an executive of an institution reporting an annual loss of $4.5 million. At the request of the Office of Thrift Supervision, the institution was not identified because it is still in private hands.
M. Danny Wall, the chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board at the time the reviews were prepared, today strongly defended the decision not to publicize the internal reviews, insisting that much of the information had already been generally known.
Mr. Wall said in an interview that he and other senior bank board officials had used the reviews to seek significant changes in 1988 and 1989 in the way institutions were being supervised at the local levels. Allegations of conflicts of interest had been investigated, he said, and directors of the home loan banks in some districts had been forced to step down.
 
 Cost Exceeded Estimates
 The documents and interviews with regulators make clear that as early as 1988 Home Loan Bank Board staff gave officials in Washington estimates that the cost of the bailout could greatly exceed the $15 billion that officials were assuring Congress and the public would be adequate. In two instances alone, the documents show, those involving the Lamar Savings Association and the Sunbelt Savings Association, the local examiners had failed to account for additional losses of $1 billion.
The most conservative estimates now are that the bailout will cost taxpayers $130 billion, excluding interest, while some have put the ultimate cost at more than $500 billion. Most industry experts now agree that hewing to the $15 billion figure delayed a comprehensive cleanup of the largest financial scandal in the nation's history, and so drastically increased its cost.
Mr. Wall said that it was only in hindsight that the higher estimates of the cost of the bailout proved accurate. He attributed the rise in the cost to the continuing decline in the economy and regional real estate markets. "What we did not have at any time was any better sense of the numbers," he said.
But Mr. Schumer said the documents and testimony from officials demonstrated that Mr. Wall had "clearly been told that the magnitude of the problem was much greater than what he had told Congress."
 
 Political Motives Seen
 Inestigators on Mr. Schumer's task force said the decision not to make the findings public was a political one, saying that since 1988 was a Presidential election year, the regulators had decided not to paint too alarming a picture.
The hearing on Tuesday is expected to address these questions. Regulators scheduled to testify include George Barclay, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank in Dallas; Darrel W. Dochow, former executive director of the bank board's Office of Regulatory Activities and now head of the Seattle branch of the Office of Thrift Supervision, and five home loan bank board examiners who prepared reviews.
In large part, the regulatory lapses described in the reviews were the result of the dual role that the home loan banks played in the late 1980's as both regulators of the industry and its business partner, providing loans and other assistance to hundreds of institutions. In 1985, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board chairman, Edwin Gray, transferred most of the examination functions away from Washington and to the district banks, increasing the salaries of many examiners, but also increasing the numbers of conflicts.
In the case of Lamar Savings of Austin, Tex., for instance, the review concluded that the supervising regulators had knowingly failed to recognize $500 million in losses because that would mean that Lamar would lose its rights to service loans by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation and because recognition of the losses would require the Federal Home Loan Bank in Dallas to advance further funds, a course it was unwilling to take. At the time, according to the peer review, the institution had a negative net worth of $797 million.
 
 Suit Against a Director
 Among the directors of Lamar was Robert Mettlen, who was also a director of the Federal Home Loan Bank in Dallas. Local examiners had recommended that Mr. Mettlen be dismissed from the home loan bank's board because of a civil lawsuit brought against him and other Lamar officials by shareholders alleging fraud, negligence and breach of fiduciary duties. He was ultimately not reappointed, but only because of the peer review, Congressional investigators said.
Lamar failed in 1988 and it ultimately cost taxpayers $805 million to bail out. The institution is also on the Justice Department's list of 100 priority cases for investigation into possible fraud.
The review team in Dallas also concluded that shareholders in the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Little Rock, Ark., might have been defrauded by senior management during a stock conversion. But the review concluded that the Home Loan Bank turned a blind eye because its directors included M. R. Godwin, chairman of First Federal. First Federal Savings was seized by the Government in August 1989 and had a negative net worth of $471 million.

HEADLINE: Judge in Eastern Case to Face Difficult Choices

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Efforts by the judge overseeing the Eastern Airlines bankruptcy case to keep the carrier flying will be severely tested tomorrow. The airline's unsecured creditors, including airplane and engine makers, banks and unions, are losing patience and are resisting attempts by Eastern to tap anew into its cash reserves.
Eastern's attempts to persuade the creditors to support a new infusion of cash have been unsucccessful, a person involved in the negotiations said yesterday.
 
Some Progress to Be Cited
 In seeking permission from Judge Burton R. Lifland to withdraw $30 million now and $40 million next month from the escrow fund established after Eastern first sought bankruptcy last year, the airline's lawyers are expected to argue that Eastern is making headway and may begin to generate enough cash by February so it will not have to come back for more. 
 Eastern is optimistic because after it doubled the amount of first-class seats on its planes on Oct. 1 and then offered them to customers who paid full price for a coach seat, the number of passengers paying full-coach fare increased by 4.3 per flight. Eastern has been run by a court-appointed trustee, Martin R. Shugrue Jr., since April.
Attorneys for the unsecured creditors are expected to contend that they have had enough of upbeat projections that have proved wrong. They believe it is time to save what money is left, shut down the airline and sell off the assets. Withdrawing more money would only shrink the amount they would get for what is owed them. The airline is losing more than $1 million a day.
Judge Lifland will have to decide whether -- with all the uncertainties about the future cost of aviation fuel, the response of leading competitors and the onset of a recession -- Mr. Shugrue should be given the chance to see whether his strategy will hold up.
The judge is running out of options to win back the creditors' support.
Last April, creditor groups had become fed up with the attempts by management, led by Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of Eastern's parent company, now called Continental Airlines Holdings Inc., to turn around the Miami-based carrier. Judge Lifland, who is the chief judge of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York, ended the crisis by ordering that the airline be turned over to Mr. Shugrue rather than be liquidated.
A court-appointed examiner, David I. Shapiro, persuaded creditors that pressing for liquidation could jeopardize Government approval of the sale of Eastern's Latin American routes to American Airlines for $304 million.
For a time, the unsecured creditors were open to Mr. Shugrue's efforts to revive Eastern. A former vice chairman at Pan American World Airways Inc. and president of Continental Airlines, Mr. Shugrue was not tainted by the legacy of labor strife associated with Mr. Lorenzo's management.
With the support of the creditors, Judge Lifland authorized $80 million from the escrow account for Mr. Shugrue to revive a slimmer Eastern.
Mr. Shugrue featured himself in an advertising campaign seeking to reassure customers about Eastern's safety and service. The airline began attracting more customers with fares lower than those of its primary rivals. But Eastern made little headway in attracting the business traveler.
Nevertheless, the unsecured creditors supported the withdrawal since April of $150 million more from the escrow fund.
According to Eastern's current motion to withdraw more money, about $257 million is left in the fund. Since Eastern filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code on March 9, 1989, about $550 million has been withdrawn from the fund and approved by the unsecured creditors.
Of the $257 million remaining, about $30 million must be paid to the Pension Benefits Guaranty Corporation, a Federal agency, in January in a settlement to secure Eastern's pension funds. About $50 million has been designated by the court for a program that would reimburse ticket holders if Eastern had to stop flying.
The unsecured creditors could benefit further from sales of Eastern assets, including gates and operations at Hartsfield International Airport in Atlanta.
But liquidation, if it comes to that, could also be costly and could further deplete what is left. Liquidation costs could run as high as $500 million to $600 million, a person involved in the proceedings said.
Eastern would have to keep on many employees as it is liquidated, pay severance to many others and pay to keep many operations going until they are sold.
Mr. Shugrue, therefore, hopes that Judge Lifland will be convinced that the airline should have more time to see whether it can win back more business fliers.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Helping Women Abroad Get Started in Business

BYLINE: By Daniel F. Cuff

 BODY:
Women's World Banking, an unusual global group that helps women get started in business, has a new president, Nancy Barry.
Ms. Barry, 41, took over the post in September from the founder, Michaela Walsh. She left a career at the World Bank to head the 10-year-old group, which operates in 40 countries with some 50 independent affiliates. She was back in New York yesterday, after a trip to visit affiliates, and explained how the organization works. "The business we are in," Ms. Barry said, "is to provide various products and services that increase access by women to credit." 
 So far, she said, 70,000 loans have been made, virtually all in developing countries. And most of these have been for what she called microbusinesses, anything from bicycle repair to buying a cow, with loans starting as low as $50.
The group guarantees half the loan, while the local affiliate takes responsbility for an additional 25 percent and the commercial bank making the loan takes a 25 percent risk. So far, Ms. Barry said, women have proved good risks. The rate of arrears is less than 5 percent and writeoffs less than 1 percent, she said. The not-for-profit group, registered in the Netherlands and with headquarters in New York, receives financing from the Canadian, Norwegian, Dutch and United States Governments, while foundations, banks and corporations also contribute.
A graduate of Stanford and the Harvard Business School, Ms. Barry started her career working for the Peruvian Government as an economist specializing in small-business development.
While at Harvard, she worked in the summer for the Tanzanian Government on rural industry development. In 1975, Ms. Barry joined the World Bank and pioneered loans for small and medium enterprises. When she left, she was division chief for industry, trade and finance. She got involved with Women's World Banking in 1981 as a trustee and the last three years she has been its vice chairman.
During her tenure, Ms. Barry said she hopes to improve access to credit, increase the average loan size and introduce venture capital funds.
The growth of the group, she said, has been "fairly miraculous," adding: "There's something so powerful about the idea itself, the simple idea of women and credit, and credit as the link to business development. It just caught on as the ultimate international word of mouth."

HEADLINE: Rise in Oil Production Fails to Blunt Price Increase

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Global oil production is running 200,000 barrels a day higher now than it was before the Kuwaiti crisis began, but even so, prices will not fall until there is an easing of tension in the Middle East, W. Henson Moore, the Deputy Secretary of Energy, said at the American Petoleum Institute's annual convention here this morning.
When calm returns, he said, prices will drop to the low $20's, roughly what they were before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. 
 Mr. Moore, the second-ranking official of the Department of Energy, also said Government and industry figures alike showed that domestic oil deliveries in October were down about 5 percent from October 1989. The reasons, experts say, are conservation induced by higher prices and an economic slowdown.
Mr. Moore addressed the closing session of a convention that attracted 1,600 industry executives, many of them in an uncertain and defensive mood.
 
 'Witch Hunt Expected'
 Allen E. Murray, the chairman of the institute and president and chief executive of the Mobil Corporation, cited attempts in Washington to begin a new "witch hunt" against the industry because of price increases. Speaking at the Chicago Hilton, he argued that the public should appreciate the industry. "We helped Americans achieve a standard of living second to none," Mr. Murray said. "We helped make America the major military and economic power in the world."
But listing the moratoriums approved by Congress on coastal drilling and the refusal to allow drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, as well as the decision not to operate the Shoreham nuclear reactor in New York, he said, "Our politicians, it seems, still pay more heed to the extremist Greens than to the Saddam Husseins of the world."
Mr. Moore said his department planned to send a list of policy options to the White House next month in an effort to reconsider those decisions.
 
 Rise in Imports Seen
 Without a change in government policy, Mr. Moore said, oil imports, which now stand at about 50 percent of consumption, would rise to 80 percent by 2030. Oil's share of total energy used would decline from the current 40 percent to about 36 percent in the same period, he said.
He added that the package of oil tax changes approved in the budget compromise would cost the Treasury about $2.5 billion over the next five years, while increasing domestic production about 175,000 barrels a day. By 2000, he said, tax breaks to encourage "enhanced recovery" of oil from fields from which no more can be extracted by standard pumping would produce and extra 320,000 extra barrels a day.
Production was 7.2 million barrels a day in September, down about 3 percent from September 1989, and for all of 1990 the decline is likely to be steeper.
 
 Looking at Legislation
 Besides prices, one cause of concern to the executives here is the Clean Air Act. Mr. Murray, the Mobil chief, said: "The environment cannot be preserved in a vacuum. It even takes energy to build and install pollution control devices, manufacture catalytic converters and refine reformulated gasoline."
Experts here said the first data from a $16 million emission study by the three major domestic auto producers and the major oil companies would be available next month. The study is seeking to determine which combination of cars, fuel and additives produces the best results.
Speaking of the new standards, Constantine S. Nicandros, the chairman of Conoco, a subsidiary of E. I. du Pont de Nemours, said, "Nobody is quite sure what exactly we're going to have to meet."
Separately, the institute released a study that said the price of gasoline in mid-October was about 60 cents a gallon lower than it was at its peak, 1981, when inflation is taken into account.

HEADLINE: Singapore to Allow Greater U.S. Military Presence

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 13

 BODY:
In a modest but symbolic expansion of the American military presence in Southeast Asia, the United States and Singapore agreed today for Singapore to serve as a base for increased American training missions, visiting warships and Air Force and Navy personnel.
An accord carrying out the agreement was signed this afternoon by Vice President Dan Quayle and Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore, as part of a flurry of diplomatic activity after the enthronement of Emperor Akihito of Japan on Monday.The agreement followed an offer by Mr. Lee last August to permit increased American use of Singapore's military sites because of the likelihood of United States troop withdrawals from the Philippines. 
 Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama of Japan also carried out 35 meetings with visiting heads of state and dignitaries from among the 158 countries represented at the enthronement.
Few matters of substance were the subject of any agreements, although Japanese officials said that much of the talk centered on requests for increased economic aid from Tokyo. Thiswas especially true, they said, in a meeting with President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines.
Japanese officials also said that the Presidents of both Pakistan and Bangladesh appealed for aid, citing sharp increases in their oil prices, and that similar appeals came from President Ion Iliescu of Romania, President Arpad Goncz of Hungary and others from Eastern Europe.
Still other similar appeals were made by leaders of Latin American countries, but Japanese news reports indicated that only Peru, whose President, Alberto Fujimori, is of Japanese descent, came away with a pledge ofnew assistance.
The Singapore-Washington agreement had been worked out in negotiations over the last several months, with virtually no involvement by Mr. Quayle or his staff, but officials said they thought that the presence of the two leaders here marked a good opportunity to highlight its importance.
The agreement would permit the United States to send aircraft to Singapore "several times each year on training deployments of several weeks each" and for the Navy to increase the duration and number of its ship visits.
In addition, the United States intends to increase the number of its military personnel to about 95, with another 75 Air Force men and women visiting with each training deployment.
An issue blocking the accord in recent weeks was Singapore's request forpayments, which the United States rejected in principle. An American statement said that while no rent of fees are contemplated, the United States would pay for housing, supplies and services supplied by Singapore.
Another issue was the United States' worry about Singapore's severe penalties, including execution, for convictions on possession of small amounts of marijuana and other drugs. In its statement today, the United States said that it had "fully briefed" American personnel on Singapore laws, and that the accord "recognizes the sovereignty of Singaporean law."
Prime Minister Lee, who is retiring at the end of this month after serving in office since 1959, has been an ardent champion of the United States' remaining in the region, especially because of the increasing possibility of withdrawal of American forces from the Philippines.
Some Asian nations are worried that if the United States withdraws military forces from Asia, other countries -- including China, Japan, Vietnam and India -- could try to fill the vacuum.
The United States and the Philippines are negotiating the future of the American military bases there, with the United States announcing last week that it would withdraw fighter planes from Clark Air Base and take other steps to reduce its troop strength.
In Singapore, the United States issued a statement saying that the Singapore increase would be "modest" and that it "enhances existing military arrangements" between the two countries, since American naval vessels have been docking in Singapore for more than 25 years.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed in Quiet Day; Gold Prices Rise Moderately

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar registered a mixed performance in quiet trading yesterday, influenced by economic forces that drove key foreign currencies in different directions.
Gold rose moderately. Traders bought aggressively amid a jump of $1.25 a barrel in the price of oil, to $33.12, in the December contract. Considered a safe-haven investment against this sign of heightened Persian Gulf instability, gold rose $3.70 a troy ounce, to $386, on the New York Commodity Exchange. At the Republic National Bank, the late bid for gold was $384.95 a troy ounce, up $3.45 from Monday's close. 
 Traders said the dollar rose against the Japanese yen amid indications of cracks in Japan's economy, where several bankruptcies were announced last week. That combined with higher interest rates in Japan to discourage investment in the yen.
Conversely, investors said the German mark was strengthened on signs of German's growing economy.
"You have a tug-a-war with the mark getting stronger and the yen getting weaker," said Robert Ryan, vice president in charge of foreign exchange at the Bank of New York.
Trading was light, as participants generally awaited an expected move by the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates in a bid to stimulate the sluggish economy. Lower interest rates can dampen demand for United States investments and potentially diminish the dollar's value against foreign currencies.
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen in New York, closing at 129.65 yen, up from Monday's 128.30. In overnight trading in Tokyo, the dollar fell to 128.77 yen from 130.50 yen at Monday's close. Later, in London, it was quoted at 129.65 yen.
In New York, the British pound also weakened, to $1.9635, from $1.9660 late Monday. But in earlier London trading, sterling cost $1.9640, more expensive than late Monday's $1.9627.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Monday, included: 1.4782 German marks, up from 1.4770; 1.2510 Swiss francs, up from 1.2468; 4.9735 French francs, up from 4.9700; 1,112.00 Italian lire, down from 1,113.00, and 1.1662 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1664.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $383.25 a troy ounce, up from the $382.25 bid late Monday. In Zurich, it rose to a closing bid of $383.50, up from $381 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at a bid of $383.61, unchanged from Monday.
On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.212 a troy ounce, up 2.2 cents from Monday's closing price. In London, silver fell to a late bid price of $4.20, down from $4.24 bid late Monday.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Morocco's Call for Arab Meeting On the Gulf Has Diplomats Astir

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 13

 BODY:
The call by King Hassan II of Morocco for an emergency Arab summit meeting to avert a war in the Persian Gulf has set off a flurry of diplomatic contacts, including the dispatch of an Iraqi envoy to the Moroccan capital, but Arab reaction to the appeal has been extremely cautious.
Only the Sudan, Mauritania and Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, readily expressed willingness to attend such a session, which the King proposed on Sunday. But even Mr. Arafat, who arrived here today from Baghdad, told associates privately that he was skeptical that such a gathering would produce the much hoped for "Arab solution" to the gulf crisis, which is now more than three months old. 
 Arab countries aligned with the United States and those opposed to the presence of American forces in Saudi Arabia are known to have reservations about convening an emergency summit meeting.
A senior Jordanian official said that Jordan, Yemen and Algeria were concerned that the session might be used as a pretext for reaffirming the condemnation of Iraq issued by a previous summit meeting in Cairo in early August, or worse, for sanctioning the use of military force to drive Iraq from Kuwait, should diplomatic efforts and economic sanctions fail.
 
Baghdad's Hostage Releases
 Egypt, Saudi Arabia and the gulf states, all of which support the presence of American forces in the region, are known to fear that Iraq might try to use a summit meeting to water down the position adopted by the Arab League at the Cairo meeting.
As diplomatic efforts continued today, former United States Attorney General Ramsey Clark said after a visit to Baghdad that the Iraqi Government had promised to release four more American hostages. Mr. Clark, who has criticized the American deployment of forces in the gulf, spoke here after concluding his independent mission to Baghdad. The Danish radio said Iraq had also agreed today to release some of the 38 Danish hostages held in Baghdad.
Iraq, holding more than 2,000 Western and Japanese men, has freed small groups in the past after visits by elder statesmen, legislators and other dignitaries.
The First Deputy Prime Minister of Iraq, Taha Yassin Ramadan, arrived in Rabat, the Moroccan capital, tonight after Baghdad suggested that it might attend an emergency Arab summit meeting. Mr. Ramadan said just before leaving Baghdad that the Iraqi Government supported "any serious Arab action at any level that would serve the Arab nation," the official Iraqi press agency said.
 
Iraqi Meets With Qaddafi
 Iraq had initially criticized King Hassan's call for a summit, noting that it had not previously been consulted.
Another senior Iraqi envoy, Saadun Hamadi, Iraq's Minister of State for Foreign Affairs and a Deputy Prime minister, held talks today with the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali of Tunisia.
Mr. Arafat consulted briefly here today with King Hussein of Jordan, who has not stated his position on the summit. Jordanian officials, who attempted last month to work with King Hassan and President Chadli Benjedid of Algeria to begin an Arab mediation process with Baghdad, were disappointed by the results. A senior Jordanian official said that Morocco had not consulted Jordan before issuing its call for the emergency meeting.
"In addition," the official continued, "it would be difficult for the main party in this conflict -- Saddam Hussein -- to attend a summit outside of Baghdad with other Arab leaders. He just can't go there."
 
Trip by 2 Soviet Officials
 President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt made an unexpected trip to Libya today for talks with Colonel Qaddafi. No details of the meeting were made public.
The Soviet Union sent two envoys to the region for consultations on the summit, according to the Government newspaper Izvestia. Neither of the two Deputy Prime Ministers, Alexander Belonogov and Vladimir Petrovsky, are scheduled to visit Baghdad during their Middle East tour.
 In London today, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said Britain believed Iraq had biological weapons and was close to acquiring nuclear arms.
"Saddam Hussein has used chemical weapons both in war and on his own people, the Kurds," Reuters quoted Mrs. Thatcher as telling a member of Parliament during questioning. "He also, we believe, has at his disposal biological weapons. It is contrary to the law to make them, let alone use them."
 
'Critical Point' in Gulf
 "And we also believe he is not far from having nuclear weapons," she continued without further elaboration.
In Paris, President Francois Mitterrand said today that the gulf crisis was approaching a "critical point." Calling on Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait now, Mr. Mitterrand said, "It is absolutely necessary that Iraq drop its policy of rejection if it wishes to avoid a resolution that would authorize intervention by force."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Kay Deal Hurts Shares of Ratners

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
GERALD RATNER has wrought a revolution in the British retail jewelry market, and now he is trying to prosper in the American market with a company that was on the verge of financial failure before he took it over. Share buyers in both London and New York are dubious.
Ratners Group, by far the largest jewelry retailer in Britain, has completed the acquisition of Kay Jewelers Inc., this country's second-largest chain of jewelry stores after the Zale Corporation.
But Kay was encountering growing financial problems before the acquisition. To succeed, Ratners must accomplish the tricky goals of sharply raising Kay's profit margins and sales while toughening its credit terms. 
 Doubts that it can be done, especially with the United States economy close to, if not in, a recession, help explain the battering the shares of Ratners have taken in London, falling 33 percent since the deal was announced at the end of June.
"Some people say we overpaid," said Gary O'Brien, the company's group finance director. But he noted that, on a per store basis, the Kay acquisition came in at a lower price than many of the company's previous acquisitions, and voiced confidence that Kay can be turned around.
Ratners, which says it has a 25 percent share of the British jewelry market, has prospered with what Mr. O'Brien calls a "down-market, value-based" approach, dominating the market under the trade names H. Samuel, Salisbury and Zales, as well as Ratners. Zales is not related to the American Zale chain.Convinced that it could not grow much more in its home market, Ratners turned to the United States in 1987, starting with the Sterling Inc. chain, and had become the third-largest jewelry retailer in this country. The Kay acquisition doubled the size of the American operations, giving the company 900 stores, operating under such names as Belden, Weisfield's, Hudson Goodman, LeRoy's, Osterman's and Shaws, as well as Kay. Over all, they now have about 4.5 percent of the United States market.
"There was a never a question as to whether we would acquire Kay," Mr. O'Brien said, explaining that the company felt it needed to make a big acquisition in this country and that Kay was the only such operation available.
 With Kay overleveraged and in danger of losing some credit lines, Mr. O'Brien said he considered delaying until Kay "entered Chapter 11," but he felt the filing would have damaged the business and delayed an acquisition, even if it produced a lower price.
To improve Kay, Ratners has brought in new inventories for Christmas that it says reflect a more efficient buying operation. Mr. O'Brien said Kay would have lower prices than before as a result, but higher margins. The advertising slogan, "It's okay to owe Kay," has been retired, he added. Bad debts were one of the problems that plagued Kay.
In the acquisition Kay shareholders received one Ratners convertible preferred share for each Kayshare they owned. Those shares, which traded as high as $12.125 in late October, fell 12.5 cents, to $10.875, in Nasdaq trading yesterday.
Mr. O'Brien suggests that the current price may reflect a lack of understanding of the shares by American investors, and he may be right. Complicated by international tax rules, there is not even a simple answer to how large a dividend they will pay. American tax-exempt holders, such as pension funds, will collect a $1.06 annual payout, but the payout to individual American investors will be $1.20 a year, for a current yield of 11 percent. Such a holder will report dividends of $1.34 a year, but will then be able to take a tax credit of 14 cents, against tax withheld in Britain. That tax break raises the effective yield.
The shares are convertible into three Ratners shares, or into one American depository receipt for a similar number of shares. Yesterday, the A.D.R., traded on Nasdaq, fell 12.5 cents, to $10.625.
The aggressive growth of Ratners in Britain was accomplished through acquisitions and determined marketing, aimed at persuading working class people to buy inexpensive gold jewelry.
The acquisitions were financed largely by selling new shares, as was the cash needed to pay off holders of Kay bonds. Consequently, the company is not overleveraged, even if the economic downturns in both Britain and the United States are not going to produce a merry Christmas for most retailers.
Not that Ratners is prepared to admit that a recession will bother it. Its operations in both countries have grown more rapidly than those of competitors, and Mr. Ratner, the 40-year-old chairman who greatly expanded the family business over the last six years, remains confident, with Mr. O'Brien quoting his boss as having said: "We've decided that we're not going to participate in this recession."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
U.S. Jobs at Stake in Gulf, Baker Says

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAMILTON, Bermuda, Nov. 13

 BODY:
With the domestic consensus for the Administration's policy on the Persian Gulf beginning to fracture, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d declared today that a primary reason the United States must confront Iraq is to save American jobs.
Speaking with reporters after a hastily arranged meeting here with Canada's External Affairs Secretary, Joe Clark, Mr. Baker dispensed with some of the more abstract explanations for the Administration's gulf policy and focused on the fate of the American worker. 
 "The economic lifeline of the industrial world runs from the gulf and we cannot permit a dictator such as this to sit astride that economic lifeline," Mr. Baker said, referring to the Persian Gulf's oil reserves. "To bring it down to the level of the average American citizen, let me say that means jobs. If you want to sum it up in one word, it's jobs.
"Because," he continued, "an economic recesssion worldwide, caused by the control by one nation -- one dictator if you will -- of the West's economic lifeline, will result in the loss of jobs for American citizens."
 
Selling an Idea
 Mr. Baker, Mr. Bush's former campaign chairman, is said to have grown exasperated with White House speech writers' inability to present the President's gulf policy in a simple, coherent and compelling fashion so that it will have the sustained support of the American public.
Since the start of the gulf crisis in August, the President's justifications for sending troops have included everything from "vital interests" being at stake, to the American "way of life" being at stake, to the principle that aggression should not be allowed to pay, to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq being worse than Hitler.
Beginning last Friday in Moscow, Mr. Baker first began to say that what was at stake in the gulf was the "pocketbook" and "standard of living" of every American.
It has become apparent to Administration officials that the eroding support for the Administration's gulf policy, if not stemmed, is going to nullify its entire gulf strategy. Mr. Bush, officials explain, is trying to make President Hussein believe that he has only two choices: stay in Kuwait and face destruction of his army and Government, or withdraw and survive.
 
Message to Iraqi
 That is the meaning of the offensive buildup in American forces in the gulf. Officials believe that until the Iraqi leader is convinced that these are his only two choices, he will never consider unconditional, or even conditional, withdrawal.
The problem, though, is that in making the threat credible to the Iraqi leader, the President has also made the prospect of war more credible to the American people, and thereby set in motion a debate on the value of such a war. That debate, officials fear, could be read in Baghdad as limiting the President's room for maneuver and thereby undermining the credibility of his now-intensified military threat.
Mr. Baker, for his part, again declined to commit the Bush Administration to seek United Nations authorization before any military operation to dislodge Iraqi troops from Kuwait. But the Secretary said that the Bush Administration would probably make a decision on this issue in "a week or 10 days, but don't hold me to a time frame."

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
New Flock for Moon Church: The Changing Soviet Student

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
The Unification Church of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon has extended its proselytizing efforts to the Soviet Union. Hundreds of Soviet college and graduate students have been brought to America for an all-expenses-paid immersion in the ways and beliefs of the church, which suggest that Mr. Moon may be the new messiah.
The visits, billed as educational excursions, are but one of a broad range of church-sponsored activities in the Soviet Union. In April, Mr. Moon met with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union and expressed support for the political and economic transformations under way in the Soviet Union. Church-affiliated groups like the World Media Association have sponsored conferences in Moscow and discussions were begun on possible joint ventures in fields like computers and ballet. 
 Recruiting for the educational trips started this summer, and three groups have already visited America under the joint sponsorship of the church-affiliated International Leadership Conference and Novosti, the Soviet press feature syndicate. The goals, church officials say, are the same as those of many other current Soviet-American endeavors: peace, mutual understanding, "closeness to your neighbor."
 
'Learning a Lot of History'
 "We're learning a lot of history," said Aleksei, a 28-year-old graduate student at Moscow's Institute of Physical Culture, said, recalling the lectures attended at the Ramada Inn outside of Hagerstown, Md., on this, his first visit to America. "They talked about how the history of Israel is connected with Christianity. How Christ was the Messiah.
"Then it seems as if there is going to be another messiah. In our time. They have shown us how the texts show that Korea is the country where he will appear. Then it seems as if he may be here. Then it seems he may be Sun Myung Moon."
Another of those attending, Irina Treibich, a student at the Institute of Management in Moscow, was enthusiastic about the experience in an essay she wrote in English for her hosts after she and about 200 others, with ages ranging from 20 to 28, spent five days sightseeing and five days in intensive lectures and seminars at the conference in Hagerstown.
 
Lectures and Discussions
 "To my mind it is a very good idea what Soviet students took part in such conference, because it help to unification of whole world," Miss Treibich wrote. "Unification of all peoples, of whole countries, I think, it's only way which save all people."
At the conference, according to the Soviet students attending, lectures alternated with small-group discussions, at which attendance was strictly enforced. Curfews were enforced by polite, insistent proctors, and the schedule and setting insured only fleeting contact with outsiders. The format, according to an expert on the Unification Church, strongly resembles the church's introductory sessions with people the church regards as potential converts.
Sponsors of the exchange, both Soviet officials and American members of the Unification Church movement, say mutual understanding and not conversion, is the objective of the exercise. The students and their hosts, however, had slightly different memories of what was discussed.
 
'Framework of Religion'
 "They are having lectures on economics," said Tony Devine, an official of the International Leadership Conference.
Aleksei said, "Mostly it's about religion."
Natasha Boldareva, a 23-year-old graduate student at the Physical Culture Institute in Moscow sat by the swimming pool at the Ramada Inn and said, "This is delightful." When asked the topic of the lectures, she answered: "Many different things. Economics. History. But everything is seen through the framework of religion."
Aleksandr Borisov, a dean of Moscow's Institute for International Relations, who accompanied the students, said: "We are trying to increase the spiritual basis of our politics. We are trying to understand problems through the prism of religious tolerance."
 
'I'm a Materialist'
 Some of the students were more practical. "No, I don't agree with what they're telling us; I'm a materialist," said one young man, who spoke on the condition that his name not be used. "But how else am I going to see America?"
"They're getting to see American democracy," Mr. Devine said. But none of six students interviewed at the Ramada Inn on Nov. 5 knew that the American elections were being held the next day. Televisions had been removed from the students' rooms "so that they wouldn't stay up all night watching during the conference," Mr. Devine said.
Many of the recent visitors were clearly impressed with the trappings of American life and with the warmth of their hosts. "Almost everything about this is positive," said Aleksei, though he compared the "pressure to conform" with his Soviet Army experience.
Two other students expressed puzzlement at their inability to meet with American students other than those who were part of the lectures and discussion groups and the organized sing-alongs that opened each day's activities. Others were taken aback when a discussion group leader said the church had chosen a wife for him. One or two students were openly skeptical about their hosts.
 
'They Are Sweet With Us'
 "They are sweet with us; sweet, sweet, sweet -- too sweet," said Igor Garilsky, 25, a student at the Institute for International Relations, who said he had read a book on the church before he came. As he spoke in a hall after midnight, his hosts patrolled the corridors of the Ramada Inn with walkie-talkies on their hips, enforcing the curfew by insistent requests that students retire for the night. One occasionally put his ear to the door of a room, apparently to hear who was inside. The two sexes were forbidden to mingle after curfew.
The Unification Church traces its roots from the Christian tradition and focuses on a belief in the imminent arrival of a new messiah. The Soviet visits come as the church, which has tax-free status as a bonafide religion, has changed its public image. The organization whose members once sold flowers at airports has now spawned affiliate organizations that underwrite film projects, have assembled parcels of real estate in Manhattan and publish newspapers including The Washington Times, The New York Tribune and Noticias del Mundo.
But Mr. Moon still selects spouses for his followers, who are then married by the thousands at mass ceremonies. The charges of brainwashing that came from former church members and their families are still heard, and the California Supreme Court last year upheld the right of two Californians -- who claim they were brainwashed -- to sue the church for fraud.
 
Appealing to the Unsettled
 Marc Galanter, a professor of psychiatry at New York University and author of the book "Cults: Faith, Healing and Coercion" (Oxford University Press, 1989) said the Unification Church had great appeal to people living in unsettled times. The students taking part in these exchanges grew up when Communism and cynicism were the twin faiths of everyday life, and arrived at adulthood to find most ideological, economic and political verities shredded in a national orgy of disillusionment.
"A large part of the reason the cult movements had the success they did in the late 1960's and 1970's was that the society was in turmoil," Mr. Galanter said. "There was the Vietnam war, all the civil turmoil. Youth had lost faith in the ideologies they had been offered.
"I think there's a definite parallel" with the situation of Soviet youth today, he added. Dr. Galanter, when told of the conference at the Ramada Inn, said it resembled some of the introductory sessions offered by the Unification Church in the United States.
Igor Drobyshev, a representative of Novosti who accompanied the students from Moscow, disagreed. "They don't try to indoctrinate the student," he said. "They wanted the students to get acquainted with this religious trend in the world. The activities of this church are based on human values, and the idea of those values is very popular right now in the Soviet Union."
But Mr. Garilsky agreed with Dr. Galanter, saying: "They see this as their chance to drive a wedge into the Soviet Union, and this is their wedge. Maybe only a few people here will become convinced. But that's fine for them. They can go back and, as we say, 'scatter flowers.' "

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HONORS 30 FOR RESEARCH

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
President Bush today awarded the National Medal of Science and the National Medal of Technology to 30 scientists, engineers and mathematicians, calling them "real life pioneers who press the very limits of their fields."
In addition, the award was given to the E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company in engineering. 
 "More and more our nation depends on basic, scientific research to spur economic growth, longer and healthier lives, a more secure world and indeed a safer environment," Mr. Bush said at a presentation ceremony in the East Room of the White House.
Mr. Bush singled out two researchers, Baruj Benacerraf, president of the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, and E. Donnall Thomas, clinical director emeritus of Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle, for their work in immunology.
"Scientists like you have helped America understand that AIDS is a disease, not a disgrace," he said.
In addition to Mr. Benacerraf and Mr. Thomas, these were the award winners in science:

HEADLINE: Dropout Fight Is Retooled for Grade Schools

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT

 BODY:
The boy seemed a loose tangle of arms and legs as he spoke of spending many of his school days last year at home watching cartoons or outside riding his bicycle. Whenever he rode, graffiti and urban decay whisked by as he pedaled along in his New York City neighborhood, flattening spent crack vials with as little alarm as if they were fallen leaves.
For months, while school was in, this fifth-grader was out. 
 At the age of 11, Louis N., who wants to be a motorcycle racer when he grows up, came dangerously close to joining the growing ranks of youngsters chronically absent from school, whom some urban eductors call "elementary school dropouts."
He said he stayed away from Public School 57 in East Harlem because he was convinced that his teacher disliked him.
"She screamed at me and called me stupid," said Louis, whose mother permitted him to be interviewed only if he was not fully identified.
Advocates for children say increasing numbers of very young pupils in troubled neighborhoods are staying home from school more frequently and for longer periods than ever before. Even first- and second-graders are doing so, crippling their chances of adapting to the demands of school and society and increasing their likelihood of dropping out for good.
"We have elementary school drop-outs," said Annie Hodge, who is a New York City district director for a nationwide dropout prevention program, Cities in Schools, a nonprofit group op- erating in 50 cities. "We have kinder- garten dropouts. They come in and don't like what they see. Depending on the homes they come from, a lot of them find too much structure in schools and stay home."
Many of these children come from single-parent households headed by women in urban areas ravaged by chronic unemployment, teen-age pregnancy, illegal drugs, violence and crime. Many receive little supervision at home, she said. Some, even before they were born, were exposed to drugs like crack, which can make them oblivious to classwork and prone to misbehave.
"So, a lot of them just don't come to school," Ms. Hodge said. "And nobody at home is making them come."
Urban school officials across the country say traditional measures, like truant officers and teacher-parent conferences, are too overburdened to work.
"The caseload per capita is so high that it is impossible to imagine the truant officer system being able to keep track of so many kids," said Charles Schultz, director of educational studies at Trinity College in Hartford. "So many are falling through the cracks that there isn't much of an official means of recapturing them."
Cities in Schools, which helped Louis N. return to classes, not only counsels the troubled student, but its workers also act as if they are part of the child's extended family and offer other support.
"I have a social worker who goes to a child's home at 7 A.M. and takes the child to school," said Deidre Meyerson, executive director of Cities in Schools in New York City. "We never penalize the parents. We try to work with them."
There are no statistics on precisely how many elementary pupils are regularly missing school, Federal education officials said. But officials of Cities in Schools say the number of elementary students who need their help has risen 25 percent to 30 percent in the last five years. Before that time, said the group's national president, William E. Milliken, the program's emphasis was almost exclusively on high school students.
"We are just beginning to move down into that age group," Mr. Milliken said of the grade school pupils who are chronically absent from school. "The attention has moved, and we realize we have to get to these kids earlier and earlier."
He said that New York was one of the first places the phenomenon had surfaced, but that similar problems have been identified in California, Florida, Texas and other states with troubled urban areas.
About four million Americans 16 to 24 years old, or 12.6 percent of the people in this age group, were out of school without a high school diploma in 1989, according to a study released this fall by the United States Department of Education. An average of 429,000 students in grades 10 through 12 drop out of school each year, which is 4.5 percent of the students enrolled in those grades, according to the same study.
The problem is most acute among Hispanic and black students, Federal education officials said. In 1989, 33 percent of Hispanic youths 16 to 24 were not enrolled in school and did not have a high school diploma; for blacks the figure was 13.8 percent.
 
Parents Aren't Doing Well
 Leslie Rescorla, a clinical psychologist at the Child Study Institute at Bryn Mawr College in Bryn Mawr, Pa., and an assistant professor of human development there, said trouble begins early for many who end up dropping out of school. Increasing numbers of low-income families are falling victim to an array of problems that are affecting their children at pre-school and elementary school ages, she said.
"A lot of kids in high drug areas have parents who aren't functioning well," she said. "Many are either not home or are basically preoccupied with their own drug or alcohol problems. It is not likely that they are going to get up early and get their kids off to school."
Another reason more young children are staying home is a lack of a family culture that supports education, said Tom Lasley, chairman of the education department of the University of Dayton in Ohio. Also, for children in many of the country's most devastated neighborhoods, he said, the example of what is achieved by those who stayed in school is often not an inspiring one.
"They look at older kids who stayed in schools and see them still walking the streets or working at MacDonald's," Dr. Lasley said. "They just don't see anything great happening to these people."
 
The Earlier the Better
 But to give these children from troubled families a chance at an education and to help them learn its value means reaching them earlier and earlier.
"When you start in high school when the child is a teen-ager, he is basically set in his mind," Ms. Hodge said. "How much intervention can you do then?"
Cities in Schools tries to help children take better advantage of a city's existing youth services, said Mr. Milliken, who founded Cities in Schools in 1977.
In most places, he said, troubled pupils are asked to navigate a maze of career counselors, health and child care officials and drug counselors, who are often scattered around the city. The Cities in Schools approach coordinates social and educational services, getting them all in a child's school.
For example, at Public School 57, also known as James Weldon Johnson School on East 115th Street in East Harlem, an education specialist, a recreation specialist and a social worker see about 45 students a week in a small classroom on the third floor. Through counseling, home visits with the parents, after-school classes and field trips, pupils are guided back into feeling they are part of their schools, Ms. Meyerson said.
Working with Cities in Schools counselors and attending after-school reading courses administered by the program, Louis N. improved his reading skills as well as his relationships with teachers. So far this year, his first year back on a full-time basis, he has only missed one day of classes.
Maria Meriles, a city social worker assigned to work with Cities in Schools, also at Public School 57, said she has watched troubled students become well adjusted when someone takes the time to listen to their problems and help them work them out.
For example, Eric I. Rosales, a plump, extroverted 12-year-old, was often late to class despite the fact that he lived across the street from school. Recently, Mrs. Meriles made a home visit with him, riding the cramped elevator to the 12th-floor apartment Eric shares with his parents and grandmother.
 
Fear of the Streets
 "I'm a little nervous, but I'm happy she's coming," he said as he escorted the social worker to his apartment's metal door. Inside, Mrs. Meriles spoke in Spanish with Eric's mother, Rosa Rosales, encouraging the family to help Eric keep up his improved record of punctuality. Eric's father, a washing machine repairman, stood nearby.
Mrs. Meriles also urged the mother, a native of Guatemala, to let her son out of the house more often. Mrs. Rosales said she feared for her son in the dangerous streets surrounding the high-rise public housing project. Mrs. Meriles said that she understood, but that Eric needed a chance to work off energy and play with other children.
After about 30 minutes, Mrs. Meriles helped Mrs. Rosales complete forms to help the family get dental care for Eric. Then she left.
While Mrs. Rosales seemed willing to cooperate in meeting her son's needs, only time will tell if she would.
Martino Black, Eric's principal, said Cities in Schools has certainly made a difference in his school in an era of shrinking budgets. The program, which is based in Washington, is in 15 New York City schools.
"Through the program, we now have the people to do the footwork and find out why that child isn't coming to school on a regular basis, why that child isn't doing as well as he can," Mr. Black said. "Their sole job is to address these kinds of concerns and deal with the potential dropout. They do it well."

HEADLINE: Journal to Close Philadelphia News Bureau

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
The Wall Street Journal announced yesterday that it would close its bureau in Philadelphia at the end of the year as an economy move and that some of the 10 reporters and editors there would be dismissed.
Roger B. May, a Journal spokesman, said that to his knowledge it was the first time The Journal had laid off news personnel, and certainly the first time in many years. 
 In October, the paper's top executives informed their management staff that the severe slump in financial advertising created by the depressed economy would require cost savings that would include the news operation.
Although there have been layoffs in other departments, the company had avoided reducing the news staff through layoffs as potentially damaging to the paper's image as a high-quality news organization.
Ron Chen, president of the Independent Association of Publishers' Employees, the union representing Journal employees, said that five reporters and one editorial assistant would lose their jobs and that two other reporters and two management people at the bureau would be transfered to other positions.
"There's lots of anxiety around here," Mr. Chen said from the paper's newsroom in New York. It is widely believed that the paper's 500-member news staff will be reduced by 25 to 40 people through attrition, buyouts and layoffs, he added.
 
 Cuts Called 'Painful'
 Mr. May said he knew of no specific goals for reducing the staff.
Norman Pearlstine, the managing editor, in a message announcing the layoffs, described the cuts as "painful."
"But the economic conditions affecting The Journal require that this news department join the companywide effort to cut costs," he added.
News of the layoffs sent shockwaves through The Journal's newsroom, despite recent management statements that news operations would not be protected from cost-cutting as they had been in the past.
In the October memo, the news-related economies involved such steps as reducing the number of special reports, shrinking the space devoted to news and eliminating the cost of relocating people by stopping most transfers.
Mr. Chen said that the paper had apparently been trying to reduce newsroom jobs by offering buyouts to some senior employees and through attrition, but that the tough economic times had made employees even more determined than usual to hold on to their jobs if at all possible.
