HEADLINE: Stocks Ease, With Dow Off by 4.95 Points

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Yesterday was a choppy one on Wall Street with stock prices dropping slightly. Trading was brisk and oil prices edged $1.25 a barrel higher, to $33.12. Program trading was heavy and small stocks picked up a bit.
Nervous investors cashed in their chips after the Federal Reserve, which was widely expected to trim interest rates as soon as yesterday or today took no immediate action. 
 By the end of the day, the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue- chip stocks gave up 4.95 points to close at 2,535.40. The American Stock Exchange's market value index and the Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter stocks edged ahead.
Some analysts expect an upturn in the broad market before many days, largely because the Fed's widely heralded rate cut is still believed to be on the way -- particularly because of growing concern that the economy is faltering badly.
Activity dropped to 160.2 million shares, from 161.4 million on Tuesday, with 836 stocks rising and 731 falling. And 18 reached new highs while 39 fell to new lows.
Birinyi Associates, which monitors program trading, said that heavy selling sliced nearly 11 points off the Dow.
In a sign that many of the smaller stocks on the Amex and on Nasdaq were gradually gaining momentum, the Value Line index also rose a little.
Traders said that second- and third-tier stocks were such big bargains that institutions and individual investors had already begun end-of-the year buying a month ahead of schedule.
Explaining yesterday's drop in the Dow, David B. Bostian, chief economist for Jesup, Josepththal & Company, said: "You had heightened expectation of a Fed cut immediately following its Open Market Committee meeting today. And since there was no immediate evidence that it did, you had some profit taking."
Some of the big market favorites slipped. Among the leaders in the high-tech group, I.B.M. slid 1, to 112, in heavy trading; Honeywell 1 3/4, to 89 5/8, and Hewlett-Packard 1 3/4, to 26 5/8. Cray Research rose 1 1/8, to 28, after Yokogawa Electric of Japan said it was negotiating with Cray on a 50-50 plan to market minisupercomputers in Japan.
 
 Tokyo Stocks Lower
 TOKYO, Nov. 14 (Reuters) -- Stocks in Tokyo closed slightly lower today. The 225-share Nikkei index was off 36.23, or 0.15 percent, to 23,937.44.

HEADLINE: News Strikers Ask Abrams to Step In

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT

 BODY:
The leaders of striking Daily News unions said yesterday that they would ask the New York State Attorney General to look into a series of actions by the newspaper that they claim may be violations of state law.
The leaders said they would ask Attorney General Robert Abrams to look into whether The News had encouraged its out-of-state security guards to attack strikers, and whether The News had violated laws governing the licensing of security guards, state antitrust laws or organized-crime statutes. 
 Mr. Abrams appeared yesterday at a union-sponsored breakfast briefing attended by about 30 other elected officials, and said he would look into any claims union leaders made, but he declined to say what areas of possible wrongdoing he might focus on.
"We are going to see if there are laws being violated here," Mr. Abrams said at the briefing. He added later through a spokesman that he would study "any allegations of wrongdoing on either side of the strike"
 
Paper Also Charges Violence
 He also said that there might be many areas that would more properly fall under the jurisdiction of the police and local district attorneys.
Asked about Mr. Abrams's remarks, a spokeswoman for The News, Lisa G. Robinson, said the Attorney General "should really be focusing on controlling union leaders," whom management has accused of directing violence and harassment aimed at crippling the paper's circulation.
"Any investigation," Ms. Robinson added, "will undoubtedly lead to the union strikers."
The unions' principal adviser, Theodore W. Kheel, said that he intended to meet with Mr. Abrams later in the week, and would cite possible violations in connection with what he said was violence against strikers by the News's out-of-state security guards.
 
Out-of-State Guards Scrutinized
 "I am not sufficently expert to tell the Attorney General what areas are in his jurisdiction," Mr. Kheel said. "But there may be possible violations of the state's organized-crime statutes in connection with the violence."
Union members, including Juan Gonzalez, a striking columnist who spoke at the breakfast meeting on behalf of the Newspaper Guild, said they believed management may have run afoul of laws governing use and licensing of out-of-state security guards.
The General Business Law, for example, prohibits a company involved in a labor dispute from offering or furnishing guards or other employees with "any arms, munitions, tear-gas implements, or any other weapons."
Although management says its security force -- partly composed of out-of-state employees -- is unarmed, some members of those forces have told reporters in recent days that they have been licensed to carry firearms.
 
Officials at Union Breakfast
 The News pressed efforts to enlist other news organizations in a public campaign to condemn the violence and what it insisted was the unions' role in organizing it. Yesterday, management was reported to have asked other companies in New York, including at least one weekly news magazine, to lend their names to full-page newspaper advertisements.
The breakfast yesterday, at the Roosevelt Hotel in Manhattan, featured strong expressions of support for the unions by many of the 31 elected officials or their spokesmen who attended. They included three Congressmen -- Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan; Ted Weiss of Manattan, and Jose E. Serrano of the Bronx; four state senators, 17 assemblymen, and six City Councilmen, including the City Council President, Andrew J. Stein.
Many officials later signed a huge cardboard petition urging The News to "end the economic violence against the employees and their families," and either negotiate "a fair and equitable settlement" or sell the paper.
In Garden City, L.I., The News said as many as 30 to 40 men smashed windows in a company bus early yesterday as it pulled out of a motel parking lot carrying nonunion drivers to the printing plant nearby. No arrests were reported. The bus operator and one driver suffered minor eye injuries from flying glass in the incident, at the Island Inn Motel, Ms. Robinson said.
She said the attackers -- whom she said had not been identified -- also smashed windows in 11 cars, as well as motel windows and a glass door.
In St. Albans, Queens, a nonunion driver told the police he had been assaulted by five men who waylaid his truck early yesterday. The driver, identified as 21-year-old Alistair Jones, received stitches at Franklin General Hospital.

HEADLINE: U.S. Output Fell 0.8% In October

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
The output of American factories, mines and utilities dropped eight-tenths of 1 percent in October, prompting many analysts to declare that the economy as a whole has now conclusively slipped into recession.
The decline, the first since April and the largest since January, was exceptionally widespread. And it intensified the belief that the Federal Reserve would move soon to cut interest rates again to arrest what could become a rapid economic contraction. 
 "The steep decline in industrial production in October demonstrates that the economy is now entering the free fall stage," said Gordon Richards of the National Association of Manufacturers. "The evidence of recession is now unambiguous."
 
 A Definite Viewpoint
 On Wall Street, economists at the securities firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette said today's figures, compiled by the Federal Reserve Board, "should remove the last vestiges of any doubt as to whether or not the U.S. economy is in a recession." The question now, they added, is its severity and duration.
Today's report, which covers sectors accounting for about a quarter of the economy, was the latest in a long litany of weak economic reports that show among other things a sharp slowdown in real estate construction and sales, a slump in retail purchases and a plunge in consumer confidence.
The report of the decline in industrial production helped sustain a rally in the bond market, where traders, apparently anticipating that the report would prompt the Fed to lower interest rates, pushed up prices of some Treasury securities as much as a point. Long-term interest rates fell to their lowest levels since the Persian Gulf crisis began in early August. [Page D13.]
 
 Fed Panel Meets
 The bleak reading of the industrial production index, which is published by the Federal Reserve, came as the central bank's chief policy-making body convened behind closed doors to set a course for monetary policy through mid-December. Most analysts speculated today that the group, the Fed's Open Market Committee, had decided to cut short-term interest rates but that it would be at least a few days until this became evident in the markets.
In the most recent easings, the rate charged on overnight loans to banks was cut one-quarter point in July and then again in late October after an agreement between Congress and the Bush Administration on a five-year package to reduce the Federal budget deficit. A cut in the overnight rate lowers banks' cost of money, allowing them to reduce the interest rates they charge on consumer and business loans.
Despite the latest economic data, a minority of analysts remained unconvinced that the overall economy, as opposed to that in one or more regions, is in recession.
One person holding that view is Charles Renfro of the Alphametrics Corporation near Philadelphia, who said that conditions outside the Northeast were generally stable and that he expected that gross national product would increase in the fourth quarter.
"When I go to New York and Boston, everybody's wringing their hands, but when I go out in the Midwest, everybody's pretty happy," he said. A major positive factor for the economy, he observed, is that exports, aided by a weak dollar, are generally strong, even without much support from the agricultural sector.
 
 A Weak Report on Autos
 Today's report on industrial output showed that a 4.5 percent drop in production of motor vehicles and parts accounted for about one-quarter of last month's overall decline. But production also fell among most of the other main market and industry groups.
Output of consumer goods, business equipment and construction supplies all tumbled by 1 percent or more, the Fed reported.
Production of durable factory goods -- those intended to last at least three years -- skidded 1.3 percent after an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent in September. Nondurables eased two-tenths of 1 percent, a slightly stronger performance than the decline of four-tenths of 1 percent the month before.
Output of both the mining and utility industries slumped, by four-tenths of 1 percent and 1.6 percent, respectively.
 
 Widespread Negative Data
 "Almost everything was negative at the same time," commented Robert F. Dieli, an economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "The breadth of this decline is what some people consider a clinching" argument for recession, he added.
Industrial output is considered a coincident indicator of economic health, neither predicting turns nor lagging behind them. One rule of thumb is that a recession is a decline in gross national product that is sustained for two or more consecutive quarters. But the committee of the National Bureau of Economic Research, which is the official arbiter of the business cycle, looks at many factors before declaring a recession, including the depth and scope of a contraction as well as its duration. The committee often does not define a period as recessionary until months after a downturn has actually started.
The Fed's report today also showed that overall use of industrial capacity fell by a sizable nine-tenths of a percentage point, to 82.6 percent, the lowest level in three years and barely above its average for the period between 1967 and 1989. Capacity usage in manufacturing fell eight-tenths of a point, to 81.7 percent, its lowest since September 1987.
 
 Other Sectors Are Down
 In addition to the drop in production of motor vehicles and parts, there was a 5.4 percent decline in production of televisions and other apppliances, a 1.9 percent decline in carpeting and furniture and 1.7 percent declines for both energy products and clothing, the Fed reported.
Construction supplies dropped sharply for the third straight month, while production of steel had a big decline after showing gains in preceding months.
Excluding the automotive sector, the decline in output was six-tenths of 1 percent, compared with a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent on this basis for September.
The industrial production index now stands at 109.6, which is 1.8 points higher than the level of October 1989.

HEADLINE: British Plan New Phone Decontrol

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The British Government said yesterday that it would pursue wide-ranging deregulation of the nation's telecommunications industry, including erasing most of the legal restrictions separating the telephone and cable television industries.
Britain has led the way in telecommunications deregulation, and its move yesterday is likely to influence policy in other countries, particularly the United States, where similar regulatory issues are under debate. 
 Peter B. Libbey, Britain's Secretary of State for Trade and Industry, told Parliament that the Government intended to allow largely unrestricted access to the local, long-distance and international service markets. Until now, only British Telecommunications P.L.C. and Cable and Wireless P.L.C. have been able to provide these services, with Telecom holding about 96 percent of the $17 billion market.
 
 The Most Open Market
 "That makes the U.K. the most open telecommunications market in the world, including us," said Janice Obuchowski, the United States Assistant Secretary of Commerce for communications and information.
Yesterday's plan was drafted by the Department of Trade and Industry in Britain, and is likely to take effect with some changes after a period of public comment expires on Jan. 14.
The proposal calls for cable companies to be allowed to offer local telephone service, an arrangement banned by many American states. British Telecom and Cable and Wireless would also be allowed to offer cable television and other entertainment over its telephone lines, but not for 7 to 10 years, an interval that British Telecom criticized as excessive.
"In an industry that is moving ahead at a frightening pace, to ossify something for 7 to 10 years is a very cautious approach," said Malcolm Argent, the corporate secretary and a director of British Telecom.
 
 Opposition in U.S.
 The American cable industry has strongly opposed proposals to allow local phone companies in the United States to enter cable television, contending that the phone companies would use profits from their regulated local monopolies to subsidize cable service illegally.
The Department of Trade and Industry also said yesterday that it would seek to impose caps on the unregulated prices that British Telecom charges for international calls. High prices for such calls have drawn criticism from the United States Federal Communications Commission. New technology has sent the cost of providing international service plummeting, but prices to consumers have fallen much more slowly.
What effect the regulatory changes would have on consumers and businesses is unclear. In the United States, political pressures to keep down local rates resulted in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company charging far more than its costs for long-distance service during the 1960's and 1970's and using the profits to subsidize local service. Long-distance rates then fell and local rates rose when competition entered the industry, prompting complaints from consumer groups.
But in Britain, the rate-setting process has been less politicized. Domestic long-distance and international rates, which until recently were paid mostly by businesses, have not subsidized local rates as much. So the effects of increased competition on different groups of ratepayers are ambiguous, other than to reduce the overall price level.
 
 Weighing Restrictions
 Economists say the issue facing the British Government is how much competition is needed to force British Telecom to operate efficiently and reduce rates, and how many restrictions should be put on the company's ability to respond to that competition. Allowing many companies into the telephone industry would increase competition only if British Telecom is not allowed to fight back by cutting prices where it is challenged and keeping prices high elsewhere.
But too many restrictions on British Telecom could also result in inefficient prices, as protected new competitors might not offer the lowest charges possible.
Yesterday's plan calls for British Telecom's local and domestic long-distance telephone prices to remain regulated through 1993.

HEADLINE: U.S., Despite Dispute, Will Go to Trade Talks

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
As the first of a series of high-level meetings leading up to global trade talks was being held today, the Bush Administration sought to quash speculation that it planned to walk out of negotiations on liberalizing trade because of sharp differences with the European Community over agricultural protection.
The assurances that the United States still plans to attend a crucial negotiating session in Brussels next month despite the split over farm trade came as President Bush met with Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy, who also holds the community's six-month chairmanship, and Jacques Delors, the president of the community's Executive Commission. 
 At a White House departure ceremony after two hours of meetings, both Mr. Bush and Mr. Andreotti stressed the importance they attached to a successful conclusion of the trade talks, known as the Uruguay Round, for the country where the talks started four years ago.
 
 'We Must Succeed'
 "We discussed at length our goals for the Uruguay Round and our strong conviction that we must succeed," Mr. Bush said, standing in a gray topcoat beside the Rose Garden.
Mr. Andreotti, who was instrumental in breaking a recent deadlock within the community over farm trade, said there was a "will to reach a positive conclusion," and warned that if an accord was not reached, it would mean "serious damage in particular to developing countries."
In Geneva today, thousands of angry European farmers, ringing cowbells and riding tractors, protested against reductions in the farm subsidies proposed in the talks.
Today's Washington meeting was the first of those scheduled for the next 10 days in an effort to generate the political will for fostering an agreement in the 105-nation talks. The talks are aimed at setting new liberal rules not only for agriculture, but also for financial services, investments and intellectual property like patents and copyrights. They will move as well along the more traditional negotiating lines of global tariff-cutting.
The Administration had been debating whether to walk out as a signal of displeasure with what was seen as a meager European farm trade offer. The proposal has angered not only Washington but other leading exporters of farm goods. Lately, however, European officials have been telling Washington that the offer is negotiable.
European officials said they understood that Mr. Andreotti and Mr. Delors, both of whom are eager for the talks to succeed, made a similar point in their conversations with President Bush.
 
 Seen by Dutch as Opening Bid
 On Friday, the Dutch trade minister, Yvonne van Rooy, told reporters after meeting with American trade officials that "it's not a final offer, but clearly an opening bid."
The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said today that she would attend the Dec. 3-7 global trade meeting in Brussels. While attacking the European Community for what she termed its inadequate offer, she stressed at a news conference that "I want to leave no stone unturned."
"I do not want to look back and say that if I had made one more flight, or attended one more meeting, or spent one more overnight maybe it could have come off," she added.
Asked what Mr. Bush would tell Mr. Andreotti and Mr. Delors, Mrs. Hills said she expected the President to stress that "if we are to have a conclusion of the Uruguay Round, which affords the world such a fantastic opportunity for economic gain, for geopolitical harmony and for realizing the economic aspirations of the poorest nations, it won't happen unless the Europeans permit the negotiations to take place in the two areas that they see fit not to permit."
 
 New Cuts of 15 Percent
 For the Uruguay Round, the Europeans have offered to cut internal farm income supports by 30 percent over 10 years, using 1986 as a starting date. Since 15 percent has already been cut since 1986, this would mean new reductions of 15 percent.
The United States and the principal agricultural exporting nations have proposed cuts of 75 percent in farm income over 10 years beginning this year. But a group of exporters of farm goods and the United States are also insisting on action in two other sectors: opening the European farm market and sharp cuts in export subsidies.
The Europeans are expected to spend $12 billion on such subsidies this year, in effect "buying market share abroad," as Mrs. Hills put it. The United States will spend about $280 million on export subsidies this year.
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who is the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said he was concerned about getting approval by Congress if an agreement comes out of the Brussels meeting.
Mr. Bentsen, whose committee oversees trade matters in the Senate, warned that, hard as it might be to achieve, a Uruguay Round agreement would not be approved unless it "gives Americans greater access to markets abroad."
 
 Backed by 37 Senators
 He said at a news conference that he was particularly worried that a resolution, now backed by 37 senators, could jeopardize passage in Congress of the accord, with its delicate balance of concessions from 105 nations.
Under "fast track" authority, which expires next June 1, the Administration would present the entire package to Congress, and members would either vote for it or against it. This, Senator Bentsen said, was the only way such an agreement could win legislative approval. The resolution by the 37 senators would withhold the fast-track authority from the agreement.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy, who also holds the post of chairman of the European Community, met with President Bush at the White House yesterday to discuss the difficulties in world trade talks. (Associated Press); Arthur Dunkel, director general of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, returned to his Geneva office yesterday after addressing European farmers protesting proposed reductions in subsidies. HEADLINE: Credit Agency Urges Mayor To Ready More Budget Cuts

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
A major Wall Street credit rating agency warned yesterday that New York City may have to make deeper service cuts than envisioned in even the worst scenario Mayor David N. Dinkins outlined last week to keep its current budget balanced in the face of a soft economy.
In a statement on the Mayor's budget plan, the Standard & Poor's Corporation said plans to leave more than 5,000 jobs unfilled and to reduce programs in many agencies might not be enough to close a budget gap for the current fiscal year. Mr. Dinkins estimates the gap at $388 million, but the rating agency said it would probably grow. 
 Last week, Mr. Dinkins released not only his plans for closing the $388 million gap, but $40 million in additional cuts that might be needed if economic conditions worsen.
The contingency plan calls for closing six fire companies, in addition to the two already planned to close; reducing the number of garbage pickups in some neighborhoods; cutting financing for senior citizens' centers; delaying bridge inspections and repairs, and delaying maintenance at parks, playgrounds and beaches.
 
A Shared Concern
 But in his statement yesterday, Hyman C. Grossman, a managing director at Standard & Poor's, said even those plans might not be enough. Asked whether his comment was simply a statement of fact or a warning, Mr. Grossman said, "A little of both."
"I expect the revenue estimates to get worse over the coming months," he added. "I'm suggesting that when the city says the '91 gap has been closed, I think it's premature to say that. I mean, it's closed as of today, but I don't expect it to stay closed. They've prepared for, hopefully, most of the contingencies, but I'm saying they may need to do a little more."
A spokesman for Mr. Dinkins, Leland T. Jones, said, "The concern they're expressing is a concern that we share." He said that the Mayor had included the contingency plan because conditions might worsen, and that Mr. Dinkins was prepared to do whatever was necessary to keep the budget balanced, and close an estimated gap of more than $1.6 billion for the fiscal year that starts on July 1.
Mr. Grossman's statement praised the city's prudence in addressing its fiscal problems. Last month, in a sign of concern, the agency placed the city's bonds on a "credit watch," warning that it might lower the credit rating, and thus force the city to pay a higher interest rate on bonds.
 
Are New Programs Worthwhile?
 Since October, when the city disclosed its deteriorating fiscal situation, the prices of New York City's bonds have fallen, and yields, or return to investors, have risen significantly -- about seven-tenths of a percent more than the premium they already traded at over bonds of other agencies with similar credit ratings. On Monday, a typical long-term city bond was trading to yield 8.50 percent.
Though Standard & Poor's has rated New York City bonds at A- since 1987, traders say the bonds are trading as if they had been downgraded to BBB, the lowest investment-grade rating given by the agency.
Since Mr. Dinkins released his revised financial plan on Thursday, trading in New York City bonds has been light, and the yields had changed little. Analysts said that suggested that the market had already taken into account the bad news.
Also yesterday, the executive director of the State Financial Control Board, a watchdog agency, said that with such vital services as sanitation and education facing reductions, the city might want to reconsider a number of smaller agencies and programs that he called "sacred cows."
Among the agencies cited by the director, Allen J. Proctor, were the Campaign Finance Board, which provides partial matching public funds to candidates for city office who agree to abide by limits on contributions and spending; a new Independent Budget Office, created under the City Charter to provide elected officials and the public with information to challenge the official budget estimates, and new city planners to be hired under the charter.
Mr. Proctor said he was not proposing the elimination of such programs, which typically cost a few million dollars each, or telling the administration what to do, but only suggesting that there should be debate over whether the city could afford them now.
"All I am saying is we are now at a point where the budget director's instructions to agencies are going to lead to reductions in major agencies providing vital services," he said. "And when you look at where the growth is, it's in some of these charter-mandated programs. And while they seemed very worthwhile two years ago, are they as worthwhile as reductions in the other agencies."

HEADLINE: Olivetti Is Said to Plan 7,000 Layoffs in Slump

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Faced with slumping profits and intense foreign competition, Olivetti, the Italian computer and office equipment giant, is planning to eliminate 7,000 jobs worldwide, or more than 12 percent of its work force, a Government official said today.
The reductions were disclosed in Rome by the Italian Labor Minister, Carlo Donat Cattin, who said they would involve 4,000 layoffs in Italy and 3,000 abroad. But union leaders said they understood that the staff cuts would come through early retirements and inducements for workers to resign.
 
 Company Is Silent
 Ing. C. Olivetti & Company S.p.A., which is controlled by Carlo de Benedetti, declined to comment on the reports until after a meeting with officials in Milan tonight. But there was little question that deep cuts were on the way, however they might be put into effect. 
 As of June 30, the company employed 55,745 people; the number has dropped slowly but steadily in the last few years as earnings slid.
Further reductions for next year were promised by company executives a few weeks ago, but the 7,000 figure was still appreciably higher than many analysts had expected. Even so, early signs suggested that Italy's often feisty unions would support the idea of staff cuts so long as they have a say in how they are carried out.
 
 Other Layoffs Expected
 "We're at the start of another wave of restructuring that will affect all of Italian industry," said Luigi Angeletti, a labor leader in Rome. "Olivetti is the first sensational case, but unfortunately it will not be the last."
These are difficult days for the European computer industry, which has fallen victim to a general economic slowdown and to aggressive competition from titans in the United States and Japan. Enormous losses and resulting job cuts have been announced by Philips N.V. of the Netherlands and Groupe Bull S.A. of France.
Olivetti has not been immune to this trend. It recently said its pretax profits dropped 41 percent in the first half of the year, continuing a decline that is now more than three years old.
 
 De Benedetti Writes Holders
 Mr. de Benedetti told shareholders in a letter sent in late September that the lira's strength against the dollar and the Japanese yen had hurt the company because much of its production costs were in lire, while 60 percent of its sales were in foreign currencies. This made Olivetti's products more expensive abroad and sliced into sales, which nonetheless rose 5.8 percent.
Despite the problems, Mr. de Benedetti has insisted that his company is in better shape than many of its competitors. It has "shown a vitality with few comparisons in the worldwide information-technology industry and a profitability that is exceptional for the European sector," he told shareholders.
 
 Other Effects Seen
 Financial analysts warned that the Olivetti cuts were likely to be repeated in other industries as the Italian economy sagged after years of sustained growth. Fiat S.p.A., for example, has laid off 30,000 auto workers for periods this fall in the face of slackened demand in Europe and a declining market share in Italy.
Confindustria, Italy's leading business group, predicts that industrial output will rise this year by only half a percent, compared with 4 percent in 1989 and 7 percent the year before. Government forecasts of overall economic growth for this year have been scaled back several times, most recently to 2.9 percent, and continued effects from the Persian Gulf crisis may make even that figure look optimistic.

HEADLINE: INVESTORS DECLINE GOVERNMENT DEALS FOR FAILED S.& L.'S

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
When Congress passed the savings industry bailout legislation more than a year ago, it had high hopes that new money from private investors would pour in to strengthen the beleaguered industry. But today, even though Wall Street pledged nearly $2 billion for the effort, only a trickle of private money has been invested.
The Government has found it almost impossible to sell failed savings institutions to private investors. As a result, taxpayers are having to shoulder the entire burden of the industry rescue, and those costs are mounting daily. 
 "None of the money has been invested in anything," said Bernard J. Carl, managing partner of Castine Partners, which invests in financial institutions. "Anyone with money or financial talent is gone."
 
Conflicting Interests
 On this point, the Government concurs. "The capital has disappeared," said William H. Roelle, director of the resolutions and operations division of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency established by Congress to oversee the savings industry.
Why so little money has been invested after so much was pledged and raised is a story of conflicting interests, expectations and objectives in Washington and on Wall Street.
Many firms contend that the August 1989 bailout legislation, and later restrictions imposed by the Government, made investing in the savings and loan business unattractive, offering scant profits and high risks. And they say they do not trust the Government as a business partner.
 
Criticism of 1988 Deals
 Federal regulators reply that the restrictions are no more than safeguards to protect taxpayers and that investors cannot expect the Government to sell institutions on the often-generous terms available in late 1988 -- in deals that have since been widely criticized as Government giveaways. In fact, much of the $2 billion earmarked by Wall Street was pledged after the 1988 deals were struck.
To date, the outcome has been an unproductive stalemate.
"This is bad from the vantage point of taxpayer costs," said Robert E. Litan, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. "It means that it will be harder to get rid of the junky thrifts and that we will have more liquidations, which are expensive."
The stay-away investors say many of the problems stem from the bailout legislation. They point to provisions that they say make it difficult to earn enough to justify the risk of buying a savings and loan -- for instance, higher deposit-insurance premiums and restrictions stating that 70 percent of an institution's loans must be home mortgages.
But even more frightening to potential investors has been the political fallout from the 1988 deals, with the Government now deciding to try to revise about 100 sales with an eye toward making them less costly for taxpayers -- and less profitable for the investors.
"Congress has sent a signal to the world not to do a deal with the Government because of the uncertainty of a Government contract," said Scott Shay, a managing director at Ranieri, Wilson & Company, which bought a group of Texas savings and loans as part of the 1988 program.
Joseph Jolson, who manages a fund for Montgomery Securities that buys stock in publicly traded savings and loans, said investors had been scared off "because the contract you negotiate could be upset if the political winds change."
He added: "Then you've got to deal with harassment from the regulators for the rest of your life. And all your friends basically think a guy who owns a thrift has robbed people blind.
"It's not a big shocker these entrepreneurs haven't come through. The Government has given no incentives."
 
Taxpayers' Cushion
 Private capital is the taxpayers' cushion. This money is tapped to protect depositors against losses before Government insurance funds step in. Capital allows a savings unit to expand and make loans to help a local economy grow. And the more private investment the Government attracts means fewer institutions will have to be liquidated, ultimately reducing the bailout's cost to taxpayers.
It is impossible to determine the exact amount the Government could save if all $2 billion were invested, but some private investors suggest that as much as $20 billion might be cut from the ultimate cost of the bailout, which some experts estimate at $500 billion.
 
Avoiding Risk
 "Capital is the ultimate protection for taxpayers," said James Barth, a former economist of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and a professor at Auburn University. "If capital declines instead of increases, your insured liabilities get larger and the taxpayer is exposed to greater risk."
Government officials say private investors are seeking unreasonably low prices on savings and loans.
"They are trying to get as much as they can for as little as they can, and they don't want to take any risk," said Mr. Roelle of Resolution Trust. "We do need private-sector money. But the real issue is profits. We want to do deals where the investor can make an honest profit and the Government can make a good deal for the taxpayers."
That has proved to be elusive. Of the nearly 500 savings and loans that have fallen into Government hands since the bailout legislation was passed, only 17 have been bought by private investors, and the Government concedes that these were small deals. This has brought in some $52 million in capital -- a minuscule amount in terms of the hundreds of billions of dollars needed to repair the industry.
Of the total, 288 savings and loans have been broken up by the Government and either liquidated or sold as "purchase and assumption" arrangements to banks, which take the deposits and pick among the loans. The remaining 195 institutions are still on the block or are working their way through the Government process.
This is in sharp contrast to Wall Street's early hopes. Lured by the lucrative 1988 deals the Government cut with Robert M. Bass, the Fort Worth investor and oilman, and Ronald O. Perelman, the chairman of Revlon Group, investors were eager to commit money to buyout pools that formed about the time the bailout legislation was moving through Congress.
At that time, at least nine investment banks were seeking to raise some $2 billion to buy savings and loans seized by the Government -- Salomon Brothers alone had gotten commitments for some $300 million. Others came from some of Wall Street's biggest houses, including Shearson Lehman Brothers; Merrill Lynch & Company, Oppenheimer & Company; Montgomery Securities, and Keefe, Bruyette & Woods. Many of these funds have since been disbanded. Others are investing in savings and loans, but only by buying publicly traded shares or acquiring institutions in private deals.
"Prior to the enactment of the legislation, people like us set up funds to recapitalize the industry," said Gerard L. Smith, a managing director at Salomon. "Then when the legislation was passed, it became clear to those of us who can read English that the law essentially forbids investors from making a profit in the industry. And the implication of that is that there isn't going to be a thrift industry if it cannot attract new capital."
Also troubling is what this lack of capital means for banks. As savings and loan deposits are bought by banks, many say the risks of one industry are transferred to another: as banks take on new deposits, their capital is stretched more thinly. "All this does is take the existing capital in the banking sector and spread it over more deposits," said Mr. Carl of Castine Partners. "And that's troubling."
Part of the breakdown between the Government and entrepreneurs is an inability to agree on prices. Well-run savings institutions now earn about a 15 percent return on equity capital. Investors say new buyers who face start-up costs can expect a 10 to 12 percent return -- hardly more than from a less risky investment. Regulators say investors want to bid only at prices that could bring them nearly the 25 percent return on capital of days gone by -- and some say that given the current economic uncertainty investors might want more.
"The regulators have been extremely aggressive in trying to unload problems at prices the market won't take," said Michael J. McClosley, a senior vice president at Paine Webber Inc., which had sought to raise $75 million. "If there is some rational behavior by the Government with regard to pricing of assets, we would go back for capital."
One prominent entreprenuer calculated that the Government would come out ahead even if it sold whole savings and loans at prices that would yield investors a 20 percent return on capital. But this supposes that the Government would protect the buyer from catastrophic real estate losses through devices like yield-maintenance agreements or indemnifications and guarantees. Such devices are politically, if not legally, impossible for the Government to offer.

The Economy
When Congress passed the savings bailout, it had high hopes that new money from private investors would pour in. But even though Wall Street pledged nearly $2 billion, only a trickle of private money has been invested. [Page A1.]

HEADLINE: BRIEFS

 BODY:

* H. F. Ahmanson & Co., Los Angeles, a savings and loan holding company, said it would complete the acquisition of Home Savings Bank, Brooklyn, on Monday.
 
* General Mills Inc., Minneapolis, expects its restaurant business to be a big growth area, chairman, Bruce Atwater, said in an interview. He said revenues from General Mills' Olive Garden and Red Lobster restaurants were good, despite a generally poor economy. "Our restaurants continue to act just as they did in the first quarter," when sales grew 18 percent, he said.
 
* General Motors Corp., Detroit, has cut ties to six health maintenance organizations and has frozen membership in 20 others in an annual review aimed at reducing its $3 billion annual bill for health care. The cuts have not been opposed by the United Automobile Workers union.
 
* Leaf Inc., Bannockburn, Ill. the maker of the Clark candy bar, announced it would close the Pittsburgh plant where the bars are made and put the 104-year-old Clark name up for sale. Prospective buyers are looking at the plant. Leaf, owned by Huhtamaeki Oy of Finland, operates 11 candy and gum plants in the United States and Canada.
 
* Norfolk Southern Corp., Norfolk, Va., a railroad operator, has acquired the assets of an Ohio River terminal near Wheelersburg, Ohio, from an affiliate of Island Creek Corp., Lexington, Ky., a coal company. Terms were not disclosed.
 
* Rank Organization P.L.C., London, a communications and entertainment concern, said it had decided not to sell its Clermont Casino to Bally Manufacturing Corp., Chicago, a gaming company.
 
* Reading Co., Philadelphia, a real estate and emergency services company, completed the sale of several properties in Philadelphia for $18.4 million.
 
* Textron Inc., Providence, R.I., an aerospace and technology company, said it would integrate its Bell Aerospace unit into its Textron Defense Systems division.

HEADLINE: Florio Facing Revolt by 4 On Tax Plan

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Four Democratic Assemblymen called today for the repeal of a major aspect of Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax package, in the latest indication of legislators seeking to distance themselves from the Governor's plan.
In a public letter, the four told Assembly Speaker Joseph A. Doria that they planned to introduce a bill when the Legislature reconvenes on Monday to have the state take back responsibility for paying teacher pensions, a major part of the Florio program involving hundreds of millions of dollars. 
 Assemblyman Joseph A. Mecca, one of the four legislators, said that if Mr. Doria did not act quickly to move the bill forward, the four Assemblymen might break ranks with their party and join Republicans in the Assembly to pass the bill. Democrats control the house, 43 seats to 37.
"The people have spoken," Mr. Mecca said of Mr. Florio's tax package. "Enough is enough. It is time to reverse this thing."
 
Revenues 'in Big Trouble'
 But a senior member of the Legislature, Senator Laurence S. Weiss, a Democrat who heads the Revenue, Finance and Appropriations Committee, said he feared that in their desire to escape the wrath of voters and cut taxes, legislators might fail to deal with a problem of revenues, which are running far behind expectation.
Even without revisions to the Florio program, Mr. Weiss said he estimated that the Governor and the Legislature would have to find $800 million in cuts in state programs to make up for revenues that have fallen short this year as a result of a weak economy.
"We are going to be short," he said, "and we are going to be in big trouble."
The repeal move by the four Assemblymen was the latest sign of continuing concern over the Governor's tax package, sentiment that was highlighted in the Nov. 6 election by the unexpectedly weak showing of Senator Bill Bradley, a Democrat. In a highly unusual move a day later, Mr. Florio took responsibility for the electoral setback and promised to consider repealing some parts of his tax and school aid package, which raised sales and income taxes and shifted school aid from more affluent to poorer districts. He agreed to repeal a tax on heavy trucks, which was designed to raise $44 million.
Mr. Mecca said that he and the three other Assemblymen preferred to work with fellow Democrats to repeal the pension measure, which infuriated teachers and school boards around the state. But if the Speaker, Mr. Doria, lets the measure languish, he said, he expects a number of Democrats to break party discipline. The Republicans in the Assembly have already endorsed a similar measure.
"It hurts to say it, but that is the way we would have to go," Mr. Mecca said.
 
Republican Challenges Loom
 Mr. Mecca, of Clifton, along with the three others who signed the letter -- John A. Villapiano and Daniel P. Jacobson, both of Long Branch, and Thomas J. Duch of Garfield -- all face tough challenges from Republicans next year and were among the most resistant to the Governor's program when he pushed it through the Legislature last year. Mr. Mecca, in fact, voted against the Governor's sales tax increases.
Although other troubled Democratic members of the Assembly and the Senate said the four were more volatile in their dissent than the majority of Democrats, their public declaration demonstrated the change in the political atmosphere here from last spring, when Mr. Florio rushed a host of spending programs through the Legislature, including the biggest tax increase in the state's history.
As part of the package passed in June by the Legislature, the cost of teachers' pensions, Social Security and health benefits of retirees were shifted from the state to local school districts

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Senators Asking President To Call Session Over Gulf

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Influential lawmakers from both parties urged President Bush today to convene a special session of Congress on the Persian Gulf crisis, as the White House confronted increasing concern about the possibility of war in the Middle East.
But the White House said it opposed a special session, fearing that it would undermine Mr. Bush's strategy, and Congress itself was fundamentally divided. Some Republicans wanted to call lawmakers back to lend clear-cut support for Mr. Bush's policies. 
 Senator Richard G. Lugar, a senior Republican on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said Mr. Bush needed that explicit backing because his decision to nearly double the American military force in the gulf region "has set the United States on a collision course in which Iraq will either withdraw from Kuwait or be forced to do so by military means."
 
Kennedy Deplores Silence
 Some Democrats who favored a special session hoped instead to limit the President's ability to commit American troops to war. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said the United States was on a "headlong course toward war" and added, "Silence by Congress now is an abdication of our constitutional responsibility and an acquiescence in war."
George J. Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, gave voice to concerns that have arisen since Mr. Bush last week dramatically increased the American force, saying that the President "has no legal authority, none whatever," to order an offensive against Iraq.
"The Constitution clearly invests that great responsibility in the Congress and the Congress alone," he said.
 
Hesitancy to Call Session
 But Mr. Mitchell said he was reluctant to hold a special session of Congress, which is not scheduled to return until January. There was also hesitancy among leading Republicans. Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader, supported a special session. But after meeting with Mr. Bush, he appeared to modify his position, suggesting that Congress might wait and see if the United Nations first explicitly endorsed military action against Iraq.
The issue overtook a Republican caucus convened to elect new party leaders in the Senate. Emerging from the meeting, Senator Bob Kasten of Wisconsin said, "There are as many opinions in that room as there are Senators."
That left the prospects for a special session in doubt. The Armed Services and Foreign Affairs committees of Congress were expected to hold hearings on the gulf after Thanksgiving, but no date was set because the chairmen of the panels said they were having difficulty getting commitments from top Adminstration officials to testify.
Mr. Bush will discuss the issue with Congressional leaders on Wednesday at the White House. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney plan a briefing on Capitol Hill.
 
War Powers Resolution
 The debate turned on complex political, military and constitutional questions. Most fundamentally, lawmakers and Administration officials are coming to grips with the question that has vexed American leaders since at least the Korean War: How much power does the President have to order troops into combat without seeking advance permission from Congress?
Like his predecessors, Mr. Bush believes that as Commander in Chief, he has the power to use the military without a declaration of war if there is a need to act speedily to protect American lives and national interests. Article 1 of the Constitution gives Congress the authority to declare war.
Congress allowed Presidents to bypass a declaration of war in Korea and Vietnam. In the gulf, Congress has not challenged the President on the basis of the War Powers Resolution, which was passed in 1973 after American participation in Vietnam had ended.
The resolution, which Mr. Bush and his predecessors have resisted, requires the President to notify Congress within 48 hours of sending troops where "imminent involvement in hostilities" is possible. Mr. Bush has asserted that the law is not relevant in the case of the gulf deployment because the American troops do not face imminent hostilities.
 
Now an Issue in Gulf
 Nevertheless, the issue has arisen because the gulf deployment has taken place over more than three months without overt conflict, and because there is now the suggestion that American forces might be used not just to defend Saudi Arabia but to attack Iraq.
Politically, the discussion underlined how the atmosphere of the gulf crisis has changed since the elections last week, as lawmakers, no longer constrained by fear for their political futures, sought to position themselves before any decision by Mr. Bush to take the offensive against Iraq.
Some Republicans said they wanted to cement public support for the Administration's gulf policy. Some Democrats said they wanted to make clear that Mr. Bush does not have carte blanche and that Congress is opposed to taking the offensive against Iraq before economic sanctions have a chance to work.
The flurry of Congressional activity came in response to Mr. Bush's order last week to nearly double the American troops stationed in the gulf region.
Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told a French radio station today that he did not believe war in the gulf was imminent as a result of Mr. Bush's action.
 
Will Troops Be Rotated?
 But the increase in forces heightened concern on Capitol Hill that the Administration was moving quickly toward war, as did Mr. Cheney's remarks on Friday that the Pentagon had dropped its plan to rotate troops in the gulf.
In an apparent effort to quiet that concern, Mr. Cheney told a closed-door meeting of the House Armed Services Committee today that he was not ruling out troop rotation and had not made a final decision, according to Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the committee. But General Powell told the panel that Pentagon planners were not discussing troop rotations, other officials present at the hearing said.
Pentagon officials say that such rotations would be very difficult to arrange in any event. In the case of the Marine Corps, which has two-thirds of its combat troops in or headed to Saudi Arabia, there are not enough Marines left to carry out a rotation.
 
Navy Reserves to Be Called
 Pete Williams, the Pentagon spokesman, announced today that the Marines would conduct an amphibious-assault exercise in Saudi Arabia. The Washington Times reported that the exercise would be held 10 miles from the border of Iraqi-occupied Kuwait, within range of Iraq's Silkworm missiles, and quoted American officials as saying that Iraq might consider that "provocative."
A Marine Corps official said the maneuvers would be held more than 35 miles south of the Saudi-Kuwaiti border, specifically outside the range of the Silkworm missiles.
The Pentagon also announced that it had authorized the Navy to increase its callup of reserves to 10,000 from 6,300 and that it will take similar steps for the other services.
 
'A Desire to Know'
 While the White House focused on maintaining support among its international allies, some Republicans argued that Mr. Bush should pay more attention to the domestic side of the gulf crisis by rallying support among lawmakers and the American public.
Senator Lugar, who first proposed the idea of a special session on Monday, said that after talking to his constituents, "I think there is a desire to know why we are there, and that leads me to believe people don't know."
Vexed by these suggestions that Mr. Bush had not made his case, the White House today insisted that popular sentiment favored Mr. Bush. But Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, went out of his way to assure the public that the President was still seeking a peaceful solution to the crisis and had not made a decision to go to war.
"There is no war," he said. "We want to do everything to avoid it. We want a peaceful resolution."

HEADLINE: An Ancient Skill, Sewing, Is Revived

BYLINE: By DEBORAH HOFMANN

 BODY:
LONG before it was possible to buy ready-to-wear clothes, generations of women learned to sew, usually at their mother's knee. Long after that era, home-economics teachers and organizations like 4-H clubs helped to spread the practice of sewing at home, mainly to economize on things like curtains or prom dresses.
By the 1970's, fewer people were learning to sew because many high schools had eliminated sewing classes, and many women who became adults in the blooming of the feminist movement hid portable sewing machines in the closet, with cheerleading skirts and Girl Scout sashes. 
 Today, sewing at home is a growing leisure-time activity. The Fortune Magazine 1991 Investor's Guide lists fabric retailing for home seamstresses as one of the seven most promising industries for the coming year, based on a consensus of investment and fabric industry analysts.
Sewing has gained its firmest foothold among working women who learned to thread a bobbin as children. Many use computerized machines that cost $300 to $3,000 and drastically trim the time needed for sewing projects. They select from a growing number of designer patterns to create Christian Dior sheaths, Chanel business suits and Anne Klein blouses, Mario Buatta draperies and Laura Ashley pillow slips.
The woman who sews at home, says the trade organization Sewing Fashion Council, is college-educated, is 25 to 45 years old, often has a child ; her household income is $35,000 to $40,000. "There is a very high correlation between highly advanced education and women who sew," said Caryl Svendsen, a spokeswoman for the Sewing Fashion Council, a consumer-information resource in Manhattan.
Among these women are Daphne Maxwell Reid, a television actress; Florence Griffith Joyner, the Olympic gold medalist; Deborah Norville, the "Today" show anchor, and Kathleen Gregory-Henschel, who manages a department of seven in forecasting budgets and analyzing profits for Chevron International, based in San Francisco.
"Men aren't into sewing -- yet," said Vicki Hastings, the director of marketing and education for the American Home Sewing and Crafts Association, a trade group. "It's still primarily viewed as a female sport: men golf; women sew." To change that perception, the association is considering a program in cooperation with the Boys and Girls Clubs of America to offer sewing classes through the group's 17,000 clubs.
Researchers for a 1989 survey by Mediamark, a New York-based market research organization, said nearly 21 million people now sew at home -- people who are buying up nearly everything associated with sewing. According to the 1987 Census of Business Trade, more than $2.5 million was spent on fabrics, patterns, notions, laces and trims that year. In 1987 sewing machine sales increased about 8 percent over 1986, according to the Sewing Fashion Council.
Today the appeal of home sewing is not necessarily economic. Women who sew at home say they find their mothers' pastime therapeutic; they speak of a necessary counterbalance and creative stimulation in their lives, and of having a stylish wardrobe.
And at the office conversations about buttonholes may be a welcome relief from talk about bottom lines.
In a recollection evocative of "Little Women," Mrs. Henschel told how she and her three sisters learned to sew from their mother, Grace. "How else were we going to clothe four girls?" Mrs. Henschel said.
On weekends, she creates nearly all her own business clothes from designer patterns. For her husband, Peter Henschel, she tailors many business suits, using wool she finds in Scotland. "I tailor them as well as anyone on Regent Street," she said.
Now, she said, in her office compliment one another on their handmade garments. "We all know the Vogue pattern numbers by heart," she said. "It's become like a greeting: 'Hey, that's Vogue pattern Number X -- I made it, too. It looks great on you.' " And, she added, sewing women at top levels of Chevron have made an in-joke of tucking a swatch of leftover silk into their breast pockets.
Ms. Norville began sewing when she was 9 and her mother helped her turn scraps of fabric into a Barbie doll wardrobe. Soon afterward, she dared to make a garment for herself: "a hideous pair of pants -- horizontal stripes of yellow, blue and red -- but all the stripes matched," she said. These days, she makes all her own maternity clothes and all the fabric furnishings for her Manhattan apartment and her country home. "I find it therapeutic," she said. "It gives me time to think."
Ms. Norville said she spends three to four hours most weekends at a kitchen counter, working at her 18-year-old Kenmore sewing machine.
"What has happened in the 90's is that professional women are fed up with being told what they can and can't do," she said. "I don't care if someone thinks that I'm a dope because I sew. I'm proud of every dust ruffle, window cushion and bedspread. They're labors of love. And these days, women stop me to compliment me on my blouse pattern, not to ask me what Willard Scott is like. We share tips on pinning, welts, zippers, markings, selvages."
Ms. Reid, who is married to the actor Tim Reid, was the daughter of a professional seamstress who began Daphne's sewing lessons when she was 9. She began by first sewing for her dolls and, in a couple of years, for herself. Now Ms. Reid tailors most of her suits, coats and gowns, about 30 items a year. A favorite is a gray wool jacket by Donna Karan with pants by Yves St. Laurent , both from Vogue patterns. "According to Donna Karan, such a suit is one-fifth of what her jacket alone, off the rack, would cost," Ms. Reid said.
Between television projects, she retreats to her private sewing studio in her Los Angeles home for days and weeks. If she's having a busy season at her job, she hides on weekends, emerging "at 3 A.M. Monday with a new designer suit," she said.
Judge Carol Higley-Lane of the Houston criminal courts spoke of learning to sew at age 10 in New York State's 4-H program. Her skill earned her prizes at county fairs, helping to pay for her college tuition.
Sewing is now a lucrative sideline; she sells garments and patterns to a growing clientele nationwide and travels around the country to conduct workshops on wearable art. Her designs, with hand-sewn appliques and embroidery inspired by Japanese kimonos, are "as far away from my judicial robe as they can be."
She uses vintage kimonos as the source of her fabric and buys them in Japan. "Sewing gives me a way to relax and to express a more exotic fantasy side," she said in an interview. "And it takes me totally away from my reality: the real world of capital offenses, murders, warrant issues."
While many women who sew concentrate on garments, a big part of the boom is in sewing for the home. The Sewing Fashion Council has reported that retailers across the country are reporting a 30 percent increase in the sale of home-decorating fabric and patterns over last year.
A 1989 survey of readers of the magazine Sew News, based in Peoria, Ill., reported that its average reader stitched seven home-decorating projects a year and spent $308 each year on sewing materials for her home, ranging from bedspreads to drapes. Sew News readers said they also spent an average of $646 a year on apparel-sewing.
In 1973, 44 percent of American households reported buying sewing supplies, according to a Consumer Expenditure Survey of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
By 1986, only 13 percent of the households surveyed reported expenditures on fabrics, patterns and notions. By then many department stores had dismantled their huge fabric and notions departments.
"The industry was flat in the last few years as women went to work," said Allan Feller, president of the Butterick Sales Company, in charge of marketing for Butterick and Vogue patterns, which together account for 39 percent of the market. "They felt they did not have time to sew. But as they've moved upward, in professional circles, they need bigger classic career wardrobes and now sewing's an economically attractive idea, too."
Now, in part because of efforts by the sewing industry to lure top fashion designers to lend their names to patterns (and at the same time investing in sophisticated sewing machines that could give homemade clothes the same finished look as quality ready-to-wear and designer clothes), the industry has tapped the psyche of the professional woman who applies the same high standards to her dressmaking and home-decorating as she does to engineering, medicine or architecture.
Such women welcomed the new sewing machines, supplemented by sergers, machines once available only to designers and manufacturers. The sergers, which cost about $600, help cut construction time in half by performing complex functions like seaming, overcasting and trimming excess fabric in one motion.
"Making clothes became less time-consuming than searching racks for the right outfit," Judge Higley-Lane said. "Creative people applied their 'what-if' instinct to the machines, changing the whole slightly disparaging connotation of 'homemade.' "
The demand for sewing classes has increased. Fabric retailers and makers of sewing machines are trying to fill the void, said Stan Ingraham, vice president for sales and marketing for Viking Sewing Machine Company and White Sewing Machine Company. The Sewing Fashion Council has begun a register of sewing instructors and plans an 800 telephone number next year.
Through classes and in the home, sewing skills are apparently being passed on to a new generation. According to research prepared by Forecast Magazine in 1989, a Scholastic Publication, about 60 percent of American teen-agers, boys and girls, said they knew how to sew by machine, and more than two-thirds said they did it for fun.
When Ms. Reid's son, Christopher Tubbs, 19, recently coveted a pair of pull-on pants like his friend's, she said: "I taught him then and there to sew. He brought the pants over, I showed him how to make the pattern and cut it. We sat at my machine, and he sewed them up.
"I'm trying to get people away from being ashamed to use their sewing machines," she said. "I don't think it was the feminist era that did this. I think memories of Home Ec and making aprons did it. I tell people to make something they're going to wear. Don't sew a scarf. Let's do those same stitches and make bike pants."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
And Then There Were 3

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
A WHO'S WHO of airline executives offered a warning last week to Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner: The first casualties in America's war of nerves with Saddam Hussein may be right here at home. Several United States carriers, already enfeebled by heavy debt and slumping passenger demand, could be forced into liquidation or merger by another six months of oil inflation.
The airlines want the White House to talk down the price of jet fuel, which has risen far more than other refinery products in the last few months. But Dan Kasper, an economist at Harbridge House, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass., argues that it will take more than a little Presidential jawboning to restore the industry to competitive health. 
 What is needed, Mr. Kasper says, is an infusion of capital from Japanese and European carriers eager to expand. Some foreign airlines, he thinks, want access to the domestic American market so badly that they (and their governments) would be willing to give what American carriers covet: the right to compete within Europe and Asia.
 When airline executives talk darkly of a financial debacle in the making, they may not be exaggerating. It is no secret that Eastern and Pan Am are on the ropes; nor is there any doubt that Continental, T.W.A. and Midway are in deep trouble. Northwest and USAir are in no danger of collapse. But they are unlikely to emerge from the recession with the ambition (or the cash) to conquer new markets.
T.W.A.'s surprise bid for Pan Am stirs the pot but cannot change the basic character of the stew. It is being widely interpeted as a diversionary tactic, intended to delay the sale of Pan Am's transAtlantic routes to United, an airline that would give T.W.A. a tougher run for lucrative European traffic. But even if the merger did go through, the new airline would be short of cash and short of domestic traffic to feed its international routes.
Thus business-as-usual is almost certain to leave American, United and Delta in firm control of the domestic market, with little prospect of a challenge from a new entrant or a regional carrier. Consumers would, of course, pay the price as surviving airlines learned to temper their inclination to compete on price. And even the mighty trio might discover their cartel-like silver cloud had a gray lining: such market concentration would invite calls for re-regulation of the industry.
The quickest fix would be a relaxation of the absolute Congressional prohibition on foreign control of American carriers -- a "failing airline" merger provision, perhaps, parallel to the waiver of antitrust scrutiny in mergers of failing corporations. Pan Am, which is running out of assets to sell to cover its monthly bills, would probably be able to make a foreign match; British Air, KLM and Japan Air Lines have been mentioned as eligible suitors. Cash-hemorrhaging Continental, which is already partly owned by Scandinavian Airlines System, would probably also be able to find a partner to guarantee its survival.
But the better way to insure competition, Mr. Kasper suggests, would be a grand deal that opened the airline markets of America, Europe and the Asian rim to international investment and competition. That would allow American and United, already powerhouses on regulated international routes, to become true multinational carriers. And it would give both USAir and Northwest a chance to merge with foreign partners, which could supply the cash to buy fuel-efficient planes and the international links to feed passengers.
A deal opening the European market would be an easy sell to the dominant American carriers, industry sources say, provided they could sell seats from country to country within Europe. And it would certainly tempt their European counterparts, which will not be permitted to maintain cozy cartel arrangements within an integrated European market and know that their main chance lies in stronger international links.
For workers at failing United States airlines, integration would be an unmixed blessing. It might be possible, moreover, to fashion deals that serve the interests of current employees at stronger carriers -- deals that protect both their tenure and their wages. But such sweeping changes would still be bound to create uncertainties, with unions competing for turf and employees of merged carriers scrapping over seniority.
The collapse of a major carrier might break the "I'm all right Jack" attitudes that have made global integration an impossible dream. But do not bet on it: neither the Chapter 11 bankruptcy of Eastern nor the slow-motion dismemberment of Pan Am has led to calls for an international rescue. Meanwhile, the prospects for preserving consumers' gains from deregulation grow dimmer.

HEADLINE: Defense Puts Eagles Into Playoff Picture

BYLINE: By THOMAS GEORGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13

 BODY:
After the Eagles finished 11-5 and reached the playoffs last season, they were projected this season as a Super Bowl contender or at least a major force in the National Conference championship race. Randall Cunningham figured prominently into the Eagles' equation, but their big-bang defense was front and center in the Eagles' promise.
After all, the Eagles' defense led the league with 30 interceptions and 26 recovered fumbles in 1989. Their 56 forced turnovers easily outnumbered their closest challenger (Denver had 43) and doubled the defensive turnovers gained by six National Football League teams. 
 But Philadelphia stumbled to a 1-3 start this year and entered its Monday night encounter here against Washington with a defense that had slipped in nearly every category and one that had not scored a touchdown after getting four last year. The defensive dropoff was a major reason Philadelphia was 4-4.
"I think a lot of what happened was just timing," said William Frizzell, a safety, who started a good thing and saw the rest of his defensive mates join the fray in the Eagles' 28-14 victory over the Redskins.
Frizzell's 30-yard interception return for a touchdown gave Philadelphia a 7-0 lead in the first quarter. The Redskins tied the score in the second and then the Eagles exploded in the third. In the final 3 minutes 50 seconds of the quarter, the Eagles scored three touchdowns, with the defense paving the way. One touchdown came after Clyde Simmons scooped up a fumble caused by Wes Hopkins's nasty sack of Jeff Rutledge and ran 18 yards for a touchdown. Another came after Byron Evans tipped a pass into the hands of Reggie White, who rumbled 33 yards to the Redskins' 9 to set up a touchdown pass by Cunningham and the Eagles' final points.
The Eagles believe that "Buddy Ball" is back.
They are not sure where it went.
"We weren't down on ourselves, but we were doing more talking than playing," Frizzell said. "But this is a group that never loses confidence in itself. We had concentration tonight. We had intensity. When we have that, we get turnovers."
Philadelphia has won three straight games. Cunningham appears more comfortable with the teachings of his new offensive coordinator, Rich Kotite, and the running game is rejuvenated with Heath Sherman, who is the first Eagle to rush for back-to-back 100-yard games since Wilbert Montgomery in 1981. Philadelphia finishes its regular season with a home game against Dallas and then at Phoenix. Its five games preceding those matchups -- at Atlanta, playing host to the Giants, at Buffalo, at Miami and being host to Green Bay -- will tax the Eagles' resurgent mix and decide their playoff chances.
"We're going to the playoffs," Jerome Brown said. "And we ain't stopping once we get there."

 
Minor League Talks

At their meeting in Dallas on Wednesday, the N.F.L. owners will take a long look at its proposed minor league, possibly voting on moving the 1993 Super Bowl from Phoenix and restructuring the league's office would give Paul Tagliabue, the commissioner, greater authority.
The World League of American Football has been a troubling project since its inception last summer. The idea was for a 12-team league in Europe and in the United States from which N.F.L. teams could draw players. From the start, it did not receive complete financial support from the league's 28 owners, with the Chicago Bears and the Phoenix Cardinals abstaining. Tex Schramm, the league's original president, refused to call it a minor league, saying it would compete with the N.F.L. for players and that its span and growth were unlimited. Schamm was let go and replaced by Mike Lynn, the Minnesota Vikings' general manager, and the league was scaled back to a minor league concept.
It is scheduled to begin play next spring, but Tagliabue indicated this week that gloomy economic forecasts both in the United States and abroad might postpone its start and even end the project.
The league still hopes that Arizona will find a way to make the Martin Luther King Holiday on Jan. 15 a statewide paid holiday. Arizona's vote against the holiday last week prompted Tagliabue to recommend that the owners move the 1993 Super Bowl from Phoenix. Norman Braman, the Eagles' owner and chairman of the Super Bowl site committee, said: "With no King holiday, moving the Super Bowl is clearly the right thing to do."
Braman, Hugh Culverhouse, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' owner, and Jack Donlan, director of the managment council, are among league figures whose roles could change if the owners adopt recommendations of a study of the league's hierarchy. Tagliabue has the report that the league commissioned from the New York-based Booz-Allen management firm a year ago that recommends that factions in the league such as N.F.L. Properties, headed by Braman, and the management council, headed by Culverhouse and Donlan, be brought directly under Tagliabue's direction. All three reportedly resist those changes and will fight against the recommendations.

HEADLINE: Metropolitan Diary

BYLINE: By RON ALEXANDER

 BODY:
A GREEN-THUMBED friend writes:
One morning a few weeks ago when the trees were full and lush a Greenwich Village neighbor phoned me. "A van just sideswiped one of the trees on our block," he said, urgency in his voice. "Part of the tree fell to the sidewalk. Can you come down? It's very sad." 
 Oh, great, I thought. I'm late for work, the cleaning lady hasn't shown up, the Persian Gulf is about to explode and now this guy wants me to look at a tree. I took my time checking it out. When I did I saw a gaping wound in the upper reaches of the trunk and broken limbs blocking the sidewalk. The sudden sadness I felt took me by surprise. I stared at this tree -- an ordinary Callery pear tree on an ordinary New York street -- I had always taken for granted, never even really noticed. Its fate, I'm told, is uncertain. But it is still standing and each time I pass it I'm grateful.
A few days later and barely a block away a New York City recycling truck smashed into another Callery pear tree, the one Vicky and Don Gabay planted in front of their brownstone when their daughter Rachel was born 21 years ago. This time the sight of a large, graceful branch smashed to the ground proved almost too painful for me.
The Gabays and their three children were distraught. Mrs. Gabay said parks department officials had assured her that someone would be sent to cut off a branch on the sidewalk side of the tree to make it less top-heavy. Before that happened, an evening windstorm snapped the wounded tree in half; less than six feet remain of a tree that had stretched proudly to the top of the Gabays' five-story home.
"The quality of life in New York has gotten so difficult, yet through it all we stayed and raised three kids," Mrs. Gabay said. "The irony is that it was a recycling truck that killed a tree that meant so much to us."
As for me, I now look at the neighborhood trees with wonder and affection.
 The scene: A Woodmere, L.I., post office.
 Cast of characters: A postal clerk, a customer and Maxine Karpen, who overhears their dialogue.
 Postal clerk: Haven't seen you for a long while. Been away for the summer?
 Customer: No. Bought a fax machine.
 Overheard by Rita Silverstein in the ladies' room at Entertainment Weekly: "Well, I finally met my first Jewish wide receiver."
 Wendi Weill and Matthew Seiden, nervous new parents from Short Hills, N.J., decided to take an intensive infant first-aid course on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. A dozen or so other mothers and fathers were also there, all looking equally apprehensive. All, that is, except one terrific-looking couple: immaculately dressed, beautifully coiffed, well-rested. Not for them the dark circles that turned up under other eyes.
Three hours into the course, after the instructor had dealt with everything from burns ("Never apply butter or ice") to electrocution ("Never leave an outlet uncovered"), he turned to choking. "Never allow your baby to swallow anything smaller than a grape!" he warned. The parents nodded numbly. The beautiful couple, brows furrowed in unison, seemed especially disturbed by the grape rule.
"But what shall we do?" the woman wailed. "Our nanny's tortellini is the only food our Catherine will eat."
