 To be filed under N, as in Never Too Late for Halloween Tales.
 
Dear Diary:
 It is just after twilight on Halloween and I am working quietly at home, pausing every few minutes to drop a box of Milk Duds (ah, tradition!) into the eager bags of the imp and gnome passers-by. When Debra, my wife, returns from work, she quizzes me on the Halloween proceedings and informs me that I've been going about things all wrong. It takes only a few moments until the doorbell rings again, providing her with an opportunity to exhibit the approved technique.
At our door we find an aspiring witch, perhaps 8 or 9 years of age, complete with black cape and peaked hat. Without even the customary greeting, the young visitor thrusts a gaping bag of candied loot in our direction. Debra bends down and patiently explains that, when she was a little girl in the Midwest, you had to do something to get your candy: sing, dance, tell a joke.
The witch blinks at this new information and then, imperturbably, thrusts forth her bag again. "Lady, I got this whole block to work," she says.
That, of course, earns two boxes of Milk Duds. -- ROBERT STONE
 Time: About 7:15 P.M. on Halloween. Place: Scarsdale. Cast of characters: A gaggle of trick-or-treaters, 8 or 9 years old, and Michael Cardozo, walking home from the train station, who overhears the following:
"Yes, Daddy, everything's fine. O.K., Daddy, I'll check back with you soon."
There are no other adults in sight, but as he turns, Mr. Cardoza sees a cute young witch return a portable phone to her trick-or-treat bag.

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 493 words

HEADLINE: Desert Sword: Time for Answers

 BODY:
Suddenly, in the wake of President Bush's declaration of possible war against Iraq, members of Congress clamor to be heard. They're acting not merely within their rights but within their responsibilities.
President Bush deserved and won wide support for creating Desert Shield in Saudi Arabia. But now, with hardly a justifying word, he has transformed that policy into Desert Sword. Mr. Bush, who has repeatedly left himself open to criticism for failing to articulate America's interests in the crisis, can now be called to account. 
 Though some members would have preferred a special session of Congress, this purpose can probably be satisfactorily met by the hearings the Senate has now scheduled. It would be folly for the White House to ignore the unease expressed in varying ways by Democratic senators like Sam Nunn, Claiborne Pell and Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Republicans like Richard Lugar of Indiana.
What all these voices are saying is that Congress has a rightful constitutional share in war-making decisions. Congress and the public need deliberate discussion of:
* Mr. Bush's abrupt turn from a policy of deter- and-defend to one of offensive capability;
* His sudden impatience with the effectiveness of the international sanctions against Iraq;
* His concept of the alliance arrayed against Iraq, for now and in the future.
Calls for a declaration of war seem premature, as do proposals to invoke the War Powers Act. Congress chose before adjourning to accept Mr. Bush's claim that American forces in Saudi Arabia were in no imminent danger, thereby avoiding the act's 60-day clock.
But the newly announced buildup has stretched to the limit the initial rationale for ducking the war powers argument. Well-wishing senators complain that they have been given little more than generalities at briefings in which even the Secretary of Defense deflects legitimate questions, saying lamely, "That's above my pay grade."
"If ever a blockade might work, it's here," says Senator Moynihan, who has yet to hear a comprehensive appraisal of the effect of United Nations sanctions on Iraq's economy. And there are other questions, like why the new buildup was announced before the U.N. Security Council could adopt a use-of-force resolution.
The unease is heightened by how much Mr. Bush has vacillated in declaring his objectives. He wanted to deter an Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia; free Kuwait, uphold world law, defend the American way of life, protect American lives and build a regional security system that would assure access to gulf oil. Now his Secretary of State proclaims that the real purpose is to save American jobs.
As a crisis manager, the President has performed admirably; as a mobilizer of political support, he has veered all over the lot. He may well have a solid case but still hasn't made it. A full-dress televised hearing will offer a proper forum, and test. The questions keep reverberating.

SECTION: Section A; Page 29; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 747 words

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Running Scared

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: BUDAPEST

 BODY:
Every country in the East has its own post-Communist problems. But they all share the discovery that things had gotten much worse than anyone realized.
Dismantling Communist structures has aggravated economic and social difficulties, demolishing old forms of organization and authority without yet being able to replace them. But the extent of collapse revealed how shaky it all was, how much was stripped away, left to rot from within, emptied of resources. 
 An American with senior government experience remarked recently that it was a massive intelligence failure by the West. He was referring particularly to East Germany, which had been considered the one relatively successful Communist economy, and it too turned out to be a sump pit.
It is hard to fault intelligence, though. There weren't secrets to steal. The leaders didn't know themselves. The most carefully planned, informant-ridden, intrusive regimes knew far less about their own societies than the casual, variegated West does about itself.
Then what were we so worried about? Why did the free world feel so threatened, not only by the Soviet arsenal but also by subversion?
A Western cold-war conspiracy to fight what seemed imminent danger is coming to light in Europe. It is already rocking the Italian Government and will touch many others. There was, it is revealed, an organized underground, provided with hidden arms depots, prepared to launch guerrilla wars and resistance in the event of invasion from the East or overthrow of democratic governments from within.
There were different epic names for the operations -- "Gladio" in Italy (manned by secret gladiators), "Rose in the Wind" in France, "Red Fleece" in Belgium. They were sometimes directed, but generally coordinated, by NATO with participation of the C.I.A. and British secret service.
Former C.I.A. Director William Colby has confirmed some of this in recent interviews with Italian journalists. They also reported that meetings of the clandestine groups were held as recently as a few weeks ago in Brussels, though several governments claim it all ended by the 80's.
The Italian Government has said there were 139 caches of clandestine arms, explosives and communications equipment of which 127 were recovered years ago. They haven't accounted for the rest.
But Rome has been scandalized because a junior judge in Venice, investigating the operations, has issued a subpoena to the President of the Republic, Francesco Cossiga, who had served as Minister of Defense and Minister of Interior. Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti, who has been in most governments for the last 40 years, refused opposition demands for a parliamentary commission.
The suspicion in Italy, Belgium and other countries is that the groups were used for domestic political purposes, possibly even terrorism to justify government crackdowns and defense preparedness. We are just hearing the beginnings of this. Sweden and Spain were also affected. No doubt there were Communist offensive conspiracies. But the question now is why democracies felt so weak, or if these were counterplots to undermine democratic governments in the name of anti-Communism.
The "Red menace" was taken deadly seriously by many rational people. One reason perhaps was U.S. demobilization at the end of World War II when Europe was still ravaged and chaotic, while Stalin managed to conceal the weakness of the Soviet Union. He did expect to take over most of Western Europe.
But his real weapon was ideological and intellectual. It is hard now to understand the Communist appeal in the postwar period. The Communists had the allure of early and vigorous anti-Fascism when many had ignored the Nazis or collaborated.
They promised a brave new world after the horrors of the Depression and war, with a moral vision of justice. They preached that money, not Moscow, was the root of all evil, and the frenetic crusade against Moscow only seemed to confirm their argument. Jean-Pierre Chevenement, now French Defense Minister, was among the many who responded proudly, "I am anti-anti-Communism."
All that is gone, dust, like medieval disputes about the sex of angels. What is left? Just money, material well-being? It was never enough, and it isn't the reason the West won the long struggle so dramatically. Freedom, consent were the bulwarks, and they proved their strength. When they are undermined, it is from within. The things we do running scared are what hurt us most.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Rally on Weak Output Data

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The rally in the Government bond market continued yesterday, as traders pushed up prices of some Treasury securities as much as a point and long-term interest rates fell to their lowest levels since the Persian Gulf crisis began.
The catalyst behind yesterday's move was a Federal Reserve report that industrial output had dropped eight-tenths of a percent in October, the first decline since April. 
 The drop in the industrial production index was slightly more than had been expected, but economists and bond dealers said the depth of the decline was not as significant as its breadth.
 
 'In a Downturn'
 "Sector after sector, product group after product group, showed declines," said Joseph Liro, a vice president and economist at S. G. Warburg Securities Inc. "The report shows that the economy is in a downturn with negative growth."
Analysts said the report, which was released just before members of the Federal Reserve Board's Open Market Committee met in Washington, would provide further ammunition to those members of the committee who are arguing for an easing in monetary policy.
"The Open Market Committee is far from united about the need to ease policy, because there is still a lot of concern about the inflation outlook," said Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon National Bank in Pittsburgh "But with these production figures, it could be that October was the month that the recession started. I think that possibility is enough for the Fed to lower the funds rate by another 25 basis points."
The Fed gave no indication yesterday that it had altered its policy stance. But Mr. Liro and other analysts said the central bank could give a signal as early as today that it is pushing down the overnight rate on bank loans in the Federal funds market from 7.75 percent, its current target level.
 
 Short-Term Rates Steady
 An easing by the Fed would be most closely reflected in the price of short-term Treasury securities, and their prices, which have risen strongly in the last week, were little changed yesterday.
The big gains were posted in bonds, and analysts said the rally among long-term securities could continue whether the Federal funds rate is cut quickly or not.
By late yesterday, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 102 3/8, up a full point, or $10 for each $1,000 face value, to yield 8.52 percent. That is the lowest level since early August. In London trading on Monday, the issue was offered at a price to yield 8.54 percent. The Government securities market was closed in the United States on Monday in observance of Veterans Day.
"Another test of the 8.50 percent yield level appears likely in the next couple of days regardless of whether or not the Fed signals an easing move on Wednesday," analysts at MMS International, an economic information service company, said in their daily market commentary.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 27/32 late yesterday, up 1/2 point, to yield 8.37 percent. But the 7 3/4 percent two-year notes rose by just 1/32, to 100 10/32, to yield 7.57 percent.
 
 Bill Rates Unchanged
 Interest rates on new three-month and six-month Treasury bills auctioned yesterday were little changed from their levels a week ago.
At the auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.05 percent, down slightly from an average rate of 7.07 percent at last week's sale.
Bids on six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 7.02 percent, compared with an average of 7.05 percent rate a week ago.
With the economy losing steam and the supply of new Treasury issues limited to short-term securities for the next month or so, analysts said the rally could be sustained for some time.
"Over the next six months, there is more to go on the upside in price and downside in yield," said Roger Froelich, president of Technical Dimensions, a bond market advisory service in Mount Kisco, N.Y.
Mr. Froelich said he was "optimistic, but not wildly bullish" about the market. He added that during the next six months the rates on three-month Treasury bills could fall by half a percentage point from current levels and that bond yields could decline to 8 1/8 percent.
 
 Corporate Sector Is Active
 The decline in long-term interest rates encouraged a number of corporations to price new debt issues yesterday.
Among the issuers was Hyrdo-Quebec, which offered $500 million of 40-year debentures through an underwriting syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation.
The 9 1/2 percent securities, which mature Nov. 15, 2030, were priced at 99.425, to yield 9.556 percent, or 1.03 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds at the time of pricing.
The securities, which are noncallable for life, are rated AA-3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In addition, the Pennzoil Company offered $250 million of 15-year debentures through an underwriting group led by Lehman Brothers.
The 10 1/4 percent securities, which mature Nov. 1, 2005, were priced at 99.36 to yield 10.341 percent, or 1.95 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-3 by Moody's and A-minus by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most issues rose by about 1/8 point to 1/4 point.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said prices of most widely quoted issues rose by about 1/4 point.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
The Wrong Strategy

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
President Bush has adopted exactly the wrong strategy in his decision to send heavy reinforcements to American troops in the Middle East, at the same time canceling plans to rotate home some of the forces already there.
By sending these signals that a war against Iraq is about to be launched, Mr. Bush has turned his back on a harder but perhaps more promising Presidential task -- preparing the American public for what may appear to be a long stalemate in the desert, while the embargo and boycott he has organized actually are squeezing Iraq into a resolution of the Mideast crisis. 
 The President obviously, almost openly, is trying to convince Saddam Hussein that he faces a choice between war and retreat. Unless Mr. Hussein soon backs out of Kuwait, that is, the U.S.-led coalition facing him along the Saudi Arabian border will attack, force his withdrawal and perhaps drive on into Iraq itself.
The trouble with this strategy is that it relies on convincing the Iraqi leader of something inherently improbable, which he is unlikely to accept despite Mr. Bush's signals.
Mr. Hussein knows that a war on Iraq would shatter the anti-Iraq coalition. As Secretary of State Baker learned on his recent tour, the idea of war wins little support among any of the coalition partners except the "front-line" Arab leaders most threatened by Saddam Hussein. And it's not certain that even they could lead their populations into full-scale war against a brother Arab nation. Nor is it clear that U.N. support for the embargo and blockade could be extended to approval of war.
Mr. Hussein can hardly be blind to the fact that the U.S. population is anything but eager for a war with Iraq. Not only is the purpose of such a war unclear -- for oil? to restore the emirate in Kuwait? to resist Iraqi aggression? -- but so is the necessity, the vital interest. Until it is crystal clear that the embargo and blockade are futile, many Americans will be hesitant to accept heavy casualties for any of these goals.
Questions now being openly raised by Senator Sam Nunn, the Democrats' most respected military spokesman, Senator Pat Moynihan and others only emphasize what Mr. Hussein must know already -- that Mr. Bush would not have undivided popular support for a Mideast war, particularly if he launched it soon.
If, moreover, as some statements and events suggest he might, the President undertook that war without either Congressional or U.N. authority, antiwar sentiment would quickly become powerful. But if he did seek such backing, doubts at the U.N. and in Congress would emphasize the opposition; and going to these bodies would destroy the possibility of a surprise attack.
Finally, Mr. Hussein probably is confident that his battle-hardened and desert-bred forces, fighting on the defensive, would make a strong showing -- perhaps even prevail, or force a stalemate, and certainly inflict horrendous casualties. Americans, with their goals unclear, their interest uncertain, their sons ill prepared and ill equipped for desert combat, would not be willing for long to sustain such a war.
So the Iraqi leader will be a "hard sell," no matter how many troops Mr. Bush deploys. The worst threat to Mr. Hussein, in fact, is not necessarily a military attack but the constant and increasing economic pressures of the boycott and the embargo. These weapons, already having some effect, will have even more as the months creep along -- at some point inevitably undermining popular morale, Iraqi fighting capacity and Mr. Hussein himself.
The problem with relying on such pressures, Administration spokesmen and war hawks now assert, is that the U.S. public will grow tired of waiting for them to succeed, and will gradually lose interest in seeing them enforced around the world. Saddam Hussein, in this view, has only to wait to be home free.
It's an odd idea, however, that bloody and destructive war would be more acceptable than peaceful, long-term pressures. If Mr. Bush, instead of threatening that war, would focus his efforts on persuading Americans to sustain those pressures, who can be sure the people would not respond? Has the "bully pulpit" lost its ability to persuade Americans -- in Harry Truman's phrase -- "to do what they ought to do without persuasion"?
President Bush, principally, organized the boycott and blockade and preached their necessity. Did he mean it? Or did he only seek to gain time to prepare for war? And who is it, anyway, that seems most nearly to be losing patience -- the American public or George Bush?

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Canadian Bank To Open U.S. Unit

 BODY:
The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, which has assets of more than $85 billion (United States) and is one of the 10 largest banks in North America, yesterday announced the formation of a group specializing in public finance to be based in New York.
The bank, which has headquarters in Toronto, said the new operation would focus on providing credit enhancements that improve the marketability and distribution of tax-exempt and taxable debt issues of states, municipalities and revenue-based authorities. Besides the traditional tax and revenue-supported bond issues, the bank said it would also work with special issuers of private financing.
Credit enhancements like insurance or letters of credit issued by banks provide an added measure of safety for a bond issue, making it more attractive to investors. Enhancements can also allow the issuer to borrow at lower interest rates.

HEADLINE: MAN IN THE NEWS: WENDELL HAMPTON FORD;
The No. 2 Man for the Democrats in the Senate

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Two years ago, Senator Wendell H. Ford stood up to face his Democratic colleagues and acknowledged that he had lost in his attempt to unseat Senator Alan Cranston as Democratic whip.
 It was an embarrassing concession for the Kentucky Senator, whom many consider to be one of the Senate's consumate insiders and deal makers. He had entered the race late, and miscalculated his chances of unseating Mr. Cranston of California, who had held the No. 2 Senate post since 1977. But before sitting down, Senator Ford announced that as of that date he was running for whip in 1990. 
 Today, with Mr. Cranston having withdrawn from the race because of prostate cancer, the 66-year-old Senator from Kentucky was approved by voice vote.
 
'Like a Birthday'
 "It's like a birthday," he said, adding he had enough commitments to win even if Senator Cranston had stayed in the race.
That will never be known. But almost everyone agreed that the Senate Democrats have added to their leadership a 15-year Senate veteran skilled in the old-style politics of back room deals, quiet negotiations and handshakes. "I believe that politics is the art of compromise," he says.
He is seldom seen giving speeches on the floor of he Senate. "Why make a speech when you can sit down with your colleagues and work something out?" he says.
It is a strikingly different style from the grandiose speeches, public confrontations and histrionics that have sometimes marked Senate debates in recent years. But it has served Mr. Ford and his home state well.
In his last election. in 1986, he received 75 percent of the vote, in part because he is one of the state's most popular politicians and his down-home style appeals to many constituents.
 
Serves His Constituency
 He serves the economic interests of big and small business, including the tobacco, liquor, coal and horsebreeding industries. And he has vigorously opposed excise taxes, export tariffs and Federal funds for competing businesses.
When Senator John Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, proposed an amendment to stop export subsidies on tobacco, Senator ord not only stood in the way of the proposal, but also threatened to retaliate against Rhode Island.
Senator Lloyd Bentson, Democrat of Texas, said of his colleague, "He's a deal maker and has very effectively defended the economic interest of his state."
In an interview this afternoon, Mr. Ford, who has a leathery complexion, square face and gentle Southern drawl, outlined his approach to politics.
"My daddy told me when you have the votes, let the other guy talk," he said. "And never leave the table without winning at least something."
He defended the need for a strong tobacco and distilled spirits industry in his state, despite the adverse publicity both have been receiving.
 
In Praise of Cash Crops
 "You have a health side to this debate, but we also have an economic side to this debate," he said. "A lot of kids in our state can go to college because they have an acre of tobacco. Spirits, that is an industry that we rely on heavily for employment in our state."
But he said he decided not to fight the excise tax on tobacco and distilled spirits "because it was a done deal."
Once elected today, he quickly fell in line with the the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, and declined to give his opinions on the Persian Gulf crisis.
"Senator Mitchell is the party spokesman, and he should speak for us," he said. "In Kentucky we are known for our horses. I plan on being a work horse and not a show horse."
Some say it was the involvement in day-to-day affairs of Senator Mitchell and his predecessor, Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, that diminished Senator Cranston's role as whip.
Officially, the post of whip is designed to monitor party sentiment on important issues, count votes and pressure wavering lawmakers. That role should well suit Senator Ford, who owns a love for such details of governing.
As chaimran of the Senate Rules Committee, he has had little to say about geopolitical matters, but he controls things like committee budgets, room assignments, computer systems, parking spaces and expense vouchers -- items that matter little to the public but very much to senators.
 
'A Dumb Country Boy'
 Wendell Hampton Ford, born on Sept. 8, 1924, to Ernest and Irene Ford, likes to couch his stry as one of rags to riches. He has referred to himself as "a dumb country boy with dirt between his toes."
That might be the result of his early experience. Growing up in Thruston, Ky., he graduated from Daviess County High School, attented the University of Kentucky but did not graduate.
He went into his father's insurance brokerage business and by the early 1960's had entered Kentucky politics, getting elected state senator, lieutenant Governor and then Governor in 1971. He has been in the Senate since 1975.
He has been married to his wife, Jean, for 47 years. They have two children and five grandchildren.
Mr. Ford is also an avid angler -- "We just take a stick, string and a cork and throw it into the water" -- as well as a duck hunter. He says he tried to get away duck hunting with his son Steven, "because it gives us a chance to talk without anything around butting in."
And, reflecting a touch of bitterness from his run-in with Senator Cranston two years ago, he says he hopes to rejuvenate the whip post.
"I think there ought to be new life and vision in the post," he said. "Being more visual on the floor, helping senators get their bills and amendments up for votes."

HEADLINE: An Impish Coloratura Who Takes Risks

BYLINE: By ELEANOR BLAU

 BODY:
In the role of Oscar, the impish page in the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Verdi's "Ballo in Maschera," Harolyn Blackwell risks perils beyond the coloratura demands of her vocal line, because her character is so active.
"He's a nonstop chatterbox, running around and being the life of the party," said Ms. Blackwell, who will repeat the role at tonight's performance and who has won high praise for her silvery tone and the charm of her portrayal. At times, she faces unexpected problems. 
 For example, in Act I the other evening, the 5-foot-1 soprano tried to snatch a heavy cape off the shoulders of a dignified judge, a piece of stage business worked out for this production, but it wouldn't budge.
Last month, on opening night, the cape yielded all right, but Ms. Blackwell's hat flew off as she twirled around. She picked it up, put it back on and dashed across the stage, where she lost it again. Next scene, another hat of hers dropped and, in Act III, off came her belt. "Oh, she's losing her clothes," people backstage teased her, she recalled.
 
Soaring Above Everyone
 As for the singing, she said, "It's tricky, because the voice is always sparkling and very staccato."
"The first aria is a combination of very staccato and then very legato, back and forth," she continued. "And in the quintet, this long, gorgeous line, you just have to soar above everyone."
"It's a very fulfilling role," she added with a grin.
The soprano, who made her Metropolitan Opera debut in 1987, chatted with animation about her role and her career the other day in her sublet apartment near Lincoln Center, a high-rise perch with fantastic street views and sounds of howling winds.
She said she was pleased that the director, Piero Faggioni, had allowed her to make Oscar as mischievous as she had envisioned him.
In previous productions, her portrayal has stressed more of Oscar's "elegant" side, she said. Ms. Blackwell has played the role in Hamburg, Germany, then Chicago and Toronto. The Chicago production, in the 1986-87 season, marked her debut with the Lyric Opera, and, as in the Met production, it starred Luciano Pavarotti as her ill-fated master, the King.
"I adore him," Ms. Blackwell said. He has given her singing tips, she added, and is easy to act with, sometimes giving her a playful nudge onstage, for instance, in the spirit of regal affection.
 
Only Musician in the Family
 She grew up in Washington, where her father, Harold, for whom she was named, was a redevelopment specialist with the Department of Housing and Urban Development and her mother taught physical education and health at the University of the District of Columbia.
Ms. Blackwell, who has three sisters and a brother, is the only musician in her family. She began piano lessons at the age of 10 and, months later, added voice lessons, with Nancy Notargiacomo, who had been her fourth-grade teacher.
That was an early start for a singer, she noted, but her teacher did not push her into arias or other vocalizing inappropriate for a child. Ms. Blackwell learned first to breathe properly, from the diaphragm, she said. She was introduced to that technique at the start of her first lesson, when her teacher instructed her to lie on the floor and pant like a dog.
"I was a very shy child," she recalled, "and my zest for life I attribute to her. I joke with her saying, 'You've created this monster!' "
She performed in musical theater in school and in community theater, but majored in education at the Catholic University of America in Washington and taught in parochial schools for a year. Feeling that "a part of me was not satisfied," she said, she returned to the university while still teaching, and received a graduate degree in music performance.
 
A Finalist in Met Auditions
 Soon she auditioned for a revival of "West Side Story" and found herself on Broadway in 1980, singing "Somewhere" from the orchestra pit and thereby confusing audience members, whom she could see searching for the source of the sound. She was also on stage in the musical, with which she toured the United States and abroad for two and a half years. She then joined an apprenticeship program of the Lyric Opera and in 1983 became a finalist in the Met's national auditions.
She made her Met debut four years later as Pousette in "Manon," then appeared as Xenia in "Boris Godunov," and also made her New York recital debut at Town Hall. Last year at the Met, she performed her first Adele in "Die Fledermaus." She will sing her first Susanna in "Le Nozze di Figaro" at the Met next May, and her first Zerlina in "Don Giovanni" next year.
So for now, she is focusing on "bread and butter roles," she said, and hearing, with some amazement, changes in her voice. "In the last two years, it's become a brighter, larger sound," she said, "and I'm feeling more comfortable with the coloratura."
She had thought of herself as a lyric soprano, and even, briefly, as a mezzo, but discovered in graduate school that her range was greater than she had known.
"My voice teacher said: 'Oh my God, you have all those notes. I think you are a lyric coloratura,' " Ms. Blackwell recounted. "I said I didn't sing above high C. I had never really used this part of my tessitura. And I was singing high G's and A's, unknown territory."
These days, she said, she is getting more into what her current teacher, Shirley Emmons, calls the "core" of her voice. "I'll be on one particular note and not getting it," she said, "that's not it, not it, and then, all of a sudden, the piano strings start to vibrate and I know I'm there."

HEADLINE: Editors Wanted; English Helpful

BYLINE: By Ken Jacobson; Ken Jacobson is editor in chief of Metals Week.

 BODY:
"Enclosed is my resume in response to Sunday's New York Times."
Well, there's a whole stack of applications here. Let's look at another. 
 "Enclosed is my resume in response to my search for an editorial/ creative position."
This is an editor's job we're offering. They can't all be like this.
"My experience in the production of newsletters, magazines, directories and on-line data bases puts me head and shoulders above the crowd of applicants you have no doubtedly been inundated with."
Fortunately, this assessment was wrong. Unfortunately, it was not as far wrong as one might expect -- or hope. The publication I work for received more than 80 applications after advertising in this newspaper; these submissions provided a catalogue of bad grammar, improper word use and plain, old-fashioned sloppiness.
But perhaps "old-fashioned" is, in the present context, itself an improper term. This editor fears that not only the sloppiness but the other shortcomings so frequently found in his small sampling of resumes and cover letters may speak more of the future than of the past.
That reporters and editors -- most of them young, all of them with college degrees -- would express themselves so poorly and show such carelessness while engaged in the solemn business of pursuing their careers raises disturbing questions about America's standards, both educational and professional.
This is not to say that the candidates lacked eagerness. One promised that he could "be compulsively detail oriented at will," another that he would bring to the job "an avowed interest in foreign affairs." Nor were they shy about their accomplishments. "My career," wrote one woman, "has been spent in journalism and the not-for-profit sector with forays in government and television." Another claimed she had "doubled [the] clientele base" of a past employer "from 150 to 400."
Some of the grammatical lapses were particularly ill-timed. "The description of responsibilities for the editor's position," wrote one young man, "correspond greatly with those of my previous job as a legal assistant. Clarity, consistency, and proper grammar are necessities that cannot be overlooked" -- except, apparently, when it comes to the agreement of subject and predicate.
In fact, a question that bubbled up through the resumes was whether those submitting them realized that part of what they were communicating was the amount of thought and care they might be expected to put into their work.
If they had, would they have failed in numerous instances to use the spell checkers on their word processors? Would there have been such self-subverting claims as: "I am able to research, organize information, simplify complex material, write on technical topics for both lay and professional readers, copy edit, proof read . . .?" Or such ironic missteps as: "I belive [sic] I have experience of all the facets needed for your position." Because we have a small staff, I perform many tasks. I serve as the only copy editor."
In a personal sense, I have little to complain about; on the contrary, glaring errors make it easier to sort applications. In a larger sense, however, I am worried. With the information age upon us, English, still the leading international language, has emerged as one of our country's most precious natural resources. But all natural resources require judicious management. The U.S. has already lost its comparative advantage in many sectors of the world economy. It would be a shame to surrender this advantage as well.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Toy Stocks Weak At Crucial Season

BYLINE: By Eben Shapiro

 BODY:
THE toy industry has been surprisingly resistant to hard times. Past recessions proved that parents will give up a lot of things before they will disappoint their children on Christmas.
Nonetheless, the stock market seems largely to be ignoring past trends and focusing more on bleak expectations for the economy and the evaporation of consumer confidence. A number of toy industry stocks are trading close to their 52-week lows.
And there are indeed some indications that this Christmas season may run counter to past trends. Cautious retailers, wary of being left with shelves of unbought goods, are keeping inventories low on all items, including toys. And fewer people are visiting shopping malls. "What the stocks are saying is, 'There might be somewhat more cyclicality here than meets the eye,' " said Steven Eisenberg, an analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company.
Analysts and toy company executives say that specific products, along with overall economic conditions, help to determine the health of the $13-billion-a-year industry. "A strong product trend can buck an economic trend," Ms. French said.
Gary M. Jacobson, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company, said the recession year of 1982 "was a great year for the toy industry." He added, "Parents know what a slowdown is, but kids don't."
B. J. French, a spokeswoman for the Tonka Corporation, agrees. "Even in the recession of the early 1980's," she said, "toy sales seemed to go up."
Nintendo continues to captivate toy buyers, andthe Japanese machines and their accompanying games, made under license by a number of companies, are again expected to be best sellers. Sales of electronic games are projected at $4 billion this year, more than 20 percent of all toy sales. Still, analysts say the video craze may finally be peaking, a result of boredom and saturation.
In any case, American toy makers largely missed the video boom. Mattel Inc., for instance, was preoccupied with financial problems several years ago and was unable to develop competitive video products. It has since found a way to take advantage of the craze with its Power Glove, which slips over a player's hand, replacing the stick control.
Hasbro Inc. spent millions of dollars developing Nemo, its own electronic video game, but never brought it out.
Going forward, any decline in video games' popularity should free a lot of dollars for other items, to the benefit of traditional toy makers like Hasbro and Mattel.
The Barbie doll by Mattel is experiencing strong sales, and large dolls are also selling well. "You are seeing emotional items doing better," said Mr. Jacobson of Kidder, Peabody. Sales are strong again for Cabbage Patch dolls, which have belonged to Hasbro since it acquired Coleco Industries in 1989.
When it comes to individual toy stocks, a mixed picture exists. "I like the two big guys, and I'd avoid everything else," Mr. Jacobson said, referring to Mattel and Hasbro.
Mattel, which has undergone a significant revamping in the last few years, is a favorite of analysts. Its stock price has nearly tripled in two years. Barbie accounted for about half of the company's 1989 sales of $1.23 billion, analysts say. Mattel's stock closed at $19.125 yesterday, down 12.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange.
Analysts cite Hasbro as a model of diversification, which makes it less dependent on the hit products that typically drive the industry. Nonetheless, investors want the company to develop a substitute for its flagging G.I. Joe and Transformer lines. A share of Hasbro closed at $15 yesterday, up 75 cents on the American Stock Exchange.
Heavy debts or concerns about management have caused analysts to steer away from other companies. "Tonka is at a critical state," Mr. Jacobson said, citing the company's indebtedness, a result of its 1987 acquisition of Kenner Parker.
Lewis Galoob Toys Inc., which makes miniature vehicles known as Micro Machines, is out of favor for its inability to develop a core line of products to sustain the company between hits.
In the short term, toy sales should benefit from changing demographics, Mr. Jacobson said, noting that last year there were nearly four million births in the United States, the most in 30 years. Plenty of money will be spent on these children of the baby-boom generation, he said, because there are more two-income households, more affluent grandparents, and more divorces, which often lead to each parent's spending heavily on toys.
But Mr. Jacobson also says that children are growing up faster and tend to quit playing with toys at a younger age. "Twenty years ago, 12-year-old kids played with dolls and cars," he wrote in a recent report. "Today they are most likely interested in CD's, movies and the opposite sex."

HEADLINE: Bucharest Journal;
The Hurdles Are Many, but the Reward Is a Child

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Romania

 BODY:
Moved by pictures she had seen of the desperate conditions in Romanian orphanages, Linda Tresgaskis came here from Austin, Tex., for the first time last July to find a year-old child to take home with her.
She recently came through a crash course in the ordeals of Romanian adoption with flying colors -- and a 2-week-old son named Charles Michael. 
 Her friend from Rochester, N.Y., who had come hoping to adopt two or three babies under one year old, is leaving with a 7-year-old daughter, a 2 1/2-year-old son, an infant and prospects for adopting a fourth baby, not yet born.
"It is funny how it works out," said the new mother, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "You cannot predict which ones you will fall in love with."
In the last few months, the adoption of Romanian children by people from the West has been steadily increasing, after a halt last summer as the Bucharest Government established new regulations. Veterans of the process say the new rules, instituting formal court proceedings in the place of President Ion Iliescu's personal signature, are still ragged, and the experience exhausting.
 
Hardships Worth Enduring
 But those who come are prepared to put up with anything so long as they can leave with a healthy child, a prize that is increasingly hard for adoptive parents to find in North America and Western Europe, particularly for single mothers like Ms. Tresgaskis.
The plight of Romania's abandoned children -- offspring of a Communist system that first forbade abortions for most women and then made it economically impossible for them to care for large families -- has opened up new reserves in the worldwide search for children in need of homes.
Under pressure from relief organizations, the Romanian Government is now trying to coordinate aid for the 130,000 children left stranded in 379 institutions, of whom almost half are considered mentally or physically handicapped.
A recent report produced some chilling findings: of the 32 hostels for handicapped children, not one is considered fit for use, and yet the children remain. Calculating the shortages of food, clothes, materials and medicines, the Government estimated it needs $27 million in immediate aid, $100 million for the long term.
Foreign adoptions, properly controlled, are one way to rescue some of the children, although proportionately the numbers are small. No national figure is available, but the flow seems to be steady.
Last summer, 67 families from Canada came here as a group, and left with 130 children. One estimate put the number of adoptions by Americans by September at 160.
 
Fewer Newborns Available
 Since January, when the draconian anti-abortion law was lifted, the number of births in Romania has fallen and the number of abortions has soared. As a result fewer newborns are available for adoption, and some organizations are turning their attention to needier children.
As they tour the orphanages and asylums, the new parents are walked past cribs of children -- often wet, unwashed and with running noses -- and asked which one they want. Older children besiege foreign visitors, calling the women "mama" and asking to be taken away on a plane.
"It feels like shopping for shoes," Ms. Tresgaskis said. "It can be an awful experience, saying no, not this one, not that one. Never in your wildest dreams did you ever think you would be in a situation like that."
At the Hotel President here, a former guest house of the Romanian Communist Party that has become a popular campground for adoptive parents, the war stories told around dinner tables are all about the bureaucratic bungling, petty corruption and 19th-century working conditions that plague the collection of the necessary adoption papers.
The court procedure can take as little as 15 minutes, or as long as five hours. In one rural town, the proceedings ended up including five judges and a full jury, drawn from citizens called in off the street to pass judgment on why one American family that already had four children wanted to adopt two more.
In this baffling maze, the prospective parents have nowhere to turn but to each other. They complain that the United States and other embassies provide conflicting, sometimes inaccurate information and that in many cases their Romanian lawyers know little more than they do.
Those who come to adopt come prepared to stay for weeks, sometimes months. Not knowing how old their child will be, they arrive with clothes and diapers for all ages, and then swap among themselves. Other essentials include dollars and cigarettes, the most acceptable form of currency in Romania's current economic crisis.
"When I came I was handing out candy bars and packs of cigarettes," said one frustrated American. "Now I am up to $20 bills, and by tomorrow it may be 50's."
 
Costs Relatively Low
 Still, the costs are relatively low. Ms. Tregaskis figured that she spent $5,000 for everything, including one round-trip ticket, hotel room, taxis, taxes and various fees. Lawyers' fees, which include a mandatory $606 state tax, can range from $1,000 to $2,500, but after bitter experience many new parents advise doing without lawyers altogether.
To save money, people can also live in private apartments, where they can stay for $20 or less a night. But often they find the hardships of Romanian life more than they bargained for -- sometimes no refrigerator and elevator and now, in parts of Bucharest, water only at certain times of the day.
The misery of ordinary life in Romania, little improved since the revolution last December, when Nicolae Ceausescu was overthrown and executed, hits the adoptive parents hard.
"I have traveled a lot, I have been in the interior of Mexico, I have seen poor people in our own country," Ms. Tresgaskis said. "But in Europe, you don't expect the ignorance, the lack of basics, this kind of poverty. When you see the homes, you can understand why the mothers had to give the children up."
Getting the legal consent from the biological parents is emotionally draining, although in some cases the parents may not have seen their institutionalized children in years. Some people report cases where the Romanian families have pressed for money or some kind of material help.
But most mothers who give their newborn infants directly to foreigners do so hoping that their child will have a better life. "The only way she could handle it was to block out all emotions," Ms. Tresgaskis said of the 23-year-old woman who gave birth to Charles Michael.
Ms. Tresgaskis, a 40-year-old nursing home administrator, said she wants her son to know where he came from. "I want him to know his heritage," she said. "I want him to know that his country is in the middle of a crisis and that his mother did what she did out of love."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I want him to know his heritage," said Linda Tresgaskis, a 40-year-old nursing home administrator from Texas, who adopted a son, Charles Michael, from Romania. "I want him to know that his country is in the middle of a crisis, and that his mother did what she did out of love." (Zigy Kaluzny for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: S.& L. Woes Creep Into California

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14

 BODY:
California has had more than its share of savings and loan fraud and mismanagement. But a robust real estate market has largely spared savings institutions here from the crippling losses suffered by their counterparts in depressed housing markets in Texas, Colorado, Arizona and the Northeast -- at least until now.
No one is predicting a Texas-style collapse in California. But analysts and regulators are increasingly concerned with the potential effect of the recent sharp downturn in housing sales and prices on the state's savings and loans. California is home to nine of the country's ten largest institutions and accounts for nearly a quarter of all savings and loan assets. 
 "Whatever the driving force is, the California housing market may be hitting the wall, and we find it serious and disconcerting," said Eric I. Hemel, a savings and loan analyst at the First Boston Corporation, in a recent research report.
Savings institutions in the state remain confident that the problem will not become severe. Yet some admit to seeing an increase in missed mortgage payments as some sectors of the California economy slow and more homeowners lose jobs. Almost all institutions have been forced to add to their reserves for loan losses to reflect the weakening markets.
The biggest fear among regulators and analysts is that as housing prices fall, the California economy will slip into recession. In the most dire situation, further layoffs in faltering industries like aerospace and construction would leave many homeowners in the state unable to make their mortgage payments and collapsing home prices would leave them with no options but to sell at a loss or walk away from their house and let the lender foreclose.
Even if California's economy holds up, savings institutions will feel the impact of the real estate slowdown in the form of reduced demand for mortgages. That would diminish opportunities for new profits at a time when most of the institutions need additional earnings to help build the higher capital levels and loan-loss reserves now required by Federal regulators.
At the annual conference of the United States League of Savings Institutions in San Francisco this week, Timothy Ryan, the director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, said regulators had not yet seen signs of major trouble in the state. But he added that regulators were meeting regularly with the managements of the major California savings institutions to monitor the situation. "We're tracking these institutions very closely," Mr. Ryan said in response to a question at a news conference.
 
Sales Down Sharply
 Concerns about California real estate have grown in recent months as the volume of home sales plummeted and price declines became widespread in the state's populous coastal regions. In September, the most recent month for which figures are available, sales of existing homes were down 27 percent from the period a year earlier and down 11 percent from August, according to the California Association of Realtors. It was the slowest month for home sales in California in nearly six years.
The statewide median home price of $190,350 in September was down 4.6 percent from a year earlier, and the price decline in most of the coastal regions was even sharper. In Los Angeles, the median price fell 7.6 percent from the period a year earlier, to $205,000.
"Everything went wrong in September -- sales volumes slid, unsold inventories increased sharply and median prices continued their slow downward trend," said Mr. Hemel, the analyst, in his report.
 
Downturn Called Exaggerated
 It is unclear how long the decline will persist, and industry executives, displaying the stubborn optimism that continues to pervade many sectors of the California economy, object strongly to any suggestion that they are heading for disaster. They say that the downturn has been exaggerated, that it is a normal "correction" after a seven-year boom, and that their companies are sufficiently healthy to weather anything they can see on the horizon.
"We do not have a disaster in California," said Richard H. Deihl, the chairman of H. F. Ahmanson & Company, the parent of Home Savings of America, the nation's largest savings and loan. "If there is considerable unemployment we will have a problem, but you can say that about any place in the world at any time."
To some extent, though, savings institutions in California are already feeling the impact. Fears of a real estate collapse have driven down the stock prices of all the publicly traded companies, including healthy ones like Ahmanson, the Great Western Financial Corporation, the Golden West Financial Corporation and others.
Virtually all California savings and loan companies have also been forced to increase the reserves they set aside for possible losses on loans, in part to reflect the weakening residential real estate markets.
 
Concern About Economy Cited
 CalFed Inc. of Los Angeles, the parent of the California Federal Bank, reported a third-quarter loss of $92.3 million after adding to reserves for possible losses on residential real estate developments in the state. CalFed said its increased reserve reflected in part "the significant decline in the previously strong demand for new residential properties in Riverside, Orange and San Diego Counties during the third quarter as more and more home buyers, uncertain about the economic outlook, chose to defer their purchases." CalFed said it would accelerate its withdrawal from the real estate development business.
The HomeFed Corporation of San Diego, the parent of the HomeFed Bank, reported sharply lower third-quarter profits, primarily because of increasing troubles with commercial real estate and apartment loans, but also because "single-family market conditions in California worsened during the quarter," said Robert F. Adelizzi, HomeFed's chief executive.
Savings and loans in the state may be better off than they might have been without legislation enacted by Congress last year. The legislation, among other things, effectively required them to put more emphasis on residential mortgage lending, forcing many to greatly reduce their activities in commercial real estate, construction lending and real estate development.
 
Commercial Market Weaker
 Analysts and industry executives agree that residential lending is a far more stable business than financing the construction of office buildings and shopping centers. The commercial real estate markets in California are even weaker than the residential market, and analysts think some of the state's big commercial banks, which have lent heavily to developers of commercial properties as well as to homeowners, are even more vulnerable to a downturn than the savings and loans, despite the heavy concentration of savings and loan assets in real estate.
Savings institutions say that more mortgage loans are being paid late, but that so far they have not seen any significant increase in foreclosures on residential mortgages. Moreover, when they have foreclosed, the institutions appear to have resold the homes at prices high enough to avoid losses. Although prices are dropping in many areas of the state, most homes are still worth more than they were even two years ago. Homes purchased earlier than a few years ago have appreciated so much tat it would take a major crash to bring them below their original sales prices.
Home Savings of America, for example, lost money on just one of the seven foreclosed homes it has put on the market in the last two months in California. The loss was just $4,000, Mr. Deihl said, and occurred on the sale of a tiny, rundown house for $22,000 in Fresno. More typical was a house in Imperial Beach, purchased two and a half years ago for $133,000, Mr. Deihl said. When the institution foreclosed in August, the balance due on the loan was $132,000. The house quickly sold for $174,000.
 
Down Payments Increase
 Moreover, savings institutions have increased the down payments required for most home loans in recent years. Home Savings used to make as many as 30 percent of its mortgage loans with a down payment of less than 20 percent. Now only 10 percent of its new loans are made at that level.
Since higher down payments reduce the loan balance relative to the value of a house, they effectively give institutions a greater buffer against losses in the event of foreclosure. Higher down payments also lead homeowners to do more to avoid foreclosure, since they do not want to lose their investment.
Jonathan E. Gray, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, made a study earlier this year to assess the effects on several major California savings and loans of a Texas-style collapse in real estate. He determined that Golden West, Ahmanson and Great Western would suffer a reduction in earnings but no losses. CalFed and HomeFed would suffer losses, but would survive without a deep cut into their capital, he found. In all cases, the primary reason for the ability of the institutions to weather a collapse was the relatively low concentration of loans with small down payments.
Still, there are those who think Californa's financial institutions, including savings and loans, continue to be overly optimistic about the prospects for real estate and the state's economy in general, especially given the persistent problems in other parts of the nation.
"The deterioration of real estate in California is far greater than what commercial banks and savings and loans are saying publicly," said R. Dan Brumbaugh Jr., an economist who is a consultant to a House Banking subcommittee. "All of this talk about California somehow being immune, it's just silly."

HEADLINE: Fast Food and Bookstores Top List for Openings in '80's

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
In the last decade, Americans' love for fast food, reading, home electronics and sporting goods helped to cause a boom in specialty stores. But other changes in shopping habits and the population mix have led to only a slight overall gain in the number of retail establishments around the country, according to a new study.
From 1980 to 1990, fast-food restaurants, bookstores, consumer electronics stores, apparel stores and sporting goods outlets led the list of new stores. The largest declines were in automotive stores, gasoline service stations and general merchandise stores. The information was compiled by Audits and Surveys Inc., one of the country's largest marketing research companies. 
 The total number of stores rose only 6 percent, to 1,845,340, in the 1980's. That compares with a population gain of 11 percent and a 43 percent increase in total retail sales, the company said.
 
'Less Demand for Stores'
 "This means that there is now only 1 retail outlet per every 134 people against a ratio of 1 to 129 persons in 1980," said Solomon Dutka, chief executive officer of Audits and Surveys.
"The World War II baby boomers are getting older and their numbers are not being replaced by new births because Americans are having fewer children per household. And there are more single-person households and later marriages. All this, despite a still growing population, means that in many cities there is less demand for stores."
The data are compiled in the New York-based company's annual census of retail distribution, which is based on a nationwide sample of more than 40,000 retail and service stores. The survey was conducted in May and June and each store was visited by an interviewer from Audits and Surveys. The sample has a margin of error of 5 percent.
The number of fast-food stores rose 78 percent in the 10-year period, to 119,880 from 67,290. It was the largest increase of all types of stores, said Audits and Surveys, followed by a 76 percent jump in the number of bookstores, to 17,620 from 10,020.
Other big gainers were consumer electronics stores, up 54 percent, to 30,600 from 19,900, and chain drugstores, up 36 percent, to 18,230 from 13,400. The biggest losers were variety stores, down 38 percent, to 10,720, from 17,400, and gasoline service stations, down 32 percent, to 107,500 from 158,540.
 
Aging Population
 Several important factors influenced store openings and closings, Mr. Dutka said. He mentioned the aging population, the increase in the number of working women, large increases in the population of blacks and Hispanic people, and more double-income families.
With more women working outside the home, the trend of couples and families eating out is growing, as is the popularity of one-stop shopping locations, he said. "The double-income household also is creating a larger market for more expensive merchandise and also provides opportunities for people to spend more money for their leisure-time activities," Mr. Dutka said.
Americans are living longer and leading more active lives, Mr. Dutka said. "This is why the sporting goods are growing so much," he said.
Some kinds of local and neighborhood stores are increasing, in great part because the two fastest-growing population groups are those of Hispanic background and blacks, who prefer to shop locally, he said. "While overall U.S. population grew 11 percent in the decade, the number of Hispanics in the country rose 32 percent and blacks by 15 percent," Mr. Dutka said.

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Up 3.2% as Low Demand Continues

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks rose by 3.2 percent in early November, suggesting that sluggish retail demand for vehicles was continuing.
The American automotive industry has suffered from slow sales for more than a year. Analysts today did not regard the slight increase for the Nov. 1-10 period as a hopeful sign, since this year's sales were compared with exceptionally weak sales a year earlier.
 
Big Three's Sales Lower
 Ronald A. Glantz, automotive analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in San Francisco, described the vehicle sales figures for the period as "a little disappointing." He noted that the foreign auto makers that build cars in American plants posted larger gains than the Big Three auto makers. He also said that the Big Three's latest figures did not include seasonal fleet sales to car-rental companies, which ended recently. 
 Some automotive analysts have been bracing for disastrous vehicle sales in light of recent economic uncertainty connected with the Persian Gulf crisis. While not strong, the latest numbers did not match those gloomy expectations. "It continues to look as if the Middle East crisis and dropping consumer confidence had never happened," said David Healy, automotive analyst for Barclays de Zoete Wedd Research Inc.
"We'll have a better feel in the next few weeks," said Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company.
Over all, retail sales of American-built vehicles were 241,357, the nine domestic car makers said today, compared with 233,948 a year ago.
Car sales rose by 8 percent, to 154,943 in the period. On a seasonally adjusted basis, that equals an annual rate of 6.5 million. A year earlier, sales totaled 143,467, and the annual rate was 5.9 million.
 
Truck Sales Down
 Sales of light trucks, which are increasingly bought for personal transportation but are generally less fuel-efficient than cars, slipped by 6.4 percent, to 86,414, from 92,283 last year. The main reason was a 33 percent decline in truck sales at the Chrysler Corporation.
Chrysler said the sales of its mini-vans were off by 26 percent; those of its Jeep Cherokees were off by 29 percent, and purchases of its Dakota pickup trucks were off by 44 percent. Shortly after announcing its sales figures, Chrysler said it was increasing cash rebates on many of its 1990 and 1991 light-truck models, including a $1,000 rebate on all remaining 1989 and 1990 mini-vans.
"Clearly, Chrysler's Jeep Cherokee is losing some of its market share in the sport-utility segment to the Ford Explorer," Mr. Heinbach said.
Sales of Chrysler cars dropped by 9.1 percent, to 18,873.
 
Ford and G.M. Gain
 The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company each posted gains in cars and light trucks. Ford's car sales were 47,106, a gain of 7.5 percent, and light-truck sales rose by 1 percent, to 31,463. G.M. sold 68,895 cars in the period, a gain of 10.1 percent from a year earlier, and 37,744 light trucks, a 2.7 percent gain.
The Honda Motor Company sold 9,609 American-built cars, a gain of 29.3 percent. The Toyota Motor Corporation sold 6,028 cars built in the United States, an increase of 7.7 percent. The Nissan Motor Company sold 2,112 domestically built cars, a rise of 17.2 percent.
Car sales for the Mazda Motor Corporation totaled 925, a gain of 74.5 percent, while those for the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation were 1,048, an increase of 6.7 percent. Subaru, the American subsidiary of Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd., had sales of 347. Last year, Subaru was not producting cars in this country.
 
High Inventories
 Although the overall inventory of unsold vehicles is lower than it was a year ago, the softness in the light-truck segment has meant a ballooning supply. The Big Three are already planning production cuts at many American assembly plants because of what they expect to be continued soft demand.
Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade publication, said the nation had a 67-day supply of unsold cars as of Nov. 1, compared with a 77-day supply a year earlier. There was a 99-day supply of unsold light trucks on Nov. 1, compared with a 91-day supply a year ago, Ward's said.
A 65-day supply is considered average by many auto executives.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Touches Lows Against the Mark for 3d Day

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar touched new lows in a broad decline against foreign currencies yesterday, dragged down by continued fears that the Federal Reserve might move soon to lower interest rates to stimulate the United States economy.
The dollar hit record lows against the German mark for the third day in a row, with the mark touching 1.4700 before settling at 1.4726, down from Tuesday's 1.4782. 
 "The basic tone is bearish for the dollar because of adverse interest rates and the U.S. economy," said Earl I. Johnson, vice president at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank. "The mark is strong because of reunification, which is going to keep interest rates there strong."
 
Strength Against Pound
 The dollar showed strength only against the British pound, which sank amid a potential political shake-up in Britain. In New York, it cost $1.9600 to buy one pound, less expensive than Tuesday's $1.9635. In London, sterling weakened to $1.9615, from $1.9640 late Tuesday.
In the biggest threat to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's political survival since she won power more than 11 years ago, former Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine challenged Mrs. Thatcher for the leadership of the Government and the Conservative Party.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.28 yen, to a closing 129.05 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 129.52 yen. In New York, the dollar fell to close at 129.09 yen, down from 129.65 yen on Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.2470 Swiss francs, down from 1.2510; 4.9670 French francs, down from 4.9735; 1,111 Italian lire, down from 1,112, and 1.1631 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1662.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Leave Kuwait First, Saudis Say of Iraq Talks

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Efforts to convene an Arab summit meeting to avert war in the Persian Gulf appeared to collapse today when Saudi Arabia said it would not attend such a meeting unless Iraq agreed to withdraw from Kuwait.
During a visit to Abu Dhabi, the Saudi Foreign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, said a meeting would be a waste of time unless Iraq agreed in advance to abide by United Nations Security Council and Arab League resolutions calling for its unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait and the restoration of the legitimate government there. 
 "Any Arab meeting will yield no fruit, or result, unless Iraq agrees to abide by the decisions of the Cairo Arab summit and international resolutions, which call for Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait," Prince Saud was quoted as saying by the United Arab Emirates News Agency.
At the Cairo meeting on Aug. 10, a narrow majority of Arab League nations voted not only to demand Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait and the restoration of the al-Sabah family, but also to send a pan-Arab force to defend Saudi Arabia.
Prince Saud's statement today reflects Saudi Arabia's unwillingness to reopen the Cairo decision to send Arab, American and other non-Arab forces to Saudi Arabia, which has further split an already divided Arab world.
Iraq made it clear today that it would not attend an Arab meeting unless Arab leaders were willing to cancel the resolutions approved at the Cairo meeting.
Speaking after a meeting in Rabat with Morocco's King Hassan II, Taha Yassin Ramadan, Iraq's First Deputy Prime Minister, was quoted by the official Iraqi News Agency as saying that the proposed summit meeting should "wipe off the resolutions of the infamous Cairo summit."
Before leaving Morocco's capital today, Mr. Ramadan reiterated Baghdad's position that any new summit meeting should include on its agenda the underlying problems of the region, which Iraq say include its longstanding border and economic grievances against Kuwait, and also the Palestinian-Israeli dispute.
On Sunday, King Hassan called for the convening of an Arab summit meeting within a week, saying it was "the last chance" to avert a war in the Persian Gulf. But diplomats, Middle East analysts and Arab officials have been skeptical that such a meeting could take place, given the cleavage within the Arab camp and each side's concern that the other might turn such a meeting to its political advantage.
Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati of Iran arrived in Baghdad today for two days of talks. Mr. Velayati is the most senior Iranian official to visit Baghdad since the eight-year Iran-Iraq war began in 1980. Teheran has condemned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, but has also denounced the deployment of troops to Saudi Arabia by the United States and more than 20 other nations.
Also in Baghdad today, the Government newspaper Al Jumhuriya said that President Hussein had removed his cousin, Ali Hassan al-Majid as acting governor of Kuwait. The paper said his successor would be Aziz Saleh al-Nouman, a senior member of the ruling Baath Party. Mr. Majid's removal is the latest in a series of high-level shuffles.
 
IRAQ CRITICIZES MANEUVERS
 BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 14 (Reuters) -- The Iraqi News Agency said today that a planned amphibious-assault exercise by the United States Marines near Kuwait was provocative and proved that Washington was preparing for war.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Posts Heavy Losses As Inflation Worries Ease

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Weak oil prices and a strong stock market combined to send gold prices reeling yesterday. Platinum and silver prices, which have been depressed for some time, posted smaller losses.
Expectations of a decline in a leading inflation barometer, the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 basic commodity futures prices, also weighed heavily on the precious metals market all day. Gold has long been considered a hedge against inflation. 
 After the close of the commodity and stock markets, the bureau reported that its index had plunged 2.54 points, to 225.59, its lowest level since Oct. 30, 1989, when it stood at 225.20.
At the close of the Commodity Exchange in New York, the spot price of gold for delivery this month settled at $377.60 an ounce, down $8.40 on the day, while the more active December contract lost $8.50, to $378.50. Spot silver fell 3.4 cents an ounce, to $4.163, with the active December delivery down 3.7 cents, at $4.175.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the price of the spot November platinum delivery was posted at $417.60 an ounce, while the active January 1991 contract fell $5.90, to $413.90.
"The first signs of weakness in the precious metals was evident in overnight trading in foreign markets, but it was not until the Comex opened that the selling accelerated," said Bette Raptopoulos, metals specialist at Prudential-Bache Securities.
What prompted the selling, she continued, was the decline in prices of petroleum and byproducts, and sharp declines in basic commodities like grains and oilseeds. Crude oil prices plunged nearly $2 a barrel yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Ms. Raptopoulos said the downward move in precious metals accelerated yesterday when the commodity funds liquidated gold holdings as the stock market strengthened.
She said that "some market participants interpreted the growing debate over whether Congress should debate the President's Middle East policy as lessening the chances of a shooting war, and this may have caused some gold hoarders to lighten positions."
She said the main sellers of bullion were commodity funds that follow computer trading programs. When gold fell below $381.50, many computer-guided funds were prompted to sell, she said. "And when gold broke through $380, it also caused some more liquidation by the funds," she added.
But the absence of heavy volume in the Comex gold and silver markets and the modest turnover in the New York Merc platinum trading indicated that most market participants were on the sidelines, several Comex brokers said.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Stands By Troubled Tax Proposal for Police

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he had not abandoned his proposal for a payroll tax to finance his ambitious anti-crime plan, even though there was virtually no support for it among state legislative leaders whose approval would be needed.
But Mr. Dinkins conceded that the financing was uncertain, that it might not be approved by the end of this year -- which would put his plan to hire thousands of additional police officers behind schedule. He said it was up to legislative leaders to tell him what taxes they preferred if they did not favor his. 
 Asked if he would fight for the payroll tax, Mr. Dinkins, who resists phrasing almost any position in confrontational terms, told reporters at City Hall: "I wouldn't say I'd fight for it. I would try to persuade thosewhose assent is necessary that it is doable."
But elaborating later, the Mayor said he would campaign for his tax proposals by greeting commuters at railroad stations in the city in an effort to persuade them to urge their legislators to support the payroll tax.
The tax would be borne by workers and employers, and the Mayor's aides have said since he proposed the plan six weeks ago that he would make an appeal to commuters. If the legislative leaders do not like hisproposals, Mr. Dinkins said, "then I most respectfully urge that it's incumbent on them to give me alternatives."
But a spokesman for Ralph Marino, the Republican majority leader in the State Senate, who opposes any tax on commuters, said, "We don't think it works that way at all."
 
'Payroll Tax Is Not Acceptable'
 "It is incumbent on whatever chief executive is coming up with a plan to come up with a way to carry it through," said the spokesman, William S. Stevens. "We have previously said the payroll tax is not acceptable, because it affects commuters and because it might not be good thing for businesses in the city in this economic climate."
Legislative leaders have said it is unlikely they would consider the plan in a special session this fall. In fact, Mr. Dinkins seemsto have missed a chance in recent weeks to press his $1.8 billion, four-year plan, which he announced on Oct. 2 with fanfare after being pressured for weeks to hire more police officers amid a summer crime wave.
On the day he announced the plan, politicians praised its goals, but the Legislature immediately raised objections to the payroll tax and also expressed reservations about a 25-cent surcharge on lottery tickets, another leg of the plan.
Since then, the Mayor and his aides have been consumed with labor negotiations, deepening fiscal problems and a meeting of big-city mayors from around the nation, and have left the crime plan on the back burner. The City Council, which has been asked to support a mid-year property tax increase in January as the third financing element of the plan, has refused to budge until Albany acts. Council members complain that Mr. Dinkins's plan is too costly and that he has not seriously negotiated with them on a compromise.
Some city and state officials have suggested that Mr. Dinkins proposed such a sweeping plan -- which also includes educational and youth programs aimed at attacking the causes of crime -- in the expectation that it would not gain financing, and thus not force him into a costly program that could limit his spending options in other fields for years.
 
Administration Still Hopeful
 But his chief political aide, Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, said that was not so.
"We're going to work very hard to make it happen," he said. "There has been discussion with the leadership in the Assembly, there has been discussion with the leadership in the City Council, and we still see this thing having some hope."
"We've got to sit down together and work out a financing mechanism for the plan," Mr. Lynch added. "We believe that can be done, either convincing them of the Mayor's plan or coming up with some other plan. I would argue that the ball is in our court in terms of doing the convincing, to build the groundswell of support."
Mr. Lynch said the Mayor had not campaigned more vigorously for the taxes before because he did not want it to be an issue in last week's election. Dinkins aides had hoped the Legislature's opposition to the taxes might soften after the election, but the reverse seems to be true.
 
A Leaner Plan Sought
 Assembly Speaker Mel Miller and Mr. Marino have said the first step is for Mr. Dinkins and the Council to agree on a financing plan, then go to the Legislature. The Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said yesterday that the anti-crime plan could not be allowed to die but that Mr. Dinkins should scale it back to make it less costly.
The Council supports a plan that would cost about half what Mr. Dinkins's would and that would rely mostly on the lottery surcharge. But legislative leaders have also expressed reluctance to approve the surcharge.
In his budget modification last week, Mr. Dinkins included $26 million to begin hiring police officers and other workers called for in the anti-crime plan.
If the special taxes for the crime plan are not obtained, the city will have to find another way to go forward with it. That will be very difficult, since the city is facing a projected budget gap of more than $1.6 billion for the fiscal year starting next July. As a result, the Dinkins administration has counted on financing the hiring of new officers outside the regular budget.
Mr. Dinkins said yesterday that more officers would be hired one way or another. But he said that "the clamor in some quarters for more police officers perhaps has dimmed a bit as they see that we do have a rational plan" for new hiring and redeployment of officers.
