HEADLINE: Connecticut Facing Wider Budget Gap, Weicker Is Warned

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Governor-elect Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut was told by retiring Gov. William A. O'Neill today that the revenue shortfall for the next fiscal year would be far greater than expected -- amounting to almost a third of this year's budget.
It was the bleakest estimate yet of the state's rapidly growing fiscal crisis.
 
 The new projection released by Mr. O'Neill said the state would collect $2.1 billion less than it planned to spend in fiscal 1991-1992 if it kept services at their current levels. Connecticut's operating budget for this year is about $7.1 billion. By state statute, the Governor must present a balanced budget each year, and the General Assembly must pass one.
The new projection includes an estimated $450 million shortfall for the current fiscal year. It is part of a draft of the 1991-92 budget that the O'Neill administration prepared for Mr. Weicker, who takes office on Jan. 9.
Three weeks, ago, the General Assembly's Office of Fiscal Analysis estimated that the 1991-92 budget gap would be $1.5 billion. Three months earlier its estimate was $1 billion. The office will release a new estimate on Friday.
Mr. Weicker, who ran as an independent on the Connecticut Party ticket, declined to comment on the projected shortfall, saying he had not yet seen the budget draft.
He added, though, that he was "not taken aback" by the $2.1 billion figure. "It could very well get even worse," he said.
Mr. O'Neill, a Democrat who had decided against seeking a third full term, was more alarmed. "The budget process will be very difficult," he said.
Asked if he thought new or higher taxes would be required to cover the budget gap, Mr. O'Neill said, "I think it will be very difficult, if not impossible, not to have them."
 
Recession Blamed
 Mr. Weicker said the economic downturn had caused the shortfall by holding down state revenues, especially those from the corporation tax.
"I think it's clear that sacrifices will be required in some form," he said.
Connecticut now receives most of its revenue from an 8 percent sales tax, the highest state sales tax in the nation. Revamping the state's tax system to include a more consistent stream of revenue, like a state income tax, has been a divisive issue in the state for decades.
The 8.25 percent sales tax in New York City is composed of a 4 percent state sales tax and a 4.25 percent city sales tax.
During his gubernatorial campaign, Mr. Weicker said he did not support a state income tax but, depending on circumstances, would not rule one out. Speaking to reporters today, he maintained that position. "I think it is a question of having the facts at hand," he said.
The 1991-92 budget projection issued by Governor O'Neill was the first made by his fiscal analysts, the Office of Policy and Management.
 
'Extraordinary Measures'
 A official with the office, Gordon J. Frassinelli, said he could not recall a shortfall projection that represented such a large percentage of the budget. "It would require extraordinary measures," he said.
In New York State, how much of a budget gap to expect next year is a matter of dispute between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Comptroller Edward Regan. Last month, Mr. Regan said the state would face a shortfall of $2 billion to $3 billion in the fiscal year beginning April 1. Mr. Cuomo's budget office said the gap would be $941 million.
In either case, the gap would be a far smaller percentage of the state budget than in Connecticut. The total New York State budget for the next fiscal year is expected to exceed $50 billion.
In Connecticut, the 1991-92 budget draft is expected to be presented to Mr. Weicker today. He is now assembling his administration and is expected to name a replacement for Mr. O'Neill's Secretary of the Office of Policy and Management, Anthony V. Milano, by the end of the week.
One person who has often been mentioned as potential replacement is former State Senator Reginald J. Smith of New Hartford, the former Senate minority leader. He was Mr. Weicker's campaign fiscal adviser and, in Mr. Weicker's mold, is considered a liberal Republican.
Another choice might be former State Representative William J. Cibes Jr., a liberal Democrat from New London who ran unsuccessfully for his party's gubernatorial nomination and who campaigned for a state income tax.
Both Mr. Weicker and Mr. O'Neill said they expect a smooth transition over the next few weeks.
Mr. Weicker, a former Republican supported mainly by liberals, Democrats and unaffiliated voters, met with reporters in the front yard of the three-story red brick governor's mansion.
Mr. Weicker, standing next to Mr. O'Neill, politely praised the home. Last week, after defeating Representative John G. Rowland of Waterbury, a Republican, and Representative Bruce A. Morrison of Hamden, a Democrat, he hinted that he would spend much time at his Greenwich home, Apple Jack Farm.
He said of the Governor's Mansion: "I think it's a lovely house. I'm sure we will fill up some of the rooms, but we won't be able to fill all of them."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Turkey Wary of Being a 'Second Front' in a War

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Nov. 14

 BODY:
The idea is still more an abstraction than a real plan, but Turkey's leaders nonetheless are making it clear that their army will not be used as a "second front" in a war against neighboring Iraq.
President Turgut Ozal, a sturdy pillar in the alliance against Iraq, recently dismissed as "pure fantasy" the notion of a Turkish second front that would attack Iraq from the north while United States and other forces move in from the south. 
 In interviews in Ankara, other officials said that their armed forces are ill equipped for such a role, a point shared by Western military specialists. Turkey has already made costly sacrifices in the Persian Gulf crisis, the officials point out, and some add that they should not abandon their traditional caution in dealing with their Middle Eastern neighbors.
To many Turks it is axiomatic that no good can come of involving themselves in disputes among Arabs.
"We have done more than expected," a senior official said. "We have to live with Iraq. We are fully implementing the Security Council embargo. What else can they expect from us?"
Turkey, a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, has not received a specific request to make its 635,000 soldiers available for possible combat or to allow its territory to be used for strikes against Iraq by other allied armies. The Government has new powers to allow foreign troops to deploy in Turkey, but thus far it has said it would support military action against Iraq only if it is authorized by the United Nations Security Council.
Nevertheless, Turks recognize that a second front is likely to become a tempting option for the American-led alliance if war does come.
Moderate officials say they are worried that Mr. Ozal, despite his objections now, could eventually agree to such a plan to show solidarity with the West.
Although custom dictates that the Turkish presidency is a ceremonial position, Mr. Ozal has taken charge of shaping his country's gulf policy, an active role that has brought applause from Washington but distresses more restrained Government officials and opposition leaders. They complain that he is deciding Turkey's future on his own. Last month, the Foreign and Defense Ministers both resigned over the handling of the crisis.
Even without committing troops to a ground offensive, Turkey has put itself on the front lines against Iraq. As an early and uncompromising participant in the anti-Baghdad embargo, Ankara estimates that it has lost $7 billion in trade, debt repayment, remittances and foreign investment.
Within days of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, Turkey closed vital twin pipelines that carried Iraqi oil to a Mediterranean port. Taking advantage of the ruling party's legislative majority, the Government has assumed war powers that normally belong to Parliament, notably the right to send Turkish soldiers abroad and to allow foreign troops here.
The United States has been permitted to keep 14 F-111 fighter bombers at the Incirlik air base in southern Turkey. And the Turkish army has sent up to 100,000 troops to the mountainous border with Iraq, where they are defensively deployed but are pinning down a similar number of Iraqi soldiers.
 
 Open-Minded on Use of Base
 It is widely assumed that the Turks would say yes to a request from Washington to use the Incirlik base. Publicly, Defense Minister Husnu Dogan has declined to commit himself.
On the second-front issue, Turkish and foreign military experts both note that Turkey's army is not as well equipped or as well trained as many Westerners believe, especially if they must fight battle-hardened Iraqis.
"Turkish troops deployed at the Iraqi border are not there for attack but for defense," a Western specialist said. "They are not properly armed, they don't have war experience and the terrain is not suitable for a large mechanized operation."
Some officials admit they are worried about Iraqi chemical attacks. Others complain that except for $300 million contributed by Kuwaitis the anti-Iraq coalition has yet to deliver large amounts of promised aid to compensate Turkey for its losses.
But a few officials, probably a minority, argue that if Turkey wants a significant role in postwar talks on the Middle East's future shape, it must first get involved militarily.

HEADLINE: Citicorp Planning to Close 9 Real Estate Lending Units

 BODY:
Following through with its previously announced plans to reduce expenses and cut back its real estate lending, Citicorp is closing 9 of the 16 commercial real estate lending offices it has in the United States, a spokesman for the banking company said yesterday.
The number of jobs lost in the move was not disclosed. Citicorp officials have said they plan to cut more than 2,000 jobs, mostly in the corporate and commercial real estate lending activities in the global banking group, which handles corporate finance in North America, Japan and Europe. 
 "The type of real estate lending we do is overbuilt," the spokesman said. "A lot of business has stopped."
 
Offices Listed
 The offices to be closed are in Seattle, Phoenix, San Diego, Cleveland, Minneapolis, Houston, Boston, Philadelphia and Miami. The remaining commercial real estate lending offices are in New York, Washington, Atlanta, Dallas, Chicago, San Francisco and Los Angeles.
Like many other American banks, Citicorp has been hurt by bad real estate loans. In its third quarter, problem real estate loans rose by $573 million, to $2.2 billion, while real estate owned because of foreclosure rose $336 million, to $1.04 billion.
Citicorp stock rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to close at $14 on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock has recently traded as low as $10.75 a share.
 
Auction Brings 11.5% Rate
 Meanwhile, at bids yesterday at Citicorp's auction of a $75 million issue of 49-day money market preferred stock, produced a rate of 11.5 percent, up sharply from the last auction of such securities.
The company, which has more preferred stock outstanding than most issuers, is paying higher rates because of its troubled real estate investments.
The lead manager, Lehman Government Securities Inc., said the rate was up from 10.75 percent for a 49-day series auctioned on Friday.
The rate was sharply higher largely because the securities auctioned yesterday will not mature until early in 1991. To justify holding the Citicorp securities through the end of the year, investors demanded a higher interest rate.
 
Republic Rates Are Reset
 In contrast, rates on 49-day money market preferred stock issued by the the Republic New York Corporation, another New York banking company, were reset yesterday at 7.125 percent, from 6.60 percent at a previous auction.
The Citicorp rate had fallen to 7.48 percent on an auctioned series on Nov. 7, after the bank holding company announced it would call $275 million of its preferred stock and leave $675 million outstanding. The less stock outstanding, the greater the value of the stock and the lower the yield.

LENGTH: 1379 words

HEADLINE: Guards Say Daily News Hired Them as 'Bait'

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER

 BODY:
The Daily News has hired unemployed veterans and other jobless men through a Kentucky security company to drive delivery trucks and collect money from news dealers. But two men who say they quit the job in disgust say the real object was to videotape them and other security personnel being beaten by strikers as evidence to use in court against the drivers' union.
"We were bait," said Jim McCully of Clarksville, Tenn. "The bottom line was that we were supposed to be cheese for the rats." 
 A 21-year-old Army veteran from the Lexington, Ky., area said: "I felt that we were being used as meat, so I got out of there. I think they did us dirty."
 Their stories were provided in separate telephone interviews in which they presented almost identical accounts. A number of details were independently corroborated.
The accounts provide one of the first glimpses inside the Daily News management's multimillion-dollar effort to defeat the striking newspaper unions, including the services of at least three private security companies.
 
'Because of Violence'
 Asked about the security operation, Lisa G. Robinson, the spokeswoman for The News, said: "I really won't speak to specifics of our security. We have security because of violence."
The men are being recruited from areas around military bases in the South -- Fort Campbell, Ky., in this case, home of the 101st Airborne Division -- where the local economies are being hard hit by the deployment of troops to Saudi Arabia.
They say they responded to advertisements in local newspapers offering "a prestigious security position" and were under the impression that the job involved guarding company property or standing on the loading docks watching over the trucks.
But soon after they arrived at their base of operations at a Ramada Inn in Fairfield, N.J., they say, they were told the job was to go out in pairs driving the delivery trucks and collecting from vendors with one man carrying a videotape camera. There were also supposed to be "follow cars" equipped with video and still cameras, they say.
Mr. McCully said that at their orientation session on Nov. 3, Bill Mills, the operations director for Securex, the Kentucky security company that hired them, told them: "Your job is to get documentation on film of union members breaking your necks. We need the evidence so we can go to court and freeze the assets of the union."
 
No Money for Bus Tickets
 "They stressed nonviolence," said the Kentucky veteran, a former military policeman who asked that his name not be used to avoid any possible legal problems. "At the briefing, basically they were telling us, if a guy steps in front of your car, stop and make no attempt to get away. They wanted us to go down in the subways making collections. I had a vision of my head on a piece of concrete and 20 pairs of boots kicking it."
The two men said others wanted to leave the job too, but were stuck because they did not have enough money for bus tickets home.
When pressed on whether The Daily News had hired Securex and whether the workers were to be targets, Ms. Robinson, the paper's spokeswoman, called back several hours later to say: "We have hired vendors from places around the country. They are licensed to do business in New York. We told them to avoid confrontation, not to carry weapons."
The former military policeman, reading from a business card, provided a telephone number in London, Ky., for Securex and said one of its main officials was a lawyer named Crabtree.
The telephone was answered by a man who identified himself as Bill Crabtree, an attorney.
Asked if the Securex concern was working for The Daily News, Mr. Crabtree at first said: "I won't speak for Securex. That company was not working up there."
Then he said he was the general counsel for Securex, adding that "I am not at liberty to comment on any of my client's activities."
Mr. Crabtree said the telephone number was not that of Securex but of his direct office line.
It was the same number given by directory assistance for Securex.
 
'Asked for Our Help'
 At the Tennessee state employment agency, Job Services, in Clarksville, Rogelio Salinas, said the agency had referred about 20 people to Securex.
"Securex came to us and asked for our help," Mr. Salinas said. "We provided the assistance. From then on, we don't know about it. They're from London, Ky. They recruit from around bases -- Fort Knox, Fort Bragg -- to get ex-military people. They take them to New York to secure areas where they go on strike. We had a couple come back -- maybe they got beat up there.
"They came a week before last and last week also. They said, 'Roy, we need more people right away.' "
"Unemployment's so high here it ain't funny," Mr. Salinas added. "We got Fort Campbell, and the 101st went to Saudi. When a division leaves with 25,000 troops, that puts a hurting on everybody."
Mr. Salinas identified the Securex representative he dealt with as Robert C. Storm, a name also provided as a top operations official for the company by both men who quit.
 
A Sketchy Outline
 The two men said they were taken by bus from London in Kentucky to the Ramada Inn in Fairfield after brief interviews and a sketchy outline of a job as a security guard.
"They were misrepresenting themselves up front," Mr. McCully said. "They were real vague and evasive until you got there and by then it's generally too late. The picture they painted was we would be standing on the docks of the plant with picketers yelling outside."
As proof of his employment, Mr. McCully sent a facsimile of an instruction sheet saying that cars and vans could be fueled at the newspaper's expense at an Amoco service station in Secaucus; a checkout statement from the Fairfield Ramada Inn and a laminated identity card issued on Nov. 11 under the name of Delta Transportation, which he said was one of the "covert style" names used in the operation.
The pay, he said, was to be roughly $700 a week, working 12 hours on, 12 off for an 84-hour week. The job was to last for 120 days, with a $1,500 bonus to anyone completing the full tour, he said.
 
'A Chase Car'
 "They had us equipped with camcorders and 35-millimeter cameras," Mr. McCully said. "Along with that they had a chase car that was supposed to follow the trucks. In the chase cars, too, were camcorders and 35-millimeter cameras. The bottom line was they were going to get some documentation on film of union members beating up on the heads of these guys so they could take them to court and freeze their assets. We were put there as bait.
"They pretty much came out and said it the second day of the orientation. They didn't use the word 'scab' until the third day. I didn't relish getting out there for $700 to have my head cracked by a gang of irate, understandably irate, strikers."
Mr. McCully managed to get enough money together to go home after his third day on the job. The Kentucky veteran said his wife sent him a money order so he could leave.
But, the two men said, many of the other recruits at the Ramada Inn did not have enough money to leave. The workers were promised $150 advances but were given only $50 when they arrived in New Jersey. The hotel rooms are being paid for, but the men must buy their own food. Mr. McCully said the room telephones had been removed.
 
'Like Hostages'
 "When they get you there, they pretty much know you are broke," said Mr. McCully, who described the men left behind as "like hostages."
"They had already established that you were destitute," he said. "They couldn't afford to go home on their own. They're losing people. Some guys are hitchhiking home."
At the Ramada Inn, two lanky men in work clothes sitting in the bar acknowledged in Southern drawls that they were working for Securex but said they could not talk about it.
"We've had plenty of trouble, but we can't discuss it," said one of them. "We signed a contract."
In the front lobby, a man in a gray suit sitting at a table had been seen giving instructions to the same men earlier. When asked, he denied knowledge of either Securex or The Daily News.
On the table in front of him were log sheets listing the names of the men and the hours they worked.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 2588 words

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
No Talk of Glory, but of Blood on Sand

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Nov. 12

 BODY:
Richard Weese, a beefy man chewing on a tiny stub of a cigar, insists he is no liberal. "I don't believe in the do-gooders who say we should go home and stick our heads in the sand," he said the other day, settling into a seat at the Sadler Cafe.
But Mr. Weese, a retired air controller, is not sure that he could support a war in the Persian Gulf either. "It's kind of hard to say you're fighting for democracy," he said, "when you know the Kuwaitis don't have one." 
 A few hundred miles to the north, in North Adams, Mass., Howard D'Amico stood amid the clutter of his bargain outlet store, expressing frustration that, at 65, he was too old to go to Saudi Arabia himself. "Let the wimps step aside," he said. "I'll go in their place."
Mr. D'Amico called himself "a strong supporter of our stand in the Persian Gulf." But when pressed, he acknowledged that he was unsure just what that stand was. "That's something I would like to know," he said. "What are we fighting about?"
As more than 150,000 United States troops prepare to head for the Persian Gulf, adding to the 230,000 already there, and as Washington talks of a possible offensive strike, the display of unity among Americans is starting to show signs of wear.
In scores of conversations from Vermont to West Virginia, Americans of all ages and walks of life expressed not just a growing fear of war, but also an increasing ambivalence about the United States' involvement and a growing frustration that President Bush had not given the nation what they thought was a satisfactory explanation for mobilizing the armed forces.
While many of those interviewed -- farmers and nurses and lawyers and soldiers -- said they would support whatever path President Bush chose to pursue in the gulf, many others said they were beginning to wonder whethe they could still back the President once the killing started. And as Americans confront the possibility of another war, history seems to present a troubling multiple-choice question: Would this be another World War II, or another Vietnam?
 
'No One Drew a Line'
 "I'm old enough to have lived through Hitler's early years, when no one drew a line," Joseph Schaaf, a musician, said the other day over breakfast in Bennington, Vt. "And I don't think someone like Saddam Hussein should be allowed to build up that degree of power."
"This is not World War II," Mr. Schaaf's breakfast companion, Adelaide Fine, objected. "This is like Vietnam. What you have is no declaration of war, and a chief executive hellbent on fighting. I can't understand why there isn't more outcry."
Ambivalence in the face of war is as old, undoubtedly, as war itself, and mistrust of those in power is probably just as ancient. But what marks the reaction to the current crisis is the way Americans are talking openly about the President's inability to "sell" war to a wary populace.
A common complaint among those interviewed was that the Bush Administration seemed unable to come up with a consistent -- and compelling -- account of what the United States was preparing to fight for. Was it to protect oil sources, they wanted to know, or to prevent further aggression, or simply to maintain the status quo?
"What I don't like is the fact that we can't get any straight answers," said Doreena Wimberly, a secretary from Rome, N.Y. "Just watching the news on TV and trying to explain to my kids why are we over there, I can't give them a justifiable reason. I just say, 'The world is crazy, I guess.' "
 
WILKES-BARRE, PA.: Portents Haunt Veterans Day
 The Veterans Day Parade is always a good show in Wilkes-Barre, the kind of event that draws people a few hours early to stake out good seats and stomp around in the cold.
Linda Garrison, who has two nephews in Saudi Arabia and a husband who could get called up any minute, thought the parade was a good opportunity to rally support for the troops abroad. She brought several hundred little yellow bows in a big plastic bag, and pretty soon there wasn't an empty lapel in sight.
Mrs. Garrison said she understood that a lot of people in the crowd had mixed feelings about going to war in the Persian Gulf. But she did not think that would affect her campaign.
"We're not asking people to believe we should be over there," she said, slipping a ribbon into the buttonhole of a reporter's jacket. "We're just asking them to believe in the people who are over there. I don't want the reception for those men to be like it was after Vietnam."
 
 Plans Are Disrupted
 The possibility of an impending war gave the Veterans Day parade this year a portentous aspect. Who knew whether there would be more veterans to mourn next year, or whether some of the men and women in the parade would soon be called up to fight?
For Specialist Robert Storz, a member of the National Guard who was getting ready to march in the parade with his field-artillery unit, the possibility of war presented itself as nothing less than a disruption of an entire life's plans.
Mr. Storz, a 19-year-old freshman at Pennsylvania State University's Wilkes-Barre campus, joined the National Guard, as he put it, "to get money for college." In return, he spent one weekend a month training with the Guard. Now there were rumors that his unit would be called to Germany to replace forces there that had been called to the gulf. He could only hope, he said, that Europe was as far as he would have to go.
"I wish they had gotten the whole thing over with already," he said dejectedly.
 
 Oil 'Not Worth It'
 Arthur Watkins, Mr. Storz's friend and fellow Guard member, said, "My parents are threatening to break my foot or my arm so I can't go."
Mr. Watkins, a 23-year-old junior at Wilkes-Barre's King's College, said he was not sure why the United States was preparing for war, but he thought it was either an effort to bring down oil prices or to punish aggression. "If they're fighting for oil, then it's not worth it," he said.
Both men, dressed in camouflage uniforms, said they were disturbed that American forces were bearing the bulk of the burden in the gulf, even though the crisis had obvious implications for other countries as well. "It's as if all the other countries were paying us to use our men," Mr. Storz said. "It's like we're mercenaries or something."
Farther down the road, Michael Basta, a Korean War veteran who was also preparing to march in the parade, expressed similar disgust for America's allies.
 
 Flying the Flag
 "Multilateral is a lot of bunk," Mr. Basta said. "You don't have to be the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff to see the writing on the wall. Unfortunately, it is our men who are going to do the fighting."
Still, Mr. Basta said he had no doubt that the President was pursuing the right course. "We went to Korea to protect people, and there are people in Kuwait who need to be protected, too," he said.
Tom Gaylets, another Korean War veteran, interrupted to say: "I hope and pray every American is supporting our boys. The American flag should be flying in front of every house."
Mr. Basta nodded gravely. "I hope we don't have any more Jane Fondas," he said.
 
BENNINGTON, VT.: Skepticism On a Campus
 The last time the United States was involved in a full-scale war, Celene Colburn war 4 years old. Yet she does not believe, she says, that peace is the primary objective of the American Government.
"The whole history of U.S. intervention in South America shows that our involvement is really relative to our economic interests," she said. "And yet it's always played out like it's a moral or an ethical thing."
On a recent slate-gray afternoon, Ms. Colburn and several of her friends were gathered over what passed for lunch -- a few apples -- in the Bennington College student lounge. When a reporter pulled up a chair and steered the conversation toward the Persian Gulf, the jovial mood of the group suddently turned sullen.
"I feel very skeptical about the information that's available to us," said Ms. Colburn, a 21-year-old dance major, drawing her legs up to her chest. "We as a nation make choices about when to get involved, and it seems to me that those decisions always have to do with the interests of big corporations."
 
 Not Just Right or Wrong
 "You can't say it's a matter of right or wrong," said Roy Kortick, a 22-year-old art-and-literature major. "We've been giving the Iraqis arms for years."
To go by the polls, college-age Americans, brought up on a vision of "morning in America," are supposed to be more gung-ho about their country these days, more apt to support patriotic causes and conservative ideals. That message, however, has apparently not yet reached Bennington, one of the country's most exclusive, and expensive, colleges. Indeed, most Bennington students seem to dismiss the notion of a high-minded American war as hopelessly naive and out-of-date, like physics before Einstein.
"The Middle east is a region that has reached this point because of other countries' involvement," Bart Arnold, a 20-year-old music major, said. "This really isn't going to do anything positive for solving the problems in the area. And I think it's really disgusting that they've gotten the U.N. involved. It's all over oil, cheap oil."
 
 At the Legion Post
 Down the hill at Bennington's American Legion post, Larry Holcomb, a Vietnam veteran, was having a mid-afternoon beer after finishing his rounds as a water- and sewer-supply salesman. He dismissed the college students' views as so much pacifist cant. But he agreed that at the heart of the matter lay a vast pool of oil.
"A dinky little country like that telling us what to do, it's ridiculous," he said. "I don't think we should leave, mainly because I can't afford what they want for gasoline."
 
ROME, N.Y.: Rumbles Felt In the Home
 Rome, the home of Griffiss Air Force Base, is a straight-talking town whose fortunes, quite simply, rise and fall with the military's. And while other towns may be starting to grow jittery at the thought of war, Rome is already shuddering.
Dawn Glasgow's husband, Eddie, who is stationed at Griffiss, headed for the gulf in August, part of the 416th Organizational Maintenance Squadron. When he left, their second child, Sean, was just 6 months old.
"I'll admit we never expected something like this to happen," Mrs. Glasgow said, sitting on the floor of her living room with Sean in her lap. "It's tough, you know, raising two kids on your own."
Mrs. Glasgow said she worried all the time about her husband, and wrote him almost every day. But, she said sighing, she knew he had no choice. "It's his job," she said. "He joined the service for a purpose. And now's his time to go over there to defend us."
"Eddie loves his job," she said. "And if he can't find another, he can't help but re-enlist."
 
 Dreading January
 Mrs. Glasgow's neighbor, Denice Weil, does not herself have relatives in the gulf but, she said, with so many local men and women over in Saudi Arabia and the holidays coming up, "It's pretty depressing around here."
"We all have a terrible feeling of dread that come January, we're going to have an all-out war," she said. "There are a lot of lonely wives around, a lot of children who don't know if they're going to see their dads again."
Residents of Rome always believed that their town, with its air base and its arsenals, would be a prime target if hostilities broke out between the United States and the Soviet Union. Last year, when the Berlin wall was chopped up into souvenirs and relations between the superpowers thawed, people in Rome felt measurably safer. But now, Ms. Weil said, they were beginning to wonder again.
"I guess we were living pretty high on the hog," she said. "We saw the Soviet Union doing things we never thought possible. And then this had to happen."
 
 Gloom in a Tavern
 Over at Walt's, a tavern in the seedier part of town that caters to servicemen, an early-evening crowd was gathering under a cardboard sign that read "No Tabs." The consensus around the bar was that the civilian population did not really know how terrible a war would be.
"I think the military is aware of how high the casualties would be," said Willie Fletcher, who spent four years in Air Force and now works part time at Walt's. "The rest of the people are not. Anybody who knows anything about what's going on, they're really concerned."
Mr. Fletcher said he had a 17-year-old son who until recently wanted to be a marine. Now he was reconsidering. "Who am I to tell him to join the Marines and go off to get killed?" Mr. Fletcher said.
Sgt. 1st Class Richard Foster, who was having a drink at the horseshoe-shaped bar, said: "I believe the casualties are going to be quite high. And if it lasts any more than five or six weeks, it is going to last for quite a long time."
"Some of the young guys, they don't know what to expect," Sergeant Foster, a member of the 82d Airborne Division who has spent 20 years in the army, continued. "There's a lot of joking at the base. I guess they do it out of fear."
As to the odds of war, Sergeant Foster said: "It's going to happen, that's all I can say. And if it doesn't happen, somebody's going to be very lucky."
 
CHARLES TOWN, W.VA.: Sense of History Adds to Alarm
 Charles Town was founded by George Washington's half-brother, Charles, more than 200 years ago, so people in the town think they have a pretty good sense of American history. When they look at the future, many Charles Town residents say, they are alarmed by the parallels.
J. Michael Cassell, a public prosecutor, said that what disturbed him was the way the country seemed to be repeating its mistakes. "I don't think the Administration has expressed clearly enough what the purpose of this is," he said, pausing at the luncheonette on his way to work.
Despite their reservations about war, many in Charles Town said theirs is a patriotic state (West Virginia, one of the nation's poorest states, has one of the highest ratios of military-to-civilian populations in the country) and would support war.
"I hate to see our guys get hurt, but I don't like the other guy neither," said Myron Gregory, a fruit-stand operator. "I wouldn't even hesitate to use the big bomb -- whatever's necessary to get the job done."
 
 Oil Is Seen as Cause
 "People will accept it and support it, although they will not like it," said Ed Dockeney, associate editor of the local weekly newspaper.
In the agricultural areas around Charles Town, several farmers said that while they were unhappy at the thought of war, they would support just about anything that would end the climb in oil prices, which has eaten heavily into their profits.
"They say it's not over the price of oil, but it is over the price of oil," said Robert Funk, climbing down from his combine. "I've got a nephew in the service, and I don't like to see it, but I can't take much more of this."
Mr. Cassell said it was crucial that the country know the reasons for its sacrifices: "Unless they understand exactly what we are there for, the American people are going to turn against this, once large number of people start coming home in body bags."
Mr. Cassell's friend, Rick Pekar, agreed. "There are a lot of young boys in this country who have never seen war," he said. "And once they do see it, this is not gong to be quite so popular. I grew up during Vietnam, too, and it was a very sad time."

HEADLINE: Trump Shifts And Talks To Creditors

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Only a few hours after declaring on Tuesday that he had broken off negotiations with holders of the "junk bonds" of his Taj Mahal casino, Donald J. Trump reopened the talks yesterday to try to avoid an involuntary bankruptcy filing on the Atlantic City property.
Mr. Trump has until midnight tonight to make a $47.3 million interest payment on the $675 million in bonds he sold to build the casino. If he fails to make the payment, he faces the possibility that bondholders could try to force the Taj Mahal to file for bankruptcy protection. 
 The New York developer has said he does not have enough money to make the payment. If a settlement is reached before a bankruptcy is forced, people close to the negotiations have said, the bondholders will receive significantly more than half of the casino's equity, as well as other concessions.
 
Previous Offer Rejected
 For many weeks, Mr. Trump has been in talks with a group of bondholders who hold approximately 85 percent of the face value of the Taj Mahal bonds. He made an offer last month to give the bondholders 19.9 percent of the casino if they would substantially reduce the interest rates on the bonds, extend the maturity and accept new bonds in lieu of cash for interest payments. The offer was roundly rejected.
Any settlement would include a reduction of the interest rate on the bonds, which were set at 14 percent when they were issued. The amount of the reduction, how long the rate would remain at a lower level, and the amount of equity that would be given in exchange for the reduction are crucial concerns in the talks.
If no settlement is reached by midnight and Mr. Trump fails to make the payment, lawyers for the bondholders' committee believe there is a way to get around the 30-day grace period provided in the contract should Mr. Trump default.

HEADLINE: Talking Deals;
Chairman's Ambitions For United

BYLINE: By Eric N. Berg

DATELINE: ELK GROVE, Ill.

 BODY:
IT is as if all of the stress of repeated buyout offers, incessant criticism from union leaders and a much-publicized plan to oust him as chairman and chief executive of the UAL Corporation has had no effect on Stephen M. Wolf.
Since Oct. 9, when an employee-led bid for UAL, the parent of United Airlines, collapsed, Mr. Wolf has emerged with a series of deals aimed at making United the first truly global airline. And he indicated in a recent interview that he was not planning to take a breather. United is in negotiations with a number of carriers, he said, to buy additional assets. 
 Mr. Wolf has had a busy month. On Oct. 15, less than a week after the protracted buyout effort fell through, he announced the largest aircraft order ever -- a $22 billion purchase of wide-body jets from the Boeing Company. The same day, he announced that United had been chosen by the Transportation Department over its archrival, American Airlines, to fly between Chicago and Tokyo.
Eight days later, Mr. Wolf held another news conference to announce plans to acquire Pan American World Airways' routes to London for $400 million.
In the interview, at UAL's headquarters in this suburb of Chicago, Mr. Wolf declined to give details of the company's current negotiations. But he said United was talking with a number of financially weak carriers, which would probably include Eastern, Trans World and Continental. While giving no indication that a purchase was near, Mr. Wolf said United was eager to do more deals.
"I don't envision anything bigger than what we are doing with Pan Am," he said, but he added, "We will continue to listen to airline managements that want to dispose of assets."
Mr. Wolf said United was building cash reserves to prepare for the financial pain of a recession. United strategists see a slowdown coming, and they predict that the revenues of all airlines will suffer.
But United also wants to raise cash to pay for "significant corporate transactions," Mr. Wolf said.
Wall Street analysts have viewed the purchase of the aircraft, as well as the acquisition of the Pan Am routes, as part of a grand plan by Mr. Wolf. That plan, the analysts say, involves establishing United as a force in North America, Europe and Asia, the most important continents for business travel.
United already has the largest presence in Asia; its North American operation is only slightly smaller than that of American Airlines, the leader, and the new Pan Am routes will make United a close second to American in trans-Atlantic travel. Indeed, analysts have said Mr. Wolf wants to give United an important presence around the world, and the United chief acknowledged as much.
"Ultimately, our objective is to be a very comprehensive worldwide carrier," he said.
To achieve that, United must establish labor peace with its three main unions -- the flight attendants, the machinists and the pilots -- all of which are currently in contract talks. Many analysts have predicted long and difficult negotiations, saying the unions will take a tough stance after failing to win control of the airline. Mr. Wolf expressed hope that new labor contracts could be reached, but he repeated an earlier offer to submit any lingering disputes in the contract talks to binding arbitration.
But even if United can win new labor accords, other obstacles remain to Mr. Wolf's plan. The chairman acknowledged that although United was scheduled to take delivery of about one new wide-body Boeing jet a week over the next four years, the airline would still be short of aircraft.
He also noted that all airlines remained vulnerable to the spike in fuel prices. Mr. Wolf said United had decided not to sign contracts locking in a price on later purchases of fuel, because it did not want to be bound to a high price if fuel prices fell suddenly.
The 49-year-old Mr. Wolf, who is 6 foot 6 and looked trim and rested, has been such a blur of motion lately that some analysts have expressed concern that he might be acting too hastily. In particular, they wonder whether United should be expanding so quickly, given the possibility of a steep drop in demand for air travel in the United States during a recession.
But Mr. Wolf said that some of United's Asian routes were growing at an annual rate of 20 percent or more and that he was confident the airline would not feel a cash pinch. Indeed, he said it was unlikely that two years from now United's balance sheet would look much different from how it appears today. And even if the balance sheet deteriorated, United's finances would still compare favorably to rivals, Mr. Wolf predicted.
United's calculations put its total debt, including lease obligations, at about $4.4 billion, compared with $7.9 billion at American and $4.6 billion at Delta. United calculates its cash reserves at $1.6 billion, compared with $720 million at American and $68 million at Delta.
"We think we will maintain a strong relative financial position, no matter what happens to the world economy," Mr. Wolf said.

(Steve Kagan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Up Only 0.1% In October

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Retail sales growth slowed to a barely perceptible one-tenth of 1 percent in October, the Government said today, prompting analysts to predict a big cutback in holiday gift-buying.
"I think holiday sales are going to be pretty lousy," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York. "Compared to Christmases past, it's just not going to look very good." 
 Sandra Shaber, an economist with the Futures Group in Washington, agreed, pointing to two months of declining sales at department and clothing stores -- often gauges of consumer sentiment.
 
'Less Money to Spend'
 "Consumers have a limited budget," she said. "With the rapid deterioration of the job market and more inflation, consumers just simply have less money to spend."
The Commerce Department said retail sales -- which cover sales at department stores, as well as auto dealers, gasoline stations and restaurants -- totaled a seasonally adjusted $152.3 billion, up from $152.1 billion in September. But like the previous two months, sales were inflated by high gasoline prices, not volume.
In fact, the department said sales actually fell one-tenth of 1 percent in October when gasoline purchases were excluded. The price of gasoline has climbed about 35 percent since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait disrupted world oil markets.
The September figure on retail sales was revised yesterday to a gain of 1.3 percent, up from a previously reported strong increase of 1.1 percent. That had been the biggest advance in four months, but economists said when it was released last month that surging gasoline prices, along with a rebound in automobile purchases, helped mask an otherwise weak report.
Analysts saw the October sales data as further evidence of weakness in an economy that many believe is in a recession. Retail sales represent about half of all consumer spending, which itself accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
Ms. Shaber predicted a repeat of last year's holiday season, when many retailers cut prices and offered other promotions to lure consumers to their salesrooms. "It's really a very, very promotional Christmas already," she said. "We have too many stores and too many malls now being aggravated by the erosion of household purchasing power."
Retailers depend on the holiday shopping season for about half of their sales and profits.
Automobiles, which represent about 20 percent of retail sales, slowed to a seven-tenths of 1 percent gain, from a 2.9 percent increase in September. But Mr. Steinberg of Merrill Lynch said unit sales were down in October, suggesting the increase represented higher prices for new-model-year cars.
Excluding the auto category, retail sales were unchanged from the previous month.
Sales of durable goods, which include cars and other items expected to last more than three years, rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, just half of their 1.4 percent gain a month earlier.
Purchases of building materials rebounded 1.5 percent after a 1.5 percent drop in September, but sales of furniture and other home furnishings fell three-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: Labor Leaders Rally to Support The News Strike

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
In a show of solidarity with Daily News strikers, the country's top union officials led a rally of demonstrators yesterday and pledged almost $300,000 in aid.
One of the officials, Lane Kirkland, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, told the cheering crowd, "You have the support of the entire labor movement behind you." 
 Flanking him were Owen Bieber of the 1.5-million-member United Automobile Workers, Morton Bahr of the Communications Workers of America, Jay Mazur of the International Ladies Garment Workers, Jack Sheinkman of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, Gerald McEntee of the 1.2-million member American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees and other union chiefs.
Other speakers included Edward J. Cleary, president of the New York State AFL-CIO, and Thomas Van Arsdale, president of the New York City Central Labor Council and Peter Brennan, a building trades official and former United States Secretary of Labor.
 
Check for $55,000
 Many of the union leaders ended their speeches with pledges of money for the strikers. Most pledged $25,000, and the largest contribution was a $55,000 check from Local 1199, of Hospital Workers Union.
The peaceful but spirited rally was held in front of the Daily News's headquarters on East 42d Street. Police estimated the crowd at 2,700, but organizers said the number was at least double that. Among the banners and signs were the emblems of carpentry, electrical, transportation, retail and workers unions.
The strike at The Daily News began three weeks ago after months of fruitless negotiations and increasing bitterness. The newspaper has continued to publish using nonunion help, but most of its circulation has been cut off by the widespread refusal of newsstands to sell the paper, and its advertising is also down.
Both sides have accused each other of attacks and harassment, and both union members and Daily News security guards have been arrested, some in melees near where papers were being distributed.
"Who brought the bully boys to New York -- who hired the thugs?" Mr. Kirkland said. He accused the company of "the economic violence of stealing people's jobs -- that's the root of anything that might be called violence."

HEADLINE: Van Gogh Drawing Sets a Record at $8.4 Million

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
The ups and downs in art auctions continued last night at Christie's sale of Impressionist and modern works that saw a painting by Vincent van Gogh go unsold and a drawing soar to record levels.
Van Gogh's boldly drawn "Garden of Flowers," from 1888, in brown and black ink over pencil, brought $8.4 million, a record at auction for any drawing. It was bought by William Acquavella, a Manhattan dealer. But van Gogh's painting "Vase With Cornflowers and Poppies," from 1890, was bid to about $9 million -- well below the price the owner would accept. The house estimate was $12 million to $16 million. 
 The previous record for a drawing was $4.8 million paid for Raphael's chalk drawing "A Man's Head and Hands," from before 1520, which was auctioned at Christie's in London in 1984 in the sale of Old Master drawings from Duke of Devonshire's collection at Chatsworth in Derbyshire.
The total in Christie's auction of 47 offerings, of which 32 were sold, was $92.4 million, considerably less than the house estimate of $129 million to $158.6 million.
The van Gogh drawing was one of six works sold for prices above the high estimates of the auction house. Fourteen other works brought prices within the estimates, and 12 were sold for less than the low estimate.
"The average of what has sold has been at the low end of these estimates," said Richard Gray, a Chicago dealer. "One thing is certain: the market has not collapsed. The best works sold, and for top prices. The average works were discounted 20 0r 30 percent, and the mediocre works did not sell but probably will again when the market adjusts."
When asked what these lower prices and unsold lots mean for future sales, Michael Findlay, who heads Christie's Impressionist and modern art sales, said: "In the next four months, my colleagues and I will be gathering works for the spring sales. We are going to appraise paintings and objects in accordance with these results. If somebody brings us a Monet 'Waterlilies' that has some relationship to the $4.4 million one we sold tonight, we are not going to put an estimate on it of $6 million to $8 million," the estimate on "Water lilies." Mr. Findlay added, "The estimates will be taken down another notch."
 
Leger Brings Highest Price
 The highest price paid last night was $9.9 million, for Fernand Leger's abstract landscape "Houses Beneath the Trees," from 1913. The buyer was an unidentified American dealer.
Mr. Findlay said American buyers were more active last night than he expected. He said about one-third of the artworks went to American buyers, one-third to Europeans and one third to Japanese buyers. Among the European buyers was Thomas Ammann of Zurich, who bought Giacometti's "Standing Woman No. 1" for $3.9 million, just under the estimate of $4 million to $6 million.
Kazuo Fujii of the Fujii Gallery in Tokyo, said as he left the sale last night: "Reason has returned to the market." Mr. Fujii bought Picasso's "Head of a Woman," from 1921, for $2 million, the high estimate.
Ernst Beyeler, a Geneva dealer, who bought Edouard Manet's "Flowers in a Crystal Vase" for $3.7 million, a price within the house estimate, said: "The sale was quite strong. I think the auction houses will be more cautious in the future, giving guarantees, and that will make the estimates lower and will loosen the situation somewhat. It is not a crash. It is different from other situations in the economy. Good paintings still remain rare, and unless there is a catastrophe, there will always be money around to buy them."

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
Scenes From Family Life: Always More of the Same

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW

 BODY:
In David Storey's novel "Pasmore," the title character is troubled by a recurrent dream. Running in a race, he finds himself overtaken by everyone, even the "idlers and dullards." Suddenly awakening, he feels an "undiminished sense of terror."
That fear -- that life itself has passed one by -- shadows Mr. Storey's new play, "The March on Russia," a seemingly becalmed but quietly turbulent drama about Colin Pasmore, a university lecturer and author, and his family. For the Pasmores, fulfillment is no longer even a wishful fantasy. All that the characters can see on the horizon is more of the same, followed by "full stop."
The play was first presented last year at the Royal National Theater in London, in a production reuniting the playwright with his symbiotic director, Lindsay Anderson. In May, Josephine Abady staged it with an American company at the Cleveland Play House, and that production opened this week at Chelsea Stage.
Though one would never suggest that the American actors could duplicate the authenticity, especially the Yorkshire accents, of their English predecessors, Ms. Abady's production is exactingly shaded and subtle in its delineation of these regional characters. Led by John Carpenter and Bethel Leslie as the father and mother, the actors capture the underlying humor as well as the sadness. The uncredited scenic design is overly spare, but the production achieves a greater intimacy on the small stage at the Hudson Guild Theater than it did on a vast stage at the National.
Each of the three younger actors, Carol Locatell and Susan Browning as the daughters and Sean Griffin as Colin, is sensitive to the disparities as well as the similarities of these siblings. Together the five actors evoke a moving family portrait.
In more hopeful times, there were happier dreams. The father recalls, with poignancy, his youthful military service invading the Crimea around the time of the Russian Revolution (his march on Russia). It was a moment of adventure, followed immediately by marriage and 45 years of work in a Yorkshire coal mine. The father's life has been more forcefully circumscribed than the lives of his wife and children, but each one has been trapped within a self-limiting world.
Family rivalries become family rituals. Which child was loved most? To the audience, it should be clear that each was equally unloved, despite signs of occasional favoritism, and that the elder Pasmores have moved past their own despair to a kind of barely controlled disharmony.
At least for the first act, the story may seem deceptively light as the three adult offspring arrive separately at the parents' retirement cottage to help them celebrate their 60th wedding anniversary. There are no character revelations, as in Mr. Storey's "In Celebration," which deals with a related family situation 20 years earlier. But "The March on Russia" is suffused with sorrow and understanding as the characters find themselves unable to achieve a sense of kinship or of mutual support.
The play becomes elegiac, a longing for lost times that never were, except perhaps for the father's "march on Russia," and even that story seems to be disappearing from his memory. At the end of the play, his wife has to prod him to remember the facts (and perhaps the fiction) of his tale, the thought of which has become as important to her as it is for him.
In his plays and novels, Mr. Storey has tellingly explored the nature of families, especially those with working-class backgrounds, in which the offspring are educated and elevated to a higher social and economic level. The generational chasm between a father who has worked with his hands as a collier and a son who works with his mind cannot be bridged. People in Storey plays may embrace, but they are unable to touch one another emotionally. Instead, they either repress their feelings (like the mother) or suffer breakdowns (like Colin).
For Mr. Storey, "The March on Russia" is a return to an earlier mode. After "In Celebration," he moved on to the poetic symbolism of "The Contractor" and "Home," and in more recent years he has concentrated on fiction. Some may regard the new work as overly traditional, but family plays are always viable when they are as deeply felt as this one and when they are written with such lyrical understatement. Though the Pasmores are definably from Yorkshire, they are recognizable wherever sons and daughters are encouraged to excel and then do not realize their own ambitions and the expectations of their parents.
 
THE MARCH ON RUSSIA
 
By David Storey; directed by Josephine R. Abady; Presented by Chelsea Stage, 441 West 26th Street.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

The Phillips Petroleum Company, Bartlesville, Okla., is offering $300 million in notes due in 1997 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

HEADLINE: The Right Response to Recession

 BODY:
The pertinent economic question for America is not whether a recession has arrived but what to do about it.
While it is true that conditions in some parts of the country are better than a year ago, over all they are dicey, and distinctly gloomy in the Northeast. 
 Most forecasters say a national recession is under way. But there is no concurrence over how deep or how long. Given the uncertainties, the proper policy for Washington is to not do too much too soon, to stay alert but cautious.
A recession is popularly defined as a drop in the gross national product, adjusted for inflation, in two consecutive quarters. The real G.N.P. was still growing in the July-September quarter, just before and after the start of the Kuwait confrontation and the sharp runup in oil prices. The annual growth rate in those months was an unexpectedly strong 1.8 percent.
But monthly statistics through October have been decidedly softer. Factory output was down 0.8 percent in October, and cutbacks were exceptionally widespread. Unemployment held steady at 5.7 percent last month, and there are 30 cities where it is more than a percentage point lower than a year ago. Even so, the national average is expected to rise soon; non-farm jobs dropped by 58,000 in September and by 98,000 more in October, and there has been a surge in unemployment benefit claims.
Statistics apart, the news is full of reports of layoffs, and consumer confidence has been sinking. The whole country is not in trouble yet. While the Northeast is in a pronounced slump, the Northwest is still expanding, the Midwest and Southwest are so-so, and the oil patch is beginning to recover from the oil price plunges of the 1980's. But after a record eight-year expansion, the economy has been slowing down for months; the jump in oil prices last summer may have been the final straw.
Because hard statistics only come after the fact, the Government's policy makers cannot know what conditions prevail right now, much less what's to come. The biggest imponderable is how the Persian Gulf crisis ends. Meanwhile, high oil prices are an economic drag.
Despite this uncertainty, there are some certain facts. Most significant, the current inflation rate of about 6 percent is less than half what it was when the Federal Reserve slammed on the brakes and brought on the 1981-82 recession. That being so, there are some clear principles for policy makers to follow at this stage of a business cycle:
There is no call for panic if the budget deficit grows; it always does in a recession, as tax collections fall and safety net outlays rise. With a plan in place for long-term deficit reduction, President Bush's renewed hankering for a capital gains tax cut is pure mischief.
Lower interest rates are needed, but only modestly so for now, as the Federal Reserve has already recognized. Structural problems need attention -- weakness in banking and insurance and the unemployment compensation system. And protectionist pressure for more barriers to trade must be resisted at all costs; the best hope for trade expansion is a successful conclusion to the Uruguay Round.
Tough times are here, but they're not so tough that they justify rash or harsh moves. It is a time to be alert.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: PUBLIC & PRIVATE;
New World at War

BYLINE: By Anna Quindlen

 BODY:
When the police arrived they found the three children alone. They were wearing dirty clothes because they hadn't figured out how to do the laundry, and their father had tacked a note to the wall, telling them how to get cash with his automatic teller card. They were 8, 12 and 13, and they were hungry. There was no food in the house. Their father had been gone a week.
He'd left for the Persian Gulf. 
 The case of Staff Sgt. Faagalo Savaiki is a worst-case scenario, an extreme illustration of the collision between a changing American way of life and the demands of war. He is divorced, his ex-wife lives in Hawaii, and she couldn't manage to pay the airfare to Tennessee, which is where the children live with their father. He's back in the states now, charged with child abuse; the children are in foster homes, and the 101st Airborne Division, to which Sergeant Savaiki belongs, is still in the Middle East.
The world has changed since this country was last at war. It's not simply the shifting sands of geopolitics. In the waning years of Vietnam we were approaching our 200th birthday, an adolescent country still devoted to muscling any comers aside and being the undisputed champion of the world. We've grown up since. And there is nothing quite so sobering as becoming adult and discovering the real world.
The if of war in the Middle East has turned in many of our minds to a when. We know that once upon a time there were formal declarations of such things, but that seems so idealistic now. We remember, too, that once we believed we fought wars for reasons straight from the side of some marble monument. We are realistic about this conflict as only a grown-up, slightly world-weary country can be. We are going to war for oil, and, by extension, for the economy. The President trots out his Hitler similes to convince us otherwise.
The military is as changed as the rest of us. A support group in California reports that many of the soldiers writing home ask about public opinion, about whether we're for them or against them. They remember Vietnam; they know that uncomplicated patriotism is no longer our style. Eleven percent of our armed forces personnel are female today, more than a tenfold increase over 20 years ago. If heavy fighting begins, a significant number of the casualties will be women. People who yearn for the good old days are sure that women in body bags will convince us that women have overstepped their bounds.
For those of us who believe sons are as precious as daughters, it will simply provide further illustration that war is hell.
There are still plenty of military families with a "Best Years of Our Lives" quality, the mother waiting with the children for Daddy to come home from the gulf. But the number of single parents in America has doubled in the last 20 years, and 55,000 of them are in the service, along with an undetermined number of two-soldier couples. When they joined up, they were told that they had to assign guardianship for their children; there is no blanket combat exemption in an all-volunteer army for someone with babies to care for, or someone raising children alone.
Most have found temporary homes for their children with relatives. But at least two mothers ordered to the Mideast have left the Army, one because her children would not stop fighting with the cousins with whom they were bunking, and another because her parents became too ill to care for her baby daughter. Both women are fighting to be given honorable discharges.
The military is providing more counseling for its families than ever before. The relatives left at home are tying yellow ribbons around trees and telephone poles from Staten Island to Seattle. This will be a different war, in some ways, than any we have fought before, because this is a different kind of country. Our reality has outstripped the traditional stories of brave men going out to fight and die for a great cause while their women wait staunchly at home and provide security and normalcy for the children.
We have become more complicated than the scripts of old movies. Now we have brave women going out to fight and die for a cause none of us are sure about while their children struggle to feel secure with grandparents or aunts or uncles. Or a father who instructs the children in how to use his bank card and then leaves for Saudi Arabia. There is neither the kind of acceptance that lulled many of us at the beginning of Vietnam, nor the rage and betrayal that lit up the end. There is a quiet disillusionment: ah, this again. And for what?

HEADLINE: Bush Has the Cards, So Why Bluff?

BYLINE: By Bill Bradley; Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, is a member of the Senate Intelligence Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
All at once, President Bush has lost key allies in the international coalition he assembled so skillfully to deter Saddam Hussein's aggression in the Persian Gulf. His approach to the crisis has lost the support of nearly half the American people, polls show.
To continue to hold the support of Congress for any military action, he must come before us in a special session and explain why he has prematurely discarded his promising first strategy for a strategy of needless, high-stakes bluffing. 
 Without hearing a convincing explanation of that change, and with the cost of Operation Desert Shield now heading toward $30 billion, Congress should authorize no expenditures for a land invasion of Kuwait or Iraq.
 By supplementing the potent military force already in Saudi Arabia with a vast new Army and Navy presence that supposedly will provide an offensive capability, President Bush evidently hopes Saddam Hussein will appreciate the dimensions of the buildup, take U.S. intentions more seriously, recalculate his options and pull out of Kuwait.
But at this moment, it is hard to imagine that Mr. Hussein will respond to U.S. threats with anything but a renewed determination to dig in further around the ruins of Kuwait City. He may see more troops facing him, but he also sees Egypt declaring that it will not participate in an offensive action; he sees the Soviet Union urging a diplomatic settlement; he sees the sudden creation of valid dissent and doubt in the U.S.; he sees major questions being raised about restoring a monarch in Kuwait instead of installing a democratically elected ruler, and he sees the U.S. committing so many troops at one time that we cannot rotate them and they may not be in top fighting trim.
Before the new buildup, the economic sanctions coupled with a troop presence in Saudi Arabia were beginning to work. The strict boycott and embargo imposed on Iraq by the U.N. Security Council told Saddam Hussein that the world would wait as long as it took for him to get out of Kuwait, and the troops told him not to take one step further toward domination of the Middle East oil supply.
The sanctions were just beginning to pinch Iraq's food and industrial supplies. Saddam Hussein had shown signs of anxiety, abruptly firing his Oil Minister and army Chief of Staff. We knew that even if sanctions ultimately failed, we still would have overwhelming air power to achieve our objectives. Time, we knew, was on our side. Then President Bush decided to give up on time and gamble on brute strength. He decided on an empty, costly show of force that is either bluff or prelude to war.
If Saddam Hussein ultimately decides to abandon Kuwait, or to negotiate seriously, it will not be because he perceives an attack as imminent. It will be because he perceives war with the U.S. as unwinnable. In six to nine months, under boycott pressure, his military machine will begin to crumble as food, fuel, spare parts and morale dwindle. Iraq's remarkable economic development will be endangered. To Mr. Hussein, the prospect of losing power and position is a greater threat than that of losing an already decimated Kuwait.
With a slowly growing contingent of rested, properly rotated U.S. troops still waiting him out across the Saudi border, Mr. Hussein would certainly have realized that war with the U.S. was a lost cause and that withdrawal from Kuwait was the only possible path to preserve the gains of his rule. But now, with more troops but less unity, more tanks but less patience, we all but invite him to call our bluff.
While declaring that the new buildup is intended to give us the capacity to launch an invasion of Kuwait or Iraq, President Bush has not explained why this should be our objective now when it was not our objective in August. He has not even demonstrated that the new troops would provide an offensive capacity that had been lacking up to now. The land-based air forces currently in Saudi Arabia could take out all known strategic sites in Iraq, and none of the three additional carrier groups or the heavy Army corps units would add much to such an air campaign.
The most visible effects of the buildup will be to involve the Army and the Navy more deeply in Desert Shield (is inter-service rivalry once again driving military decisions?) and to double the cost of the operation, from $15 billion to $30 billion in the 1991 fiscal year.
When Congress passed the Defense Department appropriations bill this fall and exempted the costs of Desert Shield from budget limits, it created a perverse incentive for the military to find every excuse possible to push costs into this unlimited category. If that is happening here, then of all the misguided policies engendered by this year's budget process we have now created the most self-destructive imaginable -- one that will cost American lives.
In refusing to acknowledge the constraints of the War Powers Resolution, the Reagan and Bush Administrations have argued that seeking Congressional consent to go to war makes U.S. foreign policy unpredictable and inconsistent. But members of Congress have been unanimously supportive for months -- and the President's foreign policy has still become unpredictable and inconsistent.
Congressional oversight is necessary for just such situations as this, to hold us back from decisions that are clearly unwise. We do not have to wait to let history judge. We do not have to wait to let President Bush explain to the parents of soldiers killed in the Persian Gulf why he abandoned a policy that was working for a policy of high-stakes bluffing. He should explain it to Congress, and if he cannot persuade us that it makes sense, then we should make sure that any special supplemental appropriation does not contain one dollar for a land invasion of Kuwait or Iraq.

HEADLINE: REVIEW/PHOTOGRAPHY;
Another Facet of Mexico's Artistic Achievement

BYLINE: By ANDY GRUNDBERG

 BODY:
Judging from the evidence now on view in Manhattan, Mexican photographers are currently of two minds. They remain indebted to the country's leading practitioner, Manuel Alvarez Bravo, who for nearly 70 years has taken pictures that combine modernist clarity, Surrealist mystery and Mexico's own cultural heritage. At the same time, they have reached beyond Mr. Alvarez Bravo's influential synthesis to adopt postwar European and American styles -- notably those descended from Henri Cartier-Bresson.
Whether Mexican photographers feel a conflict between their indigenous tradition and the need for innovation, this outside observer cannot say. But the photographs that appear as part of this fall's diverse celebration of Mexican culture certainly suggest it. Two shows in particular provide telling glimpses into a vital esthetic arena of American art that remains largely unknown in the United States. 
 The shows are "Between Worlds: Contemporary Mexican Photography," an exhibition of more than 100 photographs, which opens Sunday at the International Center of Photography's uptown headquarters, and "Women in Mexico," at the National Academy of Design. "Women in Mexico" is a show of painting and sculpture as well as photographs, but the combination helps illuminate the context in which Mexican photographers work.
"Between Worlds," which was organized by Trisha Ziff, an English curator now living in Mexico City, features the pictures of 10 photographers between the ages of 26 and 65, as well as images from a group documentary project called "Megalopolis." Although its premise is that photography in Mexico remains distinct for cultural and economic reasons, the work on the walls presents no problems in terms of comprehensibility. Most of it is in the form of sociologically oriented, personally inflected photo essays that will seem familiar to anyone acquainted with the Magnum style of photojournalism.
Topics range from migrant workers -- Mexicans in southern California, Guatemalans in southern Mexico -- to life in remote villages. Bilingual text panels describe the significance of the subjects. But the groups of 6 to 10 pictures each are not photo essays in a traditional sense, for they have no clear beginning, middle and end. Instead, they are showcases for the photographers' compositional talents. They also tend to emphasize ritual and mystery instead of exposition.
Mariana Yampolsky, the show's senior figure, is represented by a series of pictures purporting to show the life of Mazahua women, whose men have left their villages for jobs in big cities. But her two most intriguing photographs, of cactus leaves and a dust storm, have little to do with conventional documentation. The same could be said of Flor Garduno's "Bestiarium," which at its best seems like a rerun of Mr. Alvarez Bravo's old Surrealist themes.
Surrealism came to Mexico in a big way with the 1940 international Surrealist exhibition in Mexico City, and its shadow hangs over even the most resolutely photojournalistic work on view. Jose Hernandez Claire's study of blindness includes an image of an eye operation that is as chilling as the opening of the classic film "Un Chien Andalou." The part of the show devoted to the theme "Megalopolis," which is intended to document Mexico City, includes such unlikely scenes as Marco Antonio Cruz's view of an Easter celebration, in which human feet inexplicably hang from the sky, and Pablo Ortiz Monasterio's image of two boys practicing matador moves beside an elevated highway.
The odd photographer out is also the youngest, Ruben Ortiz. In addition to being one of the two artists in the show to use color, he provides the only evidence that art photography of the last 15 years has had an impact in Mexico. His colors are bright, splashy and often enhanced with flash, and he is not afraid to fabricate reality in the studio, as he does in a picture of a shirtless man wearing a crown of neon tubing.
 The Surrealist influence that echoes through the documentary pictures in "Between Worlds" is even more in evidence in the photographs in "Women in Mexico," which includes work as early as 1927 (Tina Modotti's close-up of sugar cane, inspired by Edward Weston) and as recent as 1989 (Laura Cohen's strange pairings of plants and geometric figures). Like such painters as Frida Kahlo, Maria Izquierdo, Remedios Varo and Leonora Carrington, Mexico's female photographers seem most interested in creating dream scapes in which fantasy and reality are conflated.
The camera is not always the greatest ally of fantasy, however, so some of the efforts of Lola Alvarez Bravo, Kati Horna, Flor Garduno and Graciela Iturbide can seem forced. But when they succeed -- as in Ms. Iturbide's 1979 "Angel Woman," which shows a woman holding a portable radio and facing a forbiddingly empty desert -- the photographs resonate with the tensions between nature and culture, tribal and industrial, and life and death.
Ms. Cohen and Eugenia Rendon de Olazabal, two of the exhibition's younger photographers, seem to accept such contradictory aspects of Mexican life as a given, referencing their work as much to recent photography in the United States as to Surrealism and the indigenous example of Mr. Alvarez Bravo. This is not surprising, since the two countries share more than a border, but it suggests that any assumption about a uniquely Mexican style of photography remains open to question. At the same time, "Women in Mexico" makes clear that Mexican photographers have created and continue to create images of a high order.
 "Between Worlds: Contemporary Mexican Photography" was organized by the Impressions Gallery in York, England, and is traveling under the auspices of Curatorial Assistance Inc. of Los Angeles. It remains at the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street, through Feb. 3. "Women in Mexico," organized by the Centro Cultural/ Arte Contemporaneo of Mexico City, remains at the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, through Dec. 2.
 
'Portraits of Frida Kahlo and Friends'
Carla Stellweg
87 East Houston Street
Through Nov. 22
Frida Kahlo's painted self-portraits are hard to top, but that never stopped photographers from trying to record her essence on film. The 50 black-and-white prints gathered here constitute a fascinating compendium of her many guises. There is Kahlo, the young beauty, on a train; Kahlo in front of a fresco of Lenin with her husband, Diego Rivera; Kahlo at work dressed in a formal, floor-length dress; Kahlo, haggard and infirm, wearing a ring on each of her elegant fingers.
The best portraits of her seem to have been taken by other women, notably her friends Lola Alvarez Bravo and Lucienne Bloch. The star image of the show is a straightforward print by Imogen Cunningham, taken in 1930, on which the painter drew cartoon-style tears that stream down her cheeks. Kahlo seems always to have insisted on controlling her own representation; even when she did not directly intervene in the image, she styled herself and her surroundings with great care. The result is a theater of the self that often resembles a costume party.
