HEADLINE: A Spirited Thatcher Defense To Attack on Her Leadership

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher made a spirited rejection of Michael Heseltine's challenge to her leadership of the Conservative Party in the House of Commons today.
"After three general election victories leading the only party with clear policies, resolutely carried out, I intend to continue," she said, to cheers from the Conservative benches and jeers from the Labor opposition. 
 As Mr. Heseltine officially filed his candidacy to oust Mrs. Thatcher, a poll of the 240 of the 372 Tory legislators by the Press Association news service showed only 19.2 percent saying they would vote for him in the secret ballot next Tuesday, against 53.3 percent for Mrs. Thatcher.
Though the survey was carried out in strict confidence, the Press Association said, 27.5 percent refused to say how they would vote. Robert M. Worcester, a professional pollster who runs the Market and Opinion Research International organization here, said he had decided against a survey of legislators this week, partly because he did not trust the answers so long before the actual vote.
 
Voting Intentions Secret
 All but the most committed supporters of the two leadership candidates want to be able to live with the winner, whoever it is, and are reluctant to disclose their voting intentions publicly. Even if there are many abstentions, the winner must have at least 187 votes, and also a margin of at least 56, to win on the first ballot under the party rules. A runoff, if there is one, would be held the following Tuesday.
Mr. Heseltine has had the Prime Minister in his sights since he walked out of her Cabinet as Defense Minister in protest in January 1986, after losing a battle over whether the Westland helicopter company should be taken over by a European consortium instead of the American Sikorsky company, as Mrs. Thatcher wanted.
She has never been a comfortable person to have as a boss. Sir Geoffrey Howe, who resigned two weeks ago as her nominal deputy, was the last serving member of her first 1979 Cabinet. She had dismissed him as Foreign Secretary in mid-1989 after he and the then Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson, threaten to resign if she did not give a firm commitment that Britain would tie the pound closely to the European currency system. Mr. Lawson resigned in frustration a few months later, saying his advice was not being heeded.
 
Bitter Speech by Ex-Aide
 In a bitter speech on Tuesday, Sir Geoffrey called for her replacement as party leader because of what he called her negative attitude toward the European Community. But his secretary said today that he would not discuss how he was going to vote on Tuesday. "It's a private ballot," she said. Mr. Lawson also would not discuss his vote, an aide said.
Mrs. Thatcher's campaign is being run by George Younger, who replaced Mr. Heseltine as Defense Minister until leaving the Cabinet for personal reasons in 1989, and by three other men who have also been ministers in her Cabinet. They are Norman Tebbit, one of Mrs. Thatcher's closest friends and also former Conservative Party chairman; Michael Jopling, a former Agriculture Minister, and John Moore, who held three different Cabinet posts.
Mr. Heseltine's nomination, submitted today to the backbench Conservative Members' Committee that runs the leadership election, was proposed by a former sports minister, Sir Neil Macfarlane, and seconded by Sir Peter Tapsell, a frequent critic of Mrs. Thatcher.
 
Would Change 'Poll Tax'
 The challenger was busy giving radio and television interviews today, telling BBC radio how he would move to change the unpopular "poll tax" system, a per-capita payment plan Mrs. Thatcher has imposed for municipal government services.
He said he would "find a way of making the poll tax reflect a person's ability to pay," instead of leaving it the same for everybody in each local government district, and, as a fall-back position, would have the central Government instead of the local municipalities pay for education, to reduce the payment. The "community charge," as it is officially called, went into effect in England and Wales this spring at an average of 363, or $726, a person.
This evening Mr. Heseltine was campaigning for Conservative candidates in two special elections being held in Scotland on Nov. 29 to fill vacancies in Parliament.
Aside from sitting Cabinet ministers whose jobs depend on Mrs. Thatcher, few other M.P.'s have announced their positions.
 
Ridley Backs Thatcher
 Former Trade and Industry Secretary Nicholas Ridley, who had to leave the Cabinet last summer because of the furor over an interview he gave The Spectator magazine that took Germany to task, urged his colleagues today to support Mrs. Thatcher "through thick and thin," rather than surrender to "Eurocrats" who were "close to getting control of our economy."
Barney Hayhoe, another M.P., said "It is becoming increasingly difficult to envisage how the party could truly unite behind Margaret Thatcher, although I am absolutely convinced that unity will be achieved under a new leader."
Sir Philip Goodhart, a highly visible backbencher, said he thought Mr. Heseltine had about 100 committed supporters, as his supporters Michael Mates and Keith Hampson contended.
"I think there will be a second ballot," Sir Philip said. "I went to a meeting of senior backbenchers, more center than left, last night, and only one was going to vote for Maggie. There was an assumption that there'd be a second ballot, and about a third said they would switch to Douglas Hurd then."
Mr. Hurd, Mrs. Thatcher's Foreign Secretary, is the most likely candidate to succeed her if she became incapacitated, according to an official at 10 Downing Street.

HEADLINE: The Hungry Drift Across the Sudan Amid Ominous Signs of a New Famine

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EL OBEID, the Sudan

 BODY:
On a parched, dusty plain on the outskirts of this busy commercial city, nearly 10,000 destitute herders and farmers have pitched shanties, leaving behind their drought-ridden lands and dead crops. They have come searching for food and water.
Zamzam Osman, a 27-year-old pregnant mother, said she and her family left Shershar, 75 miles north of here, two months ago, their crop of gum arabic lost for lack of rain. "We tried a crop but the soil is no good and it failed," said Mrs. Osman, waiting for her husband and two boys to return from their begging trip to the city. 
 Mrs. Osman is one of tens of thousands of northern Sudanese from the Kordofan region who have migrated to either El Obeid or the national capital, Khartoum, as part of what international food experts are calling the "early signs of famine."
The Sudan is facing its third famine in six years. Experts from the United Nations and the United States say the impending disaster, complicated by a civil war and a hopeless economy, could be as bad as in 1984-85, when several hundred thousand people died of starvation; there is no more precise estimate of the death toll.
 
The Heart of the Dryness
 Again, the heart of the dryness seems to be here in Kordofan, a mostly roadless region as large as France with a population of 3.25 million people. The drought bodes ill not only for the people of Kordofan but for the shattered Sudanese economy. About 70 percent of the Sudan's exports of camels and sheep, among the country's few foreign exchange earners, come from Kordofan.
Other areas of the Sudan that are severely affected, according to early-warning bulletins issued by the Government's Relief and Rehabilitation Commission, are the Darfur region, particularly the northern sector, and the Red Sea Hills area on the eastern edge of the country.
A 400,000-acre delta area in the east whose water is replenished by an annual flash flood from Ethiopia has not been planted for the first time in 96 years, said Trevor Page, the head of the United Nations World Food Program in the Sudan. This year, the flash flood did not materialize, and Bejar nomads from the Red Sea Hills, without sustenance for their camels and themselves, are beginning to come to Tokar, the main town of the delta.
In the southern Sudan, where civil war continues between the Arab and Muslim north and rebels from the African and animist and Christian south, the rains appear to have been more plentiful, according to the early-warning bulletins.
But war curtailed planting, leaving many normally productive farmers dependent on relief food in crowded camps around the southern cities. Workers with the International Committee of the Red Cross, which stopped its relief flights in early October because of obstruction by the Khartoum Government, say food stocks have virtually run out in Malakal, a major Government-held town in the south. The Government seeks to prevent relief supplies from helping the rebels or their sympathizers.
 
U.S. Diverts a Shipment
 This November is a difficult month all over the Sudan. Last season's food has been all but used up. In areas where the crops have not completely failed, farmers are beginning to harvest what meager produce there might be -- in pockets of southern Kordofan; the Gazira, an irrigation project south of Khartoum on the Nile, and around Gedaref, southeast of the capital.
But the coming crop is expected to be so thin that the United States Agency for International Development predicts that the Sudan will need as much as one million tons in food aid.
The United States has indicated that it is prepared to provide 100,000 tons of food aid, but wants guarantees from the Sudanese Government that the food will be fairly distributed. In October, the United States diverted a shipment of wheat in protest over what it called Khartoum's blockage of distribution, particularly to people in the south.
So far, the Government in Khartoum has declined to acknowledge a dramatic food shortage, arguing that the irrigated areas like the Gazira will yield higher quantities than in the past. The Americans and some Sudanese agricultural experts dispute this.
Here in El Obeid, the capital of Northern Kordofan, there is no reluctance by desperate regional authorities to admit the scope of the shortages.
"We need 326,000 tons for Kordofan," said the Deputy Governor, Abdul Wahap Hassan Hussein. "In Northern Kordofan it is very, very bad. No rain. We request aid."
 
Plant Is a Bad Omen
 On the track north to the town of Bara, once-arable land is intermittently covered with six-inch-high dried stumps of millet. But a reed-like plant called marikh pokes tall and green out of the golden soil. The plant is a bad omen: it is a sign of desertification, which in this case is the moving southward of the Sahara largely because of human foraging for wood.
In the small villages around Bara and farther north at Sodiri, the nongovernmental American agency Care has started to distribute 4,000 tons of American- and European-donated grain in an attempt to halt the influx of people like Mrs. Osman into the cities.
The coordinator of the distribution, Bashir Yusif, received a note from one of his monitors overseeing the grain handouts in remote villages. "I have covered 16 to 17 village councils," the note said. "You may think I am very fast, but people are so hungry they come at night as well as day" asking for food.
On the outskirts of Khartoum, truckloads of people from Kordofan arrive daily, their belongings crammed into bundles. But getting enough food is a daily enurance test even for the residents of Khartoum who have official ration cards. The new arrivals from Kordofan and the displaced from the south, 30,000 of whom were forcibly moved out of the capital by the army at the end of October, are not entitled to ration cards. They must try to find odd jobs in the standstill economy so they can buy extravagantly expensive food or hope to get handouts from humanitarian agencies.
 
Animals Sold for Food
 As bad as the conditions are in Khartoum, they are better than in Kordofan, said Fatima Adam Hamid, a 60-year-old widow who sat on a straw mat on the dirt floor of her reed shack in Souk Libya, one of the 27 camps, where she settled in early October.
"We had nothing but haboobs," Mrs. Hamid said, referring to the searing dust storms at her home in Shershar.
The family, unable to grow their traditional crop of sorghum, sold their animals to get money for food.
"When we sell the goats we have something to eat," she said. "But we sold all the goats. In two years, we sold 20 cows and 40 goats. When there was nothing left, I came."

HEADLINE: U.S. Legislators Warn Kenya Rights Record Endangers Aid

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Three United States Senators have told the Kenyan Government, once one of Washington's favorite aid recipients in Africa, that because of its poor human rights record it would not receive its usual military aid next year.
In another sign of displeasure, the Senators made clear during their visit here this week that unlike some other African countries, Kenya would not share in the more than $200 million in increased economic development aid that Congress made available for the continent in the foreign aid bill adopted this month. 
 Despite warnings from Western donors and the World Bank that aid to Africa would be increasingly tied to liberalization, Kenya, under the leadership of President Daniel arap Moi, has remained steadfastly opposed to political pluralism.
Three well-known advocates of a multiparty system have been imprisoned and kept in solitary confinement without charges since July. More than 80 people have been charged with sedition for the possession of political cassettes and publications, and about 50 people have been charged "with breach of the peace" since the political crackdown. Four people were charged with treason last month.
 
Four Conditions Set
 Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, and chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee's foreign operations subcommittee, said here that under the terms of the foreign aid bill President Bush had to certify that Kenya was meeting four conditions to receive $15 million in military aid.
The conditions were these: to charge and try or release all prisoners, including political detainees; to stop mistreatment of prisoners; to restore the independence of the judiciary, and to restore freedom of expression.
The other members of the visiting delegation were Senators Al Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, and Barbara A. Mikulski, Democrat of Maryland.
Apparently in a gesture to donors, Mr. Moi said last week that his Government would introduce a bill in Parliament to restore the tenure of judges, the Attorney General and the Auditor General. The independence of the judiciary, which had been part of the Kenya Constitution since 1963, was removed in 1988, the same time that the secret ballot in primary elections was dispensed with.
 
Freedom for Detainees
 From the tone of the message Mr. Leahy delivered at a news conference and comments by officials at the United States Embassy here, it seemed unlikely that the restoration of an independent judiciary alone would be sufficient. Implicit was the expectation that the Kenyan authorities would have to release or charge the three political detainees, Kenneth Matiba, Charles Rubia and Raila Odinga.
President Moi was in Japan, the biggest donor of aid to Kenya, during the Congressional visit but the reaction of the Vice President and Finance Minister, George Saitoti, was a version of what Mr. Moi has been saying for the last several months: that Kenya will not change its ways because donors demand it.
"Kenyans will not allow themselves to be dictated as to what changes to undertake," Mr. Saitoti said in Parliament to the stamping of feet in approval. "We shall not do anything to appease anybody."
Last year, Kenya was appropriated $15 million in American military aid but received only $10 million because the remaining $5 million was canceled after the imprisonment of the three politicians in July. Congress approved $25 million for economic development aid and $14 million for food aid for the coming year, about the same amounts as Kenya received in 1990.
Other African countries, notably Mozambique and newly independent Namibia, received increases in their aid, not only because of obvious need from war and famine, but also as rewards for introducing measures permitting a multiparty system.
Increasingly economically strapped because it is entirely dependent on imported oil, Kenya lost $20 million in aid from Norway when President Moi cut off diplomatic relations last month in a dispute over a Kenyan exile arrested on treason charges. The Danish Government has announced it will cut its aid of $35 million by one quarter because of unhappiness with Kenya's rights record.

HEADLINE: In Court, U.S. Blames Drexel For Much of the S.& L. Crisis

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

 BODY:
The Government asserted yesterday that a principal culprit in the savings and loan debacle that is costing taxpayers billions of dollars was Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and the "junk bond" market that it developed.
In arguing this case in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, the Government entered a new legal frontier in its attempt to recover some of the billions of dollars lost at failed savings institutions. 
 For the first time, it disclosed in considerable detail what it had already found about the investment firm's role in the collapse of 48 savings institutions and in the difficulties of one that is struggling to survive, the Columbia Savings and Loan Association of Beverly Hills, Calif.
Drexel accomplished its dominance of the junk bond market, the Government contends, by bribing savings executives, raising more money than necessary from one savings institution to enable it to invest in more Drexel junk bonds, and manipulating the prices of bonds, often by trading them between institutions. Among the institutions cited with which Drexel arranged deals were Centrust Savings of Miami; Gibraltar Savings of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Lincoln Savings and Loan of Irvine, Calif.
Drexel and its other creditors assert that the Government's claims are an attempt to squeeze as much as possible from the remains of Drexel, while shifting the blame away from regulators who failed to act quickly enough throughout the 1980's in the face of economic problems like bad real estate loans.
"The Government is clearly trying to stir up a lot of dust, but if it hadn't fallen asleep at the switch in the first place, then the S.& L.'s wouldn't be in the position that they are now," said Harrison J. Goldin, the former comptroller of New York City who is representing a committee of Drexel's unsecured creditors. "These claims have little merit."
Alan Miller, Drexel's main lawyer, said, "What they are trying to do is make Drexel a convenient scapegoat to deflect criticism that the regulators were inadequate." The true causes of the savings industry collapse, he maintained, had little or nothing to do with Drexel but were precipitated by a host of regulatory and economic failures including bad real estate loans.
Even if the Government prevails in its argument, it will be impossible to recover the $11 billion it is seeking because Drexel's estate is estimated at $3 billion, and the firm faces other large Government claims, included a claim expected to be filed next week by the Internal Revenue Service for about $1 billion. But the cases provide important road maps for other actions that the Government has said it will file against lawyers, accountants, savings and loan executives and their insurance companies.
 
Disclosures on Criminal Cases
 The new findings also added substantially to what Federal prosecutors had already disclosed in the criminal cases against Drexel and other leading Wall Street figures. Much of the earlier findings had been sealed because of settlements reached on those cases.
The Government's theory is that Drexel's phenomenal success throughout the last decade until its collapse earlier this year was attributable largely to its ability to tap into enormous pools of federally insured money held at scores of savings and loan associations.
"Drexel and its co-conspirators sought to create an illusion of value in junk bonds," the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Resolution Trust Corporation said in their court papers. "They set out to convince the investing public that junk bonds could be bought and sold in a liquid trading market and that the focus on junk bonds should not be the high risk but rather the 'high yield.' In fact, the 'yield' was often infinitesimal or nonexistent because the securities turned out to b worthless."
 
Bribe Charge at Centrust
 In one instance, according to the Government, Drexel raised $262 million for Centrust Savings of Miami and sold it $1 billion worth of unrated private placements at the same time that it was selling highly profitable warrants underwritten by Drexel to the institution's chief executive, David L. Paul, in effect bribing him for the business that he provided.
The Government also charges that Centrust secretly held stock owned by Drexel to avoid regulatory requirements, a crime known as stock parking. The institution was seized earlier this year by the Government, and its bailout is expected to cost taxpayers more than $1.7 billion.
In another case, the Government contends that Drexel manipulated the price of securities to permit the Gibraltar Savings Association, to which it had sold many junk bonds, to conceal the actual losses in its portfolio. Gibraltar's chief executive, Herbert Young, received warrants of a Drexel-underwritten security to enable him to make a $100,000 profit three weeks later, the Government charges. Gibraltar ultimately suffered a $44 million loss from its sale of Drexel bonds.
 
Keating Named in Lincoln Case
 At a third institution, the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, regulators said that Drexel provided kickbacks to Charles H. Keating Jr. and helped him carry out several fraudulent schemes so that Lincoln would both invest heavily in junk bonds and use Drexel as an underwriter.
The decision by the Federal regulators to pursue claims of more than $11 billion against Drexel in effect makes the bankruptcy proceeding an unusual forum in which the Government and Drexel's other creditors will explore the contributions of both the investment house and the regulators into the failures of the savings and loan industry.
Altogether, regulators are seeking $6.8 billion on behalf of 48 institutions that failed and fell into Government hands, along with $4.5 billion from Columbia Savings and Loan, which the Government may seize if Columbia is unable to turn around its unprofitable track record.
Late yesterday evening, the Federal bankruptcy judge overseeing the case delivered a setback to the Government's attempts to expand its Drexel proceeding to other savings institutions not mentioned in its court papers. The judge, Francis Conrad, refused to extend Thursday's deadline for filing new claims, arguing that the regulators had "dragged on long enough" with their investigations.
Among the institutions that the Government's lawyers told the judge they had hoped to include were the Empire Savings Bank of Buffalo and the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, the Denver institution where President Bush's son, Neil, sat as a director.
 
View of Drexel Spokesman
 A spokesman for Drexel, Steven S. Anreder, suggested that one motive for the high dollar amount of the claims was that the Government's local counsel in the case, Cravath, Swaine & Moore, is receiving its fee partially based on the amount of money it recovers.
"Regardless of the numbers of zeroes and the claims of the Government, which has a contingency fee arrangement with its lawyers, Drexel intends to vigorously defend against them in the bankruptcy proceeding," Mr. Anreder said.
The Government's lead lawyer in the case is Thomas D. Barr, a senior partner at Cravath who became well known in legal circles for his successful defense in the Government's antitrust case against the International Business Machines Corporation.
More recently, Mr. Barr represented Chemical Bank, the trustees for the bondholders in the enormous and complex legal proceedings of the Washington Public Power Supply System. He was also the chief lawyer for Time magazine when it successfully defended itself against a libel suit brought by Ariel Sharon, the former Israeli Defense Minister.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
SOVIET AIDE URGES DELAY OF U.N. MOVE ON FORCE IN GULF

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 15

 BODY:
The Soviet Union's chief Middle East negotiator called today for a delay in introduction of a Security Council resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq to give time for a final negotiating effort that would give President Saddam Hussein a "face-saving" reason to give up Kuwait peacefully.
But the official, Yevgeny M. Primakov, who has served as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's special envoy in the Persian Gulf crisis, said in an interview at the Hotel Inter-Continental in New York that if such an initiative fails, not only should a Security Council resolution authorizing force be approved, but military action should also be taken almost immediately against Iraq. 
 He said that while a negotiating initiative was under way, the United Nations Security Council should not be rushed into approving new resolutions authorizing the use of military force against Iraq.
 
U.S. Opposes Negotiations
 The United States, which holds the Council's rotating presidency this month, would like to secure such a resolution by the end of November, although it does not appear likely that military action would be taken, if at all, before next year. The United States has also opposed negotiations with Mr. Hussein.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d arrived in Brussels tonight for talks on a resolution. [Page A12.]
The Soviet diplomat said he expected these Soviet ideas to come up in talks this weekend in Paris between Mr. Baker and his Soviet counterpart, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, and also between President Bush and Mr. Gorbachev, who will take part in the meeting of leaders of the 34 nations in the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which begins on Monday.
 
Award for Soviet Official
 Mr. Primakov was in New York to receive the Citizen Exchange Council's George P. Kennan Award for promoting better Soviet-American relations.
If the Security Council decides the current economic sanctions against Iraq have failed and no negotiated solution is achieved, he said that a resolution authorizing force should be adopted, followed by an immediate attack on Iraqi-occupied Kuwait.
"We should use up all possibilities for a political solution before force," Mr. Primakov said, speaking in English with occasional help from an interpreter. But he added: "If there is to be a Security Council resolution on military force, then you should act immediately. If you adopt it without action you send the wrong signal. I'm not for bluffing with dangerous things."
Bush Administration officials in Washington said that Mr. Primakov's comments were familiar to them and that they did not believe he was speaking for either Mr. Gorbachev or Mr. Shevardnadze.
 
No Reward, U.S. Says
 "Our position has always been one that Saddam Hussein cannot be rewarded for his aggression," one official said. "This is something that Primakov himself has been told. Secretary Baker had an extremely good round of discussions with Foreign Minister Shevardnadze on this subject in his recent meeting and we expect the President will likewise have a very good discussion with President Gorbachev in France."
Mr. Primakov said the five countries with permanent Security Council seats -- the United States, Britain, France, China and the Soviet Union -- should join with the Arab League countries to send an envoy to Baghdad to present President Hussein with what he called "a face-saving package."
Such a package, he went on, would "draw together" all the ideas that have been suggested for linking a resolution of the gulf crisis with an overall Middle East settlement which would include a resolution of the Palestinian problem.
 
'Face-Saving Package'
 "We should gather up all the things that have been said in the United Nations and the Arab League about negotiating Iraq's dispute with Kuwait and settling the Palestinian problem and give them to him in one big face-saving package," he said.
Mr. Primakov, who made two trips to Baghdad on Mr. Gorbachev's behalf last month, insisted that Iraq must withdraw unconditionally from Kuwait, as the Security Council demands, and that Mr. Hussein should not be allowed to reap any tangible rewards from his invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2.
But he said President Hussein might still be persuaded to give up Kuwait peacefully if the permanent Security Council members and Arab League countries can convince him this will lead to withdrawal of foreign forces from the gulf, a resolution of the Palestinian problem and the establishment of a new security structure designed to stabilize the whole region, guaranteeing the safety of both Israel and its Arab neighbors.
 
European Security Talks
 Mr. Primakov said the idea of a new, and perhaps final, attempt to negotiate a peaceful settlement to the crisis is likely to be raised in Paris on the sidelines of the meeting of the 34 members of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe next week.
This meeting will bring together the heads of state or government of four of the five permanent Security Council members, though not of China.
Western diplomats who had questions about Mr. Primakov's statements recalled that after Mr Primakov's second visit to Baghdad, which ended Oct. 28, President Gorbachev said his envoy had detected signs that "Iraq's leadership might at last heed the voice of the United Nations."
But later official pronouncements from Baghdad suggested otherwise.
 
New Mideast Effort
 President Bush, President Francois Mitterrand of France and Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd of Britain all said in addresses to the General Assembly this year that an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait should lead to a new effort to resolve the whole Middle East question, including an agreement on Israel's boundaries, suggesting that President Hussein has a chance to present a withdrawal from Kuwait as a move that opened the door to a national homeland for Palestinians.
President Hussein has also hinted that he might be prepared to surrender Kuwait in return for the withdrawal of foreign forces from the gulf and settlement to the Palestinian and other Middle East issues.
Western diplomats say they are concerned that the Soviet Union wants to forge an unrealistically close link between the crisis in the gulf and the Palestinian problem.
 
A Shift Is Noted
 Mr. Primakov admitted that there has been little sign so far that the Iraqi leader is preparing to cooperate with the Security Council demand to withdraw from Kuwait. But he said he had seen "an evolution of his position" between his two visits to Baghdad.
During his first visit on Oct. 5, Mr. Primakov said the Iraqi leader spent much of their time together arguing his claim that Kuwait is an integral part of Iraq that was artificially separated from it by Britain in colonial days.
But when he returned to Baghdad on Oct. 28, Mr. Hussein no longer appeared interested in defending the takeover. Instead, he wondered how the Security Council could guarantee a resolution of the Palestinian issue if he gave up Kuwait. He also worried about his personal safety, recalling several plots against him after he agreedto a cease-fire with Iran two years ago. And he asked for guarantees that Iraq would not be attacked.

HEADLINE: C'est le Bronx? Ou Sont les Maisons Abandonnes?

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
It didn't rate three abandoned cars in the Guide Michelin, but a new chapter in Bronx tourism history may have been opened yesterday, when a busload of French architects rolled up the Grand Concourse to survey monuments to the borough's rebirth.
Bronx tours have been big at least since 1977, when President Jimmy Carter stopped on a rubble-strewn lot on Charlotte Street, decried the blight and promised the renewal that has followed in fits and starts. But that was what the Bronx-born tour guide, a real-estate developer named Jeffrey F. Silber, was worried about. 
 "They'll definitely feel cheated if they don't feel squalor," he said.
As he paced the foyer of the Bronx Museum of the Arts yesterday morning, waiting and waiting for the 40 architects and urban planners from L'Ecole d'Architecture de Grenoble, Mr. Silber drew his lower lip nervously over his greying, Chaplinesque mustache. He seemed to be perspiring. Bronx tours probably were easier, he said, in the days of burning trash cans, burning cars and burning buildings.
"Real battlefront action," he said.
It was, anyway, the Bronx for which the French had prepared. Over a week of visits to skyscrapers, museums and fancy architectural firms, almost all in Manhattan, many of them had caught glimpses of what they took to be demimonde: a service at a Baptist church in Harlem, a night at a sleazy Chelsea disco, a subway shuttle between Times Square and Grand Central Station.
"Le Bronx," coughed one woman from inside a thick jacket of fake fur. "There were no references to its architecture."
But in "Le Guide du Routard," a French-language backpacker's guide to America, there was a paragraph entitled "Le Bronx." It began: "Symbol of the most extreme poverty, contains nonetheless one of the biggest zoos in the world."
 
More Art Deco than Miami
 "We know of the Bronx from the movies -- the police movies," said Francois Bregnac, an architect who dragged on his cigarettes like a detective in one of them.
Mr. Silber began his slide show. Ghostly skeletons of burned-out apartment buildings flashed on the screen. Then the images changed.
"The Bronx is very green," he intoned over bright photographs.
"Vert?!" exclaimed several, in apparent disbelief.
John F. Kennedy once lived in the Bronx (in Riverdale), Mr. Silber said, having obviously hit on a crowd favorite. "Not a lot of people know that." And there are more Art Deco buildings than in Miami, he said. And forget about landscape in Brooklyn, he advised: "Flat as a crepe."
"Flat as a grape?" several in the back pondered aloud.
Finally the huge red bus lumbered north up the Concourse. Mr. Silber asked if it looked anything like the Champs-Elysees.
"It looks like Moscow," said Jean Luc Cornet, Grenoble's city planner.
The bus lurched to a halt at 180th Street in the University Heights section. Prefabricated houses were rising everywhere. The French descended in a cloud of pink cheeks, blue jeans and black leather.
Inside a red-brick two-family unit, debate over insulation ensued.
"I believe the lack of phonic isolation from one apartment to another is a source of the social problems among neighbors," said Odile Goddard, "particularly among the lower classes, which don't have sufficient culture." (She meant that prefabs were noisy.)
It was not until lunch at a Dominican restaurant on Kingsbridge Road, "El Rey del Bistec," -- "the King of Beefsteak" -- that Mr. Silber seemed to win over his charges entirely.
 
Winner: Le Roi de Bifteck
 "It's better than a hamburger," Sophie Garrel, a real-estate agent, said, chomping on a plantain chip.
But then lunch ended, and a new tour bus did not arrive. Mr. Silber finally concluded that this was no problem. "Gypsy cabs," he said.
"What do these cabs look like?" a woman asked. Battered four-door vehicles began circling the crowd. The woman looked nervous.
But 10 cabs were found, and only one had an accident on the two-mile trip to the Bronx office of the City Planning Department. And there, one of the borough's urban designers was waiting with a surprise that seemed to calm all of their nerves.
His name was Yves Trillon. And he was French.

HEADLINE: Drastic Measures Urged to Ease Two Budget Gaps;
Florio Tells Agencies 8% Cuts Are Needed This Year, Not Next

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 15

 BODY:
With his fiscal advisers preparing a report that shows the New Jersey economy worsening rapidly, Gov. Jim Florio said today that he had told his commissioners to start cutting their agencies' budgets by up to 8 percent.
Mr. Florio had previously ordered budget reductions of 8 percent in the next fiscal year, which begins on July 1. But today -- joining a chorus of budget-cutting by state and local governments throughout the region -- the Governor said he had told his commissioners to speed up that process. 
 The cuts are needed now, he said, to help close a growing budget gap that some officials expect will exceed $350 million by the end of the current fiscal year.
The shape and the depth of this year's cuts remain uncertain. But Mr. Florio said that some of the state's more than 80,000 employees might be laid off.
 
Not Getting Their Money's Worth
 "We need to start saving money right away, and not just be talking about it," the Governor told about 200 delegates to the 75th annual convention of the New Jersey State League of Municipalities.
Mr. Florio said there was more than an economic downturn behind his call for government cuts. He said voters in the Nov. 6 elections were sending a message "to me and, I suspect to other people, that they don't think they're getting their money's worth for their tax dollar."
Mr. Florio said the public was right and that he had ordered a study to see if some of the state's 19 departments can be combined to produce staff cuts and program economies. And, he added, additional cuts will be announced in the coming days.
Although the entire state budget totals about $12 billion, roughly two-thirds of that money is state aid and is therefore untouchable. The Governor is hoping that the 8 percent agency cuts will save more than $100 million from the remaining third during the current year and more than $300 million next year.
 
Cuts in New York and Connecticut
 By comparison, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York has asked his agencies to cut up to 7 percent from their budgets, and Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York City, has ordered most of his commissioners to cut 4 percent; some must cut only half that. Connecticut's Governor-elect, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., will have to deal with a shortfall that has been estimated at nearly a third of the state's $7.1 billion budget.
The 13,000 elected and appointed government officials who came to this gaming and ocean resort for their annual four-day convention often talked more about the recent election and the role Mr. Florio's $2.8 billion tax program played in the balloting, than they did the housing, environment and planning problems they were here to discuss.
The increased taxes, which are to be used for state aid to public schools and to provide property tax relief, helped raise voter disenchantment with government and inspired a protest at the polls that nearly upset the re-election of some incumbents, including Senator Bill Bradley.
After the election, Mr. Florio said his failure to build a consensus for his program before pushing it through the State Legislature was responsible for much of the voter resentment.
His speech today drew little reaction from the audience, except for some laughter when he said, "I'm well aware that people feel I sometimes moved too fast without listening to others."
 
No Vote, Just a Door in the Face
 There was no laughter on Wednesday, however, when Linda D. Stender, the council president in Fanwood and a Democrat, confronted the Assembly Speaker, Joseph V. Doria, Democrat of Bayonne, to complain that the party's state leadership did not do enough to help her and other Democratic candidates in local races.
Mrs. Stender said she and her running mate both lost, despite Fanwood's having the lowest municipal tax increase in Union County last year.
"People were slamming the door in my face," she said, "And one person said, 'I'm not voting for any Democrat this year after what your Governor did to this state.'
"I'm part of the Florio backlash," Mrs. Stender said. "I'm one of the messengers."
In his remarks today, Mr. Florio said reductions in state spending would have to be matched by similar cuts on the local level.
 
'Much More to Do'
 He said property taxes had more than doubled in the last decade and suggested that towns regionalize services wherever possible. He said some already shared police and fire communications services, libraries, recycling programs and health inspections.
"But there's much more to do," Mr. Florio said. "We still have 481 local police departments and 588 school districts, more school districts than Virginia, Pennsylvania, Maryland and Delaware combined."
The Governor called the rise in property taxes "intolerable," and said, "It destroys communities and drives people out of the neighborhoods that they helped to build."
Some of those officials who listened to his speech said it struck the right tone in times of financial problems, but offered little in the way of real help for hard-pressed cities.
Mayor Robert H. Grasmere of Maplewood, a Republican and a past president of the league, said: "Consolidation certainly makes sense, but it by no means will solve the problems of municipal finances. We need greater support from the state."
Earlier today a dozen of the state's urban mayors met to discuss ways to make the public aware of the increased school aid and property tax relief included in Mr. Florio's program. They said those parts of the package have been overlooked in the talk of repealing the increases won by Mr. Florio in both the state sales and income taxes.
"We have to make sure we don't lose the increased aid," said Mayor Robert Menendez of Union City, who is also a State Assemblyman. "If we do, some municipalities could go belly up, and we can't allow that."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 17, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about plans for budget cuts in New Jersey referred imprecisely in some copies to Gov. Jim Florio's position on layoffs of state workers. He said some of the state's more than 80,000 employees might be laid off.

HEADLINE: New York's Transit Facing Grim Steps in Budget Crisis

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Officials of the New York City Transit Authority said yesterday that to close a $272 million deficit for 1991, they could be forced to take such drastic steps as raising the fare again, eliminating all subway and bus service in early-morning hours or closing some stations and token booths.
The officials said that while they planned to offset about $170 million of the deficit through other cuts, they were still scrambling to come up with the remaining $102 million. Without additional state subsidies, which seem unlikely, the officials said they would have to take Draconian measures. 
 The figures, which represent the grimmest estimate yet of the Transit Authority's deteriorating fiscal health, were released yesterday as part of the agency's budget for the fiscal year starting Jan. 1. Transit officials presented the budget to the finance committee of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Transit Authority's parent agency.
 
A Decline in Riders
 The development comes as a weakening regional economy has already forced the authority and the metropolitan area's commuter railroads to cut service or consider doing so. The authority has also been hurt by declining ridership and rampant fare-beating.
To achieve $170 million in cuts, transit officials said they planned to reduce subway and bus service during evenings and weekends, eliminate 1,406 jobs through attrition and retraining, limit overtime, continue a hiring freeze and adopt a variety of operating efficiencies.
To meet the remaining $102 million, the officials said they had offered three options to the M.T.A. board: a fare increase, higher state subsidies or drastic cuts in service and maintenance. The board is expected to decide by the end of December what action the Transit Authority will take.
"I would rather not implement many of these more Draconian measures," said Alan F. Kiepper, the Transit Authority's president, "but these are very tough times, and you sometimes have to do things that you don't want to do."
 
4 Hours Without Service?
 Perhaps the most alarming of the options is eliminating subway and bus service between 1 and 5 A.M. -- a proposal that mass-transit advocates said was intended mainly to get the attention of legislators in Albany.
Beverly Dolinsky, a spokeswoman for the Permanent Citizens Advisory Committee, a consumer transit advocacy group, said: "New York is a 24-hour city. It's just not cost-effective to close the trains late at night. What are you going to do for the people who have to get around at night?"
She said the Transit Authority was using the threat of cutting early-morning train service to get the state government to consider supplementing its subsidies.
Joseph Rappaport, a spokesman for the Straphangers Campaign, another advocacy group, said: "Their proposal to close the system at night is idiotic and would lose them money rather than save it. It shows just how divorced from reality they are."
 
'Logistical Nightmare' Projected
 Mr. Rappaport said closing the subway system during the early morning would be a "logistical nightmare" for the agency, because subway stations would have to be secured, new yards would have to be built to park all the trains and elaborate new work schedules would have to be devised to accommodate the new hours.
Still, some transit officials said that discontinuing early-morning subway and bus service was a feasible option, because only 39,000 riders, or fewer than 2 percent of the daily total, use the system from 1 to 5 A.M. The Transit Authority projected that it would save about $11.2 million in 1991 by discontinuing subway and bus service during these hours.
Other possible actions to close the budget gap, authority officials told the M.T.A. yesterday, are trimming training and programs for the overhauling of buses, the painting of stations and the cleaning of vehicles and stations.
In addition transit officials told the board that more could be saved by closing 10 stations permanently and 25 at night, closing the Transit Museum, reducing the number of subway maps distributed to the public by half and eliminating the station-manager program, which puts trouble-shooters at the stations.
 
A Matter of Options
 "The board asked for options, and we gave them a host from which to choose," said Jared Lebow, a Transit Authority spokesman. "Some are more palatable than others."
Mr. Kiepper, the Transit Authority's president, said that while the agency was citing reductions in bus maintenance as an option, he did not recommend such a move. It would "be a setback to the system," he said, "and is the sort of cutback that got the system in trouble during the 1960's and 1970's."
In their presentation to the M.T.A. board, transit officials said a fare increase could also be used to offset some of the $102 million budget gap. A 10-cent fare rise, they noted, would produce about $10 million a month in additional revenues.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Still No Clear Signal on Fed Policy

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Credit market participants who sought an unambiguous signal that the Federal Reserve Board had eased monetary policy were disappointed again yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly and interest rates inched higher.
The Fed has been a primary focus of the fixed-income market since Tuesday, when the central bank's policy-making Open Market Committee held a meeting in Washington. 
 Many analysts said that to combat the apparent weakness in the economy the committee probably moved to lower its target for the Federal funds rate, the rate the central bank most closely controls and uses to signal a change in its interest-rate policy.
 
 More Reserves Are Added
 Yesterday, for the second day in a row, the Fed added reserves to the banking system, a move that under other circumstances might be seen as a clear indication that it wished the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other on overnight loans, to move lower.
As on Wednesday, however, the Federal funds rate was trading above the 7 3/4 percent level, which is widely seen as the Fed's target. At the time the Fed entered the market yesterday, Federal funds were trading at 7 7/8 percent.
"I don't think the Fed eased," said Robert Chandross, chief economist at Lloyd's Bank. "If they had wanted to signal an easing, they would have done it unambiguously. The fact that funds traded firmly all day suggests that they didn't ease."
The Federal funds rate, which traded as high as 8 1/8 percent yesterday, never moved below the 7 7/8 percent level.
 
 Waiting on Consumer Prices
 Mr. Chandross and others said the Fed might be waiting until the consumer price report for October was released by the Government this morning.
"A bad consumer price report, one which showed that the index rose by half a percentage point or more excluding food and energy, would make it tough for the Fed to ease immediately," he said. "But if the C.P.I. is respectable, they will feel much more comfortable to make the move."
And Jeffrey Leeds, chief economist at Chemical Bank, said, "I would think we will get a conclusive signal from the Fed on Friday or early next week."
Although prices of Treasury securities dipped yesterday, most dealers said the declines reflected concern over today's inflation report rather than disappointment with the Fed.
 
 30-Year Bonds Drop
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 102 3/8, down 6/32, to yield 8.52 percent, compared with 8.50 percent late Wednesday.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 7/8, down 3/32, to yield 8.36 percent. And the 7 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 9/32, down 2/32, to yield 7.58 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates rose slightly. By late in the day, three-month Treasury bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.08 percent, up 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. And six-month bill rates rose by 4 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.04 percent.
At yesterday's auction of $11.8 billion worth of one-year Treasury bills, bids on the securities produced an average discount rate of 6.81 percent, down from an average rate of 7.01 percent at the last one-year bill auction, on Oct. 26. It is the lowest rate on a one-year bill since the May 5, 1988, auction.
 
 Strong Gains for 'Junk Bonds'
 In other markets, prices of high-yield "junk bonds" posted strong gains yesterday, with most high-yield issues rising by about 2 points.
"A combination of continued buying by collateralized bond obligations and some equity infusions that are being proposed for some issues are helping the market," said Robert Long, head of high-yield research at the First Boston Corporation. "So too is a fundamental realization that the pessimism that drove the market down was probably overdone."
Among the positive developments yesterday was a disclosure by Fort Howard Paper that it was seeking an infusion of $250 million and had more than half of the total already in hand. The news helped to push up prices of its outstanding issues by as much as 10 points.
Market participants said the rise in junk-bond prices had little or nothing to do with the $6.8 billion suit filed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Resolution Trust Corporation against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.
 
 'No New News Here'
 The Federal regulators asserted that more than 40 failed savings and loan associations had lost as much as $2 billion because of Drexel's manipulation of the junk-bond market.
"There is no new news here," said Mariel Clemenson, director of high-yield research at Citicorp Investment Bank. "If anything, it shows that some of the product created in the late 1980's is of dubious quality. But we have so many other problems to worry about that it is basically immaterial to the market."
Along with other securities, junk bonds have taken a pounding since the onset of the Persian Gulf crisis. The rally has helped, but, as Ms. Clemenson suggested, prices in the high-yield market remain very depressed.
As of late yesterday, an index of the most actively traded high-yield issues, compiled by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, showed the securities were yielding 20.58 percent. That level is an improvement from Oct. 31, when the index was at 21.30 percent. But it is still far above the 15.36 percent level recorded on Aug. 2, the day Iraq invaded Kuwait.
 
 Flood of Corporate New Issues
 Elsewhere, in the investment-grade corporate bond market, the flood of new issues continued yesterday, as six more companies priced debt offerings.
Among the issuers was the Unocal Corporation, which offered $250 million of 10-year notes through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The 9.75 percent notes were priced at $99.56 to yield 9.82 percent, 1.45 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8.50 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities, which are noncallable for life, are rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Separately, late yesterday the Federal Reserve Board reported that the two largest measures of the nation's money supply fell during the week ended Nov. 5. But M1, the nation's basic money supply, rose by $2.4 billion during the period.

HEADLINE: Bush Says Recession Is Possible

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
President Bush conceded for the first time tonight that the country might face a recession, but he said his economic advisers did not believe a long and severe one was in the offing.
In an interview broadcast on the Cable News Network, the President said, "Most seem to feel that if we have a recession, it will not be deep and that we'll come out of it relatively soon, six months at most, and I'd like to think that is true." 
 Most economists are saying that the economy, if not in a recession now, is on the verge of one.
Mr. Bush seemed determined to present an optimistic view. "I'd like to be a little reassuring on this economy," he said. "I am concerned about the slowdown. I worry about anybody that wants a job and doesn't have one. But I am not a gloom and doom person on where the American economy will be before long. And yet I don't want to mislead you, because I am concerned that we're in a downturn here."
 
 Keeping 1992 in Mind
 If the President and his advisers hav made any important decisions on economic policy, they are not letting on, either in meetings or in interviews.
The weakness of the economy is now a clear political debit for the President and is one factor that led to his recent decline in popularity. His political advisers say that if the President is seen as holding a firm grip on economic policy and if the economy regains strength next year, he will be well positioned for his re-election race in 1992.
The CNN interview came after the President heard a gloomy assessment of the economy this morning from a group of business executives. It was the most recent of a series of meetings that the White House said was meant to help him plan economic policy for the next year.
Mr. Bush said on the broadcast that one executive told him, "It doesn't hurt to shake things out."
"Sometimes," the President said, "you have to pay for excesses, and we had a kind of go-go lending policy in some of our financial institutions."
But when Mr. Bush was asked whether he blamed the excesses on the Reagan Administration, he said he did not.
If Mr. Bush wanted a forthright appraisal of the state of the economy, he apparently got it from the executives this morning.
John G. Medlin Jr., chairman of the First Wachovia Corporation, a bank holding company in North Carolina, said in an interview he had told Mr. Bush that the economy seemed to be "tilting toward a modest downturn."
 
 Input from Different Regions
 Compared with the other nine executives at the meeting, Mr. Medlin said, "I was probably on the optimistic side."
This was the third meeting on the economy Mr. Bush has called in less than a week during an interlude between the November elections and his weeklong trip beginning Friday evening to Europe, Saudi Arabia and Egypt. A fourth meeting with 10 more executives is scheduled for Friday morning.
"The idea is for Bush to get input on the economy from different regions of the country and different components of the economic system -- bankers, industrialists and so on," a White House official said.
On the condition that they not be identified, some Administration economists said they believed the country might already be in a recession but they did not expect it to be a deep or especially long one. These economists said they did not know if the President shared their view.
At his news conference on Nov. 8, Mr. Bush said he was "concerned about an economic slowdown."
 
 Not on the Schedule
 The President went on to say, "I want to be sure that, to the degree a President can do something to soften the blow or to stimulate economic growth, that he tries to do it."
Mr. Bush said at the time that he planned to call in outsiders for advice.
Today's meeting was not on the President's official schedule, and the White House refused to release a list of those who attended. One person who was there in addition to Mr. Medlin, George H. Weyerhaeuser, chairman of the Wayerhaeuser Corporation, could not be reached afterward.
Administration officials at the session included Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, Richard G. Darman, the budget director, and John H. Sununu, the President's chief of staff.
Mr. Medlin said that neither the President nor his advisers had spoken out at the meeting. "He didn't tell us anything," Mr. Medlin said. "He went around the room, and it was sincerely a meeting where he wanted to hear the views of a variety of people about the present state of and the outlook for the economy."
 
 An Internal Split
 The meeting, around a conference table in the Roosevelt Room, lasted an hour and 40 minutes, which was 40 minutes longer than planned, the White House said.
Last weekend, Mr. Bush met at Camp David with his economic advisers, and Wednesday he met with the Government's top banking regulators.
Officials said the Wednesday meeting was called because Mr. Bush wanted to hear both sides of a disagreement that has developed within the Administration over the extent to which banking regulations have led to tight credit.
Mr. Sununu and Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher were said to take the position that the regulators have become overly zealous and are hurting the economy in general and small businesses in particular by making banks reluctant to make loans.
But Mr. Brady and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, are said to argue that market forces are the main reason that credit is less available now than in the past.
 
 No Quick Decision Expected
 "Given the savings and loan debacle and the overbuilding in many parts of the country, it's not surprising that banks are being more careful, especially in the real estate area," an Administration economist said, reflecting the Brady and Boskin views.
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has agreed with the Brady and Boskin position in public testimony and presumably in private meetings with the President. But Mr. Bush has not divulged where he stands on the matter.
Administration officials said that with the President abroad next week, firm decisions on economic policy would probably not be made until next month and might not be announced until his State of the Union Message and budget presentation in January.
Other Presidents, when the economy turned sour, have looked to tax cuts or job programs to hasten recovery. But the budget deficit, which is expected to approach $300 billion in this fiscal year even without a recession, gives this Administration little leeway.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC SCENE;
The Gulf Crisis: Its Effect on U.S.

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
WHAT will be the impact on the American economy of the Persian Gulf crisis? The first problem economists face in trying to answer that is what assumptions to make about how the conflict with Iraq will play out, and what effect different results will have on the price of oil.
Soon after Iraq invaded Kuwait, economists at the World Bank spelled out four possibilities: rapid return to normalcy, short-term uncertainty, prolonged uncertainty and war. The first might now be relabeled successful Bush threat/ rapid Hussein retreat. President Bush's plan to double American forces in the gulf to about 500,000 is regarded as a threat aimed at scaring Mr. Hussein out, although the threat would not be credible if it did not include the possibility of war. 
 Many military experts see little likelihood that the Iraqi President can be bluffed out of Kuwait. But if the threat worked, the effect on the oil price might be about what the World Bank's first possibility, rapid return to normalcy, predicted: that the price would come down fast and average $17 to $18 a barrel through 1991 and 1992, not much above the $16.40 average in the first half of this year.
The World Bank's short-term uncertainty model, which assumed no resolution of the crisis for a year to 18 months, forecast an average oil price of $31 to $32 a barrel in the second half of 1990. That prediction now looks reasonable. On Wednesday, the price tumbled to $31.16 a barrel, within the projected World Bank range, and yesterday slipped a bit more, to $31.12. For next year, that model predicts an average price of $29, coming down to $25 to $26 in 1992.
The long-term uncertainty option, which assumes that the crisis in the gulf will last several years, predicts that crude oil will average $29 a barrel for five years. But in real terms, the bank predicts, oil prices will decline steadily as a result of gradual increases in world supply and a slowdown in the growth of world demand.
The fourth World Bank option, war, assumes that the destruction of Iraqi, Kuwaiti and Saudi oilfields will remove as much as 10 million barrels a day from supply and drive the price to $65. Other experts put this figure down as an optimistic guess. After the war ends, says the World Bank script, oil prices will come down to $30 to $40 and stay there for about five years.
More hawkish strategists argue, however, that as costly as war would be, the alternative of letting Iraq establish itself as the hegemon of the Middle East and master of the oil cartel would be even costlier for the West. It would mean, they say, not only a much higher price of oil but living with, or dying with, a ruthless enemy possessing nuclear as well as chemical and biological weapons.
Other economists have other scripts. Adam E.Sieminski of the Washington Analysis Corporation lays out four:
*United States out/Iraqi hegemony: probability now, 10 percent; probability in 1991, 5 percent; oil price, $30 a barrel, 1990 through 1992.
*Hussein out/Saudi dominance: probability now, 25 percent; probability in 1991, 20 percent; oil price, $18 to $20 a barrel in 1990-91; $21 in 1992.
*Continuing stalemate: probability now, 40 percent, probability in 1991, 20 percent; oil price, $25 to $40 in 1990-91; $25, 1991-92.
*United Nations negotiated settlement: probability now, 25 percent; probability in 1991, 35 percent; oil price $22 to $24 in 1990-91; $23 in 1991-92.
The weighted average of those options is $23 to $30 a barrel for 1990-91 and $23 for 1991-92. The implication is that the oil shock this time will not have as severe an impact on the United States and world economy as did the two oil shocks of the 1970's. But this calculation does not include the effect on oil and the world economy of a protracted war.
If there is no war, the retreat of the oil price may help offset recessionary forces in the economy. Henry Kaufman, president of Henry Kaufman & Company, predicts that a rally in the bond market will be set off "either by a resolution of the Mideast crisis or a recognition by the markets that the bond risks are far less today than during the two earlier periods of oil price increases in 1973-74 and in 1978-79."
The actual increase in oil prices this time, he notes, has been only a fraction of the spikes in prices in the earlier oil shocks. The ratio of energy used per dollar of gross national product has fallen throughout the industrial world. American industry is now more experienced at substituting other energy sources, especially natural gas, for oil, the main economic weapon of Middle East aggressors.
In helping to arrest inflation and cut interest rates, declining oil prices would ease the painful readjustment the American economy must now undergo after the scandalous excesses of the 1980's.

HEADLINE: Prediction by Moody's: More Pain for Wall St.

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Moody's expects Wall Street in the 1990's to be marked by "rapacious competition" that will lead to greater consolidation of the industry, the bond rating agency said in a report yesterday.
As a result, the report said, a number of firms that are not prepared for the global competition of the next decade are likely to be driven into mergers, undergo big realignments or fail. 
 The changes will bring with them a good deal of pain, the report said. Through much of the early 1990's, Moody's Investor Service expects the large securities firms to continue to cut back on staff even more than they have to date, and to drop numerous business lines.
 
 Survivors to Be Strong
 "Ultimately, there may be few, if any, large independent securities firms," said John J. Kriz, the author of the report and a vice president at Moody's. "But by and large, these companies will be innovative, market-oriented firms with well-developed skill bases."
Despite all this upheaval, Moody's expects the Wall Street firms, which are generally well-rated, to be able to maintain their current bond ratings for the next three to five years, primarily because the changes will make the firms healthier institutions.
The Moody's report is one of the strongest signs to date that the Wall Street of the 1990's will be vastly different from that of previous decades. Because of the influence it bears on the cost of financings for firms, the Moody's report carries greater weight than some other outside analyses, primarily because a downgrading by the service can create large uncertainties in the marketplace about a firm's possibility for survival.
Indeed, the threats of potential downgrades by Moody's were one of the largest forces behind the purchase of Shearson Lehman Brothers by the American Express Company earlier this year, as well as this week's decision by executives at Credit Suisse to assume control of CS First Boston by injecting $300 million into the international securities firm.
 
 Detail on Businesses
 The Moody's report provides great detail about the businesses the rating agency expects to be the most profitable for the securities industry in the 1990's, including workouts for troubled transactions and asset management.
But it also raises some important red flags about potential credit risks at holding companies for securities firms, as Washington moves toward efforts to regulate such bodies more closely. In addition, Moody's expressed some concern that management at Wall Street firms might enter into risky transactions in desperate efforts to earn money and delay the huge restructurings that are necessary.
The problems on Wall Street are laid out starkly in the report. The cost of overhead, such as staff compensation and real estate, has quadrupled for securities firms since 1980, after roughly doubling before the 1987 market crash. That expense put pressure on the firms, with pre-tax earnings in 1989 slightly lower than in 1989.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chapter 11 Filing By a Van Maker

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 15

 BODY:
The Starcraft Corporation, a maker of recreational vehicles, filed for protection from creditors in Federal Bankruptcy Court, blaming high gasoline prices, the threat of war in the Middle East and a weakening economy. The company's chairman, J. Michael Bell, said he expected Starcraft and its units would pay off their debts and emerge from court-directed reorganization "in a healthy condition."
Van conversions, an important part of Starcraft's business, shrank at least 30 percent in September, a month after Iraq invaded Kuwait and gasoline prices began rising, according to the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation, the largest suppliers of van chassis to the conversion industry. Last month, Starcraft laid off 30 employees at its offices. The company employs about 400 people in Goshen, Ind., and about 300 in Topeka, Ind.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Murdoch Plans to Sell $1 Billion in News Assets

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
After cutting costs by consolidating his Sky Television with British Satellite Broadcasting, Rupert Murdoch said this week that the News Corporation, which he controls, wanted to go a step further and sell roughly $1 billion in assets over the next three years.
Mr. Murdoch said he would sell the assets if bankers agree to defer interest payments on much of the company's bank debt, which now stands at $8.1 billion (American), or $10.3 billion (Australian). 
 He refused to specify what assets would be sold, but one high-level publishing executive at the company's United States operations said the word was that none of the American properties -- magazines, television stations, a television network, newspapers and movie businesses -- would be put on the market. But the executive added, "Murdoch will do what needs to be done."
A spokesman for the company confirmed that Mr. Murdoch did leave open the possibility of selling the company's 50 percent stake in Ansett Airlines, the Australian domestic carrier.
 
 Earnings Advance
 The News Corporation also said yesterday that net income rose almost 54 percent to $44.1 million, or 34 cents for each American depository receipt, from $28.7 million, or 23 cents, for the quarter ended Sept. 30. Revenues jumped 49 percent, to $2.24 billion, from $1.5 billion a year earlier. But income before extraordinary items fell 27 percent, to $20.9 million, from $28.7 million for the period last year.
The price of the A.D.R.'s fell 12.5 cents each yesterday, to $8.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.
A spokesman for the company said that the extraordinary items included the sale of several regional newspapers in Victoria, Australia.
The News Corporation added that profits in the United States rose to $212.7 million, from $126.3 million. It said the 20th Century Fox Film Corporation made a good start for the year and that Fox Broadcasting continued to be encouraging, although the company did not break out any figures.
On its properties in Britain, the company reported a loss of $16.9 million, compared with a gain of $50.8 million a year earlier. It attributed the loss to start up costs associated with Sky Television and said that without those costs, profits would have been up 71 percent. The company said that as a result of the merger with British Satellite Television, it expected to return to profitability for the balance of this year.
The company said its newspapers in Britain were operating in a difficult economic environment but were maintaining market share. Recent cover price increases for both The Sun and The News of the World will improve newspaper profits for the balance of the year.
Profits in Australia and the Pacific Basin dropped marginally to $73.7 million. The company said the results for newspapers, magazines and commercial printing were less than 3 percent below the prior period.
 For the quarter, the company's interest expense rose to $304.7 million, from $236.1 million in the quarter last year. The company attributed the increase in interest expense to the acquisition of the HarperCollins Book Publishing Group, which became a wholly owned subsidiary in June.
A company spokesman said Mr. Murdoch was traveling and could not be reached for comment.
John Reidy, a media analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham, said the surprise was that there was a loss in Britain. "We had expected a profit despite start up costs because the U.K. newspapers are still generating substantial profits," he said.

HEADLINE: Confidence Index Plunges

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 15

 BODY:
Consumer confidence had the sharpest three-month decline posted in 44 years as fears about the economy mounted, a University of Michigan study showed today.
Richard Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's consumer survey group, said the university's index of consumer sentiment plummeted 24.3 points, to 63.9 percent, between July and October. In October alone, the monthly survey fell 30 points from year-earlier levels. The index is a percentage measured against the consumer sentiment level of 100 established in February 1966.
The university's index, which is a component of the Government's Index of Leading Economic Indicators, has been tracking consumer confidence since 1946.
Economists closely watch the university's data, since a sharp drop in confidence could lead consumers to rein in spending, igniting a recession. Consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of the gross national product.
"The increase in gasoline prices following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait has transformed changes in global oil markets into hometown concerns," Mr. Curtin said. "This came at a time when consumer confidence was already weakened, and the actions in the Middle East reinforced and accelerated that downward momentum."

HEADLINE: Oil Prices Are Flat on Lack of News From Gulf

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Oil prices closed nearly unchanged yesterday as war-sensitive traders stayed on the sidelines, waiting for news from the Persian Gulf.
"We're just bouncing around in a range, and there's no real news or headlines to give us direction," said Brian Tagler of Lehman Brothers. 
 Crude oil for December delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange ended down 4 cents, at $31.12 a barrel, after trading in a range of $30.15 to $31.85.
Analysts said a lack of news from the Middle East prompted important traders to stand aside. Some squared their books ahead of the weekend and next week's holiday-shortened trading period.
"We broke through some key support levels with a lack of tensions in the Mideast and with people concentrating on bearish fundamentals," said Peter Beutel of Pegasus Econometric.
Analysts said the selling was not overwhelming, indicating the market was possibly oversold after losing nearly $2 a barrel Wednesday on news that President Bush had assured Congress the new military buildup in the Persian Gulf did not mean war with Iraq was imminent.
The American Petroleum Institute, a trade group, reported on Tuesday that the nation's oil inventories increased by 878,000 barrels in the latest week to 345 million barrels, a sign that oil supplies are adequate.
Among refined oil products, December gasoline prices fell 0.23 cent, to 80.16 cents a gallon, and heating oil gained 0.03 cent, to 86.67 cents a gallon.
 
 
 Pipeline Plan Cleared
 WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- The Energy Department approved a proposal today by the Iroquois Gas Transmission System to import nearly 400 million cubic feet a day of Canadian natural gas.
The action follows Wednesday's approval by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission of the system's proposal to build the pipeline.
The Energy Department's approval will allow 18 companies to import gas through Iroquois to six Northeastern states. The Energy Department said construction of the Iroquois pipeline is scheduled to begin next month. The proposed route begins at the Canadian border near Iroquois, Ontario, and runs through eastern New York, western Connecticut and across Long Island Sound to Long Island.
The Iroquois pipeline will be able to deliver as much as 576 million cubic feet of gas a day.
