HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Revamping at Ayer Includes 30 Layoffs

BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ

 BODY:
Ayer, one of the country's oldest agencies, said yesterday that it had completed a long-expected series of changes in its senior management.
Executives at the agency also said a number of employees had been laid off. Ayer reportedly let go of about 30 employees, including some senior executives, as part of a cost-cutting effort. 
 Ayer executives said that while the agency is still profitable, revenues have been shrinking in part as a result of the overall industry slowdown and because the agency had lost two big clients, Burger King last year and Continental Airlines earlier this year.
Dominick F. Rossi Jr., the president of Ayer/New York, said the agency had reduced the number of executives overseeing the account management department in an effort to "streamline the organization and make sure that its clients' accounts are well managed."
The agency now has three managing directors who will have responsibility for account management. In the past, the department had been managed by a larger group of executives.
Janet Keeler, a senior vice president at Ayer, was made a managing director in charge of the A.T.& T., Gillette and NBC/Pay-Per-View accounts. Warren Albright and Dave Gantman, executive vice presidents who were already managing directors, are responsibile for the remaining accounts in the New York office.
Mr. Warren will have the additional duty of being the administrative chief of the entire account management department in New York.
The changes come just a week after the agency shuffled some of the senior executives in its creative department. At that time, Ayer also hired Sue Read, a top creative executive at Lintas New York, to be co-creative director along with Keith Gould.
Industry analysts welcomed the changes; Ayer had been seen as a conservative, sleepy agency that was not well equipped to compete in today's rougher advertising environment.
"The perception had been that the agency was lagging behind the times," said Arthur Anderson, a principal at Morgan, Anderson & Company, a marketing and management consulting firm. "This improves them greatly and makes them an aggressive player."
The transition at Ayer is widely regarded in the industry as the handiwork of Jerry J. Siano, the chairman and chief executive, who in January replaced Louis T. Hagopian, long-time head of the agency.
Analysts said Mr. Siano has given the agency a new spirit, in large part because he comes from the creative side of the business. "I'm very impressed with him because he leads with his head and his heart," Mr. Anderson said. "His understanding of what it takes to create advertising also inspires the staff and helps to attract top outside talent."
Perhaps the most significant change at Ayer is the addition of Ms. Read as a co-creative director. She is widely regarded as one of the more innovative creative executives in the industry, and analysts said it was a coup for Ayer to lure her away from Lintas. At Lintas she was primarily responsible for creating the Diet Coke advertising.
Patrick Cunningham, the agency's chief creative officer, said he brought in Ms. Read to shake up the creative department. "She'll bring a new style and enthusiasm," Mr. Cunningham said. "She'll motivate people because she's a real ball of fire. Creative people have to be constantly challenged. Otherwise they go stale."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Light Trading; Gold Rebounds in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar inched higher on world currency markets yesterday in cautious, choppy trading. Gold prices fell overseas but advanced in New York.
Traders said the market was thin, with most investors focusing on currencies other than the dollar. "A lot of people were selling yen and buying marks," said Gilbert Cisneros, a trader at the Bank of Boston's office in New York. 
 He said many traders were confused and not willing to bet on the dollar's direction.
 
 Waiting for the Fed
 The financial markets continue to wait for signs that the Federal Reserve has nudged interest rates lower in an effort to stimulate a weakening United States economy. Lower interest rates are generally negative for the dollar because they erode the value of dollar-denominated securities.
Marc Chandler, an analyst with the firm IDEA, said that once the Fed makes its move, traders would begin looking ahead for another easing of interest rates, probably shortly after year-end.
Some dealers are looking for today's report on the September trade deficit to rekindle interest in the dollar. With the United States currency trading at depressed levels, most economists expect some improvement from the $9.3 billion deficit registered in the previous month.
Also today, the Labor Department is scheduled to report on the Consumer Price Index for October.
 
 Dollar Rises in Tokyo
 In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 129.30 yen, from 129.05 at Wednesday's close. Later in London, it fell to 129.15 yen. In New York the dollar closed at 129.69 yen, up from 129.09 on Wednesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.9590, from $1.9615 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.9575 to buy one pound, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.9600.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.4755 German marks, up from 1.4726; 1.2518 Swiss francs, up from 1.2470; 4.9850 French francs, up from 4.9670; 1,113.25 Italian lire, up from 1,111, and 1.1624 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1631.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, where gold plunged $8.40 an ounce in the previous session, the metal gained $1.50 an ounce to settle at $379.10. Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold at $378.75 an ounce, up $1.15.

HEADLINE: Inventories Rose 0.5% In September

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Business inventories grew five-tenths of 1 percent in September while sales suffered their biggest decline in five months, the Government said today, leading some analysts to express concern that the situation could lead to further production cuts and job losses.
"It's consistent with the idea that the economy is sliding into a recession and growth will be negative in the fourth quarter," said Evelina Tainer, an economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. She noted that industrial production in October had already dropped eight-tenths of 1 percent, its sharpest cutback in nine months. 
 Analysts said the inventory level itself had not reached a dangerous level, although continued vigilance was needed to prevent an even deeper reduction in output.
The Commerce Department said inventories held on shelves and backlots in September totaled a seasonally adjusted $811.5 billion, up from $807.5 billion the previous month.
But the accumulation slowed from a gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent in both July and August, which had been the largest increases since an advance of eight-tenths of 1 percent in July 1989.
 
 First Sales Dip Since July
 Business sales dipped five-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $548.7 billion, down from $551.5 billion a month earlier.
It was the first decline in sales since a drop of four-tenths of 1 percent in July and the largest since a 1 percent decrease last April. August sales had jumped 2.1 percent.
The ratio of inventories to sales edged up to 1.48, from 1.46 in August. The ratio means it would take 1.48 months to exhaust the backlog of goods at the September sales pace.
Still, the ratio was down from its recent peak of 1.54 in July 1989, and Michael P. Niemira, an economist with Mitsubishi Bank in New York, said businesses are now able to react more rapidly to economic developments and avoid serious buildups.
The ratio reached a high of 1.74 in January 1982 during the last recession.
"I think you'll see inventories coming down, but coming down coincident with a slowdown in sales," Mr. Niemira said, noting that retail purchases last month slowed to an increase of one-tenth of 1 percent from a 1.3 percent advance in September.
In both months, however, the sales gains were led by high gasoline prices, rather than volume. When the gasoline component was excluded, retail sales fell one-tenth of 1 percent last month while rising just nine-tenths in September.
All categories posted inventory gains, with manufacturers up six-tenths of 1 percent, and wholesalers and retailers up four-tenths of 1 percent each.
At the same time, manufacturers' sales fell seven-tenths of 1 percent, while wholesalers posted a 1.8 percent decline.
Sales at the retail level jumped 1.3 percent.

HEADLINE: U.S. Has Much at Risk if World Trade Talks Fail

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Should the 105-nation talks about liberalizing trade break down because of the impasse over farm subsidies, trade wars are likely to break out and put recessionary pressure on the United States, many government and private economists predict.
"Obviously it will be a tougher world if the talks fail," said Canada's Ambassador to the United States, Derek H. Burney. "And if there's an economic downturn to boot, things will be really difficult." 
 Because exports have become the main source of American economic strength, the United States has a lot at risk if the 105-nation talks scheduled to end in Geneva next month make no progress.
 
 Serious Repercussions Loom
 "This is important to the country, to its taxpayers," said Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, whose members generate a $3 billion-a-year foreign trade surplus for the United States. If the talks succeed, that surplus could vastly increase. Protecting intellectual property rights is one of the main goals of the talks. The movie industry now loses billions of dollars through the piracy of its films in foreign markets.
A failure of the talks could also have serious political and economic repercussions, particularly in Eastern Europe, putting pressure on the new democracies, and in the Persian Gulf, where economic rifts might develop between the United States and its allies.
The chief goals of the talks, which began four years ago in Punta del Este, Uruguay, and are known as the Uruguay Round, are to lower tariffs, set guidelines for exchanges of financial and other services and provide better safeguards for patents, copyrights and other intellectual property.
 
 Worry at A.T.&T.
 Lewis M. Chakrin, director of policy and planning for international communications services at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said the worldwide market for telecommunications is worth $500 billion a year, and American companies serve about 20 percent of that market.
"A failure of the Uruguay Round means that American firms will have less of a chance to compete in these markets," he said at a conference in Washington sponsored by the Conference Board and the American Foreign Service Association.
The stumbling block in the talks, which are being conducted by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, is that the United States and a number of other food-exporting countries, including Canada, Australia and Argentina, have demanded a sharp reduction in government subsidies to farmers. They argue that such subsidies distort the market in agricultural trade and cost farmers in their nations billions of dollars annually.
 
 French and German Farm Power
 But in a number of European nations, notably France and Germany, it is politically difficult to end farm subsidies because the many small farmers are a potent political force. The European Community recently proposed a gradual 30 percent reduction in subsidies, but the United States and other nations have termed that proposal inadequate.
A failure to agree on farm subsidies would doom the talks, and cast aside progress that has been made on numerous other fronts. Agriculture is the linchpin. Developing countries are unwilling to open their economies for banking, telecommunications and other services and offer greater protection of intellectual property without getting access to the markets of industrial countries for their food exports. A failure of the talks would also mean more trade conflicts, many analysts agree.
Retaliation and countermoves would almost certainly cause exports to contract at a time when Washington is counting on export growth to offset the declining economy and the impact of budget cuts.
 
 Economic Importance of Exports
 Since 1986 exports have accounted for more than a third of American economic growth, according to a study by the National Association of Manufacturers. In the first half of 1990, exports accounted for more than 80 percent of the growth.
"If the Uruguay Round aborts, then export potential is going to lag because we will be in lots of trade squabbles," said William R. Cline, an economist at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "With the economy the way it is, this is a pretty bad time now to be stultifying export prospects."
The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said a number of lingering trade disputes that were set aside pending the outcome of the broader talks will come to the forefront.
 
 U.S.-Japan Disputes
 She cited a dispute with Japan over access to its $35-billion-a-year market in rice, which is closed to foreigners. Rice in Japan sells at seven times the price in the United States, and American rice growers have petitioned Washington to press Japan for access.
In addition to rice, the United States has complaints against Japanese barriers in supercomputers, optical fibers, semiconductors, public works construction and many other sectors.
A similar set of problems exists with Europe. The Bush Administration, the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation complain of British, French and German subsidies for Airbus Industrie. Meat packers are unhappy with European bans on American meat, imposed because slaughterhouse standards are different in Europe; telecommunications companies complain that many European markets are closed.
 
 'Only Losers, No Winners'
 If trade disputes flare up, "there will be only losers, no winners," said Yvonne van Rooy, the Netherlands' trade minister. She made her comments to several reporters on Friday after seeing Bush Administration officials. The Dutch are traditionally among the strongest free traders in Europe and are anxious to see the global talks succeed.
Many of Eastern Europe's new democracies are counting on exports to help them deliver on domestic economic promises. The market-oriented changes taking place throughout the world can be "cemented only by their incorporation into the liberal, open world economy," a group of political and business leaders known as the Eminent Persons Group on World Trade said recently after meeting in Frankfurt.
Congress is likely to offer lots of advice to the Administration on how to handle trade disputes. Many analysts expect enormous Congressional pressure to retaliate against the European Community for its farm protection.
"If Congress takes strong measures, you can expect other countries to take strong measures as well," Mrs. Hills said. "You could have a lot of legislative bodies come up with different measures that are bound to lead to trade contraction."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Hope and Fear as Wife Plans Trip to Iraq

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ODESSA, Tex., Nov. 13

 BODY:
Her trip to Iraq has not even begun and already Donnita Cole is trying to block the images of how it will probably end.
After she travels 8,000 miles to Baghdad against the advice of her Government and after she sees her 61-year-old husband, John, who is being held by the Iraqis, there will come the wrenching moment when she must leave. 
 She tries not to think of that moment as she applies for a visa, wrests promises from the Iraqi Embassy in Washington and shops for the shoes, cards and other items her husband has asked her to bring. She tries, but she fails.
 
Doing 'the Hardest Thing'
 Kissing her husband goodbye and then boarding the plane "will be the hardest thing I'll ever have to do in my whole life," Mrs. Cole said, the defiance momentarily gone from her West Texas twang. "But I've made my decision. For me, going and leaving again sure beats not seeing him at all."
When President Saddam Hussein of Iraq recently invited the families of his hostages to visit Baghdad for Christmas, he presented each family with agonizing choices: To go and risk becoming hostages themselves, or to stay home and feel the guilt of abandoning loved ones. To go and become a pawn in Mr. Hussein's public opinion game, or to stay home and watch helplessly if, as part of that game, he suddenly frees those whose relatives visited. To spend more than $5,000 on a trip when, for most families, money is tight because the primary breadwinner has become a hostage or to squander what might be the last chance to see a loved one.
The State Department has advised families to stay home, saying travel to Iraq is too dangerous. But it has also said that the United States would not try to stop any family member who chooses to make the trip.
Most of the relatives of the 1,000 Americans still being held in Iraq and Kuwait seem to be following the Government's advice.
But a few, including 10 members of the support group Coming Home, which was founded within days of the invasion to counsel and provide information to families of Americans in Iraq and Kuwait, have decided to make the trip. They will leave from Washington on Dec. 2.
 
Messages on the Wrists
 "I don't care if they're using me as a propaganda ploy," Mrs. Cole said in an interview in her one-story frame house on a dusty side street here. "I don't care if I'm going against my Government. I just want to go to Baghdad and see my husband."
Mrs. Cole, a 48-year-old woman with a booming voice, a constant laugh, a strong opinion on almost every subject and four earrings in each ear, is particularly torn by the conflict in the Persian Gulf. On her right wrist is a silver-colored bracelet inscribed "My Johnny, My Baby, Us Together Again," a tribute to her husband that she says she will wear until he is released. On her left wrist is a gold-colored bracelet with the name of her son, Specialist John Edward Cole of the United States Army, who is stationed in Saudi Arabia as part of the American buildup there. Another son and her son-in-law are also in the military, awaiting orders to leave for the gulf region.
When President Hussein issued his invitation at the begining of November, Mrs. Cole initially decided not to accept, because her husband had told her not to. She received her first telephone call from Mr. Cole several days after Mr. Hussein's offer.
"What are you doing, babe?" asked the man she had not heard from in three months or seen since April, when he left to begin a two-year oil drilling job, expecting her to join him in Kuwait in August.
"Nothing," she replied. "Just standing around waiting for your phone call."
Her words, she said, sounded calmer than she felt. "I know it's physically impossible for your heart to leap into your throat," said Mrs. Cole, who teaches cardiopulmonary resuscitation to paramedics. "But, honey, I don't care what all my medical books say, my heart was in my throat."
 
A Change in Plans
 During the eight-minute call, Mrs. Cole asked if she should visit Iraq and was told not to.
"You may be stepping into a world of trouble," Mrs. Cole quoted her husband as saying, adding that had cleaned up his language so it could be printed. She said he told her that he not only feared for her safety but that he also did not want her to see his living conditions.
"They have six hostages and six guards in a four bedroom building," Mrs. Cole said. "They must be packed in like sardines."
Like many other families of hostages, Mrs. Cole began hearing from her husband regularly after that first call. He phoned the next day and they talked about how to repair a leak in their ceiling. The next day he called again, and she again asked if she should go to Baghdad. This time he said to come.
Shortly after that call, Mrs. Cole spoke to Kim Edwards, who had just returned from a week in Iraq to visit her husband, Tony, who had been employed there as a planning consultant. Mrs. Edwards's visit was made before Mr. Hussein's invitation, and Mrs. Cole and other members of Coming Home were eager to hear about her trip.
 
Keeping a Phone Line Busy
 Mrs. Cole and the others talked to Mrs. Edwards on a conference party line that the U S Sprint Communications Company donated to Coming Home. Relatives of hostages can call at any hour and talk to anyone else who may be on the line.
Mrs. Edwards, who plans to return to Iraq in December, was soon holding daily sessions on the line, sometimes with as many as 30 people. Questions from others considering a trip to Iraq concerned things like costs, visas and appropriate clothing for a Muslim country. Mrs. Cole also wanted to know whether her two-inch red fingernails, which she has vowed not to cut until her husband can see them, would offend Iraqi officials.
Callers also discussed whether they would be held in violation of the Logan Act, which prohibits private citizens from interfering in foreign policy. They decided they would not be, and a State Department spokesman, in an interview, said there were no plans to enforce the act in these circumstances.
They also discussed whether they would could be charged with violating the economic embargo against Iraq by spending money on food and lodging there and learned that the Treasury Department might grant waivers if their trip was ruled to be for humanitarian purposes.
 
Fears of a War
 At first callers were concerned that visitors to Iraq might not be allowed to leave, but that fear is now expressed less frequently, say several people who use the line daily. "The feeling now is why would the Iraqis let 500 women and children go out then invite 10 in and keep them?" said Michael Saba, founder of Coming Home, who was in Iraq on business and escaped soon after the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait.
The newer concern is that a war could break out during their visit. "There is danger, but not from the Iraqis" Mrs. Cole said. "There's a very large danger my Government is going to attack while I'm there."
But that has not deterred Mrs. Cole. Once she decided to go, she contacted the Iraqi Ambassador to the United States and asked if the visitors would be able to meet with President Hussein. "He said he would fax the request that day and he thought it could be accomplished," Mrs. Cole said.
 
Shopping and Raising Money
 She also began shopping. With each phone call, her husband adds to the list of things he wants: size 12 shoes, playing cards and instruction manuals for bridge so he can teach his fellow hostages how to play, socks, underwear, T-shirts, a jogging outfit, paperbacks and family photographs, especially some of the youngest of his seven grandchildren, a boy who was born one month after Mr. Cole left for the gulf and who carries his name.
The rest of Mrs. Cole's time is spent raising money for her trip. Her economy-class air fare of $1,600 is being paid by an Iraqi-born doctor in South Texas who has lived in this country for 30 years but whose mother, sister and brother still live in Iraq. He has asked her not to divulge his name.
Mrs. Cole estimates she will need $4,000 for hotels and food. Mrs. Edwards spent $2,000 in her one week in Baghdad, and Mrs. Cole hopes to stay for two. The first week, she hopes, will be filled with meetings with Iraqi officials as she begs for the hostages' release. The second week, she says firmly, will be spent only with her husband.
In a recent call on the party line, the talk turned to the cost of Baghdad hotel rooms. since the Iraqi Embassy has indicated that the hostages who are being kept at strategic military sites around the country will be moved to hotels while their families are in Iraq. Mrs. Edwards said the rooms would probably cost $135 a night.
One caller, preparing to visit his son, was startled by that price and suggested that some of the families "double up" to save money.
Mrs. Cole broke in with a laugh. "You bet I'm gonna double up, honey," she said, "but it ain't gonna be with you."

HEADLINE: Arizona Struggles Anew to Erase Its Negative Image

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Once again Arizona has been plunged into political and racial turmoil, its leaders forced to protest that the state is not as narrow-minded and backward as it might seem to some outsiders.
And once again, the issue is a paid state holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The issue has reappeared more than two years after Evan Mecham, the Governor who rescinded the holiday, was impeached and ousted from office for misuse of state money. 
 On Nov. 6 Arizona voters rejected a proposal to add a holiday for the slain civil rights leader by a margin of 17,226 votes, less than 1 percent of the total votes cast. Since then the daily cascade of bad news has been topic A from Flagstaff to Tombstone.
Paul Tagliabue, the commissioner of the National Football League, recommended that Super Bowl XXVII, scheduled to be held in nearby Tempe in 1983, be played elsewhere. Hopes that Phoenix would gain a National League baseball franchise all but evaporated. The National League of Cities considered shifting its planned 1991 convention out of Phoenix. And entertainment officials predicted another round of boycotts of the state by top musical groups.
 
An Image Problem
 For years Arizona has suffered from an image of being a center of right-wing extremism and fast-buck operators. That image was not improved by the Mecham episode nor by the fact that both of the state's United States Senators, Dennis DeConcini, a Democrat, and John McCain, a Republican, face Senate ethics charges that they improperly intervened with Federal regulators to help a prominent financier, Charles H. Keating Jr., who has been accused of looting a savings and loan association. Many business and legislative leaders had hoped that the King holiday vote would clear away at least that issue.
"I feel a numbness -- after Keating and Mecham, this gives us a lot of negative impact around the world," said Bill Shover, public affairs director for Phoenix Newspapers Inc., who led the campaign to gain the Super Bowl and helped lead the effort to save the King holiday.
"This situation is not acceptable," said Richard Lehmann, chairman of Arizona's largest bank, the Valley National Bank. "We absolutely must fix this."
That will not be so easy. Allegations since Election Day that Dr. King had plagiarized portions of his doctoral dissertation have stiffened opposition.
 
'The Tip of the Iceberg'
 At a small office in Scottsdale, a suburb of Phoenix, Robert O. Rose, an accountant who led the campaign against the holiday, threatened to start recall drives against any legislator who voted anew for the holiday. "This plagiarism was just the tip of the iceberg," he said. "We honestly don't believe our kids and grandkids should revere him as a national hero."
Mr. Rose dismissed the economic threats as overblown. Backers have said the Super Bowl would inject $225 million in the Phoenix area's economy; Mr. Rose said hotels were normally fully booked anyway in January, the high season here, and that the bowl would only result in price "gouging."
For blacks, who make up about 3 percent of Arizona's population, the voters' rejection of the King holiday proposal was a deep disappointment, said the Rev. Warren Stewart, pastor of the First Institutional Baptist Church, the largest black congregation in Phoenix.
Mr. Stewart, who described Arizonans as "narrow minded, myopic," said he held the business establishment partly to blame for not working soon enough on behalf of the King holiday proposal.
 
New Plan Being Considered
 A group of community, political and religious leaders met at the church on Wednesday to devise a new plan. A consensus is emerging that the holiday measure might pass if it is modeled after the Federal plan, under which the birthdays of Washington and Lincoln were combined, thereby not creating another paid holiday for government employees.
Gov. Rose Mofford said she would put a King bill on the docket at a special session of the Legislature that has been called to set rules for a runoff in the governor's race, but only if more than two-thirds of the members of both houses supported it, thus allowing it to go into effect immediately as an "emergency measure." (Complicating Arizona's problems is that it has no governor-elect, since neither Terry Goddard, the Democratic candidate, nor J. Fife Symington, the Republican, won more than 50 percent of the vote.)
But lawmakers find little support for the emergency vote. "There is a lot of hostility out there," said Jane Hull, a Phoenix Republican who is Speaker of the Arizona House of Representatives. "It will be revisited, but not in this Legislature. I am telling people, 'Take it easy, cool down, go find something else to do.' "
Meanwhile, business leaders are trying to show that voters did not really reject the concept of a King holiday. A poll commissioned by the business-supported MLK Better America Committee found that about 60,000 voters switched to 'no' after a report on CBS Sports the Sunday before the election that the National Football League would move the Super Bowl if the holiday proposal failed.
 
'Rugged Individualists'
 "Arizonans are rugged individualists -- they do not like being told what to do," said Bruce D. Merrill, director of the Media Research Program at Arizona State University in Tempe.
Edward and Trudy Egan were among the defiant. The couple retired from Northfield, Ill., 11 years ago and moved to Sun City, about 15 miles west of Phoenix. "I think he should be entitled to a holiday," Mr. Egan said of Dr. King. "But I don't like it when everybody starts threatening you."
The ballot actually had two King holiday measures on it,presenting something of a puzzle for voters. Newspapers tried to solve the puzzle with graphics that looked like chromosome charts, showing what different combinations of votes would do. In the end, Mr. Merrill said, 63 percent voted for one holiday proposasl or the other, but both measures failed.
Local officials told out-of-state sports officials that the cities of Phoenix and Tempe and many major companies already observed Dr. King's birthday. Organizers of the Fiesta Bowl college football game, to be held on New Year's Day, added scholarships for minority students for the participating schools and promised a halftime civil rights ceremony.
"We're telling them, 'Why punish Phoenix? It has a King holiday,' " said Larry Hilliard, vice president of the Phoenix and Valley of the Sun Convention and Visitors Bureau.
All sides agreed that whatever resolution is worked out, the issue must go to another statewide vote. "It absolutely must be submitted to the people," Mr. Merrill said, "or the wrath will be terrible."

GRAPHIC: Photos: On Nov. 6, voters in Arizona rejected, by less than 1 percent, a proposal to make the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. a holiday. The Rev. HEADLINE: How to Save the Trade Talks

 BODY:
There is new hope that the Uruguay Round of international trade talks, currently stalled by protectionist bickering, will finally pick up speed toward resolution. The White House announced this week that President Bush and his European counterparts had agreed to take charge of the negotiations. The elements of a deal are clear. All that's missing is leadership.
The talks are scheduled to end early next month. Yet there is no agreement in view, primarily because of shortsighted decisions by the industrialized countries. 
 At the core of the impasse is the attempt by Western leaders to protect the economic privileges of politically powerful domestic industries at the expense of the vast majority of their own citizens. The European Community persists in protecting a few million family farmers, the U.S. proposes to exempt telecommunications, aviation and shipping; Japan won't agree to import a grain of rice. And the industrialized powers have yet to make major concessions on protectionist textile policies.
The key stalemate is over European farm policy. To protect its farmers, the Community keeps food prices high, generating tremendous surpluses that it then dumps on foreign markets at subsidized prices. The policy costs European taxpayers $100 billion a year, and devastates competing farmers in food-exporting countries.
Third world food exporters are demanding that Europe open up its markets to imports of food and textiles before they agree to rules governing trade in services and intellectual property.
Last week the Europeans offered to cut farm supports by about 15 percent from current levels. That wouldn't provide much help, especially combined with other provisions that would allow Europe to preserve its export subsidies and even raise tariffs on selected products.
The U.S. has also been obstinate. It insists on exempting some key industries from trade talks even though there is nothing to lose by keeping them on the negotiating table. The negotiators are discussing a set of basic principles -- such as the obligation for each country to treat domestic and foreign service companies alike -- that the U.S. fully supports. Deciding how to apply these principles to individual sectors won't be negotiated until later, and the U.S. will be able to veto any rule it doesn't like.
Liberalized trade could add trillions to economies around the globe over the next 10 years, more than $1 trillion in the U.S. alone. But it won't happen unless Mr. Bush and European leaders make it happen.
Europe must agree to lower export subsidies and forsake raising any other trade barriers. The U.S. must withdraw its proposal to exempt specific service sectors. And the industrialized nations must agree to phase out protectionist textile agreements.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Hijack in Washington

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
Early on the morning of Oct. 26, a handful of members of the House of Representatives, working with the Bush Administration, hijacked direct relief for the people of the Soviet Union. Americans little noted, but should long remember.
With time running out before Congress adjourned, a few members of the House were able to override the Senate and prevent a dollop of humanitarian and economic aid from going directly to the Baltic nations and people still imprisoned in the Soviet system. 
 By this act, the perpetrators sent two messages. One was that aid to the Soviet people had to be channeled entirely through the staggering Gorbachev Government.
The other was that the Congressmen and State Department officials involved give President Mikhail Gorbachev's personal and political future a far higher priority than helping the people of the Soviet republics survive the hunger bequeathed to them by Communism.
The American public does not care -- because it was never told. Things that go bump in the middle of the hectic last Congressional nights don't get much newspaper or TV attention. Anyway, betrayal of the Baltics is not much of a story in Washington; routine. Newspapers and TV paid no attention that I know of except for a column in The Cleveland Plain Dealer.
In June, legislation was introduced in the Senate calling for $10 million in humanitarian aid to be divided among Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia. President Bush had helped Mr. Gorbachev fight Baltic independence, despite almost a half-century of American endorsement of Baltic freedom. But the Baltics continue the struggle for freedom as best they can.
As a New Yorker, I am happy to report that Senators Patrick Moynihan and Alfonse D'Amato were among the major movers, as was Senator William Armstrong, Republican of Colorado. Then Senator Robert Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, introduced a measure giving the Baltic nations an additional $15 million to be spent in helping private economic development.
The Senate passed both bills. But mysteriously, the House never got around to acting. So, with adjournment rushing up, they went to a conference committee, where the necessary House agreement was expected.
But that $25 million in a foreign aid package of $15 billion stuck in the craw of a few House committee members and they killed it. The Baltic-American communities, who have been kept informed by their own organizations, hold two Democratic representatives chiefly responsible: Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana and David R. Obey of Wisconsin.
A little poking around supports that. Congressional and State Department reasoning for rejecting sending even a drop of money directly to the Soviet republics goes like this: "It would annoy Gorbachev. Also, it would upset his negotiations with the Baltics. And it would be difficult to send help or investments directly, hard to find the right banking channels, contacts, all that."
Yes, it might upset Mr. Gorbachev to show that Moscow's writ is so weak that it cannot handle relief by itself. But it is politically wise and humanly decent to send most aid directly to the republics and their people. That plea comes from all over the Soviet Union.
True, sending official American aid to the republics and private Soviet groups through U.S. organizations might be complicated at first. But somehow private American aid manages to get through Soviet customs guards. Central authority in the Soviet Union evaporates every day. It's long past time for the U.S. to work out far better communications with the Soviet people. The longer we wait, the deeper the danger of famine.
As for the Moscow-Baltic talks, the U.S. has thrown all its weight to Mr. Gorbachev. The gesture of sending the Baltics a little help would not end the shame of the American betrayal of the Baltics. But after so many decades of unfulfilled blabber about helping, it might ease their hearts, and ours too.
So that is the story of how a small, compassionate attempt to help 3 of the 15 Soviet republics was mugged in the middle of the night. But the Baltics will not go away, nor the other rising republics. Neither will hunger in the Soviet Union. The need to send help to the survivors of Communism, direct to the people and places where it will do them and us the most good, becomes more important by the day.
If that aid annoys Mr. Gorbachev, it seems a price worth bearing for all of us, even members of Congress.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Upbeat European View

BYLINE: By PAUL L. MONTGOMERY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Trade ministers from the European Community's 13 nations tried today to put a positive cast on the continuing negotiations to break the impasse on farm subsidies.
Renato Ruggiero, Italy's trade minister, who presided at today's meeting, said, "Success is possible in all 15 subjects of the Uruguay Round," including farm subsidies.
After months of deadlock, the European Community last week approved a negotiating position on farm subsidies that fell far short of the sharp cuts sought by the United States, Canada and other food-exporting nations, including Australia, Argentina and Brazil. The Europeans, who have long had a policy of subsidizing small farmers because of their political strength, finally agreed to consider a 30 percent cut in subsidies covering a 10-year period retroactive to 1986.
The big producers, including the United States, want reductions of 75 percent in price supports and 90 percent in export subsidies over 10 years beginning in 1991. Japan, where small farmers are also a potent political force, is the only major country taking the European side.
Mr. Ruggiero reiterated the community's position that its negotiating position had room for change. "We have never said it is a take-it-or-leave-it offer," he said.
France has said a 30 percent cut in subsidies is probably the limit it can hope to sell to restive farmers. Peter Lilley, Britain's trade minister, said today in a clear reference to France that some countries had done a disservice to the community by indicating the negotiating position was a final offer.

HEADLINE: Eventually, We'll Have to Legalize Drugs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Ethan Kalett states that an end to the drug war "would increase abuse and have little effect on crime" (letter, Oct. 22). But each day brings more evidence that adopting some form of drug decriminalization would enhance law and order while not necessarily leading to significantly more drug abuse over the long term. 
 Mr. Kalett refers to the British approach in which registered heroin addicts may obtain free methadone from the British Government. It is essentially the same methadone-based approach used in the United States. He seems to object on the ground that the addict's dependency is simply shifted to the state's drugs.
Why is it a problem if addicts must stay on methadone for the rest of their lives? People with diabetes and epilepsy must take insulin and dilantin, respectively, all their lives to function properly. In this sense, they are addicted. At least they are not stealing for fixes, supporting drug gangsters and clogging our court dockets and prisons.
Mr. Kalett rightly observes that methadone does not work for all heroin addicts, and that these addicts will continue to buy heroin illegally. This is perhaps what prompted Dr. Philip Connell, chairman of the Home Office Advisory Committee on the Misuse of Drugs, to urge that the British return to their earlier lessrestrictive approach to treating heroin addiction. He proposes that the British abandon the policy of treating addicts only if they promise to withdraw and accept rapidly reducing doses of methadone. He recommends giving free needles, methadone or heroin for as long as addicts request.
Dr. Connell's suggestion is gaining favor in the British medical community. At the most recent conference of the International Council on Alcoholism and Addiction in Berlin, David Turner, director of Britain's Standing Committee on Drug Abuse, said he favored seeking alternatives to drug prohibition. "We have to learn to live with drugs, rather than dissipate our energies in pursuit of the myth of a drug-free world," he stated.
The most recent surveys indicate that drug use among young people in the United States continues to decline even as they report that drugs are easily available. Changes in attitudes and concern over health are winning the war on drugs, not paramilitary strategies of interdiction. Enlisting the criminal justice system in drug prohibition undermines its ability to execute effectively its traditional function: protecting people and property. Eventually, this country will legalize drugs because the black market pathologies -- addiction-supporting crime, corruption of law enforcement, overcrowded prisons -- will prove intolerable burdens on nonaddicts.
 
FRED L. FASON, M.D.
WILLIAM E. FASON
Houston, Oct. 31, 1990
 
The writers are, respectively, a forensic psychiatrist and an analyst for the Drug Policy Research Company.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Selling Sacrifice: Gulf Rationale Still Eludes Bush

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
More than three months after the Persian Gulf crisis began, the Bush Administration still seems to be seeking a rationale to convince the American public of the need to commit hundreds of thousands of troops for a possible war to free Kuwait from Iraq.
 In an interview tonight on Cable News Network, President Bush acknowledged this problem, when he said: "If I haven't done as clear a job as I might have on explaining this, then I've got to do better, because I know in my heart of hearts that what we are doing is right. I know what the United Nations has done is correct. I know that we've got to stand up to this aggression." 
 The Administration has found itself with often contradictory-sounding explanations. This was highlighted this week when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, talking more like a former Republican campaign chairman, shrugged off the President's earlier message that the gulf operation was "not about oil" and linked it directly to oil supplies and the health of the American economy.
"If you want to sum it up in one word, it's jobs," Mr. Baker said. "Because an economic recession, worldwide, caused by the control of one nation, one dictator, of the West's economic lifeline will result in the loss of jobs on the part of American citizens."
 
An Argument That Resonates
 The fact that Mr. Baker would suggest that the protection of jobs was a primary reason American troops might have to fight a war for Kuwait seemed to be both a search for an easily appealing rationale, as well as an acknowledgment that the Administration's explanations up to now have failed to resonate with the public.
Mr. Baker's attempt at political manipulation, and the negative reception it has received from commentators, seem to have stirred the President to engage in a new effort to win the backing of the American public. In addition to the long interview with CNN, he will also be appearing in the "My Turn" column in the forthcoming issue of Newsweek.
The Bush Administration came into office priding itself on prudence and pragmatism. In its first 18 months, when the most important foreign policy decisions involved reacting to events initiated by others in Eastern Europe, its instinctive caution and pragmatisim worked well enough.
But mobilizing the country for possible war is a different enterprise, one in which a President must take the initiative to persuade the nation that his aims are clear and the sacrifices justifed.
 
Slogans Aren't Substance
 "That requires a clarity of purpose that can only grow out of a vision of America's role in the world," said Michael J. Sandel, a Harvard University political theorist. "Pragmatism is not enough. Slogans comparing Saddam Hussein to Hitler, or claiming that the whole thing is about 'jobs,' are no substitute for serious moral and political arguments."
From the very start of his term, though, Mr. Bush has seemed to believe that political debate, and the building of constituencies, were the stuff of election campaigns, while governing involved pragmatic decision-making.
As a result, when Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker found themselves in the position of having to shape a national consensus for a large-scale foreign commitmemt, their instincts seem to hark back to campaign tactics. They appear to approach the building of a domestic political base for war as though it were another political campaign, where different slogans are employed each week, hoping that eventually one will strike the right chord.
This ad hoc approach led into a web of contradictions. On Oct. 16, the President said that "the fight isn't about oil; the fight is about naked aggression," while on Nov. 13, Mr. Baker said that it was about "jobs." How can it be about jobs, but not be about oil?
 
Defending What?
 On Aug. 8, the President declared that the mission of American troops was "wholly defensive," but on Oct. 23, he declared that "we're dealing with Hitler revisited, a totalitarism and brutality that is naked and unprecedented in modern times. And that must not stand." How can the United States insure that the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait will not stand, if the mission of American troops is "wholly defensive," to protect Saudi Arabia?
These contradictions not only arise from the Administration's lack of a clearly defined purpose, but also from the very ambiguous nature of the stakes in the gulf crisis and the Administration's difficulty in sorting out the complexities.
"In World War II," said the historian Daniel J. Boorstin, a former Librarian of Congress, "the threat of Hitler was so clear and unambiguous that to be anti-Nazi was to affirm something. If your enemy is sharp and clearly defined, then just by opposing him you have principles of your own. But who is Saddam Hussein? Most Americans had never even heard of this man. Is he really Hitler, or something else? There is a real confusion here about what these people over there are all about."
If there is any argument that seems to resonate with American troops in Saudi Arabia, it is that Saddam Hussein is a dangerous dictator with chemical weapons and a nuclear potential, who, if not stopped now, will threaten world peace.
But up to now, the President has limited himself more to name-calling than explaining why this particular dictator, with these particular weapons, in this particular spot, must be stopped.
"If you say that this man is Hitler, then Hitler calls forth a Churchill," said Fouad Ajami, a Middle East expert at Johns Hopkins University. "Bush has to meet him on the symbolic level, with a sweeping historical vision and the stirring oratory that will make men ready to sacrifice to stop him. But a nation that has just bid farewell to the cold war and ideological passion is not easily summoned for a warring assignment in a faraway place against a man whom people sense is not really part of our story."

HEADLINE: Sit Down and Talk With Hussein

BYLINE: By Judith Kipper; Judith Kipper, a Middle East specialist, is associated with the Brookings Institution and the Council on Foreign Relations.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The United States should talk directly with Saddam Hussein.
As events this week in Washington underscore, President Bush cannot risk war without being absolutely sure that there is no diplomatic way out of the gulf crisis. The political repercussions, both at home and in the fractious multilateral coalition opposing Iraq, could be disastrous. Moreover, with an isolated dictator who asserts draconian control over his people and his closest advisers, direct talk is the only way to take the correct measure of the man. 
 Despite United Nations Security Council resolutions and constant but apparently ineffective public diplomacy, Mr. Hussein sees himself confronted by the U.S., not by the international community. He believes there is an American conspiracy against Iraq, and when he looks over the horizon he sees hundreds of thousands of G.I.'s to confirm his suspicion.
The script for a Presidential envoy to Baghdad is simple: "Mr. President, you still have a chance for statesmanship by withdrawing unconditionally from Kuwait or you will, Mr. President, be removed from Kuwait by other means." No concessions can be made. An American envoy can talk only about arrangements for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait and the simultaneous introduction of peacekeepers.
This is a message that even a risk-taker like Saddam Hussein can understand. He is ruthless and inexperienced in the ways of the world, but he is neither crazy nor suicidal. When he has understood past miscalculations, he has reversed himself without explanation.
If Saddam Hussein can be made to understand by an American envoy what he is up against, he may again reverse himself. If he is only 99 percent sure that Iraq has to get out of Kuwait, he will play the 1 percent for everything it is worth.
 American policy makers may remember that even friendly dictators need to be persuaded directly. In 1986 President Reagan sent his close friend Senator Paul Laxalt to see the Philippine President, Ferdinand Marcos. Despite constant contacts with officials and elected American representatives, Marcos refused the message until the President finally dispatched a veteran diplomat, Philip Habib, to Manila. Marcos left for exile in Hawaii soon after meeting Habib.
Similarly, President Bush sent senior envoys on several secret missions to Beijing shortly after the massacre in Tiananmen Square. The mission to China failed, but the President had taken a chance -- sending his envoy -- to see if the United States could influence a bad situation.
Administration officials claim that talking to Saddam Hussein would be a reward for the Iraqi dictator. This view is not shared by some European and Arab coalition partners or by the Soviet Union. They recognize that direct talks with an American envoy may be the necessary face-saving-device Saddam Hussein needs. The United States has nothing to lose. At worst, no progress will be made. At best, war will be prevented.
The decade of the 90's belongs to the Middle East. The outcome of this crisis will shape the emerging world order for this decade and perhaps for decades to come. Iraq must get out of Kuwait because sovereignty is indivisible and nonnegotiable. Using force as a primary instrument of policy is unacceptable. Regional actors like Iraq must be persuaded that they cannot act with impunity to re-arrange the map or resolve grievances. This will dissuade others tempted to resort to force, which could create global anarchy.
Three months after Iraqi forces ruthlessly invaded a peaceful Kuwait, Saddam Hussein has the upper hand. Kuwait is devastated, thousands have been killed and displaced, the price of oil has doubled, threatening Eastern Europe and the third world with economic collapse; tourism and commerce are disrupted, and the time needed to shape the post-cold-war world has been stolen by Iraq.
Thus, military action may yet be necessary. But the U.S. should not even contemplate such a step without first talking to Saddam Hussein (not to speak of Congress). The uproar in Washington this week will seem mild compared with the explosion that is sure to come if the Administration refuses to talk before going to war.

HEADLINE: The Million Dollar Disgrace

BYLINE: By James Boyle; James Boyle is a professor of law at American University.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Richard Berendzen, the former president of American University, was asked to resign this spring when it was discovered that he had made obscene phone calls from his office. He remains a tenured professor. The trustees of American University -- without consulting anyone in the campus community -- have offered Dr. Berendzen more than $1 million to sever all ties with the school.
What are we to learn from this? 
 Lesson No. 1: When I first came to American University in 1982, the janitorial service workers were just beginning to organize themselves into a union. On Christmas Eve of that year, they were all fired with two weeks' pay by a gung-ho president who said that we had to make hard decisions in order to safeguard the university's meager resources. That president's name was Richard Berendzen.
The janitors had made no obscene phone calls. No one offered them $1.2 million, asked them to appear on "Nightline," or sympathized with them in print about the wrenching effect that this must have had on their family life. Eventually, a coalition of students, faculty and staff shamed the university into rehiring these employees.
As I write this article eight years later, the contractor has just refused to bargain with the janitors' union.
Lesson No. 2: When the board of trustees makes such decisions without consulting the faculty or the students, the campus reaction is one of fury. Signs are everywhere. Some of them are substantive -- "We want a voice." Some are humorous -- "Q: If the president gets a million dollars for committing sex offenses, what should the janitors get for unionizing? A: Fired." Others are biting -- "Why did the board like having Adnan Khashoggi as a member? He supplied them with moral vision."
My reaction to the board's persistent refusal to consult students or faculty is one of puzzlement. They must have seen the students at Gallaudet and at the University of the District of Columbia speaking out for democratic university governance. They probably cheered the wave of activism in Eastern Europe, yet apparently believe that universities are no place for debate and democracy.
Lesson No. 3: I teach in a law school. In a law school, one learns to decode texts. How can we decode the board's proposed settlement? On the one hand, you might believe that Dr. Berendzen is himself a victim, that he acted out of compulsion and that the appropriate response of a caring university community is to welcome him back with open arms.
On the other hand, you might think he is a sleazy, egomaniacal criminal who has simply used his disgrace as another whistle stop in his campaign of relentless self-promotion. In that case, presumably, you would move to terminate his tenure for cause. Which of these messages does the settlement convey?
The answer is, "Neither." The settlement says, "Go away, we love you." On its face, this is a morally cretinous response. It would be morally cretinous even if the university had limitless resources. In fact, this is a university with a tiny endowment and dependent on tuition. With $1.2 million, we could have given scholarships to 50 inner-city kids. We could have paid the medical insurance of everyone on campus or given our chronically underpaid staff a raise.
The board wants instead of hand it to Dr. Berendzen as a bonus for his work at American University -- above and beyond his salary, expense account, car, house and phone privileges. The board members will not feel the effect of their decision. They will not have to pay more tuition or see their classrooms made more homogeneous. Perhaps that is why they find it easy to give the money away.
So, what lessons does the Berendzen case teach us? It teaches us that our sympathy and interest go out most easily to people of our own class and race, that we are more likely to sympathize with a disgraced university president than a fired janitor.
It teaches us that democracy is never an unimportant ideal, that you can't draw a line around elections and declare that the moral force of democracy must be restricted to this narrow arena. It teaches us that one reason we have democracy is because people make unspeakably stupid decisions without it. The American University board certainly did. Perhaps Dr. Berendzen was a pretty good teacher, after all.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Lower Rates Push Dollar To New Low Against Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined broadly yesterday and settled at a new low against the German mark as lower American interest rates drove investors from the market.
The mark has been rising on expectations that the Bundesbank may be on the verge of raising interest rates, which would make German bonds more attractive to investors, enhancing their need for marks. 
 Further hurting the dollar was the continuing expectation that the Federal Reserve is preparing to lower interest rates. In New York the dollar settled at 1.4705 marks, down from 1.4755 on Thursday.
Currency trading was active following a Labor Department report that consumer prices were up by six-tenths of 1 percent in October. But once volatile food and energy prices were subtracted, the "core" inflation rate registered a moderate three-tenths rise.
"The market seized on the figure," said John McCarthy, chief dealer at the Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank. He added that because inflationary pressures seemed to be stabilizing, the Fed had more room to maneuver interest rates downward. Indeed, around midday, the Fed injected reserves into the banking system by buying Treasury bills with the promise of repurchasing them soon, usually after the weekend.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 129.73 Japanese yen, from 129.30 late Thursday. Later, in London, it fell to 129.45 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 129.50 yen, down from 129.69 on Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.9655, from $1.9590 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.9660 to buy 1, more expensive than Thursday's $1.9575.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.2465 Swiss francs, down from 1.2518; 4.9685 French francs, down from 4.9850; 1,109.50 Italian lire, down from 1,113.25, and 1.1633 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1624.
Gold prices were mixed. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold settled at $378.90 a troy ounce, down 20 cents from Thursday. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for bullion of $379, up 25 cents an ounce.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $376.25 a troy ounce, from $379.25 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $376.20 an ounce from $378.60. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.08 an ounce, to $380.11.

HEADLINE: Legislators Seek Laws to Aid Environment

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Legislators from the United States, Europe and Japan announced plans today to introduce parallel legislation to deal with climate change, deforestation and other threats to the environment.
The legislators, members of Global Legislators Organization for a Balanced Environment, or Globe, said at a news conference here today that tough environmental legislation would be introduced into the United States Congress, the Japanese Parliament and the European Parliament. They also said they expected their initiatives to put pressure on national governments to act more decisively on threats to global ecological systems. 
 Representative James H. Scheuer, Democrat of New York and founder and outgoing president of Globe, said that the two-year-old group was "coordinating environmental initiatives and providing common standards" to governments around the world.
 
Less Energy Consumption
 At the end of their three-day meeting, the legislators agreed to back laws aimed at mitigating global warming by reducing energy consumption in their respective countries. Scientists believe the earth's surface will warm by 3 degrees Fahrenheit or more by the middle of the next century, as carbon dioxide from the burning of fossil fuels along with other industrial gases accumulate in the atmosphere and retain heat radiated from the sun.
The legislation would stress reducing dependence on fossil fuels through conservation and through developing technologies that rely on other energy sources.
They also said they would try to enact legislation for protecting rapidly disappearing tropical forests. Their proposed law would require their Governments to enter negotiations on an international timber agreement. Such an accord would reduce timber cutting, improve economic returns to the the tropical countries and encourage the sustainable uses of the forests.
 
Help for Malaysian State
 The legislators urged an 80 percent reduction in cutting in the Malaysian state of Sarawak, where, according to Hemmo Muntingh, a member of the European Parliament from the Netherlands, unrestrained logging has created a desperate situation that approached "ecological suicide" for much of Sarawak. The legislators called for a moratorium on log imports from Sarawak by the industrial nations.
An official in the Malaysian Embassy here said logging in Sarawak had already been reduced. The official, who would not give his name, said he would not comment on any of the other statements made by the legislators at today's news conference.
They also called on the United States, Canada, Japan, and the Soviet Union to draw up a treaty for protecting the ecology of the North Pacific where, they said, marine mammals, fish, and sea bird populations were being reduced very rapdily because of excessive harvesting and pollution.
Senator Albert Gore Jr., the Tennessee Democrat who is Globe's new president, said: "Whether presidents or prime ministers act in these areas or not, parliamentarians will act. The people of the world want the environment to be protected and parliaments, by their nature, are closer to the grass roots."
 
Praises From Japan
 Takashi Kosugi, a representative of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party in Japan, said that the common positions taken by Globe had helped overcome resistance to environmental protection measures by the Trade and Finance Ministries of his Government.
The legislators agreed on a letter to Maurice Strong, the Secretary General of the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development, to be held in Brazil in 1992, urging that the conference take up as a primary issue "the burgeoning human population growth in the developing world." Unsustainable population growth, the letter said, threatens "public and private programs to improve health, combat poverty, raise education levels and improve the environment."
The June 1992 conference, to be held in Rio de Janeiro, is expected to play a critical role in developing global programs for protecting the environment while promoting economic growth, particularly in the poorer nations of Latin America, Africa and Asia.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
PRAGUE TO APPEAL FOR AID FROM U.S.

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Nov. 16

 BODY:
As flags went up and a workman on Wenceslas Square painted over graffiti saying "Yankees, Get Out of Saudi Arabia," Czechoslovakia prepared today to mark the anniversary of the revolution that toppled Communism by presenting President Bush with an appeal for economic aid.
Mr. Bush is to arrive in the Czechoslovak capital on Saturday to help mark the anniversary, on the first leg of a weeklong trip to Europe and the Middle East. On the eve of the visit, Prague officially renamed its railway station in honor of President Woodrow Wilson, who encouraged an earlier Czechoslovak push for independence. 
 One year after ousting the Communist Government, Prague is looking for American help in obtaining from financial agencies like the International Monetary Fund $1.5 billion to help stabilize the Czechoslovak crown, the national currency, and $2 billion to help balance a negative trade balance.
But in the talks between President Bush and President Vaclav Havel, the former dissident who is now this country's leader, Prague will also press to set aside a State Department judgment that lumped Czechoslovakia together with the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia as Eastern European countries that are "high risk" areas for travel. Czechoslovakia received the designation because of the smoldering conflict between the Czech and Slovak regional republics.
 
Inter-Regional Relations Worsen
 Since Communism fell last November, relations between the Czech and Slovak parts of the country have become seriously aggravated.
Last Tuesday, Czech and Slovak regional leaders reached partial agreement to leave jurisdiction of areas like defense and foreign affairs with the central Government. But other key issues, like the power to impose martial law and control of the railroads and telecommunications, remain disputed.
Still, in interviews this week, Czech officials stressed harmony between the republics. The head of the Czech regional government, Petr Pithart, spoke of "agreement on all substantial questions."
President Havel had lunch today with the heads of the central Government and the Czech and Slovak republic administrations, and officials close to the President emphasized the harmony at the table.
 
Warning on Investments
 Mr. Havel has warned in recent public pronouncements that national discord could jeopardize foreign investment. Officials also admit, however, that the Government must step up the pace of change.
Michael Zantovski, Mr. Havel's spokesman, said: "To attract foreign investment, capital and loans, we have to provide a legal framework and also a feeling of security for investors. Some say we are moving too slowly."
The spokesman stressed the complex legislation needed for change, including more than 40 draft laws. But he acknowledged that some critics within President Havel's Civic Forum movement have accused the Government of dragging its feet.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chrysler Halts Plans To Make a Mini-Jeep

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Amid a worsening economic climate and pressure on automotive producers worldwide, the Chrysler Corporation scrubbed plans today to produce a mini-Jeep for lack of a joint-venture partner.
Chrysler had initially estimated that the entire project would cost $500 million. 
 The No. 3 United States auto maker had first planned to build the vehicle -- code-named JJ for junior Jeep -- as a 50-50 venture with Renault, the French auto maker. But Renault backed out in June, saying the alliance "wasn't feasible."
Chrysler tried to replace Renault with Fiat, the Italian auto maker, but talks leading toward a broad cooperative agreement, including joint production of a small Jeep, fell through earlier this month.
Although the JJ was not envisioned as an important volume seller or money maker for Chrysler on the scale of its mini-van or Jeep Cherokee, the cancellation shows how auto makers' capital resources have been strained by soft sales worldwide.
For Chrysler, the disappointment is another in a series that began when the company's performance turned downward in 1989.
A prepared statement said that "while attractive as a joint venture, the JJ project as a stand-alone program required too great a commitment of resources that are needed for higher-priority product programs."
For Chrysler's approximately 1,500 Jeep-Eagle dealers, the cancellation may be a bitter pill since they have been begging Chrysler for new Jeep models to make up for the weakness of the Eagle brand.
Chrysler said it intended to maintain a "dominant position" in the market for larger sport utility vehicles and was "studying several alternatives to enhance the value of the Jeep franchise."
Ray Scofield, sales manager of Buerge Jeep-Eagle in Los Angeles, suggested the best thing Chrysler could do would be to bring out the planned luxury Jeep model, code-named ZJ, as soon as possable.
Chrysler's stock was unchanged today at $11.25 a share on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
ACCORDS REACHED BY IRAN AND IRAQ

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 16

 BODY:
In another sign that Iran and Iraq are drawing closer even as an international alliance tries to isolate President Saddam Hussein, the two nations said today that they had reached agreement on a series of steps to end major disputes lingering from their eight-year war.
Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati of Iran, returning to Teheran after meetings with his Iraqi counterpart, Tariq Aziz, announced the accords and told reporters that he detected a willingness by Iraq to end the crisis peacefully by withdrawing from Kuwait. 
 "They are not rejecting it, that was one's feeling," he said of international demands that Iraqi forces end their three-month-old occupation of Kuwait. "I believe that they will gradually become aware that neither the world nor the region will accept the occupation and the annexation, and that this is not something that will change with time."
Under the agreements reached in Baghdad this week, Iran and Iraq will soon resume the exchange of tens of thousands of prisoners of war who are still in captivity more than two years after the end of the war.
 
Number of Prisoners in Dispute
 The prisoner exchange, which began soon after the two nations resumed diplomatic relations last summer, was suspended in September, in part because of confusion over the exact number of Iranian prisoners held in Iraq.
In an interview with the Iraqi Government newspaper Al Jumhuriya, Mr. Velayati was quoted as saying Iran and Iraq had also made "confident steps" toward resuming full diplomatic relations, including an exchange of ambassadors, and had reached an understanding that will allow Iranian and Iraqi pilgrims to visit Muslim shrines in both countries.
Mr. Velayati was the highest ranking official to visit Iraq in more than a decade, and his trip offered new evidence of Iran's determination to capitalize on the gulf crisis by taking from Iraq now what it did not secure durng eight years of war.
Mr. Velayati also told reporters that despite the resumption of diplomatic relations with Iraq, Iran would continue to abide by economic sanctions imposed on Iraq by the United Nations.
 
Alliance Worries Western Leaders
 The evolving alliance between Teheran and Baghdad has worried some Western leaders, who fear that Iran might violate the embargo by shipping vital supplies to Iraq or, in a far more ominous scenario, might agree to some sort of military partnership with Iraq against the West.
The condemnation of Iraq continued unabated today in Cairo, where President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said that President Hussein of Iraq "doesn't understand the danger surrounding him -- his aides do not tell him the truth."
At the same time, Mr. Mubarak was quoted in Cairo newspapers today as repeating his call for a delay in the use of force in the gulf, saying the United States should postpone any military action against Iraq for up to three months to allow time for a settlement.
The Egyptian leader said that after consultations with envoys from the Soviet Union and China, he was convinced that neither country would oppose the use of force in the gulf as a last resort to remove Iraq from Kuwait.
In Baghdad, 16 Danish hostages were freed today after a meeting between Mr. Hussein and former Prime Minister Anker Jergensen of Denmark. Several dozen Danes are still being held in Iraq, however.
And in Beirut, a senior Muslim cleric affiliated with the Party of God called for the release of all Western hostages in Lebanon. Western diplomats here said it appears that the release of several British hostages held in Lebanon, including the Church of England envoy, Terry Waite, may be imminent, in part because of Iranian pressure on the Party of God, an umbrella organization of Shiite groups believed to be holding them.

HEADLINE: Fed Panel Favored Easing At Meeting in Early October

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers agreed in early October to ease interest rates if a Federal budget-cutting agreement was reached and to permit further easing if economic conditions warranted, records released today showed.
Four weeks after the Oct. 2 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Federal funds rate dropped to 7.75 percent from 8 percent as the Bush Administration and Congress agreed to a deficit-reduction package. 
 The committee met again on Tuesday, and traders said today that the credit market was showing signs that the central bank had acted to drop the Federal funds rate some more.
Until recently, the Fed has been reluctant to ease credit because of fears over inflation related to the rise in oil prices after Iraq invaded Kuwait.
In fact, three of the four committee members at the early October meeting opposed an easing of rates, saying they felt "the committee risked losing sight of its fundamental objective of controling and ultimately bringing down inflation." But the increased oil prices have not spread to other costs.
According to the committee meeting minutes released today, Martha Seger, a Fed governor, also dissented from the majority vote because she favored immediate moves to permit lower interest rates.
The three who opposed any easing were Wayne D. Angel, a governor, and two presidents of Fed district banks, Robert H. Boykin of Dallas and W. Lee Hoskins of Cleveland.
The majority included Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman; three governors, Edward W. Kelley Jr., John P. LaWare and David W. Mullins Jr., and three district presidents, Edward G. Boehne of Philadelphia, E. Gerald Corrigan of New York and Gary H. Stern of Minneapolis. There is one vacancy on the committee.
 
Manipulating the Rate

The Federal funds rate, which banks charge one another for overnight loans, has been used for two years in combating inflation. It peaked at 9.75 percent in the spring of 1989 and the Fed has since let it fall in quarter-point increments to stimulate economic growth. It had declined to 8 percent last summer.
Some analysts said they thought that at the Tuesday meeting the committee might have voted to cut the discount rate it charges commercial banks for loans. That rate has stood at 7 percent for more than four years.
The committee is composed of the 7 Fed governors and 5 of the 12 presidents of Fed regional banks. It meets in secret eight times a year to formulate monetary policy. Minutes are released about six weeks later, a few days after the next meeting.
