HEADLINE: Oil Prices Drop Below $30 a Barrel

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
A barrel of oil cost less than $30 yesterday for the first time in more than three weeks, as traders reacted to conciliatory talk from Saddam Hussein and to the beginning of President Bush's trip to Saudi Arabia.
Warm weather in the United States and reports of ample oil production have also helped drive prices down.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, crude for December delivery fell $1.34 a barrel, to $29.78. The last time the spot contract closed below $30 was on Oct. 23. 
 Market experts said the $30 level was an important barrier. Some in the market had left standing orders to buy at that price, which made it a level of strong support.
After Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, oil prices began a run-up that peaked at $41.15 a barrel on Oct. 10. Yesterday's close represented a drop of 28 percent in 26 trading days. At one point yesterday oil was trading at $29.25.
"What was in the news was peace, negotiated peace," said Richard D. Donovan, senior vice president of futures trading at Lehman Brothers. "I would imagine prices are going to go down another buck or two next week," he said, adding that many people who had "gone long," or bought contracts that promise delivery in future months, were selling those contracts.
Many traders had talked about the possibility of a war in one of two "windows," between Thanksgiving and Christmas, or after Christmas but before mid-March, when the Muslim world begins observing Ramadan and windstorms begin in the gulf region. Mr. Donovan said that given the present tone of public statements by world leaders and President Bush's trip to Saudi Arabia "the first window is closing." The President began an eight-day trip to Europe and the Middle East yesterday.
At Pegasus Econometri Associates, Thomas Blakeslee, an oil analyst, said the main motivation of the market yesterday was a statement by Mr. Hussein, the President of Iraq, that he preferred a peaceful end to the standoff. But Mr. Blakeslee added, "He's made this same type of comment in the past."
"The market used this as an excuse to move toward a more 'supply and demand oriented' price level," Mr. Blakeslee said. He added that the market still had a long way to go to reach that level, down perhaps another $9.
But the fact that the market paid attention to Mr. Hussein's remark was "a good indicator that we're in a bear market now," he said.
Charles Ebinger of the Center for Strategic International Studies in Washington said the market was "discounting the prospect of near-term hostilities," but he added that this judgment could turn out to be wrong, and that a war would send prices right back up.
With the lull in war fears, Mr. Ebinger said another factor was exerting some influence: "The growing and deepening concern about recession leading to a fall-off in demand, alleviating pressure on the supply for the fourth quarter and the first quarter of next year."
On that combination, the prices of petroleum products also fell yesterday. Unleaded gasoline closed at 77.63 cents a gallon, down 2.53 cents, and heating oil was at 84.42 cents a gallon, down 2.25 cents.
The demand for heating oil has been pushed down somewhat by the recent warm weather in the Northeast, where most heating oil is used. The National Weather Service said that in New York City fuel requirements have been 9.4 percent less than normal so far in this heating season.

HEADLINE: A Bitter Pill for Trump and Maybe Another

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
For the first time, Donald Trump is being forced to hand over a share of his real estate empire to creditors. It could happen again next month.
Yesterday's agreement to surrender as much as half of his ownership in the Taj Mahal casino to bondholders is part of a quick bankruptcy reorganization that will keep the operation running.
 Losing a part of his stake in the Taj, which Mr. Trump calls the "seventh wonder of the world," may be a bitter pill to swallow for Mr. Trump, who won a bitter fight to control it while it was still under construction. But a similar setback may occur next month. 
 On Dec. 15, Mr. Trump's Castle casino hotel in Atlantic City will again owe interest to bondholders, and Mr. Trump could be hard pressed for cash once again.
It was the Castle's inability to meet debt payments last June that led to protracted negotiations with banks, which eventually agreed to put up the cash for those payments and to allow Mr. Trump to stretch out the payments on many loans to the banks. Mr. Trump's greatest success in those negotiations was that he was not forced to give up ownership stakes in any assets.
While that bank deal was touted at the time as a five-year arrangement, it later turned out that the negotiators focused almost exclusively on the money Mr. Trump and his enterprises owed to banks, while paying little attention to the money that was owed to bondholders.
As a result, it was only a matter of weeks before Mr. Trump was again involved in debt talks, as the Taj Mahal casino was unable to make a $47.3 million interest payment on its bonds. Under the agreement reached yesterday, Mr. Trump will give up 50 percent of his ownership stake in the Taj Mahal. And depending on how much cash the casino is able to come up with to pay interest over the next 10 years, Mr. Trump could end up with 80 percent. Bondholders will get to keep 50 percent if Mr. Trump's organization avails itself of interest-rate concessions.
The Castle, the weakest of Mr. Trump's three casinos in terms of attracting gamblers, in part because it is not on the Boardwalk, has suffered with the rest of the industry from the deteriorating Northeast economy and from the competition that was introduced when the Taj Mahal opened in the spring. Yesterday, Mr. Trump declined to comment on whether he expected the Castle to meet its obligations next month.
Because the casino bondholders have mortgages on the casino properties, they are in a relatively strong negotiating position, a fact that helped the Taj bondholders to get the equity stake. Whether that equity stake will be worth anything depends, of course, on the performance of the casino in the future.
While attention has been focused on a Trump bankruptcy, in the world of real estate it is not unusual for developers to see one or more projects go under. Mr. Trump did not personally guarantee payments on the casino bonds, although he did provide guarantees for some bank loans to other Trump enterprises.
"I have some very good projects, and I have some that need work," Mr. Trump said yesterday. "These are individual deals. They stand alone."
Mr. Trump is not alone as a hard-pressed borrower. Several real estate developers have defaulted on loans, the most recent being Sam LeFrak, who did not meet mortgage payments on the Newport project in Jersey City. And Rupert Murdoch, the owner of an international media conglomerate, asked his banks this week to defer interest payments to give him time to sell assets.

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Saturday about Donald Trump's debts, and another on Monday about troubles in the real estate industry, referred incorrectly to a default on a mortgage loan for the Presidential Plaza apartments, part of the Newport complex in Jersey City. Although members of the LeFrak family have an interest in the companies that own the development, neither the Lefrak Organization nor any member of the family defaulted. Other parts of the Newport project have not defaulted, and Lefrak says its financial condition is good.

HEADLINE: 3 Bids for Mexico Phone Company

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 16

 BODY:
The Mexican Government said today that two multinational consortiums and one Mexican group had made formal bids to buy a controlling share in the national telephone company, Telefonos de Mexico. The bids set the stage for what promises to be one of the largest and most complex sales of a government-held enterprise attempted by any nation.
Two of the bidding groups are made up of Mexican companies paired with giant communications concerns from the United States and Europe. One matches the Mexican concern Accival Casa de Bolsa with GTE and Telefonica de Espana. The other partnership has the Mexican Grupo Carso teaming up with Southwestern Bell and France Cable and Radio. 
 The third bidder is an all-Mexican consortium, Grupo Gentor. It is led by a prominent Monterrey-based businessman, Javier Garza Sepulveda, and other investors associated with the Mexican conglomerates Vitro and Grupo Industrial Alfa, Government officials said. The amount of the bids was not disclosed.
The bids for the company, known as Telmex, end more than a year of intensive preparation and screening for what will be the most important single element of the Government's ambitious program to transfer many state-owned enterprises to private hands.
If the overall value of the company reaches $7 billion to $8 billion, as expected, the sale would rank among the five largest privatizations ever carried out. It is also the first deal this large tried in a third world country of limited domestic financial resources and one that has designed the sale to attract foreign capital to a vital but neglected utility.
Through the sale, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari plans to gain not only a lot of foreign money for the Government treasury, but also the assurance that the new owners will overhaul a communications system that is now a big obstacle to modernization of the whole Mexican economy.
Only about 20 percent of all Mexican homes have telephone service, one of the lowest rates in the world. There are more than 1.5 million unfilled requests for installation and about one-fifth of the existing lines are out of service at any one time, making innovations like facsimile and computer communications difficult or impossible to introduce.
 
 No Bid by Nynex
 Government officials have said that about 12,000 complaints about telephone service are received daily.
In a surprise last-minute development, a consortium led by Nynex, the New York-based American communications company, did not submit a bid. Nynex, citing the potential for the rapid growth of Mexico's communication markets, said in late September that it would try to buy Telmex in association with a Mexican financial group and the parent company of Bell Canada. But on Thursday Nynex issued a statement saying the consortium had "decided not to proceed with a bid at this time."
A Nynex spokeswoman, Joan C. Huthwaite, said today that the consortium members had not felt "entirely comfortable" with the purchase after reviewing it in detail.
Under a plan intended to encourage new investment and strong management while preserving Mexican control of the company, the winning bidder in the Telmex sale will receive a 20.4 percent stake, representing a majority of full voting stock under a new capital structure made up for the sale. The rest of the Government's current 56 percent share of Telmex, with limited voting rights, is expected to be sold next year. The remainder of the company is already owned by a mix of private investors, and t he Government will retain strong regulatory control over the company, officials said.
At least 51 percent of the winning consortium must be Mexican-owned, and Government officials said that the foreign and domestic components of the bids would be considered separately to insure the best purchase price. This feature, they said, could lead to a reshuffling of groups before the announcement of the final buyer on Dec. 20.
"Arranging a marriage like this is very complex, and we want to be as flexible as possible," said Jacques Rogozinski, chief of the Government's Office for Privatization. "As far as we are concerned, somebody can meet their bride at the door of the church or bring her to church with them."
Before Telmex was opened to bids, Government officials reduced the company's debt, streamlined telephone taxes, eliminated cross subsidies between local and long-distance calls and consolidated labor contracts. These moves have increased the company's attractiveness to potential buyers, but the frustrations faced by Mexican telephone customers have remained intractable.
On Aug. 3, Government officials staged an elaborate inauguration of new public phones in San Bernabe, a working-class neighborhood of Monterrey. But when President Salinas picked up the phone in front of officials and journalists to place a ceremonial first call to his hometown, the symbolism was all too familiar. Try as he might, the President could not get through.

Many wiring cabinets, likethis one in Mexico City's Colonia Anahuac district, are exposed to weather and vandalism damage that leads to as many as 12,000 complaints daily, while only 20 percent of Mexican homes have phones. (Sergio Dorantes for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Import Fall Narrows Trade Gap

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Although the nation's bill for imported oil rose to the highest level in nine years, the American trade deficit narrowed slightly in September, the first full month after Iraq invaded Kuwait, the Commerce Department reported today.
The deficit declined because other imports fell, which many economists said reflected the reduced consumption of a weakening economy. 
 The 3.3 percent contraction of the deficit, to $9.41 billion from a revised $9.73 billion in August, marked the first improvement in the trade picture since June. It came about chiefly as a result of a 2.4 percent decline in imports, to $41.25 billion. Exports also fell, but the drop was smaller -- a decline of 2.2 percent, to $31.84 billion.
 
 Rate of $99.13 Billion
 For the first nine months, the deficit was running at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $99.13 billion, compared with $109.4 billion last year, $118.5 billion in 1988 and the record $152 billion in 1987.
"Imports are behaving the way they should be behaving in a slow economy," said Morris Cohen, of Morris Cohen & Associates, economic consultants, in Hackensack, N.J.
He predicted that because of the improved foreign trade picture -- the large decline in imports and the smaller drop in exports -- any recession would be mild. After recent talks with White House advisers and business executives, President Bush acknowledged for the first time on Thursday what many economists had said for months, that the economy might be facing a recession.
 
 Move to 'Equilibrium' Seen
 David B. Bostian, managing director of Jesup, Josephthal & Company, investment bankers in New York, predicted that the country should be moving toward "trade equilibrium over the next two to three years" because of the "recessionary climate" and a weaker dollar, which makes American products less expensive overseas, relative to goods from other countries.
Although economists caution against reading too much into a single month's figures, there was some puzzlement over the September decline in exports. After reaching a record in June, exports have fallen to the levels of early this year.
Because of delayed reactions, some experts suggested, exports could still be suffering from earlier periods of dollar strength. "It takes two and a half to three years between the time the dollar starts changing course and the time you see effects in the trade flows," said Robert A. Brusca, chief economist of Nikko Securities International.
The dollar fell sharply from 1985 to 1987, rebounded through the end of last year and started sliding again this year.
Another factor could be the weakness in some big markets for American goods, like Canada and Britain, which are in or near recessions of their own.
The rise in September oil imports, to $6.2 billion, was entirely a function of price. Oil averaged $24.31 a barrel, compared with $19.54 in August and $14.50 in July, before Iraq invaded Kuwait. The daily market price has risen as high as $41 a barrel, and now stands at around $30. The September imports of 254 million barrels were five million barrels less than in the average of the previous eight months.
 
 Fall in Manufactured Imports
 The surge in oil costs masked an unsually large drop of $2 billion in manufactured imports. Decreases came in sectors including clothing and footwear, machinery, new passenger cars and iron and steel.
Exports of manufactured goods were virtually the same as in August, with increases in office equipment, power-generating machinery and organic and inorganic chemicals. Lower exports were reported in fertilizers and general industrial machinery. Agricultural commodities declined.
J. Antonio Villamil, the Commerce Department's chief economist, said that the deficit when calculated without oil trade, as an indicator of underlying industrial competitiveness, stood at $3.8 billion in September, down from a revised $5 billion in August. Over the first nine months, it improved even more sharply, to $35.4 billion, against $49.5 billion over the 1989 period.
The United States continued to record its largest trade deficit with Japan, but the gap shrank in September, to $3.05 billion from $3.78 billion, mostly reflecting a drop in imports. In the first nine months the imbalance stood at $29.4 billion with Japan, down from $36.6 billion last year.
There was also a sharp improvement with Western Europe, where the United States went from a deficit of $374 million in August to a surplus of $882 million in September. For the first nine months the United States recorded a surplus with Europe of $3.5 billion, compared with a deficit of $600 million in 1989 and a deficit of $8.8 billion in the first nine months of 1988.
Other large deficits in September were with Canada ($1.25 billion), China ($1.07 billion), Taiwan ($1.03 billion), South Korea ($406 million), Hong Kong ($231 million) and Brazil ($105 million).

HEADLINE: CUZCO JOURNAL;
Drumming up Tourism Is Aim of 'the Safe Peru'

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CUZCO, Peru, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Voiced in the two-mile-high air of this ancient mountain city, Carlos Milla Vidal's command sounded like an ancient Inca rallying cry: Forget Peru.
Mr. Milla is not an Inca irredentist, nostalgic for the days 500 years ago when this Indian city was the seat of the Inca empire. 
 Instead, he is a modern-day Peruvian with a business card. As president of the local hotel association, he is designing a market strategy to revive international tourism here.
 
Emphasis on Incas and Andes
 "We don't want to talk about Peru -- we want to talk about the Andes," Mr. Milla said over coffee in a hotel whose thick gray stone walls bore witness to earlier tenants: Spanish colonial governors and Inca princes.
Divorcing destination from location is a sales tactic developed in recent years by desperate managers of beach resorts in troubled countries like Haiti and Colombia. Now, the technique has reached Peru's primary tourist destinations -- Cuzco, a graceful city where most people still speak Quechua, the language of the Incas, and nearby Machu Picchu, the lost city of the Incas.
In the 1980's, each new report of violence by cocaine traffickers or by the Maoist guerrilla movement known as the Shining Path seemed to push the number of foreign tourists here steadily downward.
Last year, six flights a day shuttled tourists between here and Lima, Peru's capital, on the Pacific coast. Today there are only two.
"Some of the guides have left for Ecuador, Bolivia or Chile," Rosario Salinas Salas, a nature guide, said as the flutes and drums of an Andean folklore group resounded through a virtually deserted restaurant.
With the European and North American winter fast approaching, vendors on the narrow cobblestone streets here are feverishly discounting unsold bales of alpaca sweaters, scarves and mittens.
"Our only major factory makes beer," said Rosa Maria Garcia, a tour guide.
Looking at Peru from afar, many potential visitors may have missed the fine print: in a nation three times the size of California, Shining Path terrorism has largely bypassed Cuzco and Machu Picchu. About 50 miles north of Machu Picchu starts an area of almost 100,000 acres of coca-leaf cultivation. But the clandestine crop there has not generated the violence of Peru's coca-leaf basket, the Upper Huallaga Valley.
 
Half as Many Tourists
 With tourist arrivals expected to drop to 100,000 this year, about half as many as a decade ago, Cuzco boosters have started a campaign to rewrite the fine print.
Support for the regional campaign came from President Alberto Fujimori last week. On a quick visit here, he helped push a plan to channel foreign tourists directly into what local boosters call "the safe Peru."
Mr. Fujimori announced that foreign airlines and chartered companies would now be able to fly here directly, bypassing Lima.
"We can't require foreign tourists to make a stop in Lima in order to get to know the natural wonders of Cuzco and Puerto Maldonado," Mr. Fujimori said, referring to this city and to a town 200 miles northeast of here on an Amazon tributary.
Benefiting from a surge in "green tourism," Puerto Maldonado is a gateway to the new Manu National Park, a chunk of pristine Peruvian rain forest the size of Massachusetts.
To drum up international interest, President Fujimori swept through Cuzco in a motorcade carrying the ambassadors of the United States and five Western European countries.
The United States Embassy hands out a five-page travel advisory that counsels Americans to stay away from most of Peru, including its own installations. That advice came after three bombs went off near embassy buildings in Lima last week.
 
A Lukewarm Endorsement
 "We don't recommend that Americans not go to Cuzco," Ambassador Anthony C. E. Quainton said in an endorsement that hotel keepers here might find short of ringing. One American tourist was killed in Cuzco earlier this year, and several others died in the late 1980's when a train line between here and Machu Picchu was sabotaged.
But Japanese interest in Peru soared after the inauguration in July of Mr. Fujimori, a Peruvian born to Japanese immigrant parents. In recent months, two Peruvian travel agencies have set up shop in Tokyo.
Flights to Tokyo are filled with Japanese-Peruvians fleeing Peru's bankrupt economy for relatively high-paying menial labor in Japan. Flights to Lima are filled with tourists curious about the Latin American nation that chose as President a man who speaks Spanish with a light Japanese accent.
At Machu Picchu the other day, a San Francisco college teacher rested her feet from walking the ruins. Over a cup of coca-leaf tea, she talked in a way that would have warmed the hearts of tourism promoters here.
"The Shining Path?" she said, puzzled. "What's that? A religious movement?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Peruvian officials are trying to market Peru as a fascinating Inca empire to help revive international tourism there. Above, visitors to the Sacasayhuaman Fortress in Cuzco, an ancient mountain city. (James Brooke/The New York Times)
 
Map of Peru showing location of Cuzco.

HEADLINE: Darman Says Bush Is Exploring Shift in Benefits

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Richard G. Darman, the budget director, said today that the Bush Administration was exploring ways to shift Government benefits from the wealthy and middle class and concentrate them more on the poor.
In his first public appearance since the end of this fall's budget ordeal, Mr. Darman said the new budget procedures gave the Administration and Congress a fresh opportunity to focus on principles and "basic policy analysis" rather than merely on "near-term cash flow." 
 Social Security, the Government's biggest benefit program, will be exempt from the examination of how programs affect people at various income levels, Mr. Darman said. But he suggested that Medicare and agriculture subsidies, among others, might be targets for benefit redistribution.
 
Question of Politics in Plan
 Democrats scored heavily in the battle over the budget by portraying President Bush and his fellow Republicans as patrons of the wealthy and themselves as the defenders of the more ordinary Americans.
The policy benefits aside, the Administration might see a chance to regain lost political ground by proposing to limit, for instance, Government expenditures on medical care for affluent retirees or crop-support payments to big farmers and to use the resources instead on health care for poor children in rural areas.
Democrats, who depend on political support from the elderly and farmers, could be expected to oppose such changes, and that would expose them, the theory goes, as guardians of special interests. But such a strategy could backfire. In the past, Republicans in Congress have fought changes in Medicare benefits every bit as vigorously as have Democrats.
Mr. Darman said that the matter was still being explored and that it would be weeks before the Administration's economic and budget policy for next year was developed.
Mr. Darman made these remarks in answer to questions after addressing the Council for Excellence in Government, a nonpartisan organization of former senior Government officials.
 
Making Use of Word Flair
 Unlike the didactic ones he has given occasionally during his years in the Bush and Ronald Reagan Administrations, the speech was notable mostly because Mr. Darman exercised his flair for metaphors and word-coinage. He entitled the address "Neo-neo-ism: Reflections on Hubble-ism, Rationalism and the Pursuit of Excellence (After the Fiscal Follies)."
"Neo-neo-ism" is the term he gave to politicians' search for a "bold new program" to meet every situation. "Hubble-ism," a reference to the orbiting space telescope that is malfunctioning because it was not properly tested, is the budget director's word for the political propensity to conclude that "if an idea is good enough for a few and large enough to label, it is ready to be launched at full scale."
Last year, in a widely publicized speech, Mr. Darman spoke against "now-now-ism," the tendency toward self-indulgence in the 1980's. And in an introduction to President Bush's budget this year, he played with words and metaphors again, describing the Federal budget as "the ultimate Cookie Monster," because it had the same huge appetite for consumption as the character on the children's television program "Sesame Street."
In those cases and others, Mr. Darman used his word games to take the hard edge off of serious and controversial points. Today's speech had no sharp corners to begin with. His main points were that the budget law he helped drive to enactment last month would lead to deficit reduction and that the new rules putting ceilings on spending and requiring pay-as-you-go provisions in new legislation would lead Congress and the President to focus more on how to use available resources.
He chided Democrats for standing for little more than "anti-millionaire-ism," a reference to Democratic support for legislation that would place a surtax on incomes of more than $1 million.
 
Conservative Republicans Angry
 And he raised the ire of some conservative Republicans by making light of "the new paradigm," the phrase that wing of the Republican Party uses to describe an approach to meeting social problems that emphasizes individual choice, such as giving parents the capacity to select which public schools their children go to.
"The effete might debate whether the new paradigm is, perhaps, enigmatically paradigmatic," Mr. Darman said. "At the same time, in the real world, others might simply dismiss it by picking up the refrain, 'Hey, brother, can you paradigm."'
Mr. Darman has become the scourge of the conservatives, who believe he was responsible for persuading President Bush to change his mind about raising taxes, and, however jesting Mr. Darman meant it, some took offense.
Burton Yale Pines, senior vice president of the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research institute based in Washington, said Mr. Darman had become a liability and should resign.
And James P. Pinkerton, deputy assistant to President Bush for policy planning, said sardonically, "After the success of the budget deal, it's good to see Dick returning to the dialogue of ideas."

HEADLINE: Chase Says Its Losses Will Rise

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Chase Manhattan Corporation expects increased losses on consumer and business loans in coming months, assuming that the economy continues to weaken, the banking company said in a document filed early this week with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The warning by the country's third-largest banking company confirmed the predictions of industry analysts that many large banks face more pervasive problems than the bad loans they made to commercial real estate developers. History shows that economic downturns result in sharply higher losses for all kinds of loans, as corporate profits dry up and unemployment rises. 
 A move to lower interest rates, which the Federal Reserve has recently begun, is expected to give little help to bank profits, since they manage their borrowing and lending in such a manner that gradual changes in rates have little effect on profits.
 
 Rise in Delinquencies Seen
 The Chemical Banking Corporation, the nation's sixth-largest banking company, predicted in a separate filing with the S.E.C. that the economy would continue to weaken in coming months, causing an increase in delinquencies for various
 
kinds of loans.
 Many analysts expect that banks will be slow to reduce the prime interest rate, a widely followed benchmark for loans to small businesses and consumers, because they need to compensate for rising loan losses and other expenses, like the increase in deposit insurance premiums paid to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
"The Chase filing is an admission of more problems," said J. Richard Fredericks, a banking analyst at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. "It is a reminder they have more work ahead to extricate themselves from credit problems with real estate loans."
 
 Other Poor Business Cited
 He added that other parts of Chase's business were not producing the profits needed for a quick recovery.
The description by Chase of its business pospects was part of a quarterly disclosure filing, known as a 10-Q, that all large publicly traded companies make with the Securities and Exchange Commission, usually a few weeks after they have announced quarterly earnings.
As losses on real estate loans have grown more serious for banking companies in the last year, many analysts have begun to look to the quarterly filings for clues to future developments. Analysts expect that other banks will also acknowledge that they, too, expect increased losses from business and consumer loans as the economy weakens.
"The S.E.C is getting banks to be a little more predictive in the filings, and forcing better disclosure," Mr. Fredericks said.
Chase's stock, which has not improved in recent days to the same extent as other banking issues, rose yesterday by 37.5 cents, to $11.125.
In its 10-Q filing, Chase said, "If the economy continues to weaken, and conditions in domestic commercial real estate markets continue to be adverse, there could be further increases" in charge-offs for commercial real estate, consumer and business loans. The bank added that at present it had adequate reserves to cover possible losses, but it said additional reserves might be needed if the economy worsened.
 
 Higher Charges Expected
 Chase said it expected to increase in the fourth quarter the amount of commercial real estate loans it charges off as a loss, and that charge-offs would remain high into 1991.
Earlier this year Chase was hard hit by losses on commercial real estate loans, which contributed to its overall third-quarter loss of $623 million. To improve its financial condition, Chase slashed its common stock dividend and began eliminating 5,000 jobs -- a move that will reduce its costs by $300 million in 1991.
Greater losses on consumer loans would follow several years of rapid growth, which made the consumer banking business a highly profitable part of the bank. Chase is the second-largest commercial bank issuer of credit cards in the country, after Citibank. While losses on its credit cards have been low in recent years, analysts have said they expect all banks to suffer an increase in defaults on credit cards and other consumer debt when the economy weakens.
Chase noted that its earnings would be depressed in coming months by a slowdown in business lending, particularly in loans for corporate takeovers. But it said that despite weakness in the economy, its holdings of loans issued to highly indebted companies in recent years are expected "to remain sound."
 
 Reduced Corporate Profits
 Many analysts have warned that loans made in the late 1980's to highly indebted companies to help finance corporate takeovers or other reorganizations could result in major losses during a recession. Their logic is that as a weaker economy reduces corporate profits, even pushing companies into loss positions, more companies will default on bank loans.
In recent weeks many banking analysts have forecast that banks' profits will slide in 1991. Thomas Hanley, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, recently reduced by $3 billion, or about 20 percent, his estimate for 1991 profits at 35 large banks, to $11.5 billion.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE IN OCTOBER AT A SLOWER RATE

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
In a reassuring report on inflation that appeared to lead to another interest-rate cut by the Federal Reserve, the Labor Department said today that consumer prices had climbed less in October than in the preceding two months. The bond market rallied in response.
About half the October increase in prices reflected petroleum costs, which have flattened lately. 
 The overall price rise, six-tenths of 1 percent, although large by most standards, was a bit better than had been expected and represented improvement from the increases of eight-tenths of 1 percent posted by the Consumer Price Index in both August and September.
 
Prospect of Lower Rates
 Apparently convinced that the risks of serious economic deterioration now outweigh those of inflation, the Federal Reserve moved today to cut an important short-term interest rate by one-quarter point, to 7 1/2 percent. This could lead to eventual cuts in what banks charge for loans to invididuals and businesses, thereby spurring economic activity.
The impact was felt immediately in the credit markets, as prices of long-term Treasury bonds moved higher and their yields fell. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 8.44 percent, from 8.52 percent the day before and 8.61 percent a week ago. [Page 34.]
Indications of a recession have come from a number of recent economic reports, like the one today that showed the trade deficit narrowed in September largely because consumers cut back on buying imports. Given all these signs, an easing of monetary policy was widely anticipated, although the timing remained uncertain.
In fact, a summary published today of the Federal Reserve's Oct. 2 strategy session showed that 3 of the 11 members of its policy-making committee were sufficiently concerned about inflation to vote against an easing of rates.
But today's inflation data followed the report last Friday that producer prices, excluding energy and food, remained unchanged in October, and the combined reports seem to have convinced the central bank that the task of arresting economic decline has become paramount and the inflation risks have become minimal.
Indeed, various analysts said the sagging economy was itself acting as a brake on prices. At the consumer level, price increases, excluding the volatile energy and food components, have now been held for two straight months at three-tenths of 1 percent.
Mickey D. Levy, chief economist for CRT Government Securities Ltd., called the figures a "glimmer of improvement in core inflation."
 
 Outlook on Oil
 In the oil industry, many executives are saying the price of oil has peaked, a view shared by Patrick C. Jackman, chief of the Labor Department's consumer prices branch. He said today that current indications were that oil would exert little, if any, inflationary pressure in the November report. That would be a contrast to the three most recent months, when oil caused the inflation rate roughly to double.
During the first 10 months of the year, the index covering all urban consumers has climbed at an annual rate of 6.7 percent, compared with a 4.7 percent pace during the comparable 1989 period. The difference is mainly attributable to oil-price increases that followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in early August.
The main impact has been in the transportation sector, where prices rose 2.1 percent last month, with 80 percent of the increase in motor fuels. Gasoline jumped 7.7 percent, compared with 9.5 percent in September and 7.6 percent in August.
Prices of new cars rose five-tenths of 1 percent in October, only the second rise in nine months, but used cars continued to fall and now cost 1.4 percent less than they did in December 1989. A 2.7 percent jump in airline fares was mainly responsible for a 1.8 percent rise in the cost of public transportation.
Housing, the most heavily weighted component, rose three-tenths of 1 percent as fuel oil was up sharply and local telephone service climbed. The cost of cable television fell for the second straight month but was still 12.1 percent higher than in October 1989.
 
 Variations in Food
 Food in general rose the same three-tenths of 1 percent as in September, but dairy products and meats, fish and eggs advanced more sharply.
Apparel prices fell two-tenths of 1 percent, a surprise result that was partly attributed to premature discounting in a sagging economy.
Medical care, paced this time by a 1.3 percent advance in hospital costs, rose eight-tenths of 1 percent, bringing medical inflation for the latest 12 months to 9.4 percent.
In a companion report today, the Labor Department said the real average weekly earnings of American workers fell 2.1 percent last month, the biggest decline since 1979.
This figure was derived from a 1.4 percent decline in average hours worked and a seven-tenths of 1 percent rise in the price index that covers urban wage earners and clerical workers.
Other data showed that commodities, about 45 percent of the Consumer Price Index, rose 1 percent last month, mainly because of energy. Services, representing 55 percent of the index, rose three-tenths of 1 percent, down from four-tenths in September and seven-tenths in August.
Before rounding, the index rose 0.60377, a rate that if maintained for 12 months and compounded would produce annual inflation of 7.5 percent. The index now stands at 133.5, meaning that a basket of goods and services that cost $100 in 1982-84, now costs $133.50.

HEADLINE: Trump, $47 Million Short, Gives Investors 50% of His Prize Casino

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Donald J. Trump, whose sudden financial problems this year seemed a symbolic bookend for the free-spending 1980's, agreed yesterday to turn over half ownership of his crown jewel casino to its bondholders. On top of that, the flamboyant financier must take thecasino on a brief detour to bankruptcy court, and could eventually even lose control of it.
Even though Mr. Trump faced severe troubles this spring in his real estate and gambling empire, the latest agreement, reached early yesterday morning, represents the first time he has given up part ownership in one of his properties. 
 For weeks Mr. Trump and holders of the $675 million in high-yield "junk bonds" he sold to complete his Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort in Atlantic City have been locked in tense negotiations as a Thursday-night deadline approached for a $47.3 million interest payment, a payment Mr. Trump was unable to make. The two sides, with Mr. Trump taking the lead role in recent days, carried on marathon talks into yesterday morning before finally reaching a deal that left Mr. Trump in control of the Taj.
 
Prepackaged Bankruptcy

 To make quick changes in the terms of the property's ownership and the debt it carries, Mr. Trump and the main bondholders' group are expected to file what is called a prepackaged bankruptcy petition. Such a filing will allow the two parties to present to a bankruptcy judge a complete plan to work out payments and avoid a long, contentious court battle. It is possible the plan could be approved within months after a bankruptcy petition is filed.
In the spring, Mr. Trump's bankers spent several months chiseling out a rescue package after the developer failed to make a payment on bonds for Trump's Castle. Yesterday's plan to file a prepackaged bankruptcy petition will not have a substantial impact on that rescue package, which provided $65 million in new cash and deferred about $1 billion of interest and principal payments for up to five years.
"I think it's incredible that he went into a situation with an asset where his equity was totally under water and where the bondholders could have left him with nothing" and came out with control, said a Wall Street banker who insisted on anonymity.
Under the settlement, the $47.3 million in interest on the junk bonds that Mr. Trump failed to pay Thursday will be added to the $675 million in the principal he owes on the property. The rate of interest on that debt will be reduced from the original 14 percent to 12 percent, two percentage points of which Mr. Trump can pay in new junk bonds.
 
 Budget Limitations
 The bondholders, whose investments are secured by a first mortgage on the casino, will receive 50 percent of the stock in the Taj and will be given three of the seven seats on its board, leaving Mr. Trump with control. But for Mr. Trump to keep control the Taj must come within 15 percent of a budget approved by the bondholders. If the casino fails to produce enough cash under Mr. Trump's management, he will lose control of the board.
If the Taj performs better than the projected budgets, and Mr. Trump is able to repay his junk bond debt at the original 14 percent interest rate until the bonds mature, the bondholders have agreed to give him back 30 percent of the equity they will receive.
"For him to get back the entire 80 percent we would have to get back all our original money at 14 percent plus we will keep 20 percent of the equity for the inconvenience," said Wilbur Ross, a senior managing director of Rothschild Inc., the firm representing the largest block of Taj bondholders.
As part of the agreement, maturity on the bonds was extended from 1998 to 2000.
 
 Incentives for Performance
 Yesterday's settlement plan, like the rescue package that scores of banks cobbled together in the spring, is intended to provide the developer incentives for good business performance. If Mr. Trump is able to raise the cash the Taj produces by significant margins, he will be rewarded with the bulk of the equity when the bonds mature in 2000.
Yesterday's agreement, which must be hammered out into several thousand pages of legal contracts, was reached with owners of approximately 90 percent of the face value of the bonds. The plan is still subject to approval by a bankruptcy court judge, Mr. Trump's commercial bank lenders and the New Jersey gaming industry regulators, but if those approvals are won, all the bondholders will receive stock in the casino proportional to their bond holdings. Carl C. Icahn, the corporate raider and investor, is believed to be the single largest bondholder.
The bondholders were determined to have a greater say in governing the company that runs the casino, although Mr. Trump will remain chairman. Along with the three board members, the bondholders will put in place a committee to audit the casino, and any transaction that includes sales, mergers or refinancings of the property must be approved by two of the three directors appointed by bondholders.
For his continued management services Mr. Trump will be paid the greater of $500,000 annually or 1.5 percent of the casino's earnings before expenses, taxes, and amortization and minus capital expenditures.
"It was a long, hard negotiation and I think it will be good for everyone," Mr. Trump said at a news conference to announce the settlement.
 
 Birth of the Taj
 The Taj Mahal was initially conceived by Resorts International as a grand replacement for its original casino, a refurbished old hotel that gave Resorts a head start when gambling was legalized a dozen years ago but that had grown increasingly frumpish.
Before the project could be finished, Mr. Trump had taken control of Resorts. When he sold his stake to Merv Griffin, the entertainer who later led Resorts into bankuptcy court, Mr. Trump bought back the unfinished Taj and vowed to make it the "seventh wonder of the world." Its casino is twice the size of any of its Atlantic City rivals.
With its lavish use of marble and crystal, its candy-colored onion domes perched on the rooftops and the cast-concrete elephants standing guard at the entrance, the Taj has become a tourist attraction along the Boardwalk. But the view from the bottom line is less spectacular, as high interest expense and overhead have consumed even the record-setting revenues the casino has drawn in.
 
 Operating Profits
 Since opening in April, the Taj has produced $26.4 million in operating profits and had some interest income, but fell $29.5 million in the red after paying $58.4 million in interest on its bonds and other loans.
Mr. Trump, who has been trying to sell minority interests in several of his assets in recent months in order to raise cash that will reduce his bank debt, still has other assets that cannot meet their interest payments.
On Dec. 15, he will have to make another multimillion-dollar interest payment on the bonds for his Trump's Castle. It is unclear if he will be able to raise the money.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 5.20, to 2,550.25, in Seesaw Session

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
The stock market seesawed in jagged fashion yesterday and finished higher despite a selloff of long-distance telephone issues and weakness in autos. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 5.20 points, at 2,550.25, for a gain of 61.64 points on the week.
Stocks got some good news when oil fell below $30 a barrel for the first time in three weeks, and there was evidence that the Federal Reserve Board had moved to ease short-term interest rates. The bond market pushed sharply higher. 
 There was also some moderately good news from the nation's trade figures and the Consumer Price Index. The trade deficit narrowed by 3.3 percent in September, while consumer prices rose by a moderate six-tenths of 1 percent in October.
 
 Increase in Volume
 Trading volume reached 165.4 million shares, up from 151.4 million a day before. Advancing issues topped declining ones, 766 to 725, while 37 stocks touched new lows and 9 had new highs. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks gained 0.10, to 317.12.
Despite all the news, "today was largely a random session," said Michael Metz, chief market analyst at Oppenheimer & Company. Some traders felt that the Fed had not moved aggressively enough to bring rates down, he said. And there was uncertainty during the session because of the expiration of some futures and options contracts. A weekend also loomed in which President Bush would be out of the country.
Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, said: "Initially the market went up because oil went down and evidently the Fed cut the Federal funds rate by another notch. But the stock of MCI had been taking a beating and other telephone issues declined in sympathy. Some program trading also took the market down."
In late afternoon, though, "the positive news like the lower price of oil and easier monetary policy seemed to be gaining over the pessimistic stories," he added.
 
 Effect of MCI Announcement
 The selloff of long-distance issues "inhibited a lot of speculators and was another example of a single misstep in one stock translated into a disaster," Mr. Metz said.
MCI Communications, which on Thursday said intense competition loomed as a drag on earnings for the next several quarters, plunged 7 3/8, to 22 5/8, as the most active stock in over-the-counter trading.
A.T.&T. led Big Board active stocks, down 1 1/8, to 32. United Telecommunications, operator of U S Sprint, was second most active, falling 2 7/8, to 22 1/2. GTE lost 5/8, to 27 5/8.
In the auto group, Ford Motor dropped 3/8, to 27 7/8. Analysts at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. and at Merrill Lynch lowered 1990 earnings estimates on Ford. General Motors lost 7/8, to 38 3/8, while Chrysler closed unchanged, at 11 1/4.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
On the Left, Voices Amid Confusion

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
For months, the Persian Gulf crisis has invited this surprising question: What if they gave a war and no protest movement came?
While the Pentagon was presiding over the largest American deployment since Vietnam, many of the left-liberal voices known for past condemnations of military interventions spoke in quiet or ambivalent tones. Some even supported the action. 
 That is now changing, as the recent increase in American forces in the Gulf has brought sharp criticisms from intellectuals and organizers camped under the broad tent of left-liberal opinion. But despite the criticisms, many on the left disagree about what the United States should do to counter Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
 
Conservatives Are Louder
 Some of the loudest objections to the deployment have been voiced by conservatives, like the columnist Patrick Buchanan. He and several other conservatives have parted company with their traditional allies by accusing Washington of "war hysteria" and arguing that the United States has no compelling interest in the Persian Gulf.
While the split on the political right has received much notice, less attention has been paid to the evolution of thought on the left.
"I think it's extraordinary that there hasn't been a burst of anti-interventionist activity on the left," said Paul Berman, a contributor to The Village Voice, who characterizes his thoughts as ambivalent. "That in itself is a sign that there's been a great deal of debate and a lot of confusion."
The contours of that debate were outlined in recent interviews with more than a dozen influential professors, journalists and organizers who represent left and liberal thinking. Many said they were initially reluctant to criticize the United States deployment because they shared the Bush Administration's disdain for Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi President. Many found much to admire in the way the Administration summoned United Nations support for its actions.
 
Growing Criticism
 But since Nov. 8, when President Bush announced plans to add more than 150,000 troops to the Middle East force, the vital signs of an embryonic antiwar movement have been on the rise, and not only among left-leaning intellectuals. Many in Congress are demanding consultation with the President on his gulf plans. Protestant churches and Roman Catholic bishops have issued sharp antiwar statements.
On college campuses and in the offices of peace groups, new plans are being made for demonstrations and teach-ins to spread antiwar messages.
"The peace movement took a long time clearing its throat," said the Rev. William Sloane Coffin, the president of SANE/Freeze, a large peace group, who initially refrained from criticizing the deployment. "But now, it's finding its voice, and I think it will be heard."
Within the movement, those interviewed said, people are in broad if not unanimous agreement on several issues. They include support for the economic sanctions against Iraq and alarm at the Administration's decision to increase the number of troops and cancel their rotations home. Many say this puts the United States on a war footing before the sanctions have had time to take effect.
 
Bigger Role for Congress
 In addition, most leftist opponents of the deployment contend that Congress should play a greater role in the decision-making, and many say they distrust the motives of the Bush Administration. The Administration has had difficulty explaining the goals of the deployment, suggesting at different times that it is to protect oil, jobs, or the sanctity of international borders.
But while many on the left say they distrust the Administration, they disagree about what the United States should do.
Some, like Michael Lerner of the Jewish bi-monthly Tikkun, a liberal magazine, say that questions about Iraq should be linked to the resolution of other Middle Eastern disputes, like the Palestinian conflict with Israel. Others, like Irving Howe and Mitchell Cohen, co-editors of Dissent magazine, have argued against any linkage.
Some, like Erwin Knoll of The Progressive, contend that the United States should withdraw its forces immediately, while others, including Daniel Ellsberg and Alexander Cockburn, support participating in a smaller multinational force to defend Saudi Arabia. Still others, including Mr. Lerner, have begun to discuss conditions under which an eventual attack on Iraq would be justified, like preventing it from acquiring nuclear weapons.
Among the factors slowing an antiwar response is the obvious one: there has not yet been a war. It took several years of actual fighting in Vietnam for widespread protests to emerge.
 
Other Considerations
 But other reasons exist, grounded in the specifics of this conflict. One is that Mr. Hussein has inspired none of the admiration that some opponents of previous wars had for the enemy or its leaders, like Ho Chi Minh or the Sandinistas. Secondly, many on the left say they found something to admire in the international character of the Administration's initial response -- seeking United Nations approval and assembling a multinational force that included Arabs.
A third issue is Israel and the danger that it would suffer from a well-armed and belligerent Iraq. Some groups on the left, particularly Jewish organizations, say this adds to their initial support for some American military role in the gulf.
Besides these factors, some say other, long-term trends have come into play.
Charles Peters, the editor of The Washington Monthly and a frequent critic of fellow liberals, argues that some of them reflexively opposed the military after the Vietnam War and then overcompensated by growing reluctant to question it. "They began to fear not looking strong on national security matters," he said.
He faults this strain of center-left liberalism for failing to distinguish between the differences in types of military response. While he supports the embargo and the naval blockade, and believes the United States should defend Saudi Arabia through the threat of air retaliation, Mr. Peters said that bringing in ground troops "invites a blood bath like we had in Vietnam."
"What has appalled me is how few people made the distinction," he said. "Where were the people who were supposed to have learned the lesson of 'No land war in Asia' ?"
 
Who Did and Who Did Not
 Those who immediately opposed the deployment of American troops included The Nation, The Progessive, and Arthur Schlesinger Jr.
But among the prominent figures who declined to oppose the initial deployment were Reverend Coffin, the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, and Todd Gitlin, a University of California sociologist who was a leader of the protests against the Vietnam War.
In an interview this week, Mr. Jackson said the commitment of additional troops "is boxing the nation in" and making war more likely. He added that if war came, he would support a draft, so that the military was not composed disproportionately of poor people and minorities.
 
Confusion at Magazine
 In October, the editors of Dissent magazine, a journal of democratic socialism, gathered to debate the validity of the United States' presence in the Middle East. They came to little agreement, with most of them belonging to what Mr. Howe, a co-editor, called "the party of confusion."
Tikkun has attracted attention with an article arguing that a war against Iraq could be justified to protect Israel and to stop the spread of nuclear weapons. Mr. Lerner, the editor, calls in the article for a conference linking a reduction in Iraqi military power to other Middle East issues, including the creation of a demilitarized Palestinian state.
Mr. Lerner's willingness to support a fight against Iraq as a final resort drew sharp published criticisms from many of the magazine's contributors. He entitled his article, appropriately enough, "My Inner Conflict About Iraq."

HEADLINE: Four Senators Deny Doing Favors For Keating in Exchange for Cash

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Four United States Senators forcefully defended their political integrity today, insisting to their peers on the Senate Ethics Committee that they had done no special favors for Charles H. Keating Jr., a savings and loan executive, in exchange for large campaign donations.
Their speeches reflected the Senators' personalities, legal strategies and the varied accusations against them, but each insisted that he had broken no Federal law or Senate rule. 
 Speaking with emotion from a lectern at the side of the hearing room after being sworn in, the Senators attacked the system that puts them in a constant search for campaign contributions. Yet they argued that they had done nothing sinister for Mr. Keating, and nothing that they would not have done for any constituent.
The fifth Senator being investigated by the committee, Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona, will give his opening statement on Monday.
Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, who was depicted by the ethics panel's special counsel this morning as the lawmaker who most aggressively solicited donations from Mr. Keating, recounted his 22-year Senate career and the "two-year period of much pain" brought on by the Keating investigation.
Offering few specifics about his relationship with Mr. Keating, Mr. Cranston declared, "The notion that I would risk my reputation and the reputation of this body, which I love, by raising money in any improper way is simply preposterous."
 
Painstaking Detail
 By contrast, Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, spelled out in painstaking detail his involvement with Mr. Keating, and was close to tears when he left the lectern.
"There has never been a time, and there will never be a time, when somebody walks in to see me and says, 'Look, I'd like you to do thus and so and I'll do a campaign fund-raiser for you,' " Mr. Riegle said. "Let me tell you, I enjoy doing this work, but if I had to have this job on that basis I'd be in a different line of work."
Mr. Riegle devoted much of his speech to attacking the special counsel, Robert S. Bennett, calling his presentation of the case "inaccurate in many important respects." Mr. Cranston also derided Mr. Bennett, asserting that he had based his case on "some notion of ethics never adopted by this body."
As it became clear that Mr. DeConcini would be the last to testify, he asked that his address be put off until Monday, telling the committee it would be "very detrimental" to testify since two members of the Ethics Committee had to leave before today's proceedings ended.
 The two Senators who Mr. Bennett said had the least involvement with Mr. Keating, John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, were firm, but not as combative as their peers. Instead they praised the special counsel, who characterized Mr. Cranston and Mr. DeConcini as the most deeply involved, while he said Mr. Riegle was more toward the middle.
The Senators' campaigns or causes collected $1.3 million from Mr. Keating or his associates in Lincoln and its parent company, American Continental Corporation. Lincoln was seized by Federal regulators in April 1989 after they concluded that the institution was insolvent and its parent company was draining its reserves. The Government has estimated that the loss to taxpayers will exceed $2 billion. Mr. Keating has been charged with misleading investors and is free on bond.
The Senators met with regulators when they were looking into Lincoln in 1987. The five have said that their action was no different from what they would do for any constituent operating a business aiding their states' economies. Lincoln was in California, the parent company was in Arizona and Mr. Keating had business dealings in Ohio and Michigan.
 
A Chance to Reply
 The Senators have watched their standing in public opinion polls slip during the committee's inquiry of a year. More than one remarked today that he had been waiting that long to tell his side of the story.
The Senators told of meeting with Edwin J. Gray, who was head of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, and other banking regulators. Mr. Keating had complained that the regulators were interfering with the operations of Lincoln, which was seized by the Federal Government in April 1989. The Senators insisted that such a meeting was entirely proper.
Mr. McCain addressed the committee first, with the briefest statement. "Charles Keating was a political friend and supporter from 1981 to 1987," he said. "When he came to see me in March of 1987 and asked me to do sometihng I thought was improper, I said no. When he asked me to get Ed Gray off his back, I said no. When he asked me to negotiate for him, I said no. The only thing I said I could do was to inquire whether American Continental Corporation and Lincoln Savings were being treated fairly."
Mr. McCain was followed by his lawyer, John M. Dowd, who chronicled in detail what he said was his client's story, and accused the Senator's Arizona colleague, Mr. DeConcini, of trying to involve him further.
At one point, he said that a letter among the exhibits from Mr. DeConcini to Mr. Riegle asking that the Senator attend a meeting with regulators on behalf of Mr. DeConcini and Mr. McCain "is a phony."
 
'Thank God for That'
 Mr. Dowd read another letter that Brad Boland, a son-in-law of Mr. Keating, wrote to Mr. DeConcini last year, thanking him for his "unselfish efforts" in helping Mr. Keating and attacking Mr. McCain as "probably the biggest disappointment in my life."
"Thank God for that," Mr. Dowd said of the letter, calling it "the most powerful piece of evidence."
Next to testify was Mr. Glenn. Appealing to panel members who "have known me as a colleague for nearly 16 years," he said firmly: "John Glenn does not peddle influence. Period."
Mr. Glenn also disputed allegations that he did something wrong just because he joined other Senators at two meetings with Federal regulators who were overseeing Lincoln.
"I believe that a crucial part of my job as a U.S. Senator is to insure that Federal regulators and bureaucrats are treating people fairly and carrying out their regulatory activities responsibly," he said. "I submit that every Senator on this panel has office files full of cases where regulatory mistakes have been made and injustices against individuals and businesses have occurred."
The most dramatic moment came this afternoon when Mr. Cranston, who had not been at the hearings before, took his seat at a table in the hearing room and strode to the lectern to defend himself. The Senator, who has said he would not attend the hearings after today because he will be undergoing radiation therapy for prostate cancer, spoke stridently about the "shattering" experience of being accused of wrongdoing.
 "Cynics and idealists believe that we are all corrupted by the money we have to raise," Mr. Cranston said. "It's easy to make an allegation of unethical conduct; it's hard to defend against such an allegation."
In an effort to remind members of the ethics panel that they each have designated fund-raisers on their staffs, Mr. Cranston's aides set up easels with large charts listing each Senator and their fund-raising aides.
"If someone thinks politics is a dirty, ugly, corrupt business," said Mr. Cranston, who last week announced that he would not seek re-election in 1992, "he will find evidence of it -- even if he has to distort the truth to find it."
Mr. Riegle then took to the lectern, mocking Mr. Bennett for using a jigsaw puzzle in his presentation to illustrate that his case was built on many disparate facts. The Senator, chairman of the Banking Committee, held up a jigsaw puzzle of his own, and emptied pieces of it out of the box.
"It may very well be that you are never going to get this puzzle put together properly, with the pieces you have," he said. "And you may have to make a leap of faith, and you may have to make a judgment as to what you think that puzzle finally looks like."
Responding to Mr. Bennett's contention that Mr. Riegle had forgotten many key events, he conceded: "I readily confess it. I have a lousy memory."
Echoing comments by Senators McCain and Glenn, Mr. Riegle said he had no contacts with Mr. Keating after meeting with bank regulators in April 1987.
Before the Senators presented their defenses, Mr. Bennett this morning described how there were more connections between Mr. Cranston's contributions and actions than with the other Senators. He recounted four occasions when Mr. Cranston solicited or accepted several hundred thousand dollars from Mr. Keating.
