HEADLINE: Excerpts From Ethics Committee's Session on Five Senators

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a transcript of today's session of the Senate Ethics Committee's hearings into the conduct of five Senators in the Lincoln Savings and Loan affair. The Federal News Service, a transcription company, recorded the session.
ROBERT S. BENNETT, special counsel to the committee: This is the final portion of the evidentiary presentation, and it deals with Senator Cranston. The evidence will show that on approximately four separate occasions Senator Cranston accepted or solicited several hundred thousand dollars from Mr. Keating for Senator Cranston's voter registration groups and that each of these four occasions was linked by time and circumstance to a request by Mr. Keating for assistance with the bank board. . . . 
 Mr. Keating, the evidence will show, or members of his family or individuals employed by him, gave about $49,000 to the Senator's -- Cranston's -- campaigns. . . . It appears that all of these contributions were duly reported to the Federal Election Commission. Lincoln also made, in addition to those contributions, a $300,000 line of credit available to Senator Cranston's campaign under unusual circumstances. . . .
Most significantly, Mr. Keating's companies contributed a total of $850,000 to groups closely affiliated with the Senator. These contributions were not required by law to be publicly disclosed, and Mr. Keating had asked that he be listed as an anonymous contributor. These groups were U.S.A. Votes, the Center for Participation in Democracy and the Forum Institute. They were funded, and what they did is they funded or conducted voter registration drives. The Senator's son, Kim Cranston, was a full-time unsalaried officer and director of two groups that benefited directly and indirectly from these contributions. . . .
The Senator potentially benefited from the increased registration of Democratic voters in California. Secondly, father and son benefited from knowing that organizations to which Kim Cranston gave his time and reputation had a solid financial foundation. And third, two of the organizations had hired the Senator's campaign finance director, Joy Jacobson, after his campaign was over. . . .
 
Contact by Keating Aide
Let's talk a little bit about Senator Cranston's initial contacts with Charles Keating. In 1984, Lincoln's Jim Grogan, who was, as I earlier stated, the principal contact of Mr. Keating here on the Hill, approached the Senator's finance director, Joy Jacobson, at the Democratic convention in July of 1984. He offered to support Senator Cranston. That comes from the Jacobson deposition, which is -- will be -- in evidence. Most of the $49,000 Mr. Keating raised for Senator Cranston's campaigns was raised in 1984 and 1985.
On Dec. 17, 1984, it appears that Senator Cranston met with Mr. Keating and Alan Greenspan. Mr. Greenspan, who has submitted an affidavit to us, is now chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, but at the time he was an independent economic consultant. And at that meeting Mr. Greenspan discussed his views of the direct-investment rule. Joy Jacobson, the Senator's campaign finance director, attended this meeting. As both Miss Jacobson and Senator Cranston agree, she had no substantive duties or expertise on banking matters. Nonetheless she was there with Mr. Keating and Mr. Greenspan because, in the words of Senator Cranston, and I quote, she would be more effective in fund raising, closed quote. And that appears at page 25 of Senator Cranston's deposition.
Let's talk a little bit about the loan that I referred to. The next significant event in Senator Cranston's relationship with Mr. Keating occurred in the fall of 1986, as his -- as you know, he was in, by his admission, a hotly contested Senate campaign, which was drawing to a close. His campaign officials were concerned that the campaign might not have sufficient funds to pay for last-minute media buys. So Miss Jacobson, the fund raiser, solicited a line of credit from Jim Grogan at Lincoln, and you can look at pages 87 to 93 of the Jacobson deposition, which will be in evidence.
The $300,000 loan was personally guaranteed by the Senator and his wife, and it was arranged on an expedited basis. Let me explain how that was done. A former Lincoln employee by the name of Gloria Cardu, who has provided an affidavit which will be in evidence, stated that she flew from Phoenix, Ariz., to Los Angeles, where she met Senator and Mrs. Cranston and a lawyer in a limousine on the tarmac of the airport. They reviewed and executed the documents as the car drove to downtown Los Angeles. When they got to downtown, Miss Cardu was let out. She returned to the airport with the documents. . . . As it turned out, the Cranston committee did not need to draw on the line of credit, and the loan was canceled without ever being used.
 
 Solicitations by Cranston
Let's talk now a little bit about the links between money and action. Mr. Keating has been roundly criticized in this proceeding, but I do think in fairness to him it should be pointed out that it wasn't Mr. Keating who was always seeking things. It is very clear from the evidence, which I will detail for you, that Senator Cranston solicited contributions and sought contributions from Mr. Keating.
The first occasion was in early 1987, when Mr. Keating asked Senator Cranston to help bring an end to the Lincoln exam.
On Jan. 2, 1987, a fund raiser, Joy Jacobson, wrote a memorandum to Senator Cranston to prepare him for an upcoming meeting with Mr. Keating and Mr. Grogan, and this is Special Counsel Exhibit 154. And let me just read relevant portions to you. The entire exhibit will be moved into evidence.
It's "to Alan from Joy." It's dated Jan. 2, 1987, a few months before the April meeting, and it reads as follows: "Cases/legislation: Now that we are back in the majority, there are a number of individuals who have been very helpful to you who have cases or legislative matters pending within our office who will rightfully expect some kind of resolution. Following is a short list of ones you should be aware of."
Miss Jacobson then just lists several individuals, and the last one is Charles Keating. She says: "Charlie Keating is continuing to have problems with the bank board and Ed Gray. Jim Grogan and the company's legal counsel, Bob Kielty, are coming in to see you on Friday at 1 o'clock to get your advice on how to handle the current problem. In addition, Senator Glenn is arranging a dinner in the Capitol the night of the State of the Union for you, Senator DeConcini, Senator Proxmire, Charles Keating and himself. Jim will bring you up to date on where this stands."
As far as we can determine, no such dinner meeting took place.
Three weeks later, on Jan. 28, 1987, according to Senator Cranston's calendar, it indicates that he met with Mr. Keating and Mr. Grogan. The evidence indicates that at this meeting Mr. Keating asked the Senator what could be done to help in ending the Lincoln exam.
A few weeks later, on Feb. 24, 1987, Senator Cranston informed officials of one of the voter-registration groups that they would be getting a $100,000 contribution from Mr. Keating. . . .
On March 3, 1987, Lincoln issued a check for $100,000 to America Votes. This was later named -- renamed -- U.S.A. Votes. . . . A month after this contribution, Senator Cranston attended the meeting with Chairman Gray.
 
 Calls to Board's Chairman
The second occasion when money was, from the evidence, linked to action was in September of '87. This was after Senator Cranston had been told that a criminal referral was being made about Lincoln. By this time, Ed Gray's chairmanship of the bank board had ended, and a new chairman, M. Danny Wall, was in place. By this time, Senator Cranston already had called Chairman Wall on at least one occasion.
On Sept. 24, 1987, Senator Cranston met with Charles Keating. Senator Cranston's fund raiser, Joy Jacobson, wrote another memorandum to prepare Senator Cranston for the meeting. . . . It says, "To Alan, from Joy." Date: Sept. 6, '87. And the pertinent part reads as follows: "Sept. 24, Charles Keating, Whip Office, 3 P.M. I was originally trying to reschedule a trip to Arizona on Sept. 18, but Keating was not going to be in Arizona on that date, so instead he is coming to Washington on the 24th. I've attached an article from The Wall Street Journal which talks about the views of the new F.H.L.B. chairman, Danny Wall, views that obviously are good news to Keating. You should ask Keating for $250,000."
When we deposed Miss Jacobson, we asked her why she chose the figure $250,000, and she testified . . . that she picked the figure $250,000 because Senator Cranston had wanted to ask for $500,000 and she didn't think -- she thought that was too much.
There is evidence, a followup letter from Senator Cranston to Mr. Keating, that confirms that at the Sept. 24 meeting, the two men did discuss Chairman Wall and Mr. Keating did agree to give $250,000. . . . And I don't want to take time to read it all, but I will make reference to: "I'm very grateful for your willingness to contribute $250,000. I've asked Joy to discuss with Jim Grogan the states in which you would most like to help." And in the first portion of the letter: "I also, of course, deeply appreciate your willingness to support our U.S.A. Votes program." And the first paragraph says, "It was a pleasure to see you and your lovely bride while you were in Washington last week and to hear that your meeting with Danny Wall had gone so well."
Six days after receiving the checks, on Nov. 12, 1987, Senator Cranston telephoned Chairman Wall. We've obtained Senator Cranston's notes, and the notes of this conversation indicate that he discussed the San Francisco regulators and told Wall that, quote, He shouldn't let personality factors cause difficulties for our constituents, close quote.
Third occasion: . . . On Jan. 8, 1988, Senator Cranston and his son, Kim, dined with Charles Keating and others in Los Angeles. At that dinner, according to Senator Cranston, Mr. Keating went into a tirade about the regulators -- that's the Cranston deposition, from Senator Cranston's deposition, page 191. The evidence shows that Mr. Keating asked Senator Cranston to make two telephone calls on behalf of Lincoln -- one to Chairman Wall and the other to a former bank official named Donald Havdie. And let me explain the evidence that supports this.
Following the dinner, Jim Grogan called Joy Jacobson and told her about it. . . . Based on this conversation, Ms. Jacobson wrote Senator Cranston a memorandum. . . . And this is what she says, and it's a little difficult to read, but: "I was pleased to hear that your dinner went so well with Charlie Keating. He has asked that you call Danny Wall and request that Wall meet with him next week. The reason for this meeting is that in September, when Charlie met with Wall, Wall said the investigation of Lincoln Savings would be concluded in two weeks. Charlie wants to know directly from Wall why the investigation is still" -- and there's a word I can't -- "still going on months later. Also, you apparently requested the phone number of former F.H.L.B. board member Don Havdie to discuss with him a conversation he had with an employee of the San Francisco F.H.L.B. office re the Lincoln Savings investigation. . . ."
The evidence further shows that -- and Senator Cranston has testified that -- at this dinner on Jan. 8, 1988, Mr. Keating offered to make another contribution to the voter registration groups. . . . So, the Senator said, on Jan. 20, 1988, within a few days of receiving Ms. Jacobson's memo reminding him about the telephone calls Mr. Keating had asked him to make, Senator Cranston made the calls. . . . Chairman Wall told Senator Cranston he would meet with Mr. Keating. . . . He did so on Jan. 28, 1988.
On Feb. 10, 1988, just 12 days after Chairman Wall met with Mr. Keating, as Senator Cranston had requested, the Senator and his son, Kim, went to A.C.C. [the American Continental Corporation, Mr. Keating's company] headquarters in Phoenix. Senator Cranston stayed at Mr. Keating's home, and that comes from Senator Cranston's deposition at page 228.
While there, they personally collected A.C.C. -- at A.C.C., at the offices of A.C.C. -- checks totaling $500,000 for two voter registration groups. This included a $400,000 check . . . for the Center for Participation in Democracy. And there's another check, in the amount of $100,000, to the Forum Institute. Six days after collecting these $500,000 in checks, Senator Cranston again called Chairman Wall about Lincoln, and this is from Senator Cranston's deposition at page 230.
The fourth occasion was early 1989, and there's evidence that on one other occasion Senator Cranston or his aide -- and we're not sure which -- solicited a $100,000 contribution from Mr. Keating at a time when Lincoln was seeking his assistance. In February of 1989, the bank board had issued a new and a very negative examination report on Lincoln, and Mr. Keating was eager to sell Lincoln before it was taken over. And the bank board had to approve any sale.
Senator Cranston and his banking aide, Carolyn Jordan, attended a meeting with Jim Grogan on Feb. 7, 1989, to discuss the sale. In February and April of '89, Senator Cranston personally contacted Chairman Wall on four occasions regarding the bank board's approval of the sale. He also called several other regulators, as did his aide, Ms. Jordan.
 
 Actions Proper, McCain Says
SENATOR HOWELL HEFLIN, committee chairman: The issue of which Senator would go first, which last, and the order that they would make their presentations . . . was determined . . . by a drawing of positions. This was felt to be a fair approach. . . . So we will now proceed to hear from Senator McCain. . . .
SENATOR JOHN McCAIN: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Once again, I'm glad to have the opportunity to fully and publicly account for my relationship with Charles Keating and my conduct in connection with April 1987 meetings with Chairman Ed Gray and regulators at the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
Mr. Chairman and members of the committee, Charlie Keating was a political friend and supporter from 1981 to 1987. When he came to see me in March of 1987 and asked me to do something I thought was improper, I said no. When he asked me to get Ed Gray off his back, I said no. When he asked me to negotiate for him, I said no. The only thing I said I could do was to inquire whether American Continental Corporation and Lincoln Savings were being treated fairly.
On April 2, I attended a meeting in Senator DeConcini's office with Chairman Ed Gray to ask those questions about whether Lincoln was being treated fairly.
I asked Mr. Gray if it was proper to meet and ask questions. He said it was proper. Chairman Gray said he didn't know the facts of the Lincoln investigation, and he suggested that we meet the following week with the bank board regulators from San Francisco, who could answer my questions. I again asked if that would be proper. Mr. Gray said it would be proper.
On April 9, I joined other Senators in Senator DeConcini's office to meet with these San Francisco regulators, as Mr. Gray had suggested. There's a transcript of that meeting, which has been referred to several times already during this hearing. I'd like to excerpt again what I said at the beginning of that meeting, and I quote -- and remember this is from Mr. Black, who was one of the members of the meeting, and this transcript was taken unbeknownst to me, at least. Quote: "One of our jobs as elected officials is to help constituents in a proper fashion. American Continental is a big employer and important to the local economy. I would not want any special favors for them." And I went on to say, I do not want any part of our conversation to be improper.
I was able at this April 9 meeting to make my inquiries. I learned at this meeting that Lincoln's complaints of bad treatment from the regulators were unfounded and that there would be a criminal referral to the Justice Department against Lincoln. That, Mr. Chairman, was the end of any involvement I had with American Continental or Lincoln Savings.
From then on, I had no further dealings at all with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. I had no further contact on this issue with other government officials. I had no contact with Danny Wall or others to support the sale of Lincoln Savings in 1989. I had no further contact with Mr. Keating or any American Continental representatives. I neither solicited nor accepted any campaign contributions from Mr. Keating or American Continental employees. My relationship with Mr. Keating was ended, over, and there's nothing more. . . . I know I acted ethically and properly and in compliance with all applicable standards of conduct, including my own. . . .
 
Glenn's Account of Meetings
SENATOR JOHN GLENN: As for my own conduct, the facts are very clear, and were fairly and accurately laid out for you yesterday by the special counsel.
On April 2 of 1987, I attended a meeting with three other Senators on behalf of Lincoln Savings, a financial institution headed by a former Ohioan, and whose parent company was an Ohio-chartered corporation.
A former employee of mine, Jim Grogan, had told my staff that Lincoln was being harassed, was receiving unfair treatment by Federal banking regulators. But my staff knew that before I would agree to go to such a meeting, I would have to be persuaded that Lincoln's complaints had merit.
They knew that because it was and is my normal office procedure, and they knew these procedures would have to be adhered to, even though they knew and trusted Jim Grogan.
As a result, I received detailed assurances from the senior partner at one of the nation's largest independent accounting firms that the still-ongoing audit of Lincoln was longer and more intrusive than he had ever seen.
In addition, I was given a copy of a 1985 letter written by Alan Greenspan, one of America's most respected economists, vouching for Lincoln's financial stability.
With this evidence in hand, I decided to attend the April 2 meeting with bank board Chairman Ed Gray. I did not talk with any other Senators before the meeting, discuss any aspect of it afterwards. And at the meeting itself, no one spoke for me. I spoke for myself, and only for myself. In fact, I went to the meeting with only one purpose, and that was to ask why the audit of Lincoln had gone on so long and to urge that the bank board reach some kind of a decision: either bring charges against Lincoln if they're warranted, or close the audit if they were not.
But Chairman Gray could not answer my questions -- in fact, claimed to know very little about the Lincoln situation. So Chairman Gray himself proposed that a second meeting be held with some of his supervisory staff on April 9, and I agreed to go to that meeting as well. As the transcript of that second meeting attests, I asked the very same questions I asked at the first meeting, but this time I got some answers. What I learned was that the Government had a very, very different view of Lincoln from the one I had received from Lincoln, the Arthur Young accounting firm and Dr. Greenspan.
Specifically, the regulators told me that Lincoln had very serious problems and there would be a criminal referral to the Justice Department. Well, that was all I needed to hear. Having received the explanation I sought, I closed my file. I told my staff I could not disclose what happened at the meeting. I instructed them to tell any of Lincoln's representatives who asked that we could say nothing about the meeting. And I had absolutely no contacts whatsoever with the bank board about Lincoln's problems thereafter.
 
 Cranston, Point by Point
SENATOR ALAN CRANSTON: With all my heart and soul, I want to make very clear certain facts that the evidence presented to you subsequently will substantiate.
One, I engaged in no unethical conduct.
Two, You know that I broke no law.
Three, You know that I broke no Senate rule.
Four, You know that I pocketed no money, that there was no personal gain for me or any member of my family. Most of the money now in question was in the form of charitable deductible contributions for nonpartisan registration drives in California and in approximately 20 other states, all conducted by organizations I did not control, all of this after I was re-elected in 1986.
Five, I never recommended, much less demanded, that any government official do anything improper or grant any constituent any special favor. There is absolutely no evidence to the contrary.
Six, I did nothing that affected or delayed any government action in any way. There is absolutely no evidence to the contrary.
Seven, At the two now-famous 1987 meetings of Senators and regulators: on April 2 I asked only why an audit was going on endlessly, and on April 9 I attended for only a few seconds and said nothing of consequence. There is absolutely no evidence to the contrary.
Eight, I had good reason to believe that a business which employed almost 1,000 of my constituents, in my state of California, and thus benefited their families and the communities where they live, was being dealt with improperly by a huge bureaucracy which couldn't make a decision and had a reputation for incompetence. There is abundant supporting evidence. . . .
Nine, When I first received complaints regarding the way bureaucrats were mishandling this business, and for a long, long time thereafter, there was abundant substantiating evidence that this business was solvent, sound and well managed. Among those who gave me confidence in the business in one way or another were Alan Greenspan, now chairman of the Federal Reserve Board; two of the nation's leading accounting firms, Arthur Young and Arthur Andersen; The Arizona Gazette; The Los Angeles Times, and Thrift News.
 
 Remarks by Riegle
SENATOR DONALD W. RIEGLE JR.: I'm not interested, frankly, in Mr. Bennett's notion of what the picture looks like. I'm interested in your notion as to what the picture looks like. I think his job is to give you all the pieces and not thin them down, . . . not tailor them so that they fit a picture, and that's hard to do.
Let me go straight to the bottom line on my conduct. . . .
First, the record of facts here show that at no time did I ever ask any regulator to take any action or not take any action with respect to the regulatory oversight of Lincoln. No one contests that.
Second, the facts also show that any actions taken by the regulators, or not taken by the regulators, regarding the regulatory treatment of Lincoln was not caused or influenced by me in any way whatsoever. And the regulators themselves have confirmed that with sworn testimony.
Third, this: The record will also show that I had no part whatsoever in keeping Lincoln open a single day. The regulators will testify to that fact, as they have testified before, and they're going to testify to it right here in this room.
Now, the false charge which has helped make this story a lot bigger than it really is -- that senators kept Lincoln open two and a half years at great cost to the taxpayers, that everybody in this country has heard probably a million times -- that's just not true. Never been true. Not a shred of truth to that, but it gets printed and reprinted.

HEADLINE: Budget Gap Grows Larger In New Jersey

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Less than five months after pushing through the largest tax increase in New Jersey's history, the Florio administration announced today that the state now faces a budget shortfall of more than $600 million, and that it expects the situation to grow even worse.
The State Treasurer, Douglas C. Berman, said the state was ordering an immediate hiring freeze and a freeze on major building projects while it developed plans for probable layoffs nd the possible dismantling of some government departments. 
 Mr. Berman said that a new tally of the state's receipts showed sales tax revenues down 10 percent from their expected levels in July, August and September, the first three months of the fiscal year. At the same time, he said, the state's spending on Medicaid, fuel and other items has gone up.
 
'Serious, but Manageable'
 "Clearly, something drastic happened since the summer," Mr. Berman said in a State House briefing for the press. "The situation is serious, but manageable."
The news, coming so soon after the passage of $2.8 billion in new taxes, including $1.4 billion in unpopular sales tax increases to balance the budget, brought demands from a top Republican legislator for Mr. Berman's resignation. Other Republicans said that the figures proved that the Democrats had chosen the worst possible time to begin an ambitious program of liberal social engineering and tax increases.
In addition, the new revenue estimates catch the Florio administration in a difficult political crosswind: It must now try to find hundreds of millions of dollars in savings to close the budget gaps while the public as well as Democratic and Republican legislators are crying out for tax cuts.
"The budget is just four and a half months old, and it is in a shambles," said Assemblyman Garabed Haytaian, the Republican minority leader, who has called on Mr. Berman to cut both taxes and state spending. "I want him to be fired because he is inept and inexperienced."
New Jersey's latest budget troubles come as governments around the region struggle to contend with plummeting tax revenues. In New York, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is considering furloughing state workers to close a nearly $900 million gap, and the Governor-elect of Connecticut, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., faces a gap in next year's state budget of nearly a third of this year's $7.1 billion budget.
 
Further Erosion?
 Mr. Berman said that in the first three months of the fiscal year, sales tax revenues were down $450 million dollars, taxes on financial institutions were down $30 million, taxes on the sale of real estate were down $10 million and taxes on motor fuels were down $10 million dollars, compared with the revenue projections on which the current budget were based.
In addition, Mr. Berman said, the state had discovered it would be required to spend $80 million more than expected for increases in the costs of Medicaid and to cover new costs shifted to the state by the Federal budget deficit reduction plan.
Mr. Berman's estimate of a $600 million shortfall for the 1991 fiscal year, which ends next June 30, does not take into account income and corporate tax revenues. It is too early to calculate those receipts, he said, but if they fall off as well, the gap will be even larger.
"If the projections that we now have, which is a national recession with a clear impact on New Jersey, continue to hold, we can expect further erosion of the revenues," he said. "There will be less government services; there will be smaller state government."
Mr. Berman said the state would be able to save $295 million by freezing major building projects and save an additional $50 million by reducing travel, consulting fees and equipment purchases.
 
Won't Raise Taxes
 Nonetheless, the Treasurer said, the state will still have to find $255 million in savings from still undetermined "personnel actions," which may include furloughs and layoffs. Considering the size of the shortfall, the state may have to dismiss thousands of workers.
Although earlier this week Gov. Jim Florio announced plans to cut agencies' budgets by up to 8 percent, and possibly eliminate some departments, it was unclear today if closing the budget gap would require deeper cuts.
Mr. Berman said the state would not raise taxes. Under the State Constitution the budget of more than $12 billion must be balanced when this fiscal year ends on June 30.
Last March, Mr. Florio proposed a series of controversial taxes to fill a $600 million budget gap that he blamed on his Republican predecessor, Thomas H. Kean. By passing his tax package, including a rise of the sales tax from 6 to 7 percent, Mr. Florio said, the state would protect itself against unexpected fiscal crises in the future.
But after electoral setbacks for Democrats on Nov. 6 that were widely seen as an expression of anger at Mr. Florio's taxes, the Governor promised to rescind a tax on heavy trucks and consider rescinding other parts of the tax package. Some Democrats are expected to press for major revisions of the program when the Legislature meets next week, including an end to a new sales tax on paper products.
"Wow," said Senator Richard J. Codey, a Democrat from West Orange, when told of the new budget figures.
"It's a hard message," he said, "because you raised taxes and now the public says, "Where is all the money going?' "

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER, 17, 1990

 BODY:

The Economy
Consumer prices climbed 0.6 percent in October, less than in the preceding two months, the Labor Department said. About half of the increase stemmed from higher oil prices. Apparently persuaded that the risks of a serious slump now outweigh those of inflation, the Fed acted to cut a key short-term interest rate. [Page 1.] Fed policy makers agreed in early October to ease interest rates if a budget-cutting agreement was reached, and to allow further easing if economic conditions warranted. [32.]
 The trade deficit narrowed slightly in September, the Commerce Department said. The U.S. bill for oil rose to the highest level in nine years, but imports of other products fell. [31.]
 Four Senators forcefully defended their political integrity, insisting to their peers on the Senate Ethics Committee that they had done no special favors for Charles Keating. [1.]
 About $780.7 million in unclaimed money was collected by state governments last year. The total could reach $1 billion in 1990. [29.]
 
Companies
 Donald Trump agreed to turn over half ownership of his crown-jewel casino to bondholders. On top of that, the flamboyant financier must make a brief detour to bankruptcy court, and could eventually lose control of the Taj Mahal. [1.] For the first time, Trump is being forced to hand over a share of his real estate empire to creditors. It could happen again next month. News analysis. [33.]
 Chase Manhattan said it expected increased losses on consumer and business loans in coming months, assuming that the economy continues to weaken. [31.]
 Mexico reported three formal bids to buy control of Telmex, the national telephone company. The bids by two multinational consortiums and one Mexican group set the stage for what may be the largest sale ever of a government-held enterprise. [31.]
 The Manville trust to compensate victims of asbestos poisoning is close to approving a proposal to give its senior executives a lucrative severance package, trust officials said. [31.]
 Fred Allegretti doesn't like the price fluctuations he sees on his computer screen, and his customers don't like what they see on their bills. He heads a large heating oil delivery company. [31.]
 Chrysler canceled plans to produce a "mini-Jeep" for lack of a joint-venture partner. [33.]
 A top Daily News spokesman sallied out for the company's first head-to-head, out-in-the-open debate with some of the strikers. [26.]
 U.P.I.'s union employees accepted a 35 percent pay cut for 90 days while its owners seek a buyer. [26.]
 
 Markets
A barrel of oil cost less than $30 for the first time in more than three weeks. Traders reacted to conciliatory talk from Saddam Hussein and to the beginning of President Bush's trip abroad. [31.]
 Signs that the Fed had begun to cut interest rates lifted the credit markets. Prices of long-term bonds rose sharply. [34.]
 The stock market seesawed, then ended higher, despite a selloff of long-distance telephone issues. The Dow Jones industrials closed up 5.20 points, to 2,550.25, a gain of 61.64 points this week. [34.]
 The dollar declined broadly and settled at a new low against the German mark as lower interest rates drove investors away. [40.]
 Soybean prices were lifted by aggressive commercial and professional buying. Grain, meat and livestock futures climbed. [40.]
 
 Today's Columns
 The election defeat of Rep. Robert W. Kastenmeier was significant for inventors. The crusty Wisconsin Democrat spent 21 years as head of the subcommittee that oversees patents, trademarks and copyrights. Patents. [32.]
 A Stradivarius will be auctioned on Wednesday, with the proceeds going to the donor and the UJA-Federation, in an example of the benefits of a charitable remainder trust. Your Money. [32.]

HEADLINE: Coping;
With the Sudden Loss of a Job

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
In scenes that are becoming increasingly common among companies hard hit by the sagging economy, employees are being called in, usually by an immediate superior, and being told they have lost their jobs.
Typically, that superior has been told not to show emotion or to get into an argument, but to explain how and where the employee can find out about benefits and services that are available. 
 This is where the process of out placement begins, an increasingly common company practice of helping former employees find new jobs. In fact, "Do I get outplacement help?" should be one of the first questions they ask when they are told they are dismissed.
 The first thing dismissed employees should think about is financial arrangements.
Continuation of the employee's benefits, like medical and hospital insurance (often six months), severance pay (often two weeks for each year of service) assume added importance today, as does unemployment compensation, which varies from state to state: finding a job takes longer in a recession.
Some experts say that for dismissed executives who were earning $75,000 a year or more, a year can pass before they find a similar job.
Outplacement, which originally provided help for high-level managers on an individual basis, has in recent years been offered to less senior employees.
Now, because there have been so many dismissals, a counselor may meet with them in group sessions.
The company pays the tab, which is often based on the employee's yearly salary. This is the sort of help that outplacement can provide:
*Individual counseling sessions, sometimes with a psychologist.
*Seminars at which job-searching skills can be relearned, like how to write a resume and how to act during an interview.
*For the dismissed employee, the right to use the outplacement firm's clerical services, telephones and office space while the job search goes on.
*Pointers on where to look, including newspaper ads, corporate directories, job advertising in professional publications and openings listed by college placement offices.
The more resumes sent, the more interviews won; the more research done, the better the chances.
James Challenger of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, a Chicago firm that deals in outplacement, said managerial jobs can be found in three and a half months if job-hunters take an aggressive approach.
"The individual who goes on 25 interviews has a much better chance of being re-employed than the person who goes on only 10," Mr. Challenger said.
Unlike an employment agency, an outplacement firm will not find the dismissed employee a new job. In this, the advice from Dale Winston, the president of Battalia & Associates, a management recruiting organization in New York, is simple: "Network, network, network" -- calling friends and acquaintances, including fellow members of clubs and professional societies, to ask for advice and job referrals.
Many middle managers who have lost a job now think of turning to management recruiters hired by a company when it has a specific opening to fill. Such recruiters once showed little interest in dismissed managers because the companies with the openings tended to view jobless candidates with disfavor.
Mrs. Winston said that attitude had changed in recent years because of the numerous mergers, personnel cuts and bankruptcies that have thrown so many out of work.
So recruiters now accept resumes a little more kindly than they once did, even though they have been recently deluged with them. Many recruiters say the resumes that appeal to them go into their computers for future references when suitable jobs are available.
There are reference books like the Directory of Executive Recruiters, published by Kennedy & Kennedy in Fitzwilliam, N.H. These can be found in large public libraries as well as at outplacement firms.
Some executives make contact with management recruiters early in their careers. Building such relationships can help at the time of a job loss, at least with advice about where jobs are. Finally, optimism is important for any job-seeker, as difficult as that may be to summon up.
The Hudson Institute, the prominent research center in Indianapolis, recently predicted that businesses would face supervisory and managerial shortages just as soon as the economy regains its old momentum.

HEADLINE: Review/Dance;
'Nutcracker' And Joffrey: Both Fine

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
The Joffrey Ballet made an exuberant return to New York on Thursday with the opening performance of "The Nutcracker," which runs through Dec. 2 at City Center Theater. The company, which survived an administrative and financial crisis in the spring that threatened to destroy it, is in top shape. And so its presentation of the holiday classic, in a production conceived and directed by Robert Joffrey with some new choreography by Gerald Arpino, is an even happier occasion this year.
This "Nutcracker," staged by George Verdak and Scott Barnard, is a fairly traditional one inspired by the 1940 version of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo in which Mr. Verdak danced -- itself influenced by the original Maryinsky production. The Joffrey's staging is quite different in sensibility from the standard-setting version by George Balanchine for the New York City Ballet. There were a few too many spritzes of glitter on Thursday night at City Center, and the giant Mother Ginger doll looks like a refugee from Care Bear Land, though the production, designed by Oliver Smith and John David Ridge, is otherwise so pretty and cozy it might have been created by Currier & Ives. 
 And it drew its oohs and aahs from the audience, with some tumultuous cheering for the dancers. On the crowded, swirling City Center stage, the Joffrey's Sugar Plum Fairy doesn't stand out much as a character or even as the icon that it ordinarily is. But Tina LeBlanc's ravishing dancing, so focused, precise and filled with liquid phrasing and so technically strong and daring, made the Grand Pas de Deux one of the highlights of the evening. Part of its impact was also attributable to the partnering of Tom Mossbrucker, one of those rock-steady and sensitive partners that ballerinas must dream of. Mr. Mossbrucker's own variation was danced with pleasing clarity and the kind of modesty that, though it is sometimes counterproductive, makes the Joffrey such an endearing company.
 Another of the evening's highlights was the performance of Carl Corry in the role of Fritz, the little brother of Clara Stahlbaum, whose receipt of a Christmas nutcracker sets the ballet in motion. Replacing Edward Stierle, who was indisposed, Mr. Corry was sweetly bashful and believably boyish in a role that must be difficult to pull off on that stage full of real children. But there was nothing ingenuous about his pyrotechnics as the Snow Prince, in a show-stopping performance.
The classical elegance of Douglas Martin made him stand out in the same scene, in the Land of Snow, partnering a radiant Deborah Dawn as the Snow King and Queen. The scene's central dance for Snowflake ballerinas and male Snow Winds, interspersed with ranks of little Snow Trees who look like ambulant pine cones, is a glorious confection in which Mr. Arpino sends the dancers flying through a winter storm and gives all a typical extra, beveling edge.
There was also a standout performance from Glen Harris as Dr. Drosselmeyer, the godfather of Clara and Fritz. Mr. Harris's elegant Drosselmeyer was much younger and more dashing than the usual interpretation, with a glint of irony that made the character mysterious in a more contemporary way. One of the evening's poetic moments occurred when Mr. Harris, suddenly visible behind the glitter-eyed owl that crowns the clock in the Stahlbaums' Victorian parlor, circles his head slowly in the dim light like a creature in brief contact with another, more familiar world.
In the second-act divertissements, Beatriz Rodriguez looked, enticingly, as if she knew a secret or two as Chocolate from Spain, and Mr. Martin and Julie Janus made a sensuous, expertly intertwining pair in the Coffee from Arabia duet. Tea from China was danced with spirit by Cynthia Giannini and Mr. Corry. Linda Bechtold's flashing grins epitomized the hurlyburly excitement of the Nougat from Russia quartet, also danced by Alexander Brady, Brent Phillips and Joseph Schnell. The lead cast was completed by Mary Barton as little Clara and Thomas Morgan as the King of the Mice.
And through the evening there was dancing with an extra sparkle from Valerie Madonia in Mr. Arpino's pretty Waltz of the Flowers and as an eye-catchingly tender parent in the opening party scene; from Meg Gurin as the mechanical Columbine doll and a Marzipan Shepherdess, and from Peter Narbutas as the mechnical Harlequin doll and an ardent Snow Wind.
The orchestra did itself proud under the direction of Allan Lewis, who drew some especially magical sounds from the percussion section. The singing of the Boys Choir of Harlem was celestial. And the Joffrey Ballet School had reason to be proud of the dancing children of "The Nutcracker."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tina LeBlanc and Tom Mossbrucker in the Joffrey Ballet production of "The Nutcracker" at the City Center Theater through Dec. 2. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: On Iraq's Other Front

BYLINE: By Clyde Haberman; Clyde Haberman, the Rome bureau chief for The New York Times, reports frequently from Turkey.

 BODY:
THE DUST-SWIRLED TOWN OF SILOPI LIES along a stretch of blacktop that Turks call the Silk Road. It isn't quite as glamorous perhaps as the ancient Silk Road that linked China to the West, but it carries the same whispers of prosperity and hopes of lasting security.
The highway runs east-west through southern Turkey and into Iraq. Silopi is the last Turkish town for truck drivers heading to the Iraqi border, 10 miles away at the foot of rugged humps of sandy mountains that separate the two neighbors. 
 In better times, 4,000 or more trucks a day would pass through Silopi to and from Iraq, bringing fuel and plenty of cash, which the drivers spread around the shops that line the Silk Road for many miles.
But when Iraq invaded Kuwait in August, the music died for Silopi and other towns all along the road. Turkey wasted no time in joining the international blockade of Iraq. And when the truck traffic stopped, so did Silopi. These days, townsmen spend empty hours in cafes, sipping strong coffee and tea, denouncing President Saddam Hussein of Iraq but cursing the embargo as well.
So much for whispers of prosperity.
The scene is basically the same 20 miles up the road in Cizre. But there, the active young Mayor, Hasim Hasimi, voices another fear: that Hussein would not hesitate to use chemical weapons if war broke out. That could make early casualties of Cizre's 50,000 people, Hasimi says with a glum look as he strolls across his small garden.
"This guy Saddam could do it -- we're all agreed on that," he says. "And we will be the first to feel it. We don't have gas masks or bomb shelters. Even our doctors don't known much about the impact of chemical weapons."
So much for hopes of lasting security.

IN THE TURKISH CAPITAL, ANKARA, 600 miles away, a senior Government official sat up in his chair and waved aside the possibility of an Iraqi threat. "They would not dare attack an Ottoman," he said. Few Turks still refer to themselves by the name of the long-gone empire. His use of "Ottoman" may have been intended as mild irony. Nonetheless, it was an effective reminder that time was when these trouble spots, Iraq and Kuwait, were not countries but mere outposts of the far-flung Turkish realm.
Other officials admit to being deeply worried about the Iraqi menace. Either way, no one disputes that Turkey, a NATO member, has put itself on the front line in the United States-led campaign to isolate Iraq.
When Washington needed allies in August, President Turgut Ozal said to count on him. A few days after the invasion of Kuwait, the Turks moved to shut twin pipelines stretching across their southern tier to the Mediterranean that carried more than half of Iraqi oil exports. Bowing to the will of the governing Motherland Party, an unruly coalition that Ozal controls, the Parliament handed the executive branch the power to dispatch Turkish soldiers abroad and to let foreign troops onto Turkish soil. A detachment of American F-111 fighter jets has been allowed to remain at a Turkish air base instead of returning to their station in Britain, as scheduled, after a training exercise. The Turkish Army has increased its strength near the Iraqi border to upward of 100,000 men, pinning down Iraqi forces that otherwise could be sent southward to face American soldiers in Saudi Arabia.
For Turkey, these are no small steps. Indeed, Ozal has come under domestic fire for exceeding the ceremonial role of his office and for violating the country's tradition of extreme caution in foreign affairs. Most of all, his critics complain, he broke a cardinal Turkish rule forged over centuries of empire building and losing: Only grief can come of getting involved in Arab squabbles. Both the Foreign and Defense Ministers resigned largely to protest Ozal's handling of the gulf crisis. But his decision prevailed.
Economically, the anti-Iraq embargo has cost hard-pressed Turkey dearly. Officials figure that the country stands to lose at least $7 billion a year in trade, pipeline fees and foreign investment. Relations with an unpleasant neighbor have been poisoned for a long time, no matter how the crisis ends. And if Mayor Hasimi's worst fears about chemical warfare are realized, Turkish civilians could pay a terrible price.
So Muslim Turkey, with a toehold in Europe but the rest of its expanse lying squarely in Asia Minor, expects the United States and its Western allies to remember its sacrifices when it comes time to take stock of their friends. Too often, the Turks feel their good deeds have been too quickly forgotten. "Turkey has always felt itself on the threshold of loneliness," says Bozkurt Guvenc, a professor of anthropology at Hacettepe University in Ankara.
What Turks crave is international respect, something they feel they are too often denied. The gulf situation, for all its perilous potential, has at least bolstered their image.
Just a day before the Iraqi invasion, many people were writing off Turkey's strategic importance as a thing of the past. A popular line of reasoning went like this:
For decades, the country's geopolitical strength lay mainly in its position as NATO's eastern bulwark against the Soviet Union and the Warsaw Pact. Except for the United States, Turkey, with 635,000 troops, has the largest armed force in the Western alliance. But with the cold war over, it was argued, what use are all those soldiers to the West? And if its military trump card was indeed gone, what chance would Turkey have to join the European Community, an objective that amounts almost to a holy mission?
In a single day, Saddam Hussein changed that thinking. Suddenly, the West reawakened to the fact that Turkey, at the edge of the Arab Middle East, has a continuing and vital strategic role. A simple look at the map makes that plain.
Few countries are surrounded by so many traditional rivals. To the north is the Soviet Union, to the west Greece and Bulgaria. And to the east and south lie three of the world's nastiest regimes -- Iran, Iraq and Syria. Turkey may no longer be needed to help fight the cold war, but it remains the Atlantic alliance's point man in the Middle East.

THE TURKISH ARMED forces would certainly never be willing to fight except within a NATO or United Nations framework, and military specialists agree that the Turks, on their own, would not fare well against battle-hardened Iraq.
They rely heavily on conscripts who stay on active duty for only 18 months. Since World War I, the army has seen sustained combat only twice, when it joined the United Nations force in the 1950-53 Korean War and when it invaded northern Cyprus in 1974. The main battle experience of its soldiers in recent years has come in sporadic skirmishes with Kurdish guerrillas demanding a separate state in the southeast. Moreover, the military is hobbled by obsolete weaponry. Turkey, the loyal ally, curiously enough, has found it relatively hard to obtain financing to buy the modern equipment that the West managed to give Saddam Hussein.
"I hate to think what would happen if the Turks were to go one-on-one against Iraq," a Western military expert said.
Still, serving as NATO's tripwire against an Iraqi attack gives Turkey new importance. So does its apparent, if not explicitly stated, readiness to let the United States use Turkish bases if war comes. The main installation, the Incirlik air base near Adana, a southern city, normally has a contingent of 5,000 Americans to provide backup for pilots who are stationed elsewhere in Europe and who use the base for training maneuvers.
In return for their help, the Turks have tangible goals that go beyond a pat on the head from foreigners about what stalwart fellows they are. Above all, they want the European Community to approve their membership application, and there is muted hope that the gulf crisis may alter the equation a bit.
The application was submitted in 1987 and rejected, politely but firmly, last December. Knock on our door again in 1993, the 12 existing community members said, after we have finished our vaunted economic integration. In off-the-record conversations, European diplomats allow that the Turks' prospects will remain dim for quite a while. Let's face it, they say, Turkey is too poor, too populous, too Muslim, too harsh, too culturally different, too everything.
Turkey's leaders are not fooling themselves that, just because they quickly joined the embargo of Iraq, Western Europe will suddenly admit them into the club. "Europe comes to us for help only when its backside is on fire," a senior official said. When the crisis ends, he fretted, Turks will probably be put back "in our place," and that might even include having to stand behind Eastern European parvenus like Hungary and Czechoslovakia on the European Community application line.
Nevertheless, Turks feel that they hold a strengthened hand for now, and they have an i.o.u. for the United States as well. They want the Americans to import more Turkish textiles and to provide them with dozens of F-16 fighters and other military hardware. Down the road, they would like a change in a formula that guarantees Greece, its archrival, $7 worth of American military aid for every $10 that Turkey gets. The Turks view the arrangement as unfair capitulation to a powerful Greek lobby, given that their armed forces are three times the size of Greece's and face many potential enemies.
At the core of these requests lies that yearning for respect.
Turkey's nationalism is virulent, and it sometimes seems as if it is shared by every one of its 57 million people. They greatly resent it that the very word "Turk" for many foreigners has long conjured up images of a backward place where torture is the national sport.
Regardless of political persuasion, Turks bristle when the United States Congress periodically considers a resolution referring to Turkish genocide in the killing of hundreds of thousands of Armenians in World War I, as the Ottoman Empire tottered toward collapse.
No one denies that Turks massacred Armenians. In Turkey, the most common figure for the death toll is 300,000. That is far from the 1.5 million victims generally claimed by Armenian groups, and the dispute has its odd tones. In dismissing the higher number as an outrageous exaggeration, Turks sometimes sound as if they believe that 300,000 is not such a terrible total, all things considered.
More to the point, they complain that "genocide" is a loaded word, and insist that the Armenian deaths were not the result of a deliberate extermination campaign. It was a period of general mayhem, they say, with many people killed on both sides. As Turkey sees it, a resolution on Armenian genocide like one Congress considered and then voted down in February is an unnecessary dredging of old waters and a gratuitous insult to a faithful ally.
Contributing to the Turks' troubles is a sorry human-rights record that makes it easier for Westerners to think the worst of them. While their performance is light years ahead of those in neighboring Middle Eastern states, it still falls far short of Western standards.
During three years of military rule in the early 1980's, hundreds of thousands of people were tortured, human-rights groups say. Although the situation has vastly improved, the present Government is nonetheless accused of foot-dragging on carrying out accords that Turkey itself signed. Amnesty International says that in 1989, it received hundreds of reports of torture from political prisoners, who described methods like electric shock, hosings with cold water and beatings on the soles of their feet. Police officers are often said to be casually brutal, more so than prison guards.
The Government also has a dubious record when it comes to free speech, even though Turkey boasts a lively press that shows no reluctance to criticize Ozal and others in authority. The police regularly arrest citizens who espouse left-wing causes, or challenge the country's secular principles too zealously, or write articles deemed overly sympathetic to the Kurdish separatists. This fall, a 16-year-old girl in Istanbul was arrested -- and, her sister said, possibly tortured -- for writing "No to war" on school walls.
A flint-hard line has been drawn in the battle against the Kurdish guerrillas. Last April, in an extraordinary delegation of power, the Government gave the regional governor for 11 southeastern provinces the authority to evacuate entire villages and to confiscate the printing presses of any publication whose articles he feels could undermine security operations. His decisions may not be appealed in court. In this atmosphere, editors of at least 17 left-wing publications have been arrested, and mainstream newspapers admit to self-censorship to avoid possible run-ins with the authorities.
All this notwithstanding, many Turks complain that Americans and Europeans are too quick to criticize, always ready with a lecture on how to treat one's fellow man, but slow to lend a hand when one is needed. Even human-rights advocates feel that way. "There is a double standard applied against us," said Nevzat Helvaci, secretary general of the Turkish Human Rights Association.
Helvaci tells of two Kurds who came to him asking for help in moving to Western Europe. They were among some 60,000 Kurds who had fled into Turkey two years ago after Saddam Hussein's soldiers attacked their villages in northern Iraq with chemical weapons. About 30,000 refugees remain in Turkish camps whose spare conditions are routinely deplored in Europe.
"We asked European countries to take the two Kurds," Helvaci recalled, "and they kept saying no. They said they had done all they could. The Dutch Embassy said they had already accepted 11 Kurds, and that was too many. Eventually, these two went to Germany. But usually Europe just criticizes, and doesn't help."

IT IS A SPRAWLING country, twice the size of California and just as varied, with fertile plains, barren wastes, languid Aegean islands and imposing mountains that include Mount Ararat.
It is also a land of striking social contrasts.
Istanbul, city of minarets and once the capital of Ottoman sultans, is now a bursting metropolis spread across both sides of the Bosporus. Its eight million people include a large affluent middle class that is thoroughly Westernized, with a taste for Vuitton bags and CNN television. But go to Diyarbakir, capital of Turkey's largely Kurdish southeast, and you are in the Middle East, surrounded by horse-drawn carts.
Turks can be harsh to those on society's margins, yet also remarkably generous to strangers. Heading to a late dinner in Ankara one night, I was left by a taxi driver at a building that, I discovered too late, was far from where I was supposed to be. I knocked on a door to ask for directions. The man who answered was in his pajamas and had already gone to bed. Nevertheless, he signaled for me to wait while he got dressed, and then walked me many blocks to my intended destination.
Turkey's leaders think of themselves as Europeans, yet their country struggled along on an average per-capita income last year of only $1,435. Taking care of basic needs is a formidable task. The population will reach 83 million by 2005, if its annual growth rate of 2.5 percent continues. It would be greater than any European country, including reunified Germany. Simply to absorb all the new entrants into the work force requires an economy that expands by at least 5 percent a year.
Through most of the 1980's, the Turks managed to keep pace. Last year, the economy suddenly went flat, partly because of drought-induced disasters in agriculture. But Turkey has bounced back, and, despite sharply higher fuel costs brought on by the gulf crisis, the Finance Ministry forecasts 9 percent growth for 1990.
At outdoor stands and in countless small shops, the commercial energy is almost electric, notably in and around the labyrinthine central bazaar of Istanbul. One can buy almost anything there, from antique Persian rugs to the latest electrical appliances, from slices of halvah to shares on the fledgling stock exchange.
Much growth over the last decade can be credited to Turgut Ozal. He was chief economic planner after the country fell under military rule in 1980, and then became the first civilian Prime Minister after the junta dissolved itself in 1983.
Until he came along preaching a form of the free-market gospel according to Reagan and Thatcher, the Turkish economy was state-run and insulated. In the 1970's, shortages of staples like oil and coffee contributed to a cycle of violence that finally persuaded the generals -- and many civilians -- that the army had to reimpose order.
Ozal's Government lifted heavy-handed regulations and promoted exports. It encouraged a turnover of state enterprises to private hands. It lured foreign investment and emphasized tourism. Until then, foreign exchange had come mostly from money sent home by the 2.5 million Turkish workers and businessmen who migrated to Western Europe.
Most visible of all, Ozal ordered basic improvements that were desperately needed, especially in the east, where incomes are less than half the national average. Electricity, once barely known in many areas, has been extended everywhere. In 1983, only one-third of Turkey's 34,500 villages had telephones; now they all do. The most ambitious project is a $21 billion program for the semiarid southeast. It envisions the construction of 22 dams and 19 hydroelectric stations to create, in the expansive words of one Cabinet minister, "a new Fertile Crescent."
But success has a price, and for Turks it is rampant inflation. It came close to triple digits two years ago, receding to a still-galloping 64 percent in 1989. This year's official forecast is 45 percent, but the effects of the gulf crisis put that figure into question.
Inflation has strained national harmony. Increasingly, the state and big companies are locked in struggles with workers who find that, despite hefty wage increases, they keep losing ground. Moreover, inflation accentuates fundamental imbalances and the fact that Turkey is still a developing country -- basically agricultural, industrially weak and thin in social programs that the West takes for granted.
In turning down the Turks' application, the European Community noted that their purchasing power is one-third the community average and that the gap is not likely to shrink soon, given the fast-growing population.
Turkish officials say the Europeans have it backward: Europe keeps getting older and will need the dynamism that a populous Turkey can provide, they argue. Despite the negative signs, optimists abound.
"I think we will catch the E.C. train," said Hasan Cemal, editor of Cumhuriyet, a liberal newspaper. "Maybe it will be the last cars, but we will catch it."

MODERN TURKEY WAS and still is defined by Mustafa Kemal, who became a national hero in World War I when his forces defeated the British at Gallipoli. Otherwise, that war was a disaster for the Turks. They made the mistake of siding with Germany. Defeat in 1918 sealed the death of the already-moribund Ottoman Empire.
From its ashes the present republic rose in 1923, founded by Mustafa Kemal, who had assumed the name Ataturk, or Father of the Turks. Convinced that his Muslim country had to turn westward and reduce Islam's rigid and antimodern influences, he put teachers of religion and imams under state control. He replaced Arabic script with the Latin alphabet. He banned the fez and the veil.
In short, he imposed strict secularism -- no interference of Islam in state affairs. Kemalism remains the nation's guiding principle, so strong that it has become a form of religion. Ataturk's resolute image is hard to escape. His portrait -- sometimes in uniform, sometimes in a fur-collared coat, sometimes in white tie and tails -- hangs on the walls of every public building and in many private houses. To speak out against Kemalism is to invite arrest.
While some Westerners might see this personality cult as a repression of legitimate religious instincts, Ataturk's legacy has enabled Turkey to make economic and democratic strides unknown in any other dominantly Muslim country. With only an occasional lapse, the country has also been scrupulously tolerant of the few Christians and Jews in its midst. Looking at such gains, secular Turks wonder why anyone would challenge a successful formula.
That is why they are appalled by a steady rise of Islamic fundamentalism. In fact, Turkey began retreating from strict Kemalist ways not long after Ataturk's death in 1938. But a religious surge in recent years, said to be financed in part by Iran and Saudi Arabia, goes much further.
According to the Government, 42,511 Turks made the annual pilgrimage to Mecca this spring compared with 25,644 some 10 years ago. In a country where Islamic education was once prohibited, there are now nearly 400 religious schools, five times the number 15 years ago. Their graduates have started to fill important positions in the Interior Ministry, which supervises the national police. Increasingly, dining rooms in public buildings shut down during the Islamic fasting period.
For the last few years, Turkey has been jolted by thousands of young women who, flouting a ban, insist on wearing Islamic head scarves on university campuses. A middle-aged professional woman in Ankara, like many other secular Turks, confesses that the scarves make her uneasy.
For all that, there is little fear of a Khomeini-style revolution within the largely Sunni Muslim population. Fundamentalist political parties draw a small share of the vote, and imams lack a powerful voice. "People still think that religion is something private between them and their God," said Necdet Serin, the rector of Ankara University.
Besides, if all else fails, the army is standing guard as a self-styled protector of Turkish secularism. It has staged a coup roughly every decade over the last 30 years -- in 1960, 1971 and 1980 -- and it is widely presumed to be ready to intervene again if it feels that extremists threaten Kemalist verities.
There is no evidence that the army is gearing for action. And yet other types of trouble contribute to parlor speculation about a possible coup. After a decade of tranquillity, Turkey is again confronted with a wave of political murders that seem the work of both left-wing and religious militants. Sixteen people have been killed this year, including outspoken politicians, lawyers, professors and journalists. Their deaths revive memories of the 1970's, when urban guerrillas killed more than 5,000 people, and the army felt compelled to step in. For now, however, the violence is comparatively mild. In the 1970's, 16 deaths, on average, were reported every three or four days.

NO MODERN turkish leader has been more open about his Islamic beliefs than Turgut Ozal, who often attends Friday prayers and caters to the religious wing of his ruling Motherland Party. Nor has any leader of recent vintage dominated Turkish politics like him.
A short 63-year-old man who runs to serious overweight, he is a technocrat-turned-politician with a passion for following world events through CNN, often using a remote-control device to turn up the sound even when he is being interviewed.
That is not to say he is popular; his opinion polls have been disastrous for several years. At one point, his approval rating dropped almost into the single digits, though it has improved since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. High inflation greatly eroded his strength, as did a pervasive weariness with his bluff style and sultan-like tendencies in appointing relatives to high positions. When the Defense Minister quit in October to protest the Government's handling of the gulf crisis, Ozal's nephew got the job.
But Ozal is the only Turkish politician with power, and many foreign diplomats feel he is also the only one with a global vision. In 1989, he used his party's commanding majority in the Grand National Assembly to have himself elected president, a seven-year position that has little inherent authority but provides wondrous job security for someone with terrible ratings. The main opposition groups screamed in outrage. Given Ozal's negative polls, they argued, his maneuvering was a defiance of public opinion and therefore undemocratic. But the move was totally legal, and the weak opposition had to acquiesce.
Now, even in the ceremonial presidency, it is Ozal who runs the Government, not the Prime Minister he installed, Yildirim Akbulut. It is Ozal who guides Turkey in the gulf crisis, Ozal who receives the phone calls from President Bush.
Foreigners arguably are more impressed with Ozal than the Turks are. He won high marks abroad for making an official visit to Athens two years ago in an attempt to improve relations with Greece. That effort has not produced much, though. Greeks and Turks are as divided as ever, especially over Turkey's occupation of northern Cyprus.
More successfully, Turkey is forging a new relationship with another old enemy, the Soviet Union. Two-way trade expanded last year to $1 billion. To the west, tensions have been sharply reduced with Bulgaria since the new Government there abandoned the forced assimilation of ethnic Turks, a Communist policy that drove 310,000 Bulgarian Muslims to seek refuge across the border last year.
With Turkey's Middle Eastern neighbors, relations are trickier. Iran is seen as an exporter of unwanted fundamentalism. Syria and Iraq grumble that the Turks threaten their water supplies with a new dam at the headwaters of the Euphrates River, the lifeline of ancient Mesopotamia. In turn, Turkey accuses the Iraqis and Syrians of sheltering Kurdish rebels in the southeast. More than 2,000 people have been killed in the Kurds' insurrection since 1984, and while the rebels have almost no chance of defeating the Turkish Army, they seem to be winning sympathy from villagers in the region.
There are about eight million Kurds in Turkey, concentrated in the southeast, where until recently, the authorities refused to accept them as even a distinct ethnic group. They were not called Kurds but rather "mountain Turks." Their language was forbidden in public buildings and not taught in the schools. Some restrictions have been eased in the last few years, but villagers continue to resent mistreatment at the hands of Government troops even if they fear the guerrillas just as much.
The Kurdish problem could become Turkey's Achilles' heel, and from one perspective it already may be. Kurdish leaders and their supporters account for a high percentage of torture victims, human-rights advocates say. The European Community cited Turkey's human-rights shortcomings as a big reason -- almost as important as the economy -- for rejecting the country's membership application. It is clear that as long as the words "Turk" and "torture" continue to be linked, Western Europeans will remain convinced that Turks indeed belong to a different tribe.
But then, in towns like Silopi and Cizre, they already know they are different. They are the people in between, they say, neither European nor Arabic, neither West nor East. They despise Saddam Hussein, but they also have little use for Europe's preaching. Words are important but not everything, they say. Deeds count, too. Whose bodies, they ask, are now on the front line?
