HEADLINE: A Mountain of Trouble

BYLINE: BY WILLIAM J. BROAD; William J. Broad is a science reporter for The Times.

 BODY:
YUCCA MOUNTAIN IS A BARREN, flat-topped ridge rising out of the Nevada desert. Located 100 miles northwest of Las Vegas, it stands amid a desolate expanse that is broken every so often by a Joshua tree or yucca plant. The mountain rises some 1,500 feet and runs six miles or so. Within two decades it could hold the most dangerous nuclear facility in the world.
The Government plans to build a dump inside Yucca Mountain for the most highly radioactive nuclear waste in the nation. The job is considered urgent. More than four decades after the start of the nuclear era, there is no permanent place to put the vast and rapidly growing accumulation of the most lethal of America's nuclear refuse -- the spent fuel rods and radioactive debris that constitute a largely forgotten legacy of this country's conquest of the atom. The nation has sites for the storage of low-level waste -- and one, under construction in Carlsbad, N.M., for some higher-level military byproducts -- but none for the most deadly substances of all. 
 The Government wants a final burial place for these items, now stored at Federal sites for nuclear weapons production and at many of the nation's 111 operating nuclear power plants. It wants a repository that will keep them isolated from the earth's environment for 10,000 years, until radioactive decay has rendered them less hazardous than they are today.
Yucca Mountain is the last candidate, selected after a stormy, decades-long, multibillion-dollar search that crisscrossed much of the nation and eliminated dozens of other potential sites, often for reasons of politics rather than science. Today, the site's 1,800 federal and contract workers feel great pressure to stay on schedule in assessing the site's suitability and planning the repository, which would be a labyrinth of tunnels up to 115 miles long. Its cost is expected to be up to $15 billion, some $1 billion of which has already been spent. If everything goes according to plan, it will open for business in 2010.
At first glance, Yucca Mountain seems perfect for the job. Its main virtue is aridity. The Nevada desert is one of the driest places in the United States. The water table beneath Yucca Mountain is unusually low, a third of a mile down. By contrast, the water table in the East can be within a dozen feet of the surface. In theory, canisters of radioactive waste (which are very hot both physically and radioactively) could be deposited deep inside Yucca Mountain and still be hundreds of feet above the water table, safe and dry for thousands of years, unlikely ever to contact or contaminate ground water, unlikely ever to spread radioactivity.
One scientist, however, has quietly but persistently warned that this vision of a safe repository is little more than a delusion.
Jerry S. Szymanski (pronounced sha-MAN-ski) is a geologist who works on the Yucca Mountain project for the United States Department of Energy, which is in charge of evaluating the site and would run the repository. For years, he has argued that ground water under the mountain could eventually well up, flood the facility and prompt a calamity of vast proportions. The geological action is easy to visualize. Crustal stresses in the area slowly open fractures and faults under and within the mountain. Water seeps into them. An earthquake occurs, compressing the fractures and forcing the ground water upward into the dump. As the inrushing water comes into contact with the hot canisters of nuclear waste, the water is vaporized, threatening to cause explosions, ruptures and the release of radioactivity.
Szymanski has worked for the D.O.E. since 1983. He takes pains to distance himself from foes of nuclear power. "This report is not the act of a disgruntled employee or an antinuclear freak," he wrote in the preface of a study he made on Yucca Mountain. "Rather, it is the act of a deeply concerned scientist, a public servant and a pro-nuclear activist."
He chain-smokes Winstons and drinks Scotch, neither of which seems to impair his ability to take brisk hikes up the mountain with his dog Max, a fierce-looking but friendly creature that is half Labrador, half pit bull. Szymanski's eyes flash when he speaks of those who oppose his view of the evidence. "It's banality of thought," he growls, "absence of depth." That same kind of banality, he says, was responsible for the Holocaust, around which his earliest memories revolve, and for a brutal crackdown in his native Poland, which prompted him to flee that country two decades ago with his wife and 6-month-old son. Today, he says, banality is prompting the Federal Government to court disaster.
Squinting in the bright Nevada sunlight, a cigarette firmly in his mouth, Szymanski walks into Trench No. 8, a deep scar on the side of Yucca Mountain dug at the behest of the Energy Department. It runs across a fault. He bends down to examine a one-yard-wide vein of rock whose creamy color stands in contrast to the dark, surrounding earth tones. His fingers play over its surface. The vein was deposited, he says, by mineral-laden water that welled up and turned this desolate site into an oasis.
"This is above the repository level," he says with studied understatement. The implication is clear and troubling -- where water once flowed, it might flow again.
The repository would hold up to 70,000 metric tons of waste. A large release would have an environmental impact that, by some estimates, would exceed that of a nuclear war. For perspective, the explosion of the Chernobyl reactor in the Soviet Union shot into the atmosphere just a few dozen pounds of highly radioactive nuclear waste, one of the most dangerous components of which was cesium 137 (it would also be a significant part of the waste at Yucca Mountain). Various studies say the consequences of Chernobyl will eventually be somewhere between 17,000 and 475,000 deaths from cancer, as well as an alarming number of serious ailments.
For half a decade, Szymanski's was a lone voice. His grim appraisal was opposed by almost everyone else on the Yucca Mountain project, who let their displeasure be known in subtle and not-so-subtle ways. But recently, growing ranks of geologists have backed his view. The dispute is by no means resolved.
If Szymanski is right and his warnings are heeded, it could mark the end of the Yucca Mountain project. The retreat would be a stunning setback for the Government and the nuclear-power industry, which is poised for a revival. If he is right and his warnings go unheeded, some experts say it might be the beginning of the ultimate end.
"You flood that thing and you could blow the top off the mountain," says Charles B. Archambeau, a geophysicist at the University of Colorado who has reviewed Szymanski's work and found it persuasive. "At the very least, the radioactive material would go into the ground water and spread to Death Valley, where there are hot springs all over the place, constantly bringing water up from great depths. It would be picked up by the birds, the animals, the plant life. It would start creeping out of Death Valley. You couldn't stop it. That's the nightmare. It could slowly spread to the whole biosphere. If you want to envision the end of the world, that's it."

JERRY SZYMANSKI WAS BORN, IN 1943, TO POLISH nobility. The family's prosperity ended during the Second World War as waves of invading Germans and Russians swept the area. Born amid the turmoil, Szymanski says his earliest memory is of his grandmother telling a friend about a mass grave in which thousands of Jews were buried, many of them half alive. "Hands were sticking out of the ground," he recalls his grandmother as saying. "The earth was moving." His father, active in organized resistance against the Germans and Russians, was eventually sent to a labor camp in Russia for six years.
Szymanski grew up in Communist Poland, bright, eager to learn and marked for advancement. He was sent to the University of Warsaw, where he graduated in 1965 with a geology degree. Two years later, he was hard at work on doctoral research and teaching when, in March 1968, he joined students clamoring for economic and social reform. "We wanted a dialogue," he says. "What we saw was brute, bloody force, storm troopers beating people." Students were arrested on charges of "anti-state activities," and hundreds of Jews were fired from newspaper and university posts as the Government blamed them for shortcomings in the Polish economy. Though not Jewish, Szymanski was fed up. The Government was eager to be rid of university agitators. So, in December 1968, he was allowed to board a plane with his wife, baby and two suitcases, bound for the United States.
Penniless, Szymanski went to work as a consultant to the burgeoning nuclear-power industry, helping find and evaluate sites for reactors and related facilities. Paramount in his work was the study of fault lines, breaks in rock strata that can shift and cause earthquakes. In 1972, he landed a job with Dames & Moore, a civil-engineering company with a global reputation for site-selection skill. Within some five years, Szymanski became a senior geologist, advising American companies and foreign governments in places like Iran, Korea, Spain and Chile on the geologic feasibility of setting up nuclear reactors. He also worked extensively with Federal regulators in charge of reactor licensing.
Peers held him in high esteem. "He's brilliant," says James G. McWhorter, the senior geologist at Dames & Moore. "One of his greatest talents is the ability to see the forest and the trees."
In 1977, at an international conference in Stockholm, Szymanski got a severe shock. Attending a session on the geologic disposal of used nuclear fuel, he was astonished to hear that the field was in its infancy, with one speaker after another talking only in theoretical terms. Nowhere in the world was there a permanent disposal site for the growing mountain of high-level nuclear waste. "I had been convinced there was somebody on the other end," Szymanski says. "I was wrong. The fuel cycle was not complete."
In 1982, he switched jobs, intending to address what he considered a looming obstacle to the industry's growth. At Decision Planning Corporation, a private company, he worked on Federal contracts to evaluate the merit of different types of deep geologic disposal. But he found himself only on the periphery of the process. In early 1983, he accepted a job with the Energy Department itself, though it meant a $20,000 cut in annual pay. "I figured I would have some influence," he says. Soon after, the D.O.E. offered him a position at the Yucca Mountain site, which was starting to undergo intense evaluation.
In February 1984, he arrived at the project offices in Las Vegas, blocks from the swirl of casinos, lights and illusion that make up the strip. Szymanski was one of the unit's four officials. He was in charge of gathering and assessing data from teams of scientists (mainly the U.S. Geological Survey and various contractors) whose work was to form the basis for evaluating the mountain. Equally important, he was in charge of packaging that data for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, the Federal body that would be asked to license the nuclear-waste repository.
Everything went fine until Szymanski took his first field trip that September. It became what he calls "the most incredible three days of my life." He led a party of some 30 Federal and Nevada state officials to the mountain, and as they traveled back and forth across its arms and valleys, he grew increasingly edgy. From atop the mountain he could see 10 volcanic cones. Some showed little erosion, suggesting they were geologically quite young. Also visible were signs of six major fault lines. The area clearly had a history of intense geologic activity.
At Trench No. 14, on the mountain's east side, a scientist from the U.S. Geological Survey, which had done much of the exploratory work, used the word "travertine" to describe a large, cream-colored deposit of fine, crystalline calcium carbonate exposed at one end of the ditch. Alarm bells went off in Szymanski's head. Travertine is a type of limestone found in caves (in the form of stalactites and stalagmites) and around springs. It is synonymous with the presence of water and is deposited in bands over long periods of time. Szymanski was no stranger to travertine, which is often associated with fault lines and which he had repeatedly searched for, found and examined all over the world. Its analysis can reveal the age of a fault, a fact that is important in evaluating whether it is likely to shift and damage a nuclear reactor.
Szymanski kept his concerns to himself. He doubted his perceptions, even his sanity. After all, none of the other geologists on the field trip seemed to be worried. The party continued its tour. But then came the evidence that tipped the balance. At Trench No. 8, on the west side of the mountain, was another deposit of travertine, situated, as usual, along a fault line. This time Szymanski examined it closely.
The travertine held many rock fragments in suspension, caught there by the mineral-coating process. Some had been cut in half by bulldozers. Those near the main vein had a shell of discoloration. Those farther away did not.
To Szymanski, the disparity was evidence that a warm spring had formed the travertine, etching rocks near the source but having no effect on those farther away, where the water would have been cooler. Other signs caught his eye. Travertine at the source was laced with vertical bands of minerals, including opal. The spring had definitely been warm, Szymanski concluded, carrying different kinds of water-soluble minerals up from deep within the earth.
The tour group pulled away. Szymanski stayed behind, kicking the tires of his vehicle, blind with rage. For seven years, from 1977 to 1984, he had visualized in ever greater detail what a repository should look like. Yucca Mountain did not come close. In many respects, it was the least likely site he could imagine. Moreover, he could see no means of improvement. Trying to waterproof the dump was hopeless. Barriers could be broken by earthquakes. And diversion channels for water might not be big enough, or last long enough. At best, complex man-made structures survived for hundreds of years, not thousands. In any case, the whole philosophy of the project was to have the site be safe naturally -- not made that way.
Yucca Mountain was predicated on dryness -- falsely, Szymanski was now convinced. Yet here he was, in charge of the Federal team meant to explain to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission why this site was good. Szymanski knew there was no way he could do it. In that instant, he foresaw the fights, the bureaucratic battles, the personal attacks. "Why me?" he thought to himself. "I'm just an immigrant."
It was Friday. Szymanski drove back to Las Vegas, where a friend from Dames & Moore, Timothy R. Harper, was arriving to spend the weekend. The next day, Szymanski took Harper, a geologist who is now a research scientist with a major British oil company, on a tour of Yucca Mountain, eager for an independent analysis.
"It was so obvious," Harper recalls. "Travertine is well known by the most inexperienced geologist to be a spring deposit. You walk into that trench and it shouts at you, it screams at you: 'This was an ejection of fluid.' Familiarity with a situation sometimes closes your eyes to understanding. It's quite possible that people became too familiar with seeing these deposits all over the place. But an outsider could see it straight away. You just look at the thing and know it's a fluid flow."
Harper was the first of more than a dozen independent geologists Szymanski would take through the site over the next few years. Without exception, they supported his views.

SZYMANSKI TOLD HIS Energy Department superiors of his concerns. The officials, not being geologists themselves, were in a bind. They had to rely on advice from contractors, the Geological Survey and the nation's nuclear-weapons laboratories: Los Alamos, Livermore and Sandia. Very quickly, these experts, led by the Geological Survey, came up with an explanation that became the standard reply. The deposits were superficial, they said, the result of rain, dating from an age when Nevada's climate was wetter. Calcium dust on certain kinds of exposed rock, this theory went, was picked up by the wind, carried many miles, caught in raindrops over Yucca Mountain and deposited over the course of millions of years in pools, fractures and faults, where it grew ever more concentrated.
This vision was immensely reassuring. It said that while the mountain's surface might once have been wet, the repository area deep underground had always been dry and would stay that way into the distant future. No ground water would rush up from beneath the mountain. Except for Szymanski, no one spoke of travertine any more. Instead, the cream-colored mineral was called pedogenic, meaning formed in the soil.
In late 1984, the Energy Department dispatched a bulldozer to Trench No. 14 in an effort to explore the issue, the assumption being that the limestone deposit would prove to be superficial. Roaring and grinding, the machine dug deeper and deeper, removing layers of material. Surprisingly, the deposit simply narrowed into a one-yard-wide vein that seemed to dive deep into the mountain.
Szymanski pressed his superiors to continue the investigation, to take core samples, to further expose the vein, to resolve the issue once and for all. "Nothing happened," he says. He pressed the contractors and Federal experts to document the findings and explain what they meant. "They resisted," Szymanski says.
For two years, Szymanski fought a losing battle to try to get the problem addressed. Finally, in frustration, he decided to do it himself.
Szymanksi thought the source of the surface deposits was clearly warm water bubbling up from below. So he decided to wrestle with the problem of how the springs got there in the first place, hoping a clear explanation would persuade skeptics and give his science teams an intellectual framework on which to base their work.
Ground-water levels are usually governed by climatic trends. But Szymanski theorized that levels in the Yucca Mountain area could be altered by earthquakes, and sustained that way for hundreds or even thousands of years by the earth's inner heat, through a process known as thermal convection. "It's like water percolating up in a coffee pot," he says.
To test his hypothesis, Szymanski examined the huge amount of data on the geology and hydrology of Yucca Mountain and its environs, which had been accumulated over the years. The evidence, he concluded, was indisputable. Rock samples from the mountain's core showed calcium carbonate deposits extending down many hundreds of yards. Analysis of trace elements in the deposits showed that the water creating them had been warm -- again, suggesting it came from below rather than in the form of cool rain.
But the powers that be were still not persuaded by the evidence. "My desk was moved closer and closer to the door," Szymanski recalls. "I was a forgotten man." In November 1987, he submitted a 322-page draft report. It sat in the mail room, untouched by his superior.
Meanwhile, a copy of the report came into the hands of Richard H. Bryan, then Nevada's Governor, who had strongly voiced the state's opposition to the repository. In January 1988, over Szymanski's objections, Bryan released the draft at a news conference. "If the conclusions of the report are accurate -- and state scientists have every reason to believe that they are -- there can be no doubt that Yucca Mountain should never have been selected as a possible repository site," Bryan told reporters. His comments threw the Federal bureaucracy into action.
More than 40 scientists were now put onto the job of reviewing Szymanski's draft. Their 133-page review, issued in July 1989, said the majority "doubt that there is sufficient technical basis to warrant pursuing the author's hypothesis further," adding that Szymanski's evidence was ambiguous at best. The lead reviewer, William W. Dudley Jr. of the Geological Survey, called the draft "deceitful" and riddled with "violations of scientific ethics."
In an interview last month, Dudley softened his tone, saying Szymanski's effects "probably do occur to some degree" but were blown "out of proportion." He even said that the area around Yucca Mountain may hold examples of calcium carbonate produced by the welling up of ground water but were too old to have any bearing on the repository project.
John S. Stuckless, a Survey geologist on the Yucca Mountain project, also remains unpersuaded. The disputed calcium on Yucca Mountain "cannot be deposited from the ground water," he said in an interview this fall. "That leaves only soil-forming processes." He said such action could account for much of the field data, including deposits of opal, although he conceded that the thickness of the band found in Trench No. 14 is "more than is typical in a soil horizon."
Asked about calcium carbonate found at great depths beneath Yucca Mountain, Stuckless acknowledged the possibility of ground water, but he, too, discounted its relevance. "We have a suspicion, unconfirmed, that we are looking at two different kinds of calcite, one up and one down," he said -- one deposited by rain, the other by ground water far below the repository level, too far below to threaten the project.
Szymanski was calm amid the storm. During the yearlong review, he had been listening carefully to the criticism and revising his draft. He was confident. There was no way rainwater could become concentrated enough to produce opal that was as thick, pure and banded as that found here. Only a flowing source of ground water could carry enough of the dissolved minerals. And from careful study of rock cores, Szymanski knew the mountain was riddled with calcium from top to bottom, strengthening his thesis. Moreover, chemical analysis showed these calcium deposits were, for all practical purposes, identical.
Szymanski's final report, 911 pages long, was made public in July 1989. He wrote that evidence for his ground-water model was overwhelming and dismissed the Energy Department plan for Yucca Mountain as "wishful thinking." Privately, he viewed most of his critics as decent men who were blinded to the obvious by bureacratic inertia, a desire for career and financial security and a fear that the nation and the nuclear industry would be thrown into turmoil if Yucca Mountain were to be abandoned.
The report had an introduction written by Gerald A. Frazier, a scientist at the Science Applications International Corporation who had quit the internal-review panel because he felt it was biased. After listening to the criticisms and Szymanski's responses, and after traveling extensively through the desert with Szymanksi, Frazier was sure his thesis had merit. "If there is but 1 chance in 10 that his postulates are valid," Frazier wrote, "then we must jointly share his concerns and seek resolution."

THE BATTLE BETWEEN Szymanski and the Federal bureaucracy had by now been going on for five years. In 1989, it was moved to a higher plateau by Carl P. Gertz, a civil engineer who had become head of the Yucca Mountain project two years earlier. After making public the conflicting reports, Gertz announced that Szymanski's work would be reviewed again, this time by experts outside the Federal preserve. A five-member independent panel (with two members picked by Szymanski and three by Gertz) and a 17-member group from the National Academy of Sciences, a prestigious group that advises the Government, would separately review the material.
Gertz says he is opened-minded. "We want to ask the hard questions right now," he said in an interview. "My personal view is that it's healthy for a scientific program to have debate at this stage." Even healthier, he says, would be more research to help resolve the ground-water issue. A lawsuit brought by the State of Nevada has stopped much work at the site.
"There are many things we don't know about Yucca," Gertz said. "Until we gather the data, I don't think I'll be surprised about anything out there." However, he said, the consequences of a flooded dump would probably not be as severe as Szymanski fears. The slow corrosion of canisters would be more likely than their explosive rupture, Gertz said, lessening the odds of a massive release.
John Stuckless feels that further research will resolve the ground-water riddles. "We're just starting a three-year study of this whole problem," he noted this fall, referring to a "site characterization" study the D.O.E. is undertaking. "It's not like anybody is finished." After the data has been gathered, he said, it will undergo a fairly lengthy period of analysis. By this schedule, the issues Szymanski raised in 1984 might conceivably be answered a decade later.
Meanwhile, the five-member independent panel is expected to report near the end of the year. The National Academy of Sciences group is to file an interim report in 1991 and a final one in 1992.

"MAX!" SZYMANSKI shouts. The dog bounds out of the desert into the vehicle. As we drive off, Szymanski holds up a yellow butane lighter. "My objective is to make sure we see reality and act accordingly," he says. "I don't really care what the specific actions are. But when a society starts calling a yellow lighter black, that's the end."
He says the waste project needs no more data. It simply needs to examine objectively the huge amount of evidence already in hand.
What are the odds of ground water welling up through the mountain in the next 10,000 years? "It's a sure thing," Szymanski answers, "just like death."
The project has so far failed to weigh seriously the worst-case consequences, he adds -- a major release from waste containers.
We leave Yucca Mountain behind, crossing a valley dotted with volcanic cones. At Bare Mountain, we get out and climb its lower elevations, still in sight of Yucca. Gold miners have dug on the mountain's side, exposing layers of rock as they worked their way along a fault line. Clearly evident are the same cream-colored deposits of calcium carbonate, alternating with thick, four-inch bands of opal, some of gem quality. Gold ore lies along the fault, Szymanski says, deposited there in the same manner as the calcium carbonate. "That stuff has uranium in it," he says. "You don't get that from the sky."
He picks up a cream-colored, heavily banded rock. "To say this is the result of rain is preposterous," he asserts. "Take it to Columbia University and say that. They'll throw you out of the office."
We drive away, across the dry, dusty valley toward the state highway. I ask if there are springs around like the ones he is suggesting may someday appear on Yucca Mountain. Yes, Szymanski says, including ones on the sides of mountains.
We pull up to a site known as Devil's Hole. The rocky outcropping is cut by a deep gash. At its bottom is a pool of crystal-clear water, which Szymanski says goes down hundreds of feet. "This is not rainwater," he says. A gorge leading to the gash is obviously a fault, covered with the same calcium deposits we have seen all day long.
We drive down the mountain. The sun is setting, the desert tinged with gold. Ahead is a lake surrounded by dense foliage. It is known as Crystal Pool, Szymanski says. It is spring fed, an oasis in the desert.
Covered with dirt, I pull off my clothes and plunge into the water, swimming far from shore. A flock of birds glides by. Looking back, I see Szymanski sitting on a bank near the shoreline, fully clothed. He is smoking a cigarette, waiting patiently, staring into the distance.

HEADLINE: POP MUSIC;
The Plight Of the Session Player

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WALKER; Michael Walker has written about popular music for Rolling Stone.

 BODY:
Mark Murphy's new album was just about finished, and Larry Fallon, a New York-based producer-arranger, had booked a studio to sweeten four of the jazz singer's tracks with incidental music. Strings, horns and voices were once used to enhance records, but on this day Mr. Fallon hired only one musician, Jon Cobert, a freelance keyboardist.
Flanked by five-foot-tall racks of digital synthesizers, Mr. Cobert auditioned a few sounds for Mr. Fallon, then added a blend of oboe, French horn, flute and an ethereal choir to the song "What a Way to Go." For the musicians who would have played the 12 violins, four violas, four cellos, two double basses and three woodwinds that the synthesizers replaced on this one recording session, the song title is an unwitting epitaph. 
 At studios across the country, similar scenes are played out every day with the same refrain: music is being recorded largely unencumbered by musicians. The practice, made possible by advanced digital synthesizers that emulate the sound of instruments, has become so widespread it has decimated the corps of musicians who earn their living playing in recording studios. The change is startling: a decade ago, replacing an orchestra with a synthesizer would have seemed revolutionary; today, hiring musicians is the novelty.
So-called session players are perpetually on call to sight-read whatever music is placed before them, be it blazing heavy-metal riffs, thorny jazz passages or, most typically, the stylistic hodgepodge of advertising jingles. Before the synthesizer onslaught began in the mid-80's, the session players most in demand earned more than $100,000 a year, but bookings and incomes have dropped by about half, and many players have simply dropped out. Membership in Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, to which New York's studio musicians belong, has fallen from more than 18,000 in 1982 to about 14,000 today, with the bulk of the studio jobs going to perhaps 40 players. "There's a tenth as much work and a tenth as many people doing it," says Jay Berliner, a studio guitarist for the last 25 years.
The foundering studio-musician scene is stark evidence of the synthesizer's impact and inevitability. "As scared as we are of it, there doesn't seem to be anywhere where we can make a stand," says J. Martin Emerson, president of the musicians' union. "You're talking about technological progress, and everybody knows you can't stop that."
Despite criticism that synthesized music can be metallic-sounding and rigid in tempo, it is pervasive; Mr. Berliner estimates that 90 percent of television jingles are made with synthesizers. Says David Horowitz, owner of a New York company that writes and records jingles, the bread-and-butter work for session players: "Advertising is always a follower of pop music, and the Top 40 now is totally dominated by synthesizers."
Many musicians also fear that people are losing their ear for the real thing. They point out that synthesizers get the sounds of instruments right but sacrifice the phrasing and cooperative spirit of live playing. With synthesizers, says Mr. Cobert, "it's usually one person sitting there playing the drum part, the horn part, the string parts. You don't get input from individual players, the energy and spontaneity of different people's interpretations of the music. You get the sound of the snare drum, but not the feel of the drummer reacting to the bass player reacting to the trumpet player."
Studios have traditionally served as a finishing school for hungry young players. The list of people who have worked or continue to work as session musicians includes Duane Allman, Jimmy Page, Chet Atkins, Steve Cropper, Lee Ritenour and Larry Carlton. But with jobs increasingly scarce, it is harder for young players to break in. "I sort of feel like I'm the last generation of studio musicians," says Seth Glassman, a session bassist. "I don't feel anybody lapping at my heels."
What makes the synthesizer so irresistible is its economy and flexibility. Stored in its memory are hundreds of digitally accurate samples of instruments, which can be called up in endless combinations. When linked by the technology known as Midi (Musical Instrument Digital Interface) and a sequencer, a sort of electronic piano roll, several synthesizers can be marshaled by a single player into, literally, a one-man band.
The ranks of session musicians have been thinned before by new technology and changing musical styles, like the switch from solo pop singers, who recorded with large orchestras, to the self-contained rock bands of the 60's. The coming of electrically amplified instruments in the 50's evoked the same fear and loathing many players now have for synthesizers. When the Fender electric bass began to supplant the acoustic stand-up bass, "a lot of players said, 'That's the end of us,' " remembers Herb Bushler, a former session player who contracts musicians for recording dates. "And it was the end of a lot of them, unless they learned to play the Fender bass."
The difference today is that, except for keyboard players and, to a lesser extent, drummers, there is no way for most musicians to compete with synthesizers, short of becoming synthesizer players themselves. Theoretically, many instruments can be adapted to play sampled sounds -- guitar-based synthesizers have been around since the 70's -- but keyboards predominate because of their wide range and simple, linear layout. This has been a windfall for musicians like Mr. Cobert, whose skills on piano and organ transfer readily to synthesizer playing. After programming the synthesizer components, Mr. Cobert plays sampled sounds much the way he would play a piano.
Synthesizers are particularly adept at mimicking ensembles of horns and strings, which has hit those players the hardest. Drummers, meanwhile, have taken a pounding from drum machines, a subspecies of synthesizer that plays drum samples with flawless timing. Because real drums are difficult to record -- microphones must be positioned precisely and sound checks performed -- the machines have been especially welcomed by producers.
"The sound you can get with a drum machine takes forever to get in the studio," says the session drummer Allan Schwartzberg. "A drum machine sounds great, immediately." Mr. Schwartzberg has since reached a detente with the technology: at some sessions, he wires his kit with devices that trigger drum samples when he strikes the actual drums.
The evaporating studio scene has forced session musicians to find other outlets for their talents. Jim Pugh, a session trombone player, is playing in the pit orchestra of the Broadway musical "City of Angels," an engagement he would have declined during his peak session days. Mr. Schwartzberg and others have turned to composing -- the theme to the "Geraldo" television show is his, and last winter he tutored Kevin Dillon for the actor's portrayal of the drummer John Densmore in the movie "The Doors."
There is even talk that the end of the studio grind may be a blessing in disguise. "A lot of the job had become getting the job," says Mr. Pugh, who now maintains a leisurely Sunday-brunch gig at the Blue Note, the jazz club in Greenwich Village. "There's the feeling that you're back to doing what you originally got into it for.
"It's real nice," he says, "to go out and play music just for the sake of the music."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At recording sessions, Allan Schwartzberg wires his kit with devices that trigger drum samples when he strikes the actual drums. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times ) (pg. 39)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PERSON: WALKER, MICHAEL MICHAEL MCMAHON (51%); MICHAEL MCMAHON (51%);

LENGTH: 1385 words

HEADLINE: DANCE VIEW;
Ballet Lovers, Pack Your Luggage

BYLINE: By Anna Kisselgoff

 BODY:
New York City: Dance Capital of the world. That has been the phrase bandied about by critics at home and abroad for the last 25 years, and until very recently, it has usefully described the locus of international dance activity. Foreign companies felt compelled, as a matter of course, to appear regularly in what is, by consensus, also America's cultural hub. Such seasons were essentially more glamorous versions of home-grown creativity in New York City itself -- from George Balanchine and Martha Graham to the novice giving a first concert in a downtown church or loft.
But nowadways, dance lovers -- and that presumably includes critics -- may have to travel more than in the past to keep up with major companies and premieres. Increasingly, New York City is being bypassed by companies as diverse as Mikhail Baryshnikov's new troupe and a touring ensemble from the Kirov Ballet. 
 The reasons are multiple, governed largely by economic considerations (New York is more expensive to play than out-of-town theaters) but also have to do with choice and chance. A new factor is a conscious challenge to New York's supremacy as the focus of an art form -- an attitude embodied in new commissioning projects by the Kennedy Center in Washington and summer dance festivals as well as in the ambitions of regional ballet companies.
Nothing dictates that the best of dance in America should be seen only in New York City. History provides an illuminating precedent. In the most centralized of kingdoms -- 18th-century France -- a historic ballet was staged not at the Paris Opera but in a provincial opera house. That work was "La Fille Mal Gardee," which had its premiere in 1789 in Bordeaux, where the choreographer, Jean Dauberval, was then ballet master.
In our own time, New York City, like Paris, will probably yield little ground as a pre-eminent dance center simply because choreographers thrive amid their peers in a dance community that has educated its public.
Yet for the first time, more areas of the country are seeing what New York City does not -- which is very different from the days when all tours opened in New York or its audiences saw the same premieres as elsewhere, albeit later.
This fall alone, nearly 70 dancers from the Kirov Ballet, including fresh young talent that New York audiences did not see during the Leningrad company's season in 1989, will come no closer to New York City than the Midwest during a national tour. The White Oak Project, Mr. Baryshnikov's troupe with choreography by Mark Morris, opened in Boston. But it is on the same money-making circuit formerly traveled by Baryshnikov and Friends, which always bypassed New York City.
Since Helgi Tomasson became artistic director of the San Francisco Ballet in 1985, the troupe has performed twice (most recently last month) at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. But this radically renewed company has yet to be seen under its new regime in New York. From March 12 to 24, the Kennedy Center will also present the Royal Ballet from Britain, which canceled a season last summer at the Metropolitan Opera House owing to a lack of financing.
This fall, a New Yorker needed to go to Cleveland to catch Rudolf Nureyev with the Cleveland San Jose Ballet. The novelty was not so much an aging superstar in still another role but "The Overcoat," a treatment of Gogol's story by Flemming Flindt.
A ballet fan who wants to keep abreast of developments is now an itinerant ballet fan. Like other smaller Soviet companies that slip into the country with increasing frequency, the Russian Ballet could not reach New York and performed in Atlantic City in September and October. It featured remarkably good, youthful dancers assembled by Vyacheslav Gordeyev, a former Bolshoi star with a strong following.
On another level, the Bolshoi Ballet itself came up with a spinoff group. Yuri Grigorovich, the Bolshoi's director, announced that the world debut of the Bolshoi Ballet-Grigorovich Company, a troupe with recent Soviet ballet school graduates, would take place from Nov. 23 to Dec. 2 at Texas A&M University in College Station, Tex. The university provided technical and rehearsal facilities, which may be another reason why out-of-town bookings are attractive. The troupe, which is performing Mr. Grigorovich's "Nutcracker," will appear in Miami from Dec. 4 through 7; only a last-minute booking into the Brooklyn Academy of Music at Christmastime will bring the production into New York City.
Charles Dillingham, president of the Entertainment Corporation, the commercial producing organization that is touring the Kirov and Bolshoi-Grigorovich groups, denies that the aim was to avoid New York as such. But, he said in a recent interview, the full Bolshoi and Kirov companies would be overexposed if they returned to the Metropolitan Opera House so soon (the Bolshoi was there last summer). The touring contingents (the Kirov's is topped by its stars) perform in cities that did not see the full companies (which the Entertainment Corporation plans to bring to New York every three years). The Bolshoi-Grigorovich venture was, in Mr. Dillingham's words, "a way to introduce a new company for the future."
It is obviously cheaper to put this kind of operation together in an arts center at a university like Texas A&M than in New York. Moreover, anyone aware of performing-arts centers in the rest of the country should not be surprised that they have developed both audiences and new activities.
Hancher Auditorium at the University of Iowa in Iowa City is a prime example. Its director, Wallace Chappell, and its board gave the Joffrey Ballet the residencies that contributed rehearsal time, space and money three years ago toward the company's own "Nutcracker" and reconstruction of "Le Sacre du Printemps." Iowa audiences saw portions or full versions of those productions first.
Hancher Auditorium also books attractions such as the current Kirov tour, which became the first visit ever by Kirov dancers to Iowa City. It is one of the financial contributors to "The Last Supper at Uncle Tom's Cabin/The Promised Land," the new work by the experimental choreographer Bill T. Jones. Unlike the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, which saw the first performance of the Jones piece and is known as an advocate of experimental work, the Hancher Center is also apt to book in "Les Miserables" to satisfy a broader public and stimulate box-office income.
The Kennedy Center too is a multipurpose arts center, and for this reason a new project devised by Sheldon Schwartz, its director of dance programming, could serve as a model for the future. Six ballet companies -- San Francisco, Boston, Houston, Pennsylvania, Pacific Northwest from Seattle, Ballet West from Salt Lake City -- will each commission a choreographer to create a new work that must be first performed at the Kennedy Center.
The center has received a $450,000 challenge grant from the National Endowment for the Arts, the terms of which allow each of the premieres to be transferred, free, to the other five companies (thus creating a potential of six premieres per company per year). Paul Taylor has agreed to a premiere for the Houston Ballet, and John Neumeier will work with Ballet West.
Mr. Schwartz, a former dancer, says candidly that one of his problems in presenting these companies at the Kennedy Center was their overlapping repertories. The commissioning project, he hopes, will stimulate creativity. He calls them national companies and adds, "We at the national cultural centers should feel an obligation to help American creations. I don't see anybody in New York doing this."
With a solid base of subscribers as willing to see the San Francisco Ballet as the New York City Ballet, the Kennedy Center is now the main East Coast venue for most major companies. Even the Roland Petit National Ballet de Marseilles found it worthwhile to zip into the center last January. "I wanted the Kennedy Center to get into the international marketplace without depending on the Met," Mr. Schwartz said.
There will always be those who maintain that the arts need one identifiable center to flourish. In this country, however, competition from a Rome-on-the-Potomac might well benefit an Athens-on-the-Hudson.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY

 BODY:

Hong Kong Tourism Recovering
 HONG KONG -- Hong Kong, a traditional stopover for tourists headed into and out of mainland China, experienced a dramatic decrease in tourism after China's brutal suppression of the pro-democracy movement in Beijing last year. After promoting Hong Kong as a destination in its own right, officials say the colony's tourism is now recovering. They estimate 5.8 million tourists will visit by the end of 1990, compared with 5.4 million last year. (By the end of September, there had been 4.3 million visitors.) Special events like the Hong Kong Arts Festival -- which opens Jan. 19 and runs through Feb. 10 -- have been particularly successful in drawing tourists who live in Taiwan, Japan and other Asian countries, an official said.
The 19th annual Arts Festival will offer a mix of productions -- from London's Royal Shakespeare Company presenting "Les Liaisons Dangereuses," to New York's Joffrey Ballet dancing a tribute to Diaghilev, accompanied by Shanghai Symphony Orchestra, as well as a series of Mozart concerts marking the composer's bicentennial. This will be the British colony's most ambitious festival, with 44 musical, operatic and theater events featuring European and American as well as Hong Kong and other Asian artists. Many events will be staged in Hong Kong's new Cultural Center, a boldly modern complex that was dedicated by Prince Charles and the Princess of Wales last fall. The festival opens with Hong Kong's first production of Mozart's opera, "The Marriage of Figaro," featuring an international cast.
For those who seek something more Asian, the Hubei Province Peking Opera Troupe from China will present a program of mainland operas. Pro Musica Nipponia from Japan will perform classical and modern pieces on traditional Japanese instruments. The Hong Kong Tourist Association in New York (212-869-5008) can advise on seat availability and on how to make reservations on reaching Hong Kong. -- By BARBARA BASLER
 
Treasure Cay Remains Closed
 Treasure Cay, one of the largest resorts in the Family Islands in the Bahamas, will remain closed for renovations when the winter season begins next month. A representative of the resort on Great Abaco Island said it would reopen on Jan. 25 after work was completed. The 190 rooms have been closed since Aug. 26. Bahamian residents have expressed surprise that Treasure Cay, a favorite call for yacht people, closed before Labor Day and will not be ready for the beginning of the winter season. He added that Treasure Cay will no longer be operated on an all-inclusive basis with meals, drinks and sports activities covered by one price. Meanwhile, the resort's marina, tennis courts and golf course as well as time-share units are operational. Information: 800-327-1584.
 
Hollywood Park Survives Fire
 The fire that raced through the backlots at Universal Studios Hollywood on Nov. 6 has disrupted the filming of several movies and television shows, but has had little effect on the park's tourist attractions, according to Universal officials.
"It's virtually business as usual," said Jim Yeager, a Universal spokesman. Most of the visitor attractions, including the stunt shows and thrill rides, were not damaged and the initial reports of King Kong's demise were greatly exaggerated, according to Mr.
Yeager. "Not only was King Kong not destroyed, it sustained only the slightest of damage to its electrical system," he said. Repairs on the 37-foot-tall copy of the gorilla from the movie were expected to take several days.
The fire consumed four acres of Universal's 420-acre lot, an area that includedNew York Street and Courthouse Square, which were the backdrops for such films as "Dick Tracy" and "Back to the Future." Mr. Yeager said Universal planned to rebuild New York Street and Courthouse Square as close to the originals as possible; it has not set a timetable for construction yet.
Officials said they had no plans to offer discounts or other promotions as a result of the fire, as the company's sister park in Orlando did when mechanical problems forced the closing of several rides this past summer.
 
Winter Flights To French Isles
 The nonstop weekend flights from New York's Kennedy International Airport to Martinique and on to Guadeloupe will be resumed by a French charter operation, Minerve Airlines, on Dec. 15. The flights were inaugurated last winter. Major airlines do not fly nonstop to either island from New York. Most of the seats on Minerve's 167-passenger MD-83 aircraft will be sold as part of package tours, but some seats will be available to independent travelers. The planes are scheduled to leave Kennedy at 3 P.M. on Saturdays and arrive at Martinique at 7:30 P.M. They then continue to Guadeloupe, a 40-minute flight. Northbound flights will leave Guadeloupe at 8 A.M. on Saturdays and Martiniqueat 9:45 A.M.
Seven-night packages, including hotel, Continental breakfasts and round-trip air fare, start at $759 a person based on double occupancy, in economy hotels and rise to $1,205 for deluxe hotels. Airport transfers, tax and gratuities are also included. Prices are slightly higher on peak season dates. Round-trip fare alone is $459. Reservations can be made through travel agents, Caribbean tour companies and Council Charter (212-661-4546).
 
Booking Easier For Talgo Train
 It's now easier for Americans to make reservations for Spain's six international Talgo trains. Renfe, the national railroad of Spain, has authorized an American travel marketing company to make reservations for seats and sleeping cabins as well as sell tickets on the Talgos, which run daily between Madrid and Barcelona and five other European cities: Paris, Geneva, Zurich, Milan and Lisbon. Reservations can be made with Donna Brunstad Associates, 25 Sylvan Road South, Westport, Conn. 06880 (800-468-2546 or 203-454-9780). Previously, Americans could purchase tickets in this country -- from FrenchRail, which represents the Spanish railroads -- but they could not make reservations (required before boarding) for seats and sleepers. They had to get in line at the station in Europe when they were ready to travel. Many of the seats, particularly on the Madrid-Paris Talgo and the Pablo Casals between Barcelona and Milan, both overnight trains, are reserved months in advance.
On the daytime Talgos passengers may choose to travel in first or second class. On the overnight trains, travelers have the choice of tourist class (four berths to a cabin), first class (two in a cabin with sink and hot and cold running water) and grand class (two in a cabin with private toilet and shower in addition to a sink). Examples of fares (based on 97 pesetas to $1): Madrid-Paris about $270 a person in double occupancy in first class and $310 in grand class; Barcelona-Milan, $237 in first class, $257 in grand class.

HEADLINE: S. & L. Crisis Muddies Market Outlook

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
THE fallout of the savings and loan bailout, only beginning to be felt in the housing markets of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, will become more evident next year as Federal regulators hasten their efforts to sell single-family homes, co-ops and condominiums that have been seized from failed lending institutions.
Federal officials say sales in the region will be far less widespread than in Texas, Colorado, Florida and other states where tens of thousands of homes must be sold. 
 "What we have seen so far is not going to put enormous pressure on the New York area market," said J. William Bowen, managing vice president of the First Manhattan Consulting Group, a firm that advises real estate lenders and financial services companies.
By last week, Federal regulators for the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency charged with disposing of the assets of insolvent thrifts, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which oversees commercial bank failures, said they had counted only 225 homes and commercial structures to be disposed of in the New York region. But both agencies said the task of sorting through the lenders' assets was far from complete, particularly in the cases of several thrifts taken into Federal conservatorship since June.
Some New York area analysts fear that the number of properties inventoried and slated for sale by the Federal government so far may just be the tip of the iceberg. Frederick J. Mehlman, head of the New York State Attorney General's real estate finance bureau, which has been investigating widespread defaults by the sponsors of cooperative and condominium buildings, said he knew of 500 apartments that had already fallen under control of the Resolution Trust Corporation, although fewer than 20 have so far been offered for sale by the Federal agency.
Any Government real estate sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will take place in a market glutted by for-sale signs, in part because dozens of thrifts and commercial banks that remain solvent are themselves trying to sell off foreclosed properties.
Although no precise count is available, bankers and real estate executives say there are several hundred foreclosed homes on the market in each of the three states.
One reminder of the problems facing New York area lenders came last week with the failure of the Freedom National Bank of Harlem, a Federally chartered commercial bank that had its assets seized by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The institution, New York City's oldest lender focusing on minority business, is one of 12 banks in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut that have been taken into conservatorship by the Federal agency in the last two years.
COMMERCIAL banks have smaller real estate-loan portfolios than thrifts, and F.D.I.C. officials said they had so far counted only 26 properties from the failed banks that must be sold.
But the principal problem is the failure of savings-and-loan institutions, traditionally the largest source of home mortgages. Resolution Trust, created by Congress as part of its 1989 savings and loan bailout initiative, has taken 17 of the New York region's thrifts into conservancy since February 1989.
Nine of 17 have come under Government control over the last six months, and most of their assets remain to be inventoried.
With the regulators under intense pressure from Congress to dispose of real estate quickly, their sales in New York City and its suburbs are bound to hurt a housing market that is already in a deep recession.
"Any forced sales are going to dampen the market further," said Eugene Sherman, senior economist for the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York. He added that the Government sales will be "a bad thing happening against a bad background."
Part of the Government's plan was described in October by William Seidman, chairman of Resolution Trust. In a speech to a business group in Washington, he said the agency would try during the first three months of 1991 to sell "almost all" of the 30,000 homes and land parcels it has so far counted in its national inventory that are appraised at under $100,000.
"The faster disposition of these small assets will maximize our returns by freeing up our staff to concentrate on large sales where the real dollars are concerned," he said. Other agency officials said most of the sales would be auctions, some of them absolute auctions with no minimum price.
Some had feared that the government's plan to dispose of properties quickly would undermine already weak housing markets, particularly in the Southwest. But their worries have so far proven unfounded. In Houston and Dallas, realtors said last week that there had not been any evidence of panic selling in advance of the government sales, and some maintained that their housing markets could only be strengthened by the elimination of the huge backlog of properties held by Resolution Trust.
By far the greatest number of homes seized by the Government is in Texas, where Resolution Trust has published a list of more than 6,000 properties -- mostly single-family houses and condominiums appraised under $100,000. In the New York metropolitan area, not many of the properties to be sold will fit Mr. Seidman's description of "small assets" because the real estate boom lifted market values in this area far above $100,000 on most homes.
But Resolution Trust said it would approach the region's market next year as a determined seller, just as it plans to do in Texas, even when it is trying to dispose of expensive properties.
"It depends on the complexity of marketing the property, but in some cases we will be using the auction process" in the New York area, said Andrea Plater, an agency spokeswoman at the eastern regional office in Atlanta.
For prospective buyers, the first listing of properties that the agency is trying to sell is already available, in many cases at local libraries. Since August, Resolution Trust has been distributing its first Asset Inventory of real estate in each state, which will be updated as properties are sold and others fall into Government hands. For now, all the properties are being listed with local brokers.
In the New York region, the offerings are diverse, if not extensive. For the affluent, there is 1059 Peguot Avenue in Southport, Conn., one of the nation's most expensive suburban enclaves. The four-bedroom colonial lacks floors or fixtures for its kitchen and bathrooms, which were left unfinished when its builder was foreclosed on by his lender, Community Federal Savings and Loan of Bridgeport. That lender was taken under Government conservatorship this year.
The asking price for the Southport house, first offered at $815,000, is now $650,000.
Those on a lower budget might consider 6 Stuart Lane in West Windsor, N.J., a four-bedroom stucco residence offered at $315,000, or 273 Densign Court in Mays Landing, N.J., a four-bedroom brick house listed in only "fair" condition and offered at $69,900. There is also 129 Hoyt Street in Dunkirk, N.Y., another fixer-upper with three bedrooms that is listed at only $34,500.
The Government listings also include more than 40 New York City co-ops and condominiums, many of them occupied by rent-regulated tenants who elected not to buy their apartments when their buildings were converted. Among them are eight condominiums a 444 East 57th Street, eight co-op apartments in a large complex at 64th Avenue and Burns Street in Rego Park, Queens, and seven co-op units at 24 West 75th Street.
Resolution Trust has raised a storm of protest in its efforts to dispose of some of the apartments.
In September, saying it was under orders from Congress to get the highest prices it could for the assets of failed thrifts, the agency sent letters threatening to evict eight rental tenants at 444 East 57th Street, a luxury building near Sutton Place.
THE Federal regulators maintained that the tenants, with rent-stabilized leases, paid less in rent than was necessary to cover the monthly carrying charges assessed on their apartments. If the apartments were vacant, the officials said, they would be far more attractive to buyers.
But the evictions would violate New York State law and would require Resolution Trust to invoke Federal statutes to attempt to circumvent those of a state. Attorney General Robert Abrams, responding to the eviction threat, said hundreds of rent-regulated tenants could be vulnerable to losing their homes if the Government evicted those at 444 East 57th Street.
Mr. Abrams said his staff would challenge the evictions in court. Since then, Resolution Trust has temporarily withdrawn its eviction threat at the East Side building and said it would give further study to how it will deal with the rent-regulated apartments. Last week, spokesmen for both the Federal agency and Mr. Abrams said the matter was still under study in Washington.
And while the legal questions surrounding co-ops and condominiums remain unresolved, real estate executives say the bigger question facing the New York region is how many more properties will fall into Federal Government control and wind up on Resolution Trust's for-sale list.
Properties make their way onto the list only after they are foreclosed on by a thrift institution and the thrift itself is taken into conservancy by the Government.
"There appears to be no bright light at the end of the tunnel in the Northeast," said Joseph E. Robert, chairman of the J. E. Robert Company, one of the largest managers of property seized by Resolution Trust.
He said the number of listings in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut would grow rapidly as Federal officials sort through the assets of thrifts they have taken over in recent months, as the thrifts they control foreclose on more property and as more thrifts fail.
"The number of properties has got to grow significantly in 1991," he added.
Indeed, the Federal takeover of failed thrifts, which had become widespread in many regions during 1989, did not begin to pick up momentum in the New York region until this year. Among those seized over the last six months whose assets have not yet been fully inventoried and offered for sale are the Ensign Bank in Manhattan, Nassau Federal Savings and Loan of Brooklyn, Whitestone Federal Savings and Loan of Whitestone and Yorkville Federal Savings and Loan of the Bronx.
In New Jersey, recently seized thrifts include Nassau Federal Savings and Loan of Princeton, the Mutual Aid Savings and Loan of Manansquan, United Savings of Paterson and United Savings and Loan of Trenton. And in Connecticut, the Charter Federal Saving and Loan of Stamford and Financial Federal Savings of Hartford have both fallen into Federal conservatorship since June.
In an analysis of the documents filed with the Government, Mr. Bowen of the First Manhattan Consulting group found that the 17 thrifts under control of Resolution Trust in the New York region had foreclosed real estate on their books with a total appraised value of $363.1 million. Although the number may seem vast to home buyers, he said it was "not a big deal" in a market where the total appraised value of real estate would run far in excess of $100 billion.
Still, Mr. Bowen's analysis showed that the number of foreclosures was all but certain to grow. He found that the 17 thrifts had "problem loans" to property owners and developers -- loans that were 90 days or more past due -- totaling $1.6 billion.
For now, disposal of assets is moving at a snail's pace.
Although interested buyers can read through six separate volumes of listings in Resolution Trust's Asset Inventory, including homes, apartment buildings, commercial structures and land in all states, brokers assigned to sell the properties in the New York region say there are been many more frivolous inquires than serious buyers.
"PEOPLE seem to have the impression that they can buy these properties at such incredibly reduced prices that they are a steal, and that's not the case," said Doug Bisset, broker with William Pitt Real Estate of Fairfield, Conn., who has been trying to sell Resolution Trust's unfinished colonial home in Southport. He said there had been more than 20 inquires on the house since it came on the market in June, most from people in New York City, Connecticut and Boston who had found it listed in the Asset Inventory. Some made offers, he said, but they were rejected as ridiculously low.
A broker in Queens, Margie Elstein, has been assigned responsibility by Resolution Trust for selling several of its co-op apartments. She said inquiries have come from New York, Boston and Philadelphia.
But she said most of the prospective buyers lost interest immediately when they learned the apartments were occupied by rent-regulated tenants who cannot be evicted unless Resolution Trust carries out its threat to circumvent New York State law.
Those willing to buy the occupied apartments as long-term investments have another problem, she said. With co-ops under financial strain across New York City, she said, banks are unwilling to finance investment in occupied units. That means anyone willing to buy them would have to pay cash. So far, she said, one vacant co-op in the Rego Park complex has been sold for $29,000. None of the occupied apartments has been sold.

HEADLINE: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester;
Fairfield's Back in the Relocation Game

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
WHILE New York City fights to retain companies considering moves to the suburbs, southwestern Fairfield County, where so many New York companies resettled more than a decade ago, is experiencing a surge of newcomers. This time, they are smaller companies and divisions of the large ones, rather than huge corporations.
 Local brokers say the resultant employee relocations, which have risen by 25 percent in the last year, are a glimmer of light in an otherwise dim housing market. 
 "Fairfield County was born because people wanted to move out of New York," said Peter Helie, president of residential real estate at William Pitt Realtors in Stamford. "That beat still goes on."
 Holger Arning, the company's senior commercial broker, said he believes that 68 companies -- mostly from Manhattan and Westchester County -- will have moved into the county by the end of the year, equaling last year's total. Those that have already moved this year include the New York offices of Hitachi Instruments, Chevron Oil International, Eastman Kodak, Chrysler Capital Corporation, Corroon & Black Insurance, and General Electric Capital Corporation.
 Office vacancy rates countywide have declined since the third quarter of 1989, going from about 29 to about 20 percent vacant, according to the Grubb & Ellis commercial realty office in Stamford. As the offices fill up at a rate of about 600,000 square feet a year, the demand for housing rises.
 "The exodus of companies has all but stopped, and we have a decline in the number of houses that corporations must sell after employees have left," said Ann Moore, relocation director for William Pitt.
 The US West Capital Corporation, which provides financing for customers of the Denver telephone company, relocated from Denver to Stamford in January. Like many capital corporations, the company needs to be near New York's banks and credit markets, but the employees like the quality of life in the suburbs, said Judith Thomas, its human resources director. Another incentive has been the decline in residential real estate prices.
 Timothy Gallagher of suburban Chicago is one of several people recruited by US West and transferred to Stamford. He sold his house in Willamette, Ill., on his own and, working through US West's relocation program, bought a house in New Canaan, getting a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage at just under 10 percent from Prudential Home Mortgage. "The house had been for sale for two years and the asking price had come down 30 percent," he said. "The location is a strong drawing card. We have the benefits of the city without having to be there."
 His only problem now is one endemic to Fairfield. "We are trying to hire clerical help at the office and it's very difficult," he said. "They can't afford to live here."
 Listings in most Gold Coast towns now include a few houses under $200,000, and dozens between $200,000 and $300,000. "Not since the early 1980's have we had inventory at these prices," said Douglas Milne, president of Kelly Milne Realtors in Darien. Most relocating executives look for homes in the $350,000 to $600,000 range, most brokers said.
 Among Mr. Milne's recent customers are Anthony and Susan Ibarguen, transfers from Boca Raton, Fla., who bought a house in New Canaan last July. Mr. Ibarguen is a vice-president at JWP, a technical services company based in Purchase, N.Y. His wife, Susan, is Westport sales manager.
 The Ibarguens, former Manhattan residents, ruled out living in New York City or Westchester. "New York taxes are outrageously high," said Mr. Ibarguen, "and when we go into the city now it's shocking. Whether it's the people on the streets, or the lack of space, or being afraid to use the subways, it's not the life style we want."
 Their relocation involved only moving costs. Their Florida apartment was a rental, and friends in Connecticut steered them to realtors and mortgage lenders, many of whom offered better terms when they learned the couple was being moved by an employer, Mr. Ibarguen said.
 Relocating an employee's family can cost up to $50,000. US West paid for the Gallaghers' moving, house-hunting trips and temporary housing and paid some points on their new mortgage. To save monthly carrying charges, repair bills and commissions, some companies urge employees to sell their own houses. In return, the company may pay off several thousand dollars worth of interest on the employee's new mortgage. Some companies hire local placement services.
Home Buyers Assistance Corporation in Westport does not buy or sell real estate, or finance mortgages. "We provide advice and counsel to the transferees," said Robert J. Vossler, the president, "matching towns to pocketbooks, evaluating rental against purchase, discussing financing, schools and services in the area and finding the appropriate real estate agent and lender."
His county tour costs $600. "To keep a $200,000-a-year executive happy, the companies think it's worth it," he said.
OTHER relocation firms include Prudential Connecticut Realty, based in West Hartford. Its Fairfield County office in Norwalk just added three people to the staff because "companies are getting interested again in relocating to Fairfield County," said Linda Lara, the agency's president.
 In the early 80's, when interest rates were climbing, Homequity relocation service opened in Wilton and "transferees were first perceived as real buyers, not tire-kickers," said Linda Alt, Homequity's president. Today it moves 40,000 families a year for Champion International and other local companies.
 Relocations, once viewed as steps up the corporate ladder, had been rejected in recent years by many executives who resented disrupting family life. Now, as the economy slows, it is regaining acceptance as employees realize that somebody else may be waiting to take the job.
"We placed an ad in The New York Times for a director of financial planning," said Ms. Thomas at US West, where 150 management people will eventually be hired, "and we got 600 answers."

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

M.C.I. Rent Increase
 
Question: What are the sorts of major capital improvement expenses for which a rent-stabilized tenant can be charged? Would pointing, for example -- which it seems to me is maintenance rather than an improvement -- qualify? What about new plumbing or the cost of a lobby renovation? . . . Mary Watson, Manhattan
 
 Answer: It would depend on the extent of the work. According to the New York City Rent Stabilization Code, most work must be a new installation and not the repair of old equipment. New plumbing would qualify.
Some procedures, like pointing and waterproofing, could be eligible for M.C.I. rent increases. However, to qualify, any work must be done not on part of the building or in some units, but buildingwide, and benefit all tenants.
As for lobby renovations,Thomas R. Viola, a spokesman for the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, said this kind of work would probably not qualify for M.C.I. increases unless it was done in connection with some other type of capital improvement project in the lobby.
"If an owner made some changes in the way the lobby looked in connection with other improvements like new elevators or new buzzer system," said Mr. Viola, "part of the expenses for the renovation project might qualify. But redecorating would not qualify for M.C.I. increases."
For more information, call the Rent Hotline at the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal at (718) 739-6400 or send for fact sheet #11, available at both Manhattan locations: 156 Williams Street, N.Y., N.Y. 10038, and 163 West 125th Street, 5th Floor, N.Y., N.Y. 10027.
 
 Sublet Surcharge
 
 Question: I own a cooperative apartment that I sublet. When I bought it there was a 10 percent surcharge on the maintenance for subletting. A letter from the management recently stated that the by-laws of the co-op had been changed, increasing the sublet fee to 20 percent of the maintenance.
Can the board raise the maintenance fees for some owners but not for the majority of shareholders? . . . Howard Furman, Howard Beach, Queens
 
 Answer: No. But the sublet fee is is a surcharge, not a maintenance increase. The Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court upheld the right of co-op boards to impose "reasonable" sublet fees without the approval of a majority of the shareholders. The fact that the bylaws for your co-op have been amended to increase the sublet fee strengthens the board's position.
 
 Sublet Without a Lease
 
Question: I am subletting a stabilized apartment from an acquaintance without a formal lease. Our arrangement is that I can live there as long as I wish. Conditions have deteriorated over the last few years. Paint is peeling from the ceiling and the contact paper on the walls has started to come off. Repairs are needed. Do I have any legal recourse? . . . W. J. F., Manhattan
 
 Answer: No. If you cannot persuade the prime tenant to improve the conditions, your only options without a legal lease are to live with them, do them yourself or move out.
Your situation illustrates the risk of subletting without a lease. Both you and the person who has allowed you to live in the apartment are vulnerable to eviction. The rent stabilization rules give prime tenants the right to sublet for two years in any four-year period and a landlord can not unreasonably deny a prime tenant the right to sublet. But the rules also require that subtenants have subleases signed by landlords.
