HEADLINE: The '91 Budget's Impact on Homeowners

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
THE nation's 1991 deficit-reduction package will make real estate a slightly less attractive tax shelter for the most affluent families while continuing incentives for low-income housing, according to accountants and tax experts.
The legislation leaves in place the deductibility of mortgage interest and local property taxes, but starting next year taxpayers will have the amount they can claim for those and other itemized deductions reduced by 3 percent for every dollar of income above $100,000. That change represents more a nibble than a bite. 
 Real estate related deductions will become slightly less valuable to those at the upper end of the income spectrum. For families with incomes below $100,000, however, the full amount of their mortgage payments and property taxes will remain deductible.
"Many people will be paying higher taxes and getting less deductions," said Jeffrey Perone, a tax partner in Deloitte & Touche, one of the nation's largest accouting firms. "The higher your income, the bigger the bite."
Others said the 1991 tax law changes will do more to weaken than support real estate markets that have already slumped into recession.
Particularly vulnerable are New York, New Jersey and Connectict, which are home to the nation's largest concentration of upper-income taxpayers.
"People are going to feel less wealthy, and they will think twice about buying new homes," said David L. Milstein, chairman of the national real estate practice of Coopers & Lybrand, an accounting firm based in Manhattan.
"Layered on top of our weak real estate markets, I do not see the new tax law as positive."
Nevertheless, the changes in the 1991 tax code will have a less dramatic impact on real estate than the sweeping overhaul enacted in 1986. Under the 1986 act, investors, who had previously been allowed to deduct interest payments on an unlmited number of properties, were limited to their own home and one vacation home or investment property.
Passive loss provisions, which had attracted investors into rental housing and commercial ventures, were largely eliminated and depreciation schedules were lengthened, further reducing the returns of real estate investors.
Although the 1991 revisions will be modest by comparison, real estate industry executives maintain that the decision by Congress to reduce itemized deductions, even by a little, is a troubling sign.
"It bothers us more in principal than practice," said John Tucillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors. "It means that the deductibility of mortgage interest is on the table and could remain on the table in the future."
Some provisions of the tax code and Federal budget that for years have been supporting low- and moderate-income housing, and had been threatened with elimination in 1991, survived the Congressional ax.
One is the mortgage revenue bond program, used by most states to raise capital through tax-free bond issues, with the funds used to make low-interest mortgage loans available to low- and moderate-income home buyers. Although qualifications vary from state to state, the mortgages are usually offered to families buying their first homes.
"We really were at risk," said Carmen A. Culpeper, president of the State of New York Mortgage Agency, or Sonyma, which issues the mortgage revenue bonds in New York. At times in the lengthy negotiations over the Federal budget, support for the state programs was deleted but ultimately the program was restored.
NEW YORK'S program, which is larger than those in any of the other states except Alaska, has committed $2.6 billion in mortgages to 36,000 home buyers since 1983. Income qualifications vary depending on the cost of housing in different parts of the state -- New York City families can qualify with higher incomes than families in Buffalo, for example -- but Ms. Culpeper said the typical family getting a mortgage has $33,000 in income and is buying a $74,000 house.
Those receiving Sonyma mortgages pay 8.5 percent interest and can finance up to 95 percent of the price of the homes.
Another Federal program that was targeted for elimination by some in Congress was the Low Income Housing Tax Credit, offered since 1986. The program has attracted dozens of corporate sponsors into low-income housing development by offering them credits that can be used to reduce their corporate income taxes. Originally authorized for three years, the program was due to be phased out in 1991.
Although proponents had lobbied Congress heavily to have it extended indefinitely, the compromise budget package for 1991 extends it only one year, and even that concession came in last-minute negotiations.
"THIS is the only Federal subsidy we have left for rental housing designed for the truly poor," said Martin D. Levine, vice president of the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, which has invested $150 million in the tax credit projects.
One of the biggest beneficiaries of the program has been New York City, which has relied heavily on the tax credit program in its $5.1 billion, 10-year plan to rehabilitate city-owned property into low-income housing, as well as build new apartments and houses for poor and moderate-income people. Investors in the New York City program include Fannie Mae, the American Express Company, the Brooklyn Union Gas Company and Pfizer, among others
"We see wide support for this program," Mr. Levine said. "We had hoped to see it extended permanently."
Some real estate industry groups lobbied heavily, but unsuccessfully, for new investment incentives or at least the restoration of those lost in the 1986 overhaul. One such incentive would have been provided in the budget proposal by President Bush, which would have lowered capital gains taxes. While most experts said the measure would have had its most pronounced effect on stocks, bonds and other more liquid investments, it might also have lured more money into real estate ventures.
Under the compromise passed by Congress, householders in the income tax "bubble" -- those currently paying a top rate of 33 percent -- might benefit by waiting to sell their homes until next year.
That is because the capital gains rate they pay on the sale would be the same as their tax rate this year, but will be reduced to 28 percent in 1991.
Nonetheless, analysts said they did not expect the slight relief in capital gains taxes to lend much encouragement to those considering real estate purchases.
Another proposal, advocated widely by the real estate industry, but rejected by Congress, was to restore the passive-loss provisions of the pre-1986 tax code. Those provisions allowed large investors in rental property who were not getting enough rental income to meet their expenses to deduct part of the loss from their income for tax purposes.
Under current law, left intact by Congress, passive-loss deductions can be claimed, but only by small investors on a tightly limited basis. Only those making less than $100,000 qualify and they can claim no more than $25,000 in deductions from their taxable income.

HEADLINE: Collectors of Classic Jigsaw Puzzles Love to Pick Up the Pieces

BYLINE: By CAROLYN BATTISTA

 BODY:
IN 1908, jigsaw puzzles were advertised as "all the rage of Newport." Now the puzzles are much the rage in Connecticut. Craftsmen are cutting them from wood, manufacturers are stamping them out of cardboard and at least one collector is saving the puzzles that were such a hit with the smart set in Rhode Island.
"There's a considerable interest," said Anne D. Williams, an economics professor at Bates College in Maine and author of the just-released "Jigsaw Puzzles, an Illustrated History and Price Guide," published by Wallace-Homestead Book Company. She and other fans say old puzzles are part of history, contemporary ones present new challenges, and a good puzzle from any era is simply fun to assemble. 
 Stephen J. Olin of Woodbridge, a toy collector, said he has put together each of the 200 antique puzzles in his collection. The walls of his home are adorned with completed, framed 19th-century puzzles, some of them depicting steam-powered boats and locomotives. Shelves and tables hold jigsaw puzzles with interlocking pieces and puzzles of strips or blocks.
Mr. Olin pointed proudly to "The Permutation Dissected Map of the United States," made by Milton Bradley in 1868. Its rectangular pieces were assembled to show a map of the nation as it was then. "Look, no Oklahoma," Mr. Olin said, "only Indian Territory."
He also displayed an 1876 puzzle featuring the buildings of that year's Phildadelphia Centennial Exposition. The celebration introduced to the public the power scroll saw, or jigsaw, that soon produced fancy woodwork and intricate puzzles.
An 1891 puzzle in Mr. Olin's collection advertises Hood's sarsaparilla, an all-purpose remedy. Others are from the E. I. Horsman Company, which promoted its wares as "all the rage of Newport."
Professor Williams noted that puzzles were also the rage during the Depression, when some people made puzzles to make money, and many people had ample time to do them.
Faith Kenton, a kindergarten teacher in Willimantic, said her mother and brother cut puzzles during the 1930's and sold them door to door. Recently, Mrs. Kenton began cutting them herself, she said, because she wanted puzzles that would help children learn and that would not bend, break or peel.
"I specialize in children's literature puzzles," she said, adding that her puzzles have illustrations of classics like Mother Goose rhymes, with words printed on them. "It's exciting. You have kids who don't want to look at letters, but they'll do a puzzle. And then you can read it together."
Mrs. Kenton said she still has her mother's worn saw but uses a new electric scroll saw with a fine blade to cut puzzles from birch plywood. Besides making puzzles for her classroom, she operates Primary Pieces, a part-time business through which she sells puzzles for $5 to $30 each.
"Teachers are my best customers and grandparents my second best," she said.
For Robert Godfrey of Thompson, making wooden puzzles became a full-time occuaption a few years ago, when he retired from his job as a sales manager for the Monsanto Company. He said he was inspired by his grandfather's puzzles, long kept in his family's Maine cottage.
"Every summer, we'd drag them out," Mr. Godfrey recalled. "They were cut back in the 1920's and 1930's, and today they're just as good as they were then."
When he decided to make such puzzles, "at first, I had to experiment," he said. Now his creations of basswood plywood range from simple puzzles for children to more complex ones for adults. Each includes Mr. Godfrey's trademark, a piece shaped like a flying gull.
Some of his puzzles include custom pieces. A puzzle for a devoted owner of corgis, for instance, included pieces shaped like the dogs. Mr. Godfrey said he makes adult puzzles "as difficult as possible," employing diabolical devices like a straight line that does not form an edge but is in the middle.
 
Presidential Note
 Mr. Godfrey often makes puzzles of decorative maps of the Maine coast, and he recently sent one to President Bush depicting Walker Point, the area of the Bush family home in Kennebunkport. "I got a nice thank-you note," he said.
Mr. Godfrey charges around $10 for a children's puzzle of 8 to 10 pieces and up to $300 for an adult puzzle of 500 to 600 pieces. He said that his customers include older people who fondly remember the puzzles of their youth and younger people who say they have never seen such things before.
Professor Williams noted that Stave Puzzles Inc. of Norwich, Vt., has sparked interest in well-crafted wooden puzzles. The company, established in 1974, makes intricate wooden puzzles, selling for $200 to $3,000 apiece, that are cut by hand and can be made to order.
Liza Weihman of Greenwich said that she is fascinated by the beauty and complexity of Stave puzzles and regularly orders them cut with special features, like pieces that represent sports enjoyed by her three children. For a cousin who likes good wine and classic cars, she ordered a puzzle with pieces shaped like wine bottles and the Bentley insignia.
Stave puzzles "are really brilliant, and they become like popcorn," Mrs. Weihman said. "But you find out how selfish you are. You don't want anyone to help you."
Mass-produced cardboard puzzles are also successful in Connecticut. The Bepuzzled Division of Lombard Marketing in Bloomfield produces booklets containing mystery stories that a reader cannot solve without assembling an accompanying jigsaw puzzle.
 
Map of Soviet Union
 "You get literal and visual clues," said Mary Ann Lombard, who owns the company with her husband, Robert, adding that business is good. Among the Bepuzzled titles (around $10 to $20 each) are "Death by Diet," "Double Cross" and "Bomb." The customers for the latter, Mrs. Lombard said, include the Central Intelligence Agency.
The Great American Puzzle Factory in Norwalk produces cardboard puzzles that cost $5 to $15. One is a map of the Soviet Union designed by Kirill Doron, an artist from Moscow who now lives in Redding.
"People really want to know more about the Soviet Union, and this is a fun way to learn," said Pat Duncan, president of the company. Other Great American items include "Where's Waldo?" puzzles, to accompany the popular series of "Waldo" books for children, and "Celestial Planisphere," which shows the stars and glows in the dark.
Ms. Duncan also said that business is good, noting that people are especially likely to stay home with puzzles "when the economy is not doing too well."
Although her employees are busy, Ms. Duncan said, they know how to relax. "Sometimes we put the phones on hold," she said, "and do a puzzle."

HEADLINE: Tape Recorder vs. Court Reporter

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
A STATE Supreme Court committee's search for the most efficient way to insure accurate records of court proceedings has intensified a debate over the use of tape recorders in the state's trial courts.
Though electronic recorders have been a fixture in many New Jersey courtrooms for almost 20 years, opponents of the technology say their use in civil and criminal trial courts will have a negative impact on the administration of justice and could be prejudicial to poor litigants. 
 Lawyers say the use of recorders restricts their ability to move about the courtroom and makes it difficult to comply with jurors' requests to rehear specific testimony without exposing the jurors to exchanges they should not hear, like objectionable testimony or conferences at the bench between the lawyers and the judge. In addition, they say, tape recordings often result in ambiguous, incomplete and even incorrect transcripts of the proceedings.
Proponents of electronic recording, however, say that properly operated modern tape recorders can do everything a human stenographer can do and more. They say recorders provide the most cost-effective, efficient and reliable method of obtaining accurate, permanent records of proceedings.
Caught in the middle of the debate are the hundreds of certified shorthand reporters, 200 of whom are official court reporters, and scores of students of the profession who are striving to keep one step ahead of the advancing technology that threatens their future livelihood.
 
Two Views on Accuracy
 "Basically, if you want an accurate record, then there's only one way to get it, and that's with a court reporter," said Barbara Johnson, a certified shorthand reporter in West Orange.
But Charles Gspann, of the Sound-Arts Company, an Ocean Township concern that installs sound systems in courtrooms, said: "There is no question about it. The right piece of recording equipment in a courtroom will far and away exceed anything that one human can do."
Tape recorders and court stenographers have been quietly coexisting, each with its own niche in the court system. But that balance began to shift when Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz of the State Supreme Court acknowledged late last year that he was considering replacing some retiring court reporters with tape recorders.
Lawyers and court reporters objected, and as a result Justice Wilentz appointed a 24-member committee to study the issue and make recommendations.
 
Public Hearings Held
 At two public hearings last month at the New Jersey State Bar Association Center in New Brunswick, the committee heard testimony. The majority of those who testified spoke in support of the court reporters.
"I would say that the organized bar is generally in favor of court reporters," said Judge Herman D. Michels, presiding judge of the Appellate Division of Superior Court and chairman of the committee.
"I also solicited the views of all the judges, and I would say that many of them are in favor of the court reporters, although those who already work with electronic recorders find it acceptable," he said.
 Judge Michels said he expected to hold at least one more hearing to give those familiar with the recording technology an opportunity to make a presentation. In addition, he said, the Certified Shorthand Reporters Association in New Jersey and the State Bar Association have asked for another opportunity to address the committee.
"I want the committee to see how this all stacks up when both sides are compared," Judge Michels said. "We hope to reach our conclusions by June."
Tape systems, which cost about $5,000 a courtroom, are considered to be an economical alternative to stenographers in some situations. Most lawyers say that nonjury proceedings in the Family Court and the Appellate Division do not require a court reporter.
But a reporter is essential, they say, in the trial courts.
"The tape just doesn't cut it," said Thomas J. Vesper, president of the New Jersey affiliate of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America. Mr. Vesper's organization, many lawyers and the State Bar Association are opposed to the use of recorders in trial courts.
One of the reasons that lawyers disdain electronic recording, Mr. Vesper said, is that transcripts made from tapes are often incomplete, with words like "inaudible," "unintelligible" and "indiscernible" inserted in place of words or phrases the transcriber could not understand.
 
'Whoa, One at a Time'
 That occurs, he said, when two people speak at the same time, or when extraneous noise is picked up by the tape recorder's microphones. With a court reporter, Mr. Vesper said, that can be avoided.
 "When a court reporter hears two people talking at the same time," Mr. Vesper said, "he can just put up his hand and say, 'Whoa, one at a time.' " And if a witness's testimony is obscured by outside noise, he said, the reporter can simply ask the person to repeat what was said.
Those in favor of sound recordings, however, say they are more accurate, more economical and less subject to the personal interpretation of the transcriber.
"The court stenographer is the only person who can read his own notes," said Terry Gribben, owner of an Eatontown tape transcription service. "With us, if you don't agree with the transcript, you can just get the tape and listen to it yourself."
 In addition, Ms. Gribben said, the concerns expressed about the clarity of the recordings and monitoring of the proceedings are exaggerated.
"There's a live person running that machine," she said. "And that person can monitor the recording and make the same suggestions that a court stenographer can if two people are talking at the same time."
 
Used in Municipal Courts
 Tape recorders are now used in all of the state's municipal courts and in the Superior Court's Family Division, Special Civil Part and Law Division for some nonjury trials.
In addition, the State Supreme Court, the Appellate Division and the State Tax Court also record their proceedings.
Most of the state's trial courts, however, use official court reporters who have been hired from among the approximately 900 certified shorthand reporters licensed in New Jersey.
In 1981, Justice Wilentz froze the number of official court reporters at 215. Since then, as the result of retirements and a subsequent hiring freeze on all state jobs, that number has fallen to about 200. The average salary for an official court reporter is $45,000.
The courts that now regularly use reporters instead of recorders are the civil and criminal trial courts. And for trials, lawyers say, stenographers are far superior to tape recorders.
"With a tape recorder the lawyer is handcuffed to the counsel table," said David Ben-Asher, a lawyer in the state's Office of the Public Defender. "He's restricted in his mode of argument; he can't move away from the counsel table toward a witness or the jury."
In courts that use tape recorders, Mr. Ben-Asher said, participants must always be near a specific microphone in order to be identified on the recording. In most courtrooms, four microphones are used -- one in front of the judge, another at the witness stand and one at each counsel table.
As a result, Mr. Ben-Asher said, it is difficult to record conferences at the bench between the judge and the lawyers and private conferences in the judge's chambers, which are part of the trial's official records.
And transcripts of recorded proceedings, he said, are often inferior to those provided by stenographers.
 
More Reversals Expected
 "We think that there will be a greater number of verdicts reversed on appeal simply because the record can't be re-created," he said.
As a result, Mr. Ben-Asher said, some litigants will hire their own court reporters if the hearing is being electronically recorded.
"And that is something that indigent litigants have less of a capacity to do," he said.
Steven M. Koskinen, an official court reporter in Superior Court in Hudson County, agreed.
"We're seeing that people with money are bringing their own freelance reporters into court," he said. "There are going to be two forms of justice: one for the rich and one for the poor."
Mr. Koskinen said that to demonstrate the inaccuracy of the sound recording technology, he recently ordered second transcripts of tape recordings that had already been transcribed, with the second set prepared by a different transcription company from the first.
"In about 200 transcript pages there were over 1,000 differences in the actual words that appear," Mr. Koskinen said. The transcripts, he said, were turned over to the committee.
"The tape recorder does not record language," Mr. Koskinen said. "It just mindlessly records sounds."
 
Eliminating Many Problems
 But Frank Gspann, vice president of Sound-Arts and son of Charles Gspann, said that the new "digital audio tape" technologies, or DAT, can eliminate many of the problems now associated with electronic recording.
"With a good, four-channel DAT machine, four people can talk simultaneously, and you can later identify what everybody said," Mr. Gspann said. Such a system, he said, would cost about $6,000 to install.
"Technically, all of the problems can be addressed," he said. "But we're dealing with lawyers and judges who don't understand technology and what's doable and what's not doable."
Mr. Gspann said he would demonstrate the benefits of the new machines to the Supreme Court committee at its next hearing.
 
Meeting the Competition
 And while the proponents of electronic recording extol the virtues of their advanced technology, the new wave of court reporters emerging from stenography schools are being prepared to meet their competition on equal terms.
"Court reporters do not believe that this is a new technology replacing the old," said Stanley Rizman, an official court reporter in United States District Court in Newark and vice president of the Certified Shorthand Reporters Association in New Jersey. "Court reporters believe that they themselves are the new technology."
Mr. Rizman was referring to the ability that court reporters now have to connect their stenographic machines to computers. The computer, using a dictionary of stenographic terms, then translates the reporter's cryptic shorthand into everyday English.
As a result, instantaneous transcripts of the proceedings can be made available to the judge and lawyers during the trial.
Though no such systems are now in place in New Jersey courts, they are being used in courts in other states and in some Federal courtrooms.
Indeed, students who are now training to become certified shorthand reporters must be familiar with the new technology in addition to being able to take dictation on their machines at the rate of 225 words a minute.
 
Concern on Replacement
But even armed with their technological advances, and backed by most of the lawyers in the state, some court reporters in training are nevertheless concerned with the prospect of eventually being replaced by a machine.
"It's really dog eat dog in this business," said Crizella Smith, a 25-year-old Fort Lee resident, who is just completing three years of training at the American Business Academy in Hackensack.
"It's constant practice, keeping your confidence up and building speed," Ms. Smith said. "You look around and you know you're going to be competing with all the other students for jobs. And then you hear that they want to start bringing in tape recorders. Sometimes I think it's just not fair."

HEADLINE: For Kean, Drew Has Become a Laboratory for His Ideas

BYLINE: By PRISCILLA VAN TASSEL

DATELINE: MADISON

 BODY:
TEN months after leaving public office, former Gov. Thomas H. Kean says he is thriving in his new role as Drew University's 10th president. A bicycle has replaced the state car and driver, and Cabinet meetings have given way to faculty meetings, but his new position is allowing him to pursue the some of the education reform issues that meant so much to him as Governor.
As Governor, Mr. Kean was accustomed to speaking at length and in the superlative about the importance of schooling. These days he still does, only instead of prodding New Jersey's diverse network of public schools and colleges into improvement, the 2,200-student university has become his laboratory. 
 "I don't think it's hyperbole and I don't think it's impossible, but I want to make Drew the finest small university in the country," Mr. Kean said in an interview.
 
'A Virtual Drew Demigod'
 Even with these aspirations, living up to the standard the Drew community has set for its new leader may be somewhat difficult. An article in the alumni magazine said that Mr. Kean was regarded as a "consummate fund-raiser, mediator and publicity gold mine -- a virtual Drew demigod." The Theological School dean gave Mr. Kean a sign that read, "Please don't walk on the water."
Mr. Kean said he had been in the water a lot since coming to Drew, but about the only mistake that has been noted is when he put his mortarboard on backward at his inauguration in April.
Both students and faculty have been surprised by Mr. Kean's visibility at Drew. He darts along campus paths on his bicycle to theater productions and sports events, eats meals with students, plans to teach political science next year and holds a weekly office hour for students who wish to drop by to discuss concerns. Professors were flabbergasted that he would actually sit through an entire faculty meeting.
"There's a presence we never had before," said Dr. Donald Jones, chairman of the University Senate and a professor of religion. "He is more hands-on in managing the internal affairs of the university than some of us thought he would be."
Along with the pleasures of the new post have come old headaches Mr. Kean was hoping to escape, like a work calendar that keeps him out an average of five nights a week, leaving little time for his family. But he said he has for the most part dodged feeling like what his friend Lamar Alexander, former Governor of Tennessee, has warned was the fate of former governors: "Rooster today, feather duster tomorrow."
Mr. Kean was reluctant to talk specifically about the policies of his successor, Jim Florio, but he made no secret of the fact that he disapproved of much of what Mr. Florio has done.
"Obviously I would have done things very differently, and everyone who knows me knows I would have done it differently," Mr. Kean said. "One thing that Keynesian and supply-side economists agree upon is that raising taxes in a falling economy is a mistake. I hope that if the economy continues to drop, the current administration will find some way to readjust the taxes."
Mr. Kean has little sympathy for the difficulties Mr. Florio is confronting in trying to eliminate a major budget deficit and comply with the New Jersey Supreme Court mandate to increase state aid to urban school districts in a weakening economy.
"We were in a worse situation my second year as Governor than Governor Florio is in now," he said. "We had the worst recession since the Great Depression, there was 12 percent unemployment and the Legislature was in opposition."
Mr. Kean is as far from Mr. Florio on the issue of education as he is on taxes. He said Mr. Florio's sweeping revision of New Jersey's public school financing law lacked accountability and might well diminish the state's finest school systems. Mr. Kean added that he was equally concerned about a 10.7 percent cut in this year's higher education budget.
"I have stayed totally out of the discussion because I thought that, had I involved myself, it would become political, rather than academic, and that's as it should be," he said. "But if next year's higher education budget is 8 percent lower than this year's, you'll not only have the highest cut in the country, but the highest cut in the history of the country in the last two years. I don't think that can be sustained without losing the progress we've made, losing presidents and faculty members."
 
Autonomy for State Colleges
 Under Mr. Kean, state expenditures for higher education reached record levels, state colleges were granted unprecented autonomy from Trenton and a competitive grant system was established that has been emulated by other states.
Jon Shure, director of communications for Governor Florio, said that accountability was a "cornerstone" of the Governor's new financing plan for public schools and that the cuts in higher education were a result of hard times.
"When Mr. Kean raised taxes in 1982 before the economy really started to improve, he realized you can't be on the side of increasing spending and also not increase revenues for the state," Mr. Shure said.
"These are very tough times, and hard decisions have to be made," he added. "In the process of cutting the higher education budget, the Governor increased the amount of money available for tuition assistance. It's a case of tough priorities."
"My theory as Governor was that a strong system of higher education enhanced jobs and created jobs," Mr. Kean said. "It was always at the top of our priority list."
With shrinking demographics and a shaky fiscal outlook, this is not the easiest time to be the president of a university, and Drew is no exception. This year the university's enrollment is 7.5 percent smaller than had been anticipated, largely because of an insistence that the quality of students admitted to the university not decline. After more than 30 years of balanced budgets, a small budget deficit last year grew to a $1.9 million deficit this year that is expected to grow to $3.5 million by next year.
In addition, Mr. Kean has acknowledged that morale on campus was low but said it was improving. He said that the morale problems were due to the fact that some Drew students "didn't recognize just how good this place was."
 
Building on Strengths
 He plans to enhance the university's reputation by building on its strengths in the areas of technology, multicultural understanding and teaching, rather than changing direction. He hopes that in the process Drew will become a model of what other universities should be doing.
Mr. Kean said Drew had just begun to enlist technology in the service of a liberal arts education. The university says that in 1984 it became the first liberal-arts school in the country to issue computers to students, who now routinely leave messages, submit homework and check the library card catalogue with their machines as part of an elaborate computer network. They can also watch European theater productions and foreign newscasts in their rooms by satellite.
"The liberal arts teach the student how to think, but these days you also have to be technologically competent," he said. "If you produce a student who is both -- who has the ability to think and adapt and is also technologically competent -- you've got a very special product."
As a second objective, Mr. Kean would like to make Drew's foreign study option mandatory within five years. Currently one-third of Drew's undergraduates spend at least one semester studying abroad. Four new faculty positions have also been created for next year in Asian, African, Russian and Arabic studies, despite the university's strained financial resources.
"We're a much changed, much smaller world," Mr. Kean said. "The U.S. is not going to be No. 1. It is going to be one of three or four strong economic powers. And if a person cannot understand how to work with other cultures, then eventually the country will not succeed."
 
$10,000 Award Created
 The third aspect of university life Mr. Kean hopes to develop is in the area of teaching. He has created a $10,000 president's award to go to a Drew faculty member for teaching and community service, which he believes is the largest award in the country for teaching.
The concept of rewarding the best teachers monetarily echoes an unsuccessful effort by Mr. Kean to introduce a master teacher plan throughout the state when he was Governor. But this time, without union resistance and with the help of an anonymous donor, the Drew plan is expected to go forward.
The specifics of the award are still being worked out -- how often it will be given and what portion of the money, if any, would be used to improve education at Drew. Mr. Kean said both faculty and students would help select recipients.
 
Considered a Coup
 Signing on Mr. Kean as president of Drew was considered a coup for the university. It was the late Rutgers University president, Dr. Edward Bloustein, who encouraged Mr. Kean to look at smaller universities, saying that effecting change at larger institutions would take a minimum of 10 years. Dr. Bloustein died last year.
Just how long Mr. Kean will remain at Drew is unclear, but there is an assumption that he will be gone in a few years.
"We know he won't be here for a decade," Dr. Jones said. "At first we thought he'd be here for about five years, and now it might be four or four and a half."
That timing coincides with speculation that Mr. Kean might challenge Senator Frank R. Lautenberg for his seat in 1994. Mr. Kean, who serves on President Bush's education advisory committee, said he had made no promises to the university about the length of his tenure there. He did, though, deny rumors that had been circulating that he would be replacing Lauro F. Cavazos as United States Secretary of Education or would run against Governor Florio in 1993.
"I'm a Jeffersonian," he said. "You serve your time and then you do other things. Eight years to me is a long time, and I did my best. Now it's time for other people and other ideas."
But Mr. Kean, ever the politician, left the door open for the future. Speaking of government positions, he said, "I hope frankly that there's never a year when I'm not doing something."

HEADLINE: L.I.R.R. Planning To Drop 60 Trains

 BODY:
THE Long Island Rail Road, beset by a budget gap of $27 million and a shrinking ridership attributed to "the unexpected depth of the recent downturn in our region's economy," is planning to cancel 60 trains a day and close Pennsylvania Station and the Flatbush Avenue terminal in Brooklyn from 1:30 A.M. to 4:30 A.M.
The cuts would go into effect on Jan. 21, if approved by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the railroad's parent agency.
In a brochure distributed on all trains last Wednesday, the railroad said that "despite significant, continuing belt-tightening and streamlining internally," it was turning to service changes to balance its 1991 budget, which totals $643 million.
The railroad said that the changes would preserve its core commuter service while targeting areas where alternative service was available and that the changes reflected "the conclusion that L.I.R.R. service in many cases is scheduled beyond the capacity of our physical plant to carry it."
 
Faulting the Economy

The railroad is re-evaluating its service in the wake of five years of signal upgrading between Jamaica and Penn Station, which culminated in Harold reconstruction project last summer.
The L.I.R.R. said the timetable revisions were "exceedingly complicated" because each change can ripple through the system and the movement of crews has to be coordinated with equipment maintenance and regular service.
"Into this complex scenario," the brochure said, "comes the current state of the economy," adding:
"About half our budget comes from government subsidies, mainly through state business, real estate and insurance taxes. Because the regional economy is depressed, tax receipts are down, and other subsidies have been trimmed."
The railroad noted that almost one-third of the commuters worked in the depressed finance, insurance and real-estate industries, "so we've felt the impact of a slowdown there in the form of lower ridership."
With subsidies and commuter revenues falling, the railroad said, it would have to trim its budget by 4 percent from the original projections for 1991. In 1990, the railroad added, it had already cut its budget 3 percent and made cuts not related to schedules. Any reductions in the work force, the railroad said, would be by attrition.
 
1.1% Decrease in Morning Seats

Beginning on Jan. 21, there will be 11 fewer trains in the morning rush hour and three fewer in the evening. The other eliminated trains are from off-peak hours, mainly in the morning. A spokeswoman for the railroad said the changes would translate to a 1.1 percent decrease in seats for the morning rush hour.
These are the major proposed changes:
BABYLON BRANCH: Eliminating the 5:02 A.M. and 8:37. Combining the 6:32 with the 6:56 from Wantagh and the 6:58 from Freeport into two trains, one from Babylon at 6:33 and the other from Wantagh at 6:54. Merging the 7:46 runs from Freeport and Merrick into a 7:42 departure from Merrick. Combining the 7:41 from Seaford and the 7:33 from Babylon into a 7:27 from Babylon to Brooklyn.
FAR ROCKAWAY BRANCH: Eliminating the 8:12 and the 6:40 from Penn Station.
HEMPSTEAD BRANCH: Eliminating the 8:20. Changing the 8:03 to leave at 8:08, adding a stop at Queens Village.
LONG BEACH BRANCH: Eliminating the 8:05. Combining the 4:55 and 4:59 from Penn Station, to leave at 5 o'clock.
MONTAUK BRANCH: Eliminating the 7:27 from Speonk. Adding an 8:12 departure from Speonk.
PORT JEFFERSON BRANCH: Changing equipment on the 5 A.M. Combining the 5:56 and the 6:51 from Huntington.
Two runs from Penn Station would be added, 7:42 A.M. to Ronkonkoma and 7:50 A.M. to Babylon.
A hearing on the changes is scheduled for 4 P.M. on Dec. 5 at the Nassau County Board of Supervisors Executive Building in Mineola.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Mills;
Still for Women Only, With New Curriculum

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif.

 BODY:
A half-year after Mills College reversed its decision to admit men for the first time in its 138-year history, faculty members have begun a plan to revitalize the liberal-arts curriculum and thus make ends meet by attracting 225 more female students in the next five years.
The plan centers on a pilot program of interdisciplinary classes for freshmen and sophomores. 
 Marilyn Chandler, the English department head, who is teaching one of the classes, said Mills's experiment was part of a national trend. "A lot of schools are going in the direction of interdisciplinary, cross-cultural and ethnic studies," she said, adding that recent writings, like Allan Bloom's "Closing of the American Mind," have raised questions about what educated people should know.
The college's acting president, Virginia Smith, said: "If we think about how people use liberal-arts education, it is rarely used within the confines of any one discipline. Life isn't so neatly divided."
Ms. Smith, the former president of Vassar College, replaced Mary Metz, who resigned in July, saying she could no longer provide the strong leadership that she felt Mills would need during the next five years. Her nine-year tenure had ended in a student and faculty uproar over a May 3 decision by the trustees, supported by Ms. Metz, to make Mills coeducational.
 
 Enrollment Goal
 In reversing their decision on May 18, the trustees set various goals for fund raising and alumnae participation as well as enrollment -- to 1,000 -- for the college to meet by 1995. The proposed curriculum changes are intended to help attain those goals.
The freshman seminars -- "Women at Work in America," "Ecological Policy and Public Catastrophe" and "Understanding Revolutions" -- and the sophomore core course, "Critical Perspectives on Human Problems," are taught by teams of professors from two different disciplines. In "Understanding Revolutions," for example, students are asked to research and define a revolution from both a historical and a political point of view. "Ecological Policy" draws from biology and government.
Although many colleges offer freshman seminars, Ms. Chandler said, the sophomore course is more unusual. Ms. Chandler and Bruce Pavlik, a biology professor who also teaches the course, said they were trying to provoke thought and to question assumptions about subjects like space, time and knowledge systems.
During the unit on space, for instance, professors from different disciplines lecture weekly on spatial concepts, maps, urban planning, indoor and outdoor space in photography and ancient peoples' sacred space, Ms. Chandler said.
 
Different Perspectives
 The students will learn "how to step back and think rather broadly about the assumptions surrounding an issue," using these different perspectives to help them, Ms. Chandler said. In her planning, she talked to core class directors at Princeton University and at Occidental College in Los Angeles, which has an integrated humanities program for freshmen and sophomores.
The faculty voted to start the pilot courses last April, when it also voted on a motion to remain a women's college. The professors and students in the classes will turn in evaluations at the end of this semester that the full faculty will use to decide whether to continue the classes.
Nancy Thornborrow, an economics professor who helped develop the program, said the idea was for first-year students to complete a semester-long seminar and move on to a two-semester sophomore core course, eventually choosing an interdisciplinary major.
 
Staff Turnover
 Because of staff turnover and less than adequate advertising, the pilot courses "didn't get the kind of student response we expected," Ms. Chandler admitted. They also were not "bracketed as new" in the registration course packet given to students or listed in the course catalogue. Professors sent freshmen information on the classes during the summer, but most of the interest came from juniors and seniors who were allowed to enroll because of the low number of freshmen and sophomores.
Elin Caughey, a freshman from Indianapolis who is an art major, said that the seminar concept reminded her of humanities classes in high school and that she liked having two professors for a seminar.
Salome Portugao, a freshman from San Francisco who is majoring in education, is taking two seminars. "It's neat getting two different perspectives," she said.

HEADLINE: The Love for Cars: A Quarter-Century of Best Sellers

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
THE BEST-SELLING car today is a lot different from what it was 25 years ago. In the affluent and resource-abundant 1960's, an occasional Ford won out, but for the most part Americans saw the U.S.A. in a full-size Chevrolet. And No. 1, selling well over a million models, was a massive beast, stretching to 18 feet and more and weighing a couple of tons. To move all this metal took a powerful V-8 engine, which was mounted in the front to drive the rear wheels -- an arrangement that required a large hump in the passenger compartment to accommodate the drive shaft.
Late in the decade, gasoline mileage, never outstanding for a V-8, was further reduced by the onset of air pollution control equipment. At the worst, in 1974, the best seller got a mere 10 miles to a gallon. In 1974, the cutoff of oil by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries jolted the country with long lines at gasoline stations and rapidly rising prices. Sales of small, fuel-efficient imported cars, many from Japan, jumped as buyers opted for efficiency. 
 In 1975, Washington made it law: Detroit had to get an average of 27.5 miles to the gallon by 1985. Americans weren't shrinking, but their cars had to. The solution was to convert to front-wheel drive, eliminating that passenger-space hump by putting the entire power train under the hood. On average, the domestic car shed nearly 1,000 pounds and developed an overwhelming liking for smaller engines.
When the second oil shock hit in 1979, the General Motors Corporation kicked off with a four- or six-cylinder, front-wheel-drive Chevrolet Citation compact that claimed first place, until ousted by the even smaller Ford Escort. As the price of gasoline, adjusted for inflation, declined through the 1980's, a subtle shift occured. The better-performing V-6 began to gain on its four-cylinder counterpart.
Meanwhile, the number of models from domestic and import manufacturers proliferated into the hundreds. And the Japanese began building factories in this country to evade import restraints imposed to protect Detroit in the early 1980's. Last year, sales of just 362,707 units qualified a car as the best seller. For the first time, it bore a foreign name: Honda. But in some ways, it is as American as apple pie; 60 percent were assembled in Ohio.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/November 11-16

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
A New Claim on Drexel
 The Government's claim for $11 billion from Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. reads like an indictment of organized crime: Drexel plundered failed savings and loans "through bribery, coercion, extortion, fraud and other illegal means." The market for Drexel's "junk bonds" depended on the savings and loans, the Government said, and the collapse of dozens of these institutions can largely be blamed on Drexel. Drexel, still kicking, suggested that the Government is asking for so much because its New York law firm, Cravath, Swaine & Moore, will share in the money recovered. Thomas D. Barr, the Cravath partner handling the Government's case, knows plenty about fighting Federal charges himself. He defeated a 13-year antitrust effort to break up the International Business Machines Corporation. But even he can't recover $11 billion. Drexel's estate is worth only about $3 billion, with other claimants swarming.

Major Surgery at First Boston
 Another wounded veteran of the takeover battles of the 1980's is pulling through with intensive care. CS Holding Inc., the parent of Credit Suisse, the ambitious Swiss bank, gained control of CS First Boston last week by pouring in $300 million. First Boston underwent two other delicate, expensive operations: First, CS Holding removed from the First Boston portfolio hundreds of millions of dollars in weak loans. Then came a major amputation, with First Boston dismissing nearly all senior executives in real estate. The only major American investment bank to come under foreign control, First Boston is just the latest to require emergency resuscitation. Samuel G. Liss, a securities industry analyst at Salomon Brothers, said, "The difficulties that began with the demise of Drexel, which intensified the scrutiny of brokerage firm balance sheets, forced the hands of CS First Boston, Kidder Peabody and Shearson." General Electric has had to invest hundreds of millions in Kidder, and American Express had to buy full ownership of Shearson Lehman. On Wall Street, as elsewhere, health care costs are rising out of control.
 
Sad Days for Freedom Bank
 It only had assets of $101.9 million. But Freedom National Bank of New York was often the first place black business people turned for a loan. Freedom was founded in 1964 by investors, among them Jackie Robinson, who wanted to promote Harlem's redevelopment. By the late 80's, overly ambitious goals mired the bank in bad loans. Federal regulators took it over as private rescue efforts failed. On Tuesday morning, Freedom opened its doors to pay off depositors who had been lining up on West 125th Street since 4 A.M. But a larger black-owned institution still thrives justdown the street: Carver Federal Savings Bank, with more than twice the assets, a healthy financial base and managers who know they can't afford as many mistakes as the bigger lenders downtown.
 
Another Chance for Eastern
 Attracting more domestic business travelers helps, but Eastern Airlines's survival might depend on events in the Middle East. On Wednesday, a Federal bankruptcy judge gave Eastern $15 million from an escrow fund to keep flying. The creditors, who say that continued losses are draining their potential payoffs, clamored for the airline's liquidation. Martin R. Shugrue, the airline's trustee and manager, says that the offer of first-class seats for full-fare coach travelers gives the airline a chance of breaking even by March. "He's having some success," said Thomas Longman, an analyst at Bear Stearns. The judge's forebearance has reassured travelers, who are keeping their reservations. But Mr. Longman said that Mr. Shugrue's plans are based on 90-cents-a-gallon aviation fuel. The fuel rose from 58 cents in July to as much as $1.40 more recently, but sold for less than a dollar a gallon last week.
 
Shaky Days at Pan Am
 The only United States airline that flies to Moscow is looking as harried and hungry as most Soviet consumers. The Pan Am Corporation sold its London routes last week to United Airlines for an urgently needed $400 million. United also agreed to guarantee $100 million worth of Pan Am tickets, so travelers would not be stranded if Pan Am folds. The airlines will coordinate their schedules and share their frequent-flier programs -- measures likely to feed passengers from United's domestic network onto Pan Am's international flights. The British and United States Governments have yet to approve the deal. But the airline's survival also depends on the price of fuel. Pan Am's fallback is a $450 million takeover offer from Trans World Airlines and its chairman, Carl C. Icahn.
 
Donald Trump Pays His Dues
 Donald J. Trump agreed on Friday to carve up his interest in the Taj Mahal hotel and casino and serve his creditors as much as half. He missed a $47.3 million interest payment, forcing the Atlantic City hotel into a quick bankruptcy reorganization and losing some assets to creditors for the first time. A payment on Trump's Castle casino comes due next month.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
The President's Optimism
 The economy is really in trouble if even the President says it might be in a recession. Until recently, President Bush was able to find prosperity where most economists found decline. On Thursday, his tone changed, somewhat. "I am concerned about the slowdown," he said. "I worry about anybody that wants a job and doesn't have one." Not that the President has lost his ability to sound as upbeat as someone who has just thrown a half dozen ringers one after the other. His economic advisors gave him word that a recession is likely to be mild, he said, "six months at most." He must hope so, or else he could be the one in need of a job come January 1993. .
 
The Inflationary Slope
 Higher energy prices are giving rise less to an inflationary spiral than a gradual slope. The cost of energy did raise the consumer price index six-tenths of 1 percent last month, but only three-tenths without food and energy -- the same pattern as the producer price numbers reported earlier. With a weak economy, said David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, "we're not seeing the oil price shock being translated into a permanent acceleration in core inflation."
 
Tarnish on the Bright Spot
 The weak dollar, an exporter's best friend, resulted in no increase in September shipments. Exports, which had been growing, fell 2.2. percent. "That takes care of the one bright spot in the economy," said Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at Manufacturers Hanover. Some economists blamed weaker growth and reduced demand abroad, while others said that air cargo companies were too busy carrying military goods to the Middle East. The trade deficit fell 3.3 percent, to $9.4 billion, as imports also declined 2.4 percent. Dr. Kellner drew encouragement from oil imports that rose from in September despite the embargo against Iraq. "It shows there is plenty of oil," he said.
 
In Brief
 Most of last week's other figures confirmed the economists' consensus that the nation is entering a recession. Industrial production fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in October. Retail sales grew just one-tenth of 1 percent. The Federal Reserve apparently responded by pushing down interest rates.
 Oil prices fell $4.11 to $29.78 a barrel last week, as oil traders said that their fear of a a Middle East war had diminished.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Trade Talks in Jeopardy
 A dispute over European farm subsidies last week threatened the success of four years of trade talks. The Europeans reluctantly offered to cut their subsidies, down 15 percent since 1986, another 15 percent by 1996. Inadequate, said Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, as the Administration debated whether to stalk out of the negotiations. Her response helped convince the Dutch trade minister, Yvonne van Rooy, to speak of the 15 percent reduction as "not a final offer, but clearly an opening bid."
 
Mrs. Thatcher's Challenge
 A "Europeanist" has arisen to challenge British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's 11-year reign. Michael Heseltine, who quit her Cabinet in 1986, said on Wednesday that he would contest her leadership in a vote by Conservative members of Parliament on Tuesday. Mr. Heseltine sides with many business people but not Mrs. Thatcher in wanting Britain to take part in the European Community's drive towards economic union. A news service survey gave Mrs. Thatcher a clear edge. But the British public appears restive under high inflation and a headstrong leader.
 
Japan's Quiet Green Movement
 Japanese corporations fear that their envirnomental efforts will be greeted with the sound of no hands clapping. Accused of single-minded dedication to efficiency and growth, some are pursuing recycling, conservation, beautification and rain-forest renewal. Semiconductor companies are working on ways to clean printed circuit boards without using chlorofluorocarbon gases that destroy the ozone layer. But the Japanese consider it defensive and immodest to boast of such efforts, reports the daily Nihon Keizai in an Asia Foundation translation. "Even within corporations, people look askance at environmental proselytizing," the newspaper said. "Action-team members risk accusations of grandstanding by colleagues for using recycled business cards."
 
In Brief
 No longer will natty New Yorkers have to risk a shopping trip downtown. Barneys New York, with support from a Japanese partner, plans to open an 11-floor clothing store on upper Madison Avenue in 1992.
 Scali, McCabe, Sloves gave up the $40 million Volvo advertising account last week. A recent commercial demonstrating the car's ability to hold up under the onslaught of a monster pickup truck turned out to have been rigged.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
One Muni Fund's Dismal Days

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
SOME mutual funds are born troubled. Others become troubled through their own efforts. And still others have trouble thrust upon them. But the best explanation for the mess brewing at the New York Muni Fund, with $230 million in assets, would seem to be "all of the above."
The tax-exempt fund's early days were shadowed by regulatory problems that continue to affect the day-to-day management of the fund. The fund's managers subsequently bought a number of small bond issues of uncertain provenance, and then carried some of them at premium prices after they had defaulted. And, along with all other regional muni-bond portfolios, the fund has had the mounting worries about New York, state and city, added to the problems it already faces. 
 The result is bad news for the New York Muni Fund's shareholders, whose principal value has declined sharply already, and a clear warning that all investors should monitor the quality of the bonds their funds own, and the prices ascribed to them.
 The New York Muni Fund is managed by Fundamental Portfolio Advisors, which is owned by Vincent Malanga, the fund's president, and Lance M. Brofman, the fund's chief portfolio strategist. The same firm also manages the California Muni Fund.
According to the New York fund's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Brofman "is limited in his activities" at the funds until Jan. 6, 1992, because of sanctions imposed on him by the commission in 1987. Without admitting any wrongdoing, Mr. Brofman settled a complaint that he had caused the fund's former investment advisory firm to make false and misleading statements about the California Muni Fund.
The New York Muni Fund's portfolio includes a number of small, illiquid bond issues that were sold by the brokerage firm of Matthews & Wright, which earlier this month agreed to plead guilty to criminal conspiracy charges in connection with a municipal bond scandal in the mid-80's. Further clouding its portfolio, New York Muni is the sole owner of all the bonds sold on behalf of certain private projects, giving fund shareholders a nerve-wracking stake in the ventures.
Of course, given the state of the New York economy, New York Muni was not alone in lagging behind the national averages for tax-exempt mutual funds in October. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytic Services, reports that his sample of 48 New York muni funds trailed all tax-free funds for the month, and five funds besides New York Muni saw their principal value actually decline. Those six funds, Mr. Lipper found, had invested a larger share of their assets, on average, in lower-rated bonds than the better-performing state and national funds had.
But the drop at New York Muni was more than twice that of the next-ranking fund, and it followed an equally bad third quarter. Some of the reasons were first reported last week by Barron's magazine, which noted that two Niagara County Industrial Development Agency issues, totaling $14 million and making up 6 percent of fund assets, had missed two interest payments.
The bonds were sold on behalf of the private developers of a local retail and amusement arcade that is a year behind schedule and remains 30 to 40 percent vacant. Nevertheless, as recently as June 30, the bonds were listed on the fund's books at $106 for each $100 in face value.
Since only a few muni-bond issues change hands often enough to produce reliable quotes from traders, most funds rely on independent services to provide prices, based on interest rates and comparable trades. Mr. Malanga, the fund adviser, said on Friday that the prices he has ascribed to the Niagara issues -- about $93 these days, he said -- came from Interactive Data. A spokesman for Interactive Data said that no one was available to discuss how the firm had arrived at its past and current prices on the Niagara County issues.
 Mr. Lipper noted that "there is more art than science" in municipal bond pricing. And considerable artistry would have been needed to persuade most people to pay a premium price, or even 93 cents on the dollar, for bonds that are two payments late on debt service. But Mr. Malanga explained that there is "some sort of reserve fund" that would have covered the two missed payments -- except that "some judge" intervened.
He and Mr. Brofman were both somewhat vague about the reserve fund's size and the legal problems that have barred its use. But Mr. Malanga said he was confident "the situation will resolve itself over the next few months or so." John Bartolomei, the attorney for the various developers, was equally uninformative about the legal tangle affecting debt service. "I heard there were some liens," Mr. Bartolomei said Friday. "Or maybe not liens, exactly, but something. You could call the trustee."
The trustee for both bond issues is Norstar Bank in Albany. Mary McCraken, trust officer for the bonds, declined to answer any questions about them. She did say, however, that the S.E.C. had recently called about the issue. "Perhaps you could check with them," she said. A commission spokesperson said, "The staff is not authorized to confirm or deny the existence of any investigation."
In any case, John C. Drake, the assistant director of the Niagara County agency that issued the bonds, said that the Niagara County Urban Renewal Agency sold $5.9 million worth of bonds last year to help bail out the Falls Street project. As it happens, that entire bond issue was bought by the New York Muni Fund. As of June, the latest report available, the bonds were priced at 98 cents on the dollar.
But consider another small issue in the fund's portfolio, sold by the Erie County Industrial Development Agency to finance a private warehouse project. Those bonds defaulted sometime in 1988, and the project is being liquidated. The fund valued the bonds at 79 percent of par last December; by June, that price had fallen to 40 percent of par.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Pinning All The Blame On Drexel

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
THE demonization of Mike Milken is proceeding apace. Now, the Government says he was a significant villain in the savings and loan debacle. Mr. Milken will be punished for other crimes, but the latest claims appear to be highly exaggerated, at best.
There were many causes of the savings and loan losses, and what the Government calls Drexel Burnham Lambert's "gospel of greed" was part and parcel of the times. But it should not be forgotten that the losses followed from the Government's decision to let the industry go off and make whatever risky investments it wished, secure in the knowledge that Government-guaranteed deposits would provide the needed cash.
The fraud factor in the savings debacle cannot be ignored, and the Government allegations make a case that Drexel and Mr. Milken played a role in some suspicious transactions with the two most infamous bank executives of our time, Charles Keating of Lincoln Savings in California and David Paul of Centrust in Florida. But neither is fraud anything like the whole story.
Drexel did raise billions for savings institutions, which promised to pay high interest rates and had to take big risks to have a chance of succeeding. That was clear at the time, but regulators chose to look the other way. Most of the unwise risks, and most of the bad loans, came in that old staple of savings and loan lending, real estate, not from savings institutions buying the junk bonds Mr. Milken was peddling.
As it happened, junk bond prices generally rose last week, even as the Government was using its heaviest rhetoric to declare that the entire market was little more than a giant fraud. The hope is that the Federal Reserve will push down interest rates and thus ease the economic pain. The same stimulus helped raise stock prices, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 61.64 points, to 2,550.25, despite the growing evidence of a weak economy. That is keeping companies from passing on cost increases, and thus holding down inflation.
The rising stock prices also reflect the new conventional wisdom that while there is a recession, it will be mild and brief. The bottom-fishers like bank stocks, and the N.Y.S.E. financial index has risen 10.7 percent over the past three weeks, the best such period in more than six years. (For the year, it remains down 25 percent.)
Whether that rosy forecast is correct will depend in part on just how long it takes to work off the excesses of the 1980's, excesses that go far beyond the fraud the Government was talking about last week.
"Keating and Paul and Milken are fast becoming villains of a Saturday matinee variety," says James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer and a man who was denouncing junk bonds long before it became fashionable to do so. "I have no doubt they did many bad and money-losing things, but they did not lose half a trillion dollars.
"If the limits of the thrifts' problems were junk bonds," Mr. Grant added, "we'd all be a whole lot better off."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Gold: No Longer the Sure Thing

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
THE dollar is falling. American banks are in trouble. In the Persian Gulf, a war seems as likely as a debilitating standoff. And gold, the usually perfect play in such circumstances, is going nowhere.
Since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, gold has twice rallied to more than $400 an ounce, once in August to $415 and then in September to $406. But it fell hard both times and now stands at $379. That is just a few dollars higher than where it was the day before the invasion ($373) and far below its high for the year of $422 in February. 
 "If you had told me last winter that Saddam Hussein would invade Kuwait and cut oil production, that oil prices would reach $40 a barrel and that the dollar would fall, I would have forecast a gold price of $450 an ounce easily," said Warren Myers, vice president at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
There are several reasons for gold's misbehavior. Some are short-term, like a surge in supply through large sales by the Soviet Union and governments in the Middle East. But there is a longer-term factor that will continue to have an impact on gold far into the future. It is the opening, diversification and growth of global financial markets and the resulting decline of gold's traditional role as a haven for investors in times of trouble.
In the 1970's, the global foreign exchange market was still relatively small. The financial markets in places like Germany, Switzerland and Japan were just beginning to grow. Trading in these and other markets was not easy because of restrictions and a lack of liquidity.
But all this had changed by the beginning of the 90's. Foreign exchange has exploded into a $500 billion-a-day market and liquidity in securities outside the United States is growing, making it easier to get in and out of an investment quickly. The markets in Japan are huge and growing and are becoming more accessible to foreign investors. Germany, with the tearing down of the Berlin wall and this year's unification, has become one of the most attractive markets in the world. London has become a center for Europewide trading. And the coming economic union of Europe is forcing markets throughout the continent to drop trading barriers.
Indeed, trading -- whether in currency, bonds or stocks -- is fast becoming a global game played 24 hours a day. With computer trading and improvements in settlement practices, money and trades move much faster than ever before, giving investors and money managers the confidence they can respond swiftly to changing political and financial events.
All this adds up to a much more modest role for gold, which flourished in the 70's when there were not nearly as many investment alternatives that could serve as safe harbors in times of crisis.
"The world is much more sophisticated, especially in finding other places to invest money," said Ian C. MacDonald, manager of precious metals at Credit Suisse in New York. "A lot of the money is going to Switzerland and Germany."
Added Mr. Myers of Merrill Lynch, "You can move money, hedge and do all these things. Gold is not the only game in town." The general worldwide commitment to fight inflation has also lessened the attractiveness of gold as a hedge, he said.
These changes have also affected investments in platinum. Purchases are expected to fall to 115,000 ounces this year, down from 630,000 in 1988, according to Johnson Matthey, a major manufacturer of platinum products which is also an important dealer of the metal. "There are a lot of other options now," said Michael Steel, director of research at Johnson Matthey.
With other options available, the short-term factors affecting the price of gold have even more of an impact. Gold quickly lost much of its attractiveness in August and September when speculators were hurt by sharp falls in prices that resulted from minor shifts in the outlook for war in the gulf.
Mr. MacDonald said it would take a major revival of interest in gold as a speculative or long-term investment to push the price up again. "There is a lack of conviction in the gold market now," he said. "There is not a reason to go into gold."
Also holding down the price in the near term are sales of gold by the Soviet Union, which needs to raise Western currency to provide transfusions for its faltering economy. Some countries in the Middle East have also been selling gold, in part to help pay for the military standoff with Iraq.
"All this adds up to a temporary and artificial extra supply on the market and that dampens the price so gold does not behave like people expect it to," said James P. Hildebrandt, vice president for investment at the World Gold Council, a Swiss-based association of gold-producing companies.
To be sure, the price of gold is likely to jump if there is a war in the gulf. But without the usual signposts it is hard to say how high the price might go, and how long it might stay there, making gold look especially dicey. And since the stock prices of gold companies also depend on this outlook, they are risky bets as well, even though many have fallen to more attractive levels.

HEADLINE: When Businesses Decide to Flee

 BODY:
In a Forum article, "A Company Gives Up on New York" (Nov. 4), Stuart Meyers, a partner in a small family-owned business, wrote that after 20 years, he was moving his business out of New York. An unusually large number of letters were received in response.

 
 
It's Not New York's Fault
 To the Editor: It seems to me that the true reason Mr. Meyers is moving his business out of New York City is that his company has lost 30 percent of its business in five years and that modern technology has made it possible to locate elsewhere. Mr. Meyers seems to be confusing the reality of reduced earnings and changing technology with a series of events that have nothing to do with his company's declining revenues.
It made me angry to read that he used the tragic story about one of his workers who killed someone as an example of this city's social problems. Is Mr. Meyers implying that murder only occurs in the working class and that the working class is responsible for our city's social ills?
Also, Mr. Meyers allowed his company's burglary insurance policy to lapse because he said that after repeated break-ins, his premiums had become too high. It doesn't seem to be a wise business policy to let your burglary insurance lapse in any large metropolitan area where protection of any kind against theft is just the prudent cost of doing business.
He also relates the story of how his company van had to be left on a city street overnight because of mechanical problems and was then vandalized and ticketed for being illegally parked. It would not have happened if he had had the van towed to a garage for repairs and safekeepingovernight.
And what does he mean when he says his workers incurred delays when they went to get replacement parts for the van? In this case the pejorative use of the verb incur has been used to blame the employees for mismanagement by the employer.
I believe Mr. Meyers would not have bothered to take the time and the energy to write an article filled with such ill will and prejudice toward the city that treated him and his family so well for so many years if his company's profits had increased substantially.
I wish Mr. Meyers the best of luck at his company's new location and in his career as a novelist. With his attitude, he'll need all the luck he can get.
 
JOHN MESTRES
Queens, N.Y., Nov. 7
 
 
 
The Rats Will Return
 To the Editor: Item: Another rat jumps ship. Response: Good riddance.
I made the mistake of reading Stuart Meyers's farewell speech to the metropolis before I went to bed. Instead of partaking in the dreamless, I became restless, angry. It isn't enough to leave the city while the getting is good; it's become de rigueur to grandstand it in a major publication.
Some of Mr. Meyers's comments as they relate to New York require examination. Was the shock that Mr. Meyers felt upon learning that one of his employees committed murder based on the act or the staffer's candor? I guess they don't commit murder in Mr. Meyers's new locale, Connecticut. No -- it must be that they don't have the bad manners to talk about it.
I had to smile at Mr. Meyers's admission that, due to his inability to run his business from his office during the unfortunate water main break, he and his partners "had to visit our customers in person." Now, there's a real imposition. Can you imagine actually having to leave your office to meet face to face with the people who provide you with your raison d'etre? Mr. Meyers forgets, or perhaps never knew, that business was conducted this way once upon a time, before the advent of the very telephone systems that his company installs.
Perhaps most galling are what seem to be Mr. Meyers's attempts to blame New York City for what in effect were his own poor management decisions.
He didn't back up his data files and his computer was stolen; he wasn't insured for the loss because he let his policy lapse. Sandwiching these facts between his litany of woes makes it seem that big, bad New York is big enough and bad enough to be the scapegoat for every problem.
It is my guess that New York was pretty good to Mr. Meyers and his brothers for 20 years or so, or they probably would have taken off sooner. It's hard not to get angry at a breed of businessman who feeds off the lifeline that is New York, only to abandon it when the going gets tough.
Perhaps we should coin a new term for this army of turncoats heading beyond our borders -- Tambys, or this ain't my backyard no more.
As Mr. Meyers and his compatriots gaze adoringly over their Beamers and Jags in their new office parking lots, I hope they think about this: that the homeless they choose not to look upon are still here. That the crime and horror that pervade this city cannot be wished away. That we simply cannot blame the politicians who inherited this mess without doing our part to get the city back on its feet. And that the executives who had the courage and the wherewithal to open businesses in New York should have the backbone to bolster the city when it falls, rather than turn tail and run.
I propose that we construct an edifice that complements the Statue of Liberty. This lady would be erected in the upper East River. Instead of robes, she'd be dressed in the familiar orange and brown garb of a New York traffic officer. And rather than holding a book and a torch, her arms would assume a dramatic gesture northward, the better to guide the fleeing horde beyond the pale.
When New York again becomes the flavor of the month, the opportunists will likely return in droves. That's to be expected; everyone will want a taste of the Apple once it's been de-wormed.
 
JILL A. SALTER
Brooklyn, N.Y., Nov. 5
 
 
 
Another Woeful Tale
 To the Editor: One morning while watching the news on television, a reporter announced that my office building was destroyed by an explosion! The space I occupied had very little damage, and all records were retrievable. I had insurance and a temporary space to move to. It really wasn't so terrible.
But after spending a tremendous amount of money to keep the business intact, the insurance company raised questions. Due to the condition of the space I was renting, it questioned whether paying for costs incurred was required. But the building had been condemned. And as a result, I had no access to the space. It had been padlocked!
It has been two and a half years since the explosion and no decision has been made on recovering my costs. Perhaps Mr. Meyers saved himself from another disappointment.
Can we survive in New York? Not easily. My firm moved to the Design Center in Long Island City. We are surviving.
One questions what the current economic conditions are doing to the city. How many mergers and acquisitions or bankruptcies will there be?
This was a city of opportunity. Good luck Stuart Meyers.
 
KAREN JAYNE
Long Island City, N.Y., Nov. 7
 
 
 
The City of Opportunity
 To the Editor: I understand why the article written by Stuart Meyers was included in last week's business section -- his horrible experience and his decision to leave New York are legitimate business news.
Nevertheless, it does seem irresponsible to fail to run an article on a business that has experienced the positive effects of moving to New York.
In 1989 we moved our editorial, publicity, art and subsidiary rights departments into New York from Secaucus, N.J. Despite various problems that arose as a result of the move, it has been a primary reason that revenues have risen more than 200 percent in less than two years. There are opportunities in this city that simply don't exist anywhere else.
 
STEVEN SCHRAGIS
New York, Nov. 7
 
 
 
Taking Advantage
 To the Editor: The sad part is not so much that Mr. Meyers is moving his company to the 'burbs. He had a tough time and everything seemed to go wrong. He can put all of that in the novel he's writing. In fact, I detect a bit of the novelist's imagination in the article, but so be it.
The tough part for New York is that Mr. Meyers will still count on continuing to do business with the 70 percent of his customer base that did not disappear or downscale during the past five years. (Actually, any company that can keep 70 percent of its customer base for five years is doing pretty well; would he have done better anywhere else?)
Let him relocate to the Sun Belt, and sell his telephones there. New York can certainly survive without those who run, if we who continue to ply our trades here will only give our telephone and other business to those who stay here with us. It's the guy who goes to the suburbs but continues to draw on the city for his customers who hurts us. He wants our business; he wants to congest our streets by driving in from his office; he wants to use the many facilities provided by the taxes on New York City companies -- sure he has a competitive advantage.
Our association, National Marine Manufacturers Association, has been in New York City since 1904. We have a great mix of employees because we draw on the five boroughs, on Long Island, New Jersey, Connecticut. They love our central location, the opportunities to shop, to lunch.
We love it here, and we have a stock response for suburban suppliers who call requesting our business.
 
FRANK SCALPONE
New York, Nov. 7
