HEADLINE: A Setback for Polystyrene

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
MANUFACTURERS of polystyrene, the lightweight plastic packaging material, have been struggling for two years to improve their environmental image by establishing a recycling program. But all of their efforts may have been undone by the decision earlier this month by the McDonald's Corporation to switch from plastic foam to paper packaging for its hamburgers.
Leaders of the polystyrene recycling effort, which is backed by some of the biggest petrochemical companies in the nation, vow they will press on despite the defection of McDonald's. The fast-food chain, the biggest in the nation, was the most prominent participant in pilot recycling programs based in New York and Massachusetts and was to have been part of a planned nationwide program. 
 "What McDonald's did was give us another quarter of red ink," said Russ Welton, vice president of the National Polystyrene Recycling Company, which is building four recycling plants across the country. Without McDonald's, company executives are scrambling to line up school and industrial cafeterias, big users of foam cups and plates, as new sources of supply.
But some industry observers say the switch by McDonald's will have much bigger repercussions for the $2.5 billion industry.
"Food manufacturers will think twice about continuing to use polystyrene and other plastic packaging," said Peter Coombes, the editor of Chemical Week magazine.
"McDonald's was the engine driving this program," said Nancy Wolf, executive director of the Environmental Action Coalition in New York. "Without them, the whole polystyrene recycling system may collapse."
Some environmentalists have questioned the value of the recycling effort, saying it puts a mantle of respectability on a material whose manufacture generates pollution and which is particularly troublesome as litter. They say the foam is so light it is difficult to collect and transport economically. And they argue that if the chemical industry withdraws the subsidies it has used to start recycling, the effort may end.
"THUS far, polystyrene recycling is more a problem-ridden theory than a proven option," said Frederic D. Krupp, executive director of the Environmental Defense Fund, which is helping McDonald's improve its environmental performance and influenced the company's decision to drop the foam box. "There is a lot of pressure on the companies that make polystyrene to say they are recycling, but saying it does not mean it will really happen."
Mr. Krupp noted that the recycling program does not even address the approximately 50 percent of the packaging that leaves fast-food restaurants with takeout orders.
Leaders of the foam recycling effort concede that early efforts to re-use the material have not been profitable and have been hampered by contamination with paper and food waste. But they say four new, much larger plants in the Chicago, Philadelphia, Oakland, Calif., and Los Angeles areas will be able to stand on their own financially .
"Startups always lose money initially," said Mr. Welton of National Polystyrene. "But we are not saying to the industry, 'Subsidize us for 10 years.' I think we can get to a positive cash flow by the end of 1991."
The polystyrene industry began the recycling effort late in 1988 after some areas, including Suffolk County on Long Island, banned the material as part of their response to the solid-waste crisis. Although foam plastic is a small part of all solid waste, hamburger boxes have been singled out by environmental groups because of their very short useful life and prominence as litter.
However, most of these bans include exceptions for materials that are, or can be, recycled. To keep the enacted bans from taking effect, as well as to deter new ones, the polystyrene producers must keep the recycling program alive.
In November 1988, Mobil Chemical and the Genpak Corporation set up a recycling operation in Leominster, Mass., called Plastics Again, which has since been absorbed by National Polystyrene. Early last year, the Amoco Foam Products Company established Polystyrene Recycling Inc. in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn in association with McDonald's.
Since then, the industry has united behind National Polystyrene and pledged to recycle 250 million pounds of the material by 1995. Company executives said this represents about one-quarter of the billion pounds of plastic foam used in various food packaging applications, and thus is responsive to the Environmental Protection Agency's goal of reaching a 25 percent recycling goal by that date.
The companies that each put up $2 million last fall to start National Polystyrene are Amoco Chemical, Arco Chemical, Chevron Chemical, Dow Chemical, Fina Oil and Chemical, Huntsman Chemical, Mobil Chemical and Polysar.
But the amount to be recycled is a small fraction of the more than 5 billion pounds of polystyrene used in this country each year. Sometimes referred to by the Dow Chemical trade name Styrofoam, polystyrene is also used as molded packaging blocks for shipment of electronic devices, loose packing materials and in the construction and home furnishing industries. Most of these products end up in landfills, where they break down very slowly. But a huge amount simply becomes litter.
"WHEN we did a cleanup of the Merrimack River, the biggest single item we found was Styrofoam," said Pat Scanlan, the director of recycling at Wheelabrator Technologies Inc., recounting a cleanup effort he was part of in Massachusetts with a group of friends. "A lot of it was packaging. People threw boxes in the river after buying appliances. The cardboard dissolved, but the Styrofoam floated on to the shore."
Foam plastic's light weight is the major obstacle to recycling, environmentalists and industry executives agree. Although re-using the material simply involves remelting and forming into a new shape, the obstacles posed by collection, shipment and decontamination remain formidable.
"The people who run curbside collection programs don't want to have anything to do with it," Mr. Scanlan said. "They are paid by the ton of material delivered, but the polystyrene takes up space without adding much weight."
"The big cost is transportation," said Tom Tomaszek, the former manager of the Plastics Again plant who now heads a plastics recycling company in Fort Edward, N.Y. "You have to go after other materials in addition to polystyrene to get favorable economics."
Ollie Ligon, an executive at Amoco Foam Products and president of the Brooklyn operation, conceded that "the cost of collection and processing exceeded the value of the resin." The Brooklyn plant paid nothing for the material it received; the shippers benefited by not having to pay the cost of disposal.
MR. WELTON said new methods of compressing the foam are being developed, allowing economical truckloads. But the manager of a recycling program in Fitchburg, Wis., said it took all night in a baling machine to compress 275 pounds of foam. A bale made quickly, she noted, only weighs 75 pounds.
In addition, foam that has been used in connection with food has to be washed before it can be remelted, or the resulting contamination will weaken the mechanical properties of the plastic. Executives at National Polystyrene said McDonald's was unable to persuade its customers to separate the plastic foam hamburger boxes from paper wrappings and food waste. As a result, the material arrived at the Leominster facility heavily contaminated and yielded low-quality plastic.
For that reason, Rubbermaid Inc., which said it was eager to use recycled plastic in its household and office products, has only accepted one shipment that was remelted at Plastics Again. "The quality of the material we were getting from McDonald's was terrible," said Mr. Welton of National Polystyrene, the current owner of Plastics Again. "And the material we were producing at the plant was not sufficient to meet the needs of customers like Rubbermaid."
Charles J. Lancelot, materials manager for Rubbermaid Commercial Products, said the company had used only "modest" amounts of recycled plastic foam. But he said Rubbermaid was prepared to use more "if it is consistently available in the right quantity and quality."
Mr. Welton said the new plants, the first of which will open later this year in the Los Angeles area, will each be capable of recycling 13 million pounds of plastic a year, compared with 3 million at Leominster. "At 2 to 3 million, I'm marginal," he said. "At 13 million, I can be profitable."
But McDonald's isn't the only fast-food chain to turn away from foam. Burger King, the second-biggest chain, has used paper-based packaging all along except for coffee cups, which it plans to replace as well. Other chains say they may soon follow suit.
To make up for the loss, the polystyrene recyclers say they are focusing on school and industrial cafeterias. Schools, they note, do not have the carryout problem of fast-food restaurants and students are more dutiful in separating foam trays from other wastes.
National Polystyrene has signed up the Los Angeles school system, and executives say this is typical of the types of supply arrangements the company will use to replace McDonald's. The company's plant in Corona, Calif., will pay 4 cents a pound for foam delivered to its doors.
Beth Lauargand, a business manager for the school system, said it already hauls its own garbage, so it has trucks and a collection system in place. Recycling the foam, she said, "would be very difficult to do unless you are fortunate enough to be in our circumstances."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Workers at Plastics Again, a recycling plant in Leominster, Mass. (Joe Wrinn for The New York Times); diagram: waste bales by size and weight of regular polystyrene and new polyethylene terepthalate.

HEADLINE: Suddenly, the Specter of Capitalism Is Haunting Intourist

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
INTOURIST, the vast Soviet agency that has monopolized foreign tourism for decades, is packing for a new destination: the world of competition.
Top Intourist officials say they are preparing to make their 61-year-old agency less like a bureaucracy than a business, all in the spirit of Government plans to open the economy to investment from abroad and market forces at home. 
 "We welcome everybody who wants to be involved in tourism," said Anatoly V. Skripnikov, deputy chairman of the State Committee for Foreign Travel, Intourist's parent.
With challenges expected from big Western travel companies, other Soviet state agencies and perhaps hundreds of private enterprises, Intourist has responded with a whirlwind of change: it is building 30 new hotels, renovating 15 others, signing up foreign partners, including an American hotel chain, and freezing its tour prices. Acknowledging a history of surly behavior, it is even trying to teach employees to greet guests with smiles instead of scowls.
But less may be changing than meets the eye, say Soviet experts in the West. In practice, Intourist is still guarding its official dominance, giving rivals the same cold welcome extended to many of its guests. And it continues to advocate strong central oversight of prices, accommodation standards, investment and strategy, and the avoidance of what it calls "unhealthy competition."
Foreign tourism companies are only a minor threat to Intourist so far, since few are willing to chance the chaotic Soviet economy, and those that do venture in sometimes form partnerships with Intourist itself. Intourist has refused to help foreign interests find private-sector partners in the Soviet Union, Mr. Skripnikov said. [See box.]
To be sure, the revamping of Soviet tourism will raise the quantity -- and maybe the quality -- of hotel rooms, open broad new reaches of the nation that were once off-limits to foreigners and make it possible, on occasion, to avoid using Intourist.
But Soviet experts say that Intourist will remain firmly in charge of most tourism. And some are skeptical about how committed the agency is to repairing its reputation for bad service and mediocre facilities.
Without tougher competition, Intourist "will still be fat, lazy, inefficient and rude," said Michael Mandelbaum, director of the Project on East-West Relations at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York.
Indeed, Intourist's obstinacy suggests the difficulty of persuading entrenched state agencies to join the march toward free markets, Dr. Mandelbaum said, calling Intourist "one of the pathologies of a planned economy." Because many visitors bring hard currency, it is easier to attract Western competitors to Soviet tourism than to most other industries, he said. But, he warned, "Intourist is going to hold on and resist."
No other Soviet travel service can come near to matching Intourist's size or reach: it owns 110 hotels and is affiliated with more than 800 travel agencies abroad. Intourist handles about 2 million of the nation's 2.5 million foreign tourists each year, and arranges Soviet travel abroad.
"THEY are in a very strong position," said Tomasz Telma, an economist at Planecon, a Washington consulting firm. "They have access to all the infrastructure."
Intourist officials themselves boast that the agency's size and ready access to hard currency will help it grow much more rapidly than other agencies serving foreign visitors. By the year 2000, Intourist plans to expand to 250,000 beds, from 55,000 now. "Intourist will undoubtedly remain for a long time the leading tourist firm engaged in receiving and rendering service to foreigner travelers," said a recent agency report.
Intourist's strongest rivals so far are two other state agencies, Intourbureau and Sputnik.
Intourbureau, also called the Central Council for Tourism and Excursions, was established in 1967 to handle trade-union exchange programs. It remains part of the Government's trade-union organization, but in recent years it has gingerly ventured into commercial travel, encroaching on Intourist's domain. With hotels in at least 25 cities, Intourbureau expects to host 200,000 foreign visitors this year.
Sputnik, affiliated with Komsomol, the Communist youth organization, handles tours for the young, loosely defined in the Soviet Union as those no older than 35.
Intourist officials say they expect further competition from hundreds of local and regional authorities and private establishments newly authorized to host foreign tourists. But few of these local agencies have representatives in other countries.
UNDER current plans, the Soviet Government would continue to hold a major stake in Intourist. Mr. Skripnikov said that his agency is seeking the authority to regulate other tourist organizations, especially to police those that might provide inadequate service or accommodations.
Yet Intourist's own standards have offended many a guest. Visitors often encounter lost reservations, dilapidated buildings, lackadaisical tour guides, dingy rooms, glowering floor attendants and interminable waits in restaurants where menus bear little resemblance to what is available. In Moscow, with hotel rooms chronically scarce, the daily rate typically is more than $100 and can sometimes exceed $200.
"We feel more and more responsible for providing better service," Mr. Skripnikov said, alluding to the pressure from the Government to lure more visitors bearing hard currency. "All the improvements must contribute to the development of tourism."
Like many other Soviet agencies, Intourist often feels the state planners tugging on one arm, the proto-capitalists on the other. Intourist officials envision the sale of shares to employees and to local and national authorities. "Soon, perhaps, to anyone," said Vladimir B. Lebedev, an Intourist press officer.
But a report Intourist issued earlier this year seeks to keep decentralization and the friction of free markets from getting out of hand. "Only a state organ can solve such tasks as elaboration of a long-term strategy," the document said, citing the need to maintain "adequate pricing policy and uniform standards."
For now, at least, a certain amount of confusion reigns in the new world of Soviet tourism.
"There are more options," said Elizabeth O'Shea, director of the Moscow office of Barry Martin Travel, a London-based agency specializing in the Soviet Union. "But the traveler doesn't necessarily know what his options are."
THE nation's growing political openness, and its hunger for foreign currency, have encouraged the authorities to open remote and exotic regions to tourism. "Areas you and I have never heard about," said Robert Woolis, sales manager for Anniversary Tours, a New York-based firm specializing in Soviet travel.
Intourist's local offices, and the many local governments that have their own hotels, already have the right to deal directly with foreign tourists and travel agencies. Yet few have ready means of offering their services.
Anatoly Matytsin, Intourist's manager in the United States, suggests that tourists take the initiative. He urged anyone eager to see the Soviet Far East, for example, to get directly in touch with the Intourist office in Khabarovsk. By phone? Might not work, he said, but added, "They've got their own telex machines."
Some officials are more confident of expanding tourism in the major cities first. There, the skirmishing between Intourist and Intourbureau has already begun. Intourist managers paint Intourbureau lodging as little better than camping out -- accommodations suitable for hardy Russians, but not for cossetted Westerners. "Only small pensions and some low-grade hotels, so this speaks to their possibilities and potential," Mr. Lebedev sniffed. "Intourist has the best hotels."
Intourbureau officials accuse Intourist of monopolizing central locations and trying to squeeze Intourbureau out of the market. "Nobody likes competition, but we must compete," said Ludmilla Obratsova, Intourbureau's deputy manager.
Intourbureau plans to continue undercutting Intourist's prices, but Mr. Skripnikov said that Intourist would hold its prices for the next two years. Intourbureau, too, is lining up joint venture partners, planning new hotels and training employees abroad.
But for Intourbureau, some reversals might be in store. Its parent agency, the Central Council of Trade Unions, is disintegrating, with many workers supporting trade unions independent of the Government. And both Intourist and Intourbureau are considering whether to demand hard, convertible currency from East Europeans beginning next year, a step likely to keep visitors away.
But even then, Intourist has the edge. Flush with Western visitors, it can better afford to adopt more exclusive ways.
 
 
A REVOLUTION IN HOSTELRY
 Radisson Hotels International's first rule for hiring employees at its soon-to-open Moscow hotel: avoid anyone contaminated by experience in Soviet hotels.
As the first Moscow hotel under American management, the Radisson Slavjanskaya aims to be distinctive. While the skylit lobby and endless halls may have the same sleek impersonality as dozens of other $200-a-day hotels in the West, these features seem reassuring compared with most Soviet accommodations.
The Slavjanskaya (the j is pronounced like a y) is one of several new joint-venture hotels involving Intourist and other Soviet agencies. Intourist's first luxury joint-venture, the renovated Savoy Hotel, opened near Red Square last year in a partnership with Finnair, the Finnish airline. Its services -- including Cable News Network and room-service caviar -- are so far beyond the scope of most Moscow hotels that some visitors fly Finnair for help in getting reservations.
Other Soviet agencies have found their own American partners to compete with Intourist. The Sheraton Corporation and Aeroflot, the Soviet airline, plan hotels in several major cities. Their first, the Sheraton Moscow Hotel, a partnership with the Pan Am Corporation and the City of Moscow, is set to open by 1993.
Ramada Inc. has joined the City of Moscow and Fiat, the Italian auto maker, in an agreement to build and manage two hotels, one to open in 1991, the other two or three years later.
Virtually every American chain has held talks with Intourist or other Soviet agencies, said Dieter Janssen, a Sheraton executive. But high initial costs and the Soviet bureaucracy have discouraged many.
Intourist officials hope that joint ventures will bring in capital and expertise. Until recently, foreigners could own at most 49 percent of a joint venture. Now a foreign company could, in principle, open a hotel on its own. In practice, many foreign companies will need Intourist or another native partner to guide them through the welter of Soviet laws.
The Slavjanskaya is Intourist's first new Moscow hotel since 1972. Radisson, a subsidiary of the Carlson Companies of Minneapolis, will manage the hotel, while the Americom International Corporation of Irvine, Calif., will operate an adjoining business and conference center. One thing it shares with other Intourist projects is a busted schedule. Its opening has been delayed from this year to next April.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
John Templeton's Faith and Patience

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
THERE are certain words that crop up in discussions with money managers and John Marks Templeton knows them all. But in his 50 years of money management, he has been just as likely to weave God and patience into a paragraph as yield and return. In today's market, there's more of a connection than usual.
Mr. Templeton, widely regarded as the dean of international investing, controls 52 mutual funds worldwide, with $13 billion in assets. Of the 11 mutual funds for sale in the United States, four are global stock funds that have underperformed the overall market and the global-fund segment this year, and the others are doing about as well, or a bit better than others in their segments. Two of the global funds -- the $3.6 billion Templeton World Fund and the $679.7 million Templeton Global Fund -- have taken a serious beating. 
 But Mr. Templeton, who turns 78 on Nov. 28 and says that strong religious beliefs underlie his investing principles, is unperturbed. "It's all a question of patience," he said. "In our 50-year history," he added in a recent telephone conversation, "there have been other years, sometimes two, when we have lagged the results of others. That will always be the case."
But why, specifically, have the two big global funds been hit so hard? There are several reasons.
Mr. Templeton, whose investment empire is headquartered in Nassau, the Bahamas, is a global manager and a value manager, too, hunting for bargains among companies all over the world. But value managers, as a group, have not done very well this year. "Value managers usually do poorly going into a recession, but pick up steam and perform better as a recession takes hold," said Don Phillips, vice president of Morningstar Inc., Chicago-based mutual fund consultants. He argues that "this is a terrific time to buy Templeton funds" because prices are so low.
Another reason for the funds' slippage is their focus on smaller companies. Stocks of smaller companies, especially the emerging growth stocks favored by the two Templeton global funds, have been hit hard this year. Not that that has shaken Mr. Templeton's belief in them. Indeed, the Global Fund is being renamed the Smaller Companies Fund; its entire portfolio is invested in that market. The World Fund is about two-thirds invested there.
What has also hurt both funds is that they are heavily invested in the United States. Global is 61.4 percent in American stocks; World, 47.8 percent. This year, international stock fund managers have beaten their domestic counterparts by four full percentage points, according to Lipper Analytical Services, which tracks mutual funds.
There were other problems for the two funds. They held virtually nothing in health care, a sterling performer this year. (Mr. Templeton believes it is overpriced.) And they hold big positions in financial services -- 14.4 percent of the Global portfolio and 24.3 percent of World's -- which has done poorly.
But Mr. Templeton believes financial services companies will be good bets over time. He has bet heavily on mutual fund companies and brokerages with large fund businesses because, he says, mutual funds are the most rapidly growing part of the industry. "Americans have a thousand times more invested than they did 50 years ago, and it's only the beginning," he said.
As for banks and insurance companies, he says "the risks on the downside are small" compared to upside potential. "If they recover -- and most banks will -- you earn three to four times the amount of your present investment," he said.
Clearly, his is a long-term outlook. His funds hold stocks for an average of five years, one of the longest holding periods in the industry. And he plans no major changes in his holdings.
But, he said, he is always looking for better values. "It is our custom to buy shares at the lowest price in relation to what we think companies may earn in the long term," he said. He sells a stock whenever he can find a comparable stock that is 50 percent cheaper. Right now, he sees bargains galore. In August, he began buying stocks heavily, but will not say what he is buying. Among his biggest holdings in World Fund are National Australia Bank Ltd. and Merrill Lynch. In Global, they include the Quantum Corporation, United Carolina Bancshares and Atlantic Southeast Airlines.
He contends that the United States is in the later stages of a bear market that began in August 1987, and predicts unprecedented global prosperity over the next 40 years. His optimism is reflected in his just-published book, "Riches for the Mind and Spirit," comprising inspirational writings from the Bible, history, literature and other sources. His strong spiritual sense -- he is a devout Presbyterian -- is also reflected in the Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion, worth $800,000 this year, which he endowed because "the laws of love and charity differ from the laws of mathematics." How? "The more we give away," he said, "the more we have left."

 
 
THE BROKERS TAKE VENGEANCE
 CONVENTIONAL wisdom holds that in tough times, independent mutual funds sold by stockbrokers flounder because brokers, pushed to fatten profits, are selling more funds sponsored by their own firms.
But the reality is quite different this year. The market share of both types of funds has remained static even as the stock market has taken a beating. (The August blip, so evident in the accompanying chart, came from big sales pushes for several global income funds created recently by big brokerage firms.)
Why? Brokers are not pushing mutual funds sponsored by brokerages; they don't want to tie themselves too tightly to employers in a period of layoffs, says Dean Eberling, vice president at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. In other words, brokers with clients heavily invested in funds sponsored by their employer will find it tough to take them along to a new employer. Mr. Eberling doesn't expect that to change until employment at the big brokerages stabilizes.

HEADLINE: Technology;
A Thirsty California Is Trying Desalination

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

DATELINE: SAN RAFAEL, Calif.

 BODY:
FACING a possible fifth year of sustained drought, communities along the California coast are looking to desalinated ocean or bay water as a way to quench their thirst and water their lawns.
While most water districts are only looking at desalination now because alternative sources are dry, advances in technology over the past few years have helped make seawater a competitive source for drinking water. As California's population growth continues to outstrip its water supply, communities are looking beyond the current drought and investigating desalination as a long-term solution. 
 Most are considering some form of reverse osmosis, a kind of ultrafiltration technology first developed in the late 1960's to supply super-pure water for use in manufacturing computer chips. In the Middle East, most countries use various distillation methods that heat the salt water and recapture the purified water as condensed steam. While this method consumes more energy, it can be efficient when coupled with a power plant that utilizes the waste heat.
No matter which method is used, desalinated water is expensive -- two or more times the cost of water from natural resources. But in areas where those resources are drying up, polluted or simply overtaxed, it may be the most viable alternative.
"You back into desalination; you do it when you don't have other choices," said Robert S. Castle, senior engineer of the Marin Municipal Water District, which is currently operating a pilot desalination plant near the north end of San Francisco Bay. Despite the costs, desalination "uniquely fills our needs," he said. "It is incremental in supply; you can run it only when you want it; and it's drought-proof."
The bay is less salty than the ocean, but it is more turbid, clouded with silt from rivers, industrial waste and microscopic marine life. As a result, Marin County is experimenting at the pilot plant with various types of pre-treatment filtration systems to clean bay water before it goes into the desalination plant. After the larger particles are removed, the still-salty water is sent to the reverse osmosis unit. Wheras conventional filters can only remove suspended solids, reverse osmosis can remove dissolved solids, like salt.
In reverse osmosis, the salt water is pumped along a porous cylindrical membrane at high pressure. The process is a continuous one, and because the water is flowing along the membrane rather than perpendicular to it, the flow tends to flush the very small pores, so only occasional cleaning is needed.
Water molecules pass through the membrane, while salt molecules, bacteria and pollutants, which are larger, are left behind. It takes two or three gallons of salt water to make one gallon of fresh, depending on the saline content. Solid particles are collected and dumped at a landfill, while the concentrated salt brine is often blended with sewer outfall, which, being non-salty, brings overall salinity back to normal ocean or bay levels.
One development that made possible the current generation of seawater reverse osmosis equipment is the spiral wound membrane. Winding the membrane material like paper towel on a tube allows much larger amounts of membrane surface to fit in a given space. And the membrane materials themselves have evolved to the point where they can reject more than 99 percent of the total dissolved solids.
IT takes just one pass through the reverse osmosis unit to reduce total dissolved solids from the 35,000 to 40,000 parts per million typical of seawater to less than 500, the level considered safe to drink. But to make a better tasting water, Marin and other counties perform two passes, and then run the water over limestone to restore some mineral taste. Water sampled at the Marin pilot plant was very fresh and clean-tasting.
Unlike some communities that plan to operate or lease desalination plants only for the duration of the drought, Marin County plans to build a permanent, five-million-gallon-a-day plant to supply up to 25 percent of its water needs. Mr. Castle estimates that water from the plant would add about $6 to the average $25 monthly residential water bill.
Other California communities considering desalination include Santa Barbara -- which is already building a $25 million plant to supply one-third of the city's needs by 1992 -- Monterey, San Diego, Morro Bay, Ventura, Oxnard and Los Angeles. So far, no other states have seawater desalination, although reverse osmosis is commonly used in Florida to purify brackish water for drinking.
Compared with alternatives like pipelines or tanker ships, desalination plants offer communities the advantages of an unlimited water supply and greater self-sufficiency.
"You can place a desalination plant anywhere there's seawater," said David Grunau, vice president of Aqua Design Inc. in Campbell, Calif., which has installed 30 reverse osmosis plants on seven Caribbean islands. Owning such a plant means "nobody else controls your water supply," he said.
The Caribbean plants built by Aqua Design and most of the reverse osmosis plants envisioned for California are relatively small. But the Bechtel Corporation recently completed a 15-million-gallon-per-day plant in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, the largest of its kind in the world. David C. Bolton, Bechtel's project manager for desalination, said the simultaneous advance of several technologies made such a large plant viable.
Reverse osmosis "technology has advanced fairly dramatically in the last three years," Mr. Bolton said. "What actually has happened is that the entire system has come together, not just membranes, but pumps and other components have gotten better."
COSTS still need to drop further, but Mr. Bolton said it is wrong to compare desalinated water with the natural resource. "In the U.S., the cost of desalted water still tends to be prohibitive when compared with natural resources, but that's only when they are natural," he said. "In California, they are drying up." Given the pressures on the water supply, he said, desalination is "a long-term solution that has been brought up by a short-term problem."
Indeed, the Metropolitan Water District, which supplies water to southern California, is considering building several very large plants. These would be distillation operations, utilizing the waste heat from electricity-generating plants for greater energy efficiency. For the 100 million-gallon-per-day size planned, such plants are still considered more economical than reverse osmosis.
"Distillation has been around a long time; the only problem is cost," said Gary M. Snyder, the district's assistant chief engineer. "But as other sources of water get more expensive, and as we bring down the cost of desalination, there may be a point where they cross."

HEADLINE: FORUM;
An Oil Policy That Can Keep the Peace

BYLINE: By HOSSEIN ASKARI; Hossein Askari is professor of international finance at George Washington University and senior adviser to the Petroleum Finance Company. From 1978 to 1981, he was adviser to the Minister of Finance of Saudi Arabia.

 BODY:
THE Persian Gulf crisis has once again shown the underlying volatility of the international oil market and the world's economic dependence on gulf oil. While the restoration of Kuwait is the moral imperative, the international community should at the same time look ahead to formulate policies to support stable oil supplies and prices.
Oil price volatility during the last two decades can be attributed only marginally to the policies of individual exporting countries or of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Supply shortages, panic buying and the resulting price volatility have been due to three factors: political instability in oil exporting countries (during the Iranian Revolution), regional conflicts (the 1973 Arab-Israeli war, the Iran-Iraq war and the current gulf crisis) and the absence of adequate strategic oil supplies. 
 A precondition of avoiding disruptions in oil supplies is the internal stability of gulf nations. The Iraqi invasion has focused on the internal conditions of some countries in the region. As was the case in Iran, human rights, free elections, inequitable income distribution, rampant corruption and the legitimacy to rule are the standard concerns. The fortunate people living in the region have money but are still wealthy servants. But in the end, there is never enough money to buy the hearts, minds and self-respect of any person with a soul. President Bush's proposal for a United Nations Commission on Free Elections underscores world opinion on this issue.
A second area of concern is regional security to deter aggression. A visible and permanent American presence is opposed by most governments and citizens of the gulf. Instead, the world community, through the United Nations, should adopt a resolution stating that any act of aggression will be rebuffed immediately. For such a resolution to be effective, the world community must be consistent in condemning aggression -- something that was not done after the Iraqi invasion of Iran.
An additional component of regional peace is the settlement of the Israeli-Palestinian dispute. Although this issue may be temporarily out of fashion, even in Arab circles, while attention is focused on Kuwait, it remains critical for any permanent regional solution. A solution to this problem is important for the credibility of the United Nations.
A third helpful policy is the development of a world strategic petroleum reserve to ameliorate unforeseen supply disruptions.
Although several prosperous countries, including the United States, have strategic reserves, they have not been used to make up for supply shortfalls. The need is for a world strategic petroleum reserve to meet shortfalls for all countries, with its use being more or less automatic and commensurate with the shortfall to deter panic buying and speculation.
This strategic reserve should be stocked when there is excess worldwide production capacity. All exporting nations should be asked to take part. The supplies should be stored in several locations around the world, reflecting import demands. The level of reserves should be substantial, say the output of the largest producer in the world for six months.
To implement a world petroleum reserve, many technical issues must be addressed. Should the oil be bought or leased? An approach discussed with Saudi Arabia for the American strategic petroleum reserve was for oil exporters to lease the oil to the importing countries.
Leasing, as opposed to outright sales, reduces budgetary pressures on importing countries, while leasing affords oil exporters some revenues. The oil exporters would receive annual lease payments -- based on the market price of oil when leased -- for their oil in storage. The lease rate is another issue. It could be fixed at the level of interest paid on the World Bank bonds.
If the oil is leased, who owns the oil in storage and thus decides when it can be used? If the World Bank controlled the reserve, it would be possible to establish an acceptable distribution of voting power between World Bank directors representing exporters and importers.
Another issue is how to set the price for suppliers? This is a classic inventory problem and must be negotiated.
A WORLD strategic petroleum reserve would not necessarily erase the need for national reserves. Some existing national reserves could be made a part of the world reserve, affording additional budgetary relief to countries like the United States.
The Persian Gulf crisis, though a tragedy, gives the world community a chance to look ahead and conceive policies to promote petroleum security and price stability. These opportunities can only be overlooked at great risk.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
All the Wrong Moves on the Deficit

BYLINE: By ROBERT ORTNER; Robert Ortner was Under Secretary of Commerce during the Reagan Administration. He is author of "Voodoo Deficits."

 BODY:
THE agreement on the budget deficit is doomed to failure. All that time and effort were spent debating the wrong problem. The budget deficit is not the cause of our ailing economy, it is a symptom. By focusing on the deficit, our leaders found political accommodation but they did not begin to address the economy's actual short- or long-term problems, let alone solve them. In fact, the budget agreement could actually make our economic situation worse.
The United States has probably already entered its ninth postwar recession. Cutting spending or raising taxes -- or both -- will only slow the economy still more. Fiscal tightening at this time should be deemed a political felony -- reckless endangerment of the economy. In addition to taxing away more of our incomes, our elected officials will cause many of us to lose our jobs as the economy slows. 
 What got lost in the debate is that both the Federal deficit and total Federal debt are not at emergency levels. Today's outstanding debt is equal to about 42 percent of our gross national product -- not too bad by historical standards. During the post-World War II boom, total debt was gradually brought down from more than 100 percent of G.N.P. immediately after the war to about 25 percent a decade ago. It was brought down gradually through economic growth and not with debt-reduction measures.
The United States has been growing at about 2 percent to 2.5 percent or less each year while Japan has been growing at 4 percent to 5 percent. The reason Japan outstrips us in growth is that it allocates a much larger share of its domestic output to research and development and to capital spending than we do. While Japan invests about a quarter of its national income in new plants and equipment, we manage to invest only an eighth. Japan's investment allocation is highest among the major industrial countries. Ours is the lowest. The inevitable result is that productivity in Japan, especially in manufacturing, is growing more than twice as fast as in the United States.
These are not just cold, dry numbers. Throughout this century, the real wages of American workers have risen in line with productivity. Real wages represent our purchasing power and, hence, our standard of living. Some writers have taken comfort in noting that the level of American output per worker is still the highest in the world. That is true, for now. But Japan will surpass us in this decade.
Rather than concern itself with cutting the deficit, Congress should have reinstated the Investment Tax Credit. A lower tax rate on capital gains -- as was proposed by the President -- will not do the job of a tax credit. A cut in the capital gains tax will not encourage enough needed investment in plant and equipment. Instead, much of its impact will be diverted to purely financial transactions like leveraged buyouts. It would largely be a tax break for the rich.
AT a 2 percent growth rate, our economic pie will double in 35 years. If growth increases to 5 percent, the pie will double in only 14 years. By accelerating our economic pace through investment, we will not only raise our standard of living, we will have more resources available to deal with our pressing social problems. And of course, what Congress failed to understand, is that faster growth will help bring down the budget deficit without a tax-rate hike.
In the coming months and years, it will become clear that the 1990 budget summit was not a battle of Democrats against Republicans but of government against the people.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert Ortner (George Tames for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Gulf Isn't the Only Crisis

BYLINE: By Sam Nunn; Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, is chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Since Aug. 2, our attention to events beyond our borders has been confined largely to the Iraqi aggression in the Persian Gulf. In recent days, our preoccupation with Iraq has been magnified by the debate that was triggered by President Bush's announcement of new U.S. military deployments to the region.
However, three other ominous foreign policy problems -- serious energy shortfalls in Eastern Europe; severe food shortages in the Soviet Union and the chronic ills of the Middle East -- lurk just over the horizon. These problems lack the immediacy of the gulf crisis but if left unaddressed could spawn crises of even greater magnitude.
While the countries of Eastern Europe, including Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland, face potentially crippling energy shortfalls, their traditional supplier, the Soviet Union, is suffering its own oil production and energy problems. In addition, Moscow says it will soon shift to world prices and hard currency in its trade with former client states, which could mean billions in additional fuel costs for Eastern Europe.
These countries had planned to receive Iraqi oil in payment for past sales of Eastern European arms and other exports to Iraq. For the U.S., Japan and Western Europe, the U.N. embargo means we will not buy oil from Iraq. For Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland, the embargo means these countries will not receive the oil Iraq already owes them.
The world community cannot neglect Eastern Europe as it struggles to overcome an impending energy crisis that could doom its quest for market economies and even jeopardize its emerging democracies.
In addition to asking the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank to increase assistance to Eastern Europe, which the Administration is doing, I believe Saudi Arabia and our other friends among the oil producing states should be called upon to help. This should not pose an undue burden to the oil producers. Saudi Arabia alone has already realized a windfall profit of about $16 billion to $20 billion from higher oil prices and increased oil output.
We should urge the Japanese to help Eastern Europe with grants and low interest long-term loans, preferably through international organizations. This could be a much more meaningful Japanese contribution to stability than sending a few thousand Japanese troops to the Middle East.
As for the likelihood of serious food shortages in the Soviet Union, here is how a leading Soviet economic expert describes the domestic economic situation: "The market has collapsed, the budget deficit is dreadful . . . monetary circulation and the financial system are on the brink of complete disaster." Against this gloomy backdrop, much of the fall harvest has been lost because of bad weather, poor transportation and inadequate storage and processing facilities. Moreover, because the ruble has become virtually worthless, farmers are refusing to sell their output to the central Government.
Should we help the Soviet people overcome a potential crisis of food supply as they struggle to move from a command to a market economy, from dictatorial one-party rule to representative democracy? The answer is yes: Chaos in a nation that possesses 10,000 nuclear weapons is not in our national security interests.
Two measures would help us as well as the Soviet Union. We should bring the recently initialed U.S.-Soviet trade agreement into force and waive the Jackson-Vanik amendment, which denies the Soviets most- favored nation treatment and U.S. Government credits. The President has said he would not initiate waiver action until the Soviet Parliament passes a suitable law governing emigration. Though the Parliament has not yet done this, Soviet emigration to Israel and other countries is booming. Free emigration is why the Jackson-Vanik amendment was originally passed. President Bush should forget the formalities and deal with the realities.
Waiver, rather than repeal, of the Jackson-Vanik amendment would keep its sanctions in our arsenal, in case Soviet emigration practices take a turn for the worse. Meanwhile, such U.S. Government programs as Commodity Credit Corporation credits, intended to facilitate the export of U.S. agricultural products, would be able to swing into action. This would help the American farmer and our economy while providing relief to the Soviet people as they weather a particularly difficult phase of their economic transition.
Second, the Soviet Union has under-exploited proven oil reserves and inadequately explored potential oil reserves. This overall energy potential cannot be realized quickly. But it is a valuable and needed asset, and U.S. companies have the expertise to enhance current oil extraction and explore new oilfields in the Soviet Union.
The bottom line here is an exchange of the Soviet Union's energy resources for our agricultural products. To make this happen, we need to clear away outmoded legal and bureaucratic obstacles that handicap our businessmen and farmers and needlessly complicate such logical, mutually beneficial deals.
The third problem is the stability of the Middle East after the gulf crisis. There are four factors that predate the current crisis and exist independently from it, but which make it more complex and dangerous: the wide gap between the have and have-not Arab states; the Arab population boom throughout the region; the lack of democracy in Arab states as well as a lack of regional economic cooperation among the Arab countries, and the Arab-Israeli conflict.
Taken together, the problems make difficult the possibility of peaceful economic and political development within and among Arab states. The per capita gross national product in the region varies from more than $10,000 in the richest countries to under $1,000 in the poorest, with the bulk of the population living in the poorer countries.
A present Arab population of something over 200 million could swell to some 500 million by the year 2025, placing unprecedented demands on limited resources, including water. And at the moment there is neither a genuine working democracy among the Arab countries nor any significant regional economic cooperation among them. Interrelated problems of this magnitude defy easy solution. There is an encouraging historical precedent, however.
In the late 1940's, the United States responded to economic stagnation in Western Europe with the Marshall Plan, which offered economic assistance once the European countries developed a common plan for economic recovery. Despite the obvious differences between postwar Europe and today's Middle East, the Arab countries need to think in terms of a similar area-wide approach, financed primarily by the region's oil exporting countries.
Regional cooperation should help to ease population pressures and vast economic disparities among Arab states, which taken together with the absence of democratic government contain the seeds of desperation and confrontation. The United States and other democracies should work with the countries of the Middle East to assist their transition to genuinely representative government.
Regional stability cannot be achieved, however, without settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict. This is no time for high-profile initiatives that could exacerbate tensions between the Israelis and Arabs. But at some point the conflict will have to be settled through negotiations. Left unattended, the Arab-Israeli problem polarizes and radicalizes the peoples of the region. It provides cover for militarization and military rule in the area. It fuels an ever more lethal regional arms race.
This problem is distinct from the gulf crisis created by Saddam Hussein. Yet out of the current crisis could come a coalition of Arab nations willing to pursue peace directly with Israel. The goal of quiet and creative U.S. diplomacy should be to facilitate renewal and success of the peace process, in the light of changing Middle East realities. Benign neglect is not an acceptable option.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Budget Agreement Seen as Likely to Help the Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Tom Wicker's pessimistic analysis of the Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990 in "A Bad Budget Deal" (column, Nov. 4) does a disservice by overlooking a large body of evidence suggesting that the act will help the economy.
Moreover, Mr. Wicker is mistaken in his implication that the framers of this legislation acted in ignorance of, or indifference to, its likely economic effects. He argues that the package, which will reduce the deficit by about $490 billion over five years, will weaken the economy and reduce investment, and that its authors must have overlooked a number of arguments that purportedly shed light on the legislation's economic effects.
The architects of the budget deal acted because economists of virtually every ideological stripe advised them over the last few years that a significant reduction in the deficit would increase, not reduce, economic growth and living standards. To be sure, the spending cuts and tax increases in the package may temporarily weaken private investment and aggregate demand. But most economists are confident that, after some delay, these developments will be more than offset by positive ones.
In contrast to Mr. Wicker's arguments, private investment should increase because of a reduction in interest rates resulting from scaled-back Federal borrowing. The decline in rates should be helped along by an easing of monetary policy that the Federal Reserve chairman has all but promised to deliver in response to the budget pact. Exports should strengthen as the nation comes to depend less on foreign capital to finance its excessive deficits. In turn, stronger investment and net exports will yield higher incomes and living standards.
Additional public investment may also benefit the economy, as Mr. Wicker argues in "America's Real Deficit" (column, Nov. 7), but this does not diminish the benefits that are likely to flow from the budget deal. The spending cuts in the legislation did not significantly affect Federal investment. Moreover, the budget act leaves policy makers free to shift Federal spending toward investment, thereby fulfilling Mr. Wicker's wish.
 
ROBERT D. REISCHAUER
Director, Congressional Budget Office
Washington, Nov. 8, 1990

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: India Gets $450 Million Loan for Gulf Hardship

BYLINE: By SANJOY HAZARIKA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Nov. 17

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund has agreed to loan India $400 million to $450 million to address an economic crisis caused by rising oil prices and shortages after the Iraqi takeover of Kuwait, a top Indian finance official said today.
But the release of the funds depends on a formal application by the new minority Government of Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar, who in the past has been a sharp critic of international lending institutions and multinational corporations. The impending decision is likely to reflect the economic thinking of Mr. Shekhar, whose views may now be tempered by harsh economic reality and a balance of payments crisis, aides said. 
 A top aide to Mr. Shekhar said separately that the Prime Minister was not against foreign assistance and that "we will make a decision very soon" on the issue. The aide, Yashwant Sinha, who is expected to get a major post in the Government, indicated that a decision on the I.M.F. offer would be made after the Prime Minister brought more ministers into his Cabinet. The Prime Minister has appointed only Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal so far.
The monetary fund's executiveboard cleared the assistance in principle this week. The money is to come from an I.M.F. reserve called the Contingency Compensatory Financing Facility, said a Government official familiar with the negotiations.
The reserve is meant to help third-world countries with foreign-exchange difficulties and pay the cost of food imports. After much lobbying from third-world countries, the fund agreed to expand its role to help meet problems arising from the sudden jump in oil prices after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Two Indian officials met with fund officials in Washington this week to press for special assistance to overcome high oil prices.
In an interview today, Mr. Sinha identified the new Government's economic priorities: holding the line on prices, increasing foreign-investor confidence, slashing Government spending, tightening management of resources and a review of all major uncompleted projects.
"I think that Mr. Chandra Shekhar would like to follow the policies of Mrs. Indira Gandhi, a happy amalgam of the principle of self-reliance with foreign assistance in required high-technology areas," he said. Mrs. Gandhi governed India for two terms and began a process of gradual economic liberalization that was continued by her son and successor, Rajiv Gandhi, and by V. P. Singh, Mr. Shekhar's predecessor.
Mr. Singh was ousted last week after a conservative Hindu party withdrewits support in Parliament and Mr. Shekhar broke with Mr. Singh by leading a dissident faction out of his party and reaching a deal with the Congress Party of Mr. Gandhi for the requisite support in Parliament.
Mr. Sinha said many of those involved in recent Hindu-Muslim and caste disputes that led to rioting and deaths across Northern India "are now in a chastened mood" after the turmoil led to the fall of Mr. Singh's Government. "Perhaps, it was necessary to go through this trauma," he said.
Still, the Bharatiya Janata Party, which withdrew support from Mr. Singh in a dispute over its plans to build a temple on the site of a mosque at Ayodhya, is prepared for a renewed confrontation with Mr. Shekhar; it has called for a new march on the site by followers on Dec. 6. Mr. Shekhar isreaching out to Hindu and Muslim religious and political leaders in an effort to calm both sides.
Mr. Shekhar was sworn in as India's eighth Prime Minister Nov. 9 and won a confidence vote Friday night with the support of the Congress Party and other smaller regional party allies.
Mr. Sinha said the Government must set deadlines for clearing foreign applications and cut the bureaucratic procedures that make many foreign companies wary of investing here.
"It is largely a problem of management," he said. "Foreign companies dislike delays and uncertainty the most. They do not know how long the clearance will take or if the sanction will come through at all. I think that the Government must set deadlines like 15 or 20 days in which an application is examined and cleared or rejected."

HEADLINE: The Ex-Im Bank Replies

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The article ("Time for the Ex-Im Bank to Fade Away," Nov. 4) which criticized Ex-Im Bank's loans and guarantees alleged we had outlived our usefulness.
The facts are that Ex-Im Bank makes loans only to support the export of American goods and services and only when an Ex-Im loan is necessary for the American exporter to win the export sale. We do not, and should not, finance a large percentage of total American exports. However, the bank does play a key role in expanding the American export base. For example, last year, about 27 percent of its authorizations went to small business. Ex-Im loan and guarantee support is critical to American exports to some markets by certain manufacturing sectors in our economy.
In a perfect world, there would be no need for trade subsidies, no export agencies. However, the reality is that our trading partners have active, well-funded export credit agencies similar to Ex-Im Bank. I can think of no time in the last decade when the muscle of Ex-Im Bank was more needed to secure our global commercial interests. American business would be at a severe disadvantage without an export subsidy to meet the competition head on.
The other major export credit agencies have more than $210 billion in outstanding credit to developing countries. Only $26 billion or 13 percent of that is American Ex-Im Bank credits. In the Pacific Basin alone, the United States loses a minimum of $4 billion a year in export sales due to the use of mixed credits (a mixture of commercial credits and government subsidized loans) by competitors.
Export credit agency exposure in the half dozen emerging free market economies of Central Europe is now about $20 billion, plus $15 billion more in the Soviet Union. The Ex-Im Bank share is $1.8 billion -- we are hardly a factor. Obviously, American firms need to be more aggressive in securing a share of these markets. With commercial banks shying away from foreign investments, the demand for Ex-Im Bank to guarantee worthwhile credit risks in developing global markets is growing, not diminishing.
 
JOHN D. MACOMBER
Washington, Nov. 8
 
The author is president and chairman of the Export-Import Bank of the United States.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
WEST IS REBUKED BY JORDANIAN KING

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 17

 BODY:
King Hussein opened the Jordanian Parliament today with a largely bleak assessment of Jordan's prospects in the wake of the Persian Gulf crisis and attacked what he called the "blatant and shameless" hypocrisy of nations involved in the military buildup in Saudi Arabia.
While the King did not mention the United States by name, his attack was clearly directed at the Bush Administration and its Western allies. 
 "Their actual goals stem from their desire to control our destiny and the Arab nations' resources," said the Jordanian monarch, using language that was uncharacteristically harsh. "Their blatant and shameless conduct must confirm to us that their real motives are far from being the hollow claim to uphold legitimacy and defend principles."
 
Signs of Fatigue
 King Hussein, whose speech to the opening session of Parliament amounted to a Jordanian State of the Union address, spoke in a solemn, deliberate tone, the fatigue of recent weeks visible on his face.
He said his nation of three million people was at a "crossroads" and that without an Arab solution to the crisis, the Middle East could be on "the verge of a catastrophe which would destroy our existence and place the future of the Arab nation in the hands of others."
King Hussein, an Arab leader who has promoted close ties to the United States and other Western nations during his 38-year reign, is a man with few palatable options as a result of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last August.
Torn between his affection for the West and his longstanding economic and military alliance with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, the Jordanian leader suggested today that it was hypocritical for nations to try to uphold international law in the Persian Gulf while ignoring the plight of Palestinians living under Israeli occupation.
 
'Double-Standard Attitude'
 "These powers adopt the complacent stand toward Israeli aggression while assuming the role of defenders of international legitimacy and human rights in the Gulf," he said. "They maintain this double-standard attitude with the least regard for principles."
He charged that some of those nations had responded with a "timid rebuke of victim and aggressor" after at least 17 Palestinians were slain by the Israeli police in a clash last month at Al Aksa Mosque in Jerusalem.
He called again for the removal of the thousands of Western troops deployed in Saudi Arabia, calling the deployment "a visible and persistent threat to the Arab nation's hopes and aspirations for a unified and impregnable homeland." The King has said that the crisis can be solved only through negotiations among Arab nations.
 
Moves Toward Democracy
 His speech to the Jordanian lawmakers came a year after King Hussein allowed the first parliamentary elections in this country in 22 years.
In his address, the King said he hoped a special commission would complete its work on what is called a national charter for Jordan by year's end. The charter, which is separate from the Jordanian Constitution, is expected to set guidelines for multiparty politics.
According to news reports reaching here today from Baghdad, Western diplomats in the Iraqi capital are hopeful that many more American hostages than originally planned will leave Kuwait on evacuation flights Sunday.
 
U.S. Hostages to Leave
 Reuters said in a dispatch from Baghdad that about 180 Americans, mainly women and children, would be aboard two Iraqi Airways jets being chartered by the State Department.
The dispatch said the planes would fly to Baghdad, where the passengers would be joined by a few Britons, and all would board an Iraqi Airways Boeing 747 for a flight to London.
The department said earlier this week that it had chartered only one plane, a smaller Boeing 707, and that only about 100 Americans were expected to make the trip. An American Embassy spokesman in Amman said today that he had no information on the Reuters report.
The situation remained bleak for other Western hostages being held in Iraq. Twenty-one Swedes being detained by Iraq released a statement today accusing their Government of doing too little to win their freedom.
"After 117 days as hostages, we no longer believe in Sweden's silent diplomacy or the Government's humanity," the hostages said. They asked that the Swedish Ambassador send envoys to Baghdad to negotiate their release.

GRAPHIC: Photo: King Hussein saluting palace guards at the opening of the Jordanian Parliament yesterday in Amman. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN EUROPE;
Arms Pact to Codify Europe's New Power Balance

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 17

 BODY:
In an important postscript to the end of the cold war, the Soviet Union is to renounce its traditional huge superiority in conventional arms in Europe when a far-reaching East-West disarmament treaty is signed at the opening of a 34-nation European-security summit meeting here on Monday.
With the treaty allowing the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the 6-member Warsaw Pact a similar number of heavy weapons in an area stretching from the Atlantic to the Urals, the West can now move more confidently toward reducing its military strength in Europe. 
 Although perennial fears of a surprise Soviet attack on Western Europe were buried in the ruins of Eastern Europe's Communist regimes, the treaty has been hailed as the most comprehensive East-West disarmament agreement to date because it formalizes the dramatically changed balance of power in Europe.
 
Big Cuts for Soviet Union
 Once the treaty has been ratified by the 22 nations, probably by mid-1991, the Soviet Union will have three years in which to destroy tens of thousands of tanks, armored vehicles, artillery pieces, combat aircraft and helicopters, to achieve parity with NATO.
In contrast, NATO, whose stockpiles of conventional weapons are already close to the ceilings allowed by the treaty, is expected to destroy fewer than 4,000 tanks, half of which belonged to East Germany and were counted as Western after German unification last month.
The agreement does not deal with troop levels, but this question will be tackled in subsequent negotiations that are to begin in Vienna on Nov. 26 and take into account current moves and announced plans by Moscow and Washington to cut back their military personnel in Europe.
The importance the United States gives to the so-called Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe is such that President Bush warned that he would not attend next week's Paris summit meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe unless it had already been concluded.
 
U.S. Delegate's View
 "We ended up with a treaty that is awfully close to what we were seeking a year or two ago," R. James Woolsey, the chief American delegate at the conventional arms talks, said after the final text was approved in Vienna Thursday evening.
NATO's task was made easier, though, by the fact that the start of negotiations in March 1989 was soon followed by the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe, by the virtual disintegration of the Warsaw Pact and by the voluntary withdrawal of many Soviet troops and weapons from the territory of Moscow's former satellites.
"You could say that, to some extent, the treaty has been overtaken by events," Manfred Worner, NATO's Secretary General, noted, "but this does not make it superfluous. What was done unilaterally can be revised unilaterally. So the treaty pins down the changes and makes them irreversible."
 
Easing the Soviet Threat
 Mr. Woolsey said the West originally saw the negotiations as a way of reducing Soviet military might in Eastern Europe and forestalling a quick thrust into the West. "But that was done by Vaclav Havel, Solidarity and others," he said, refering to the role played by the Czechoslovak dissident leader and the Polish labor movement in toppling Communist regimes.
Now, he went on, the treaty provides institutions and mechanisms to insure that the changes of the past year become permanent. And he stressed that, along with weapons destruction, it also contains crucial verification provisions that "make it much harder to think of a strike or a surprise military movement."
As a result, according to NATO experts, the Atlantic alliance will have a warning period of two to three years should a new buildup of Soviet conventional forces seem to pose a threat to the West. And if this violated the treaty, the experts said, NATO would have the right -- as well as ample time -- to respond.
Both Western and Eastern negotiators said the Vienna talks took place in a remarkably cordial manner, with Moscow apparently eager for a treaty even though its bargaining position was being steadily weakened by the surge of democracy in Eastern Europe and by mounting economic and political troubles at home.
 
'A Balanced Treaty'
 "It's a balanced treaty," Istvan Gyarmati, the chief Hungarian negotiator, said. "Militarily, the Soviets gave more than they gained, but politically they got a lot. And what they gave up militarily, they couldn't finance anyway."
Western officials also insisted that, while they are concerned, they are not alarmed about intelligence reports that over the last two years the Soviet Union has moved close to 20,000 tanks and more than 30,000 artillery pieces from Europe to east of the Ural mountains, beyond the area affected by the treaty.
If they were still stationed in Europe at 9 A.M. on Sunday, when the signing countries must provide information on their conventional weapons, the treaty would have required their destroyed. But Soviet officials have argued that many were moved as part of Moscow's withdrawal from Eastern Europe and that most will be destroyed or converted for civilian use.
"The Russians have given us assurances and have been forthcoming with information," Mr. Worner said, "and we do not distrust them. But we have told them that we will closely monitor what happens because, without absolute transparency, it will be difficult to get ratification of the treaty."
 
New Treaty Ceilings
 Since details of each country's conventional weapons will not be revealed until Sunday, Western experts said they still do not know how many will fall above the new European ceilings for each alliance: 20,000 battle tanks, 30,000 armored vehicles, 20,000 artillery pieces, 6,800 combat aircraft and 2,000 attack helicopters.
The last estimates considered reliable by NATO showed that when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev announced a unilateral program of Soviet military cuts in December 1988, the Warsaw Pact had 60,000 tanks, including 46,000 Soviet tanks, in the area of the Atlantic to the Urals, compared with just 22,000 for all of NATO.
The Warsaw Pact enjoyed a similar advantage over NATO in other heavy weapons -- 63,000 to 27,000 in armored vehicles, 61,000 to 21,000 in artillery pieces, 14,000 to 6,300 in combat aircraft and 3,000 to 2,000 in attack helicopters. Most of those -- 45,000 armored vehicles, 47,000 artillery pieces, 11,000 aircraft and 2,800 helicopters -- were attached to Soviet forces.
Western officials said that, in mid-1990, Warsaw Pact nations provided information suggesting that the alliance still had 41,000 tanks, 52,000 armored vehicles and 49,000 artillery pieces in Europe. "These figures are much lower now," an American official said, "but we think they will still have to destroy around 13,000 tanks. Aircraft, of course, can be easily flown out."
 
Limits on Single Countries
 One additional restraint on Soviet military strength involves a treaty provision limiting any single country to about two-thirds of the total weapons its alliance is alloted in most of the separate categories, and about three-quarters in others. And, in practice, Moscow's Eastern European partners forced it to accept slightly less than the maximum tanks and artillery pieces it was allowed under the treaty.
Further, during the negotiations, it became increasingly apparent that the Warsaw Pact no longer functioned as a military alliance, with several Eastern European countries often endorsing NATO positions.
The 111-page treaty itself is enormously complicated. It even details approved ways of destroying tanks, including damaging them with explosive charges, crushing them with an eight-ton iron ball, squashing them in a powerful vice, cutting them up and using them for target practice. "Japan is very interested in all the scrap metal," the American official said.
A 22-nation Joint Consultative Group will also be established to verify information provided by countries over the next 120 days, while signing governments will be allowed to witness destructions and carry out on-site inspections of storage installations once the three-year "destruction period" is over.
Two questions considered crucial by the United States -- troop levels and aerial inspections -- were not included in the treaty, in part because of the rush to reach agreement in time for next week's summit meeting. But they will be tackled in talks scheduled to begin later this month.
The United States and the Soviet Union in fact agreed last February to limit their ground and air force personnel stationed in Europe outside their national territory to 195,000 each, with an additional 30,000 American troops allowed to remain at a greater distance from the Soviet border.
But this provisional accord was overtaken by events as the Soviet Union came under pressure to withdraw its troops from Eastern Europe. "Moscow found itself tied to an agreement authorizing 195,000 American troops in Europe when it soon would have no troops beyond its own border," a Western official explained.
Having agreed to pull out its forces from Hungary and Czechoslovakia by June 30 next year, from the former territory of East Germany within four years and from Poland probably in 1992, the Soviet Union obtained Washington's agreement in September to postpone negotiation on troop levels until the subsequent talks.
NATO officials said that after a united Germany pledged to reduce its armed forces to 370,000 men and women Bonn was eager not to be seen as being singled out among European countries; it favored incorporating its troop reductions into a broader agreement. Germany is nonetheless expected to repeat its commitment to the lower troop levels here Monday.
The signers of the treaty have agreed to embark on an entirely new round of conventional arms reduction talks after a planned summit meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe in 1992. But under the presumption that the Warsaw Pact will no longer exist even in name by then, the plan is for them to involve all 34 members of the European security conference.
