HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Iraq Could Have Atomic Arsenal by 2000, Intelligence Experts Say

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
Iraq has acquired a nuclear weapons capacity that could enable it to begin manufacturing and using a small but devastating stock of nuclear missiles, shells and bombs within 10 years, American, British and Israeli intelligence experts have concluded.
The experts say that Iraq has amply demonstrated that it intends to build a nuclear arsenal from scratch. They add that unless Iraq is prevented from doing so by foreign military intervention or foreign economic restrictions, its engineers could almost certainly begin limited production of nuclear warheads within a decade. 
 Drawing from its immense oil revenues, Iraq has already acquired some of the foreign expertise, military secrets, tools, processing machinery, special alloys, electronic components, chemicals, computers, uranium ore and other materials needed for the task.
 
Threats Taken Seriously
 As Iraq hastens development of a fleet of intermediate- and long-rang missiles, moreover, its explicit and implied threats against Israel, Europe and even the United States are taken increasingly seriously.
But even the most pessimistic Israeli assessments assume that Iraq will need at least two years to begin warhead production. Most Western analysts believe that Iraq still faces enormous technical problems in creating a credible nuclear arsenal and that it would take 5 to 10 years to deploy nuclear warheads, even if the current international blockade of Iraq's borders and coasts were to be lifted.
"My own feeling," said Donald Kerr, an analyst with the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London, "is that it will be five to seven years, provided someone doesn't destroy Iraq's industrial capacity before then. The physics of nuclear explosions is fairly well understood, but the engineering of warheads is a much more difficult matter."
The large plants that would be needed to manufacture nuclear explosives would be impossible to conceal or camouflage, nuclear engineers say, and would be easy targets for attacks like Israeli air raid in 1981 that destroyed Iraq's nuclear breeder reactor at Tuwaitha.
 
Plant Would Be Hard to Hide
 Another British intelligence analyst said: "I really cannot imagine that Israel would leave standing an Iraqi gas-centrifuge uranium separation plant if one should appear in a satellite photograph or intelligence assessment. The Iraqis are wily about hiding their clandestine foreign purchases, their chemical and biological warfare facilities, their missile tests and so forth. But hiding a uranium separation plant would be like hiding an elephant in a bathtub."
A welter of reports and rumors have circulated in recent months that Iraq is close to beginning production of nuclear weapons. One set of speculations centered on some highly-enriched uranium fuel salvaged from the breeder reactor after the Israeli attack. This fuel could be used to make one crude nuclear weapon relatively quickly, although it is regularly inspected by experts from the International Atomic Energy Agency to make sure it has not been diverted to military use. Several days ago Iraq invited the agency to conduct a new inspection, suggesting that Baghdad has no immediate military plans for the fuel.
Other speculations have been based on seizures by European governments of materials and components bound for Iraq that could be used for the production of nuclear weapons.
In March, British customs officials, acting on information from United States authorities, seized a shipment of special capacitors consigned to Iraq. Such devices can store electricity and release it in a few millionths of a second as a powerful pulse. Nuclear weapons of the type Iraq is believed to be planning -- the type that destroyed the city of Nagasaki in 1945 -- depend on just this type of capacitor.
 
Germans Seize Machinery
 On July 15, German customs officials in Frankfurt seized a consignment of Swiss-made machinery bound for Iraq. The shipment consisted mainly of items fabricated from a special high-strength, corrosion-resistant steel essential to the construction of gas centrifuges -- advanced devices capable of separating fissionable uranium 235 from its inert isotope, uranium 238.
Iraq already possesses substantial stocks of crude uranium. Most of it is imported, but some reports say Iraq is also trying to exploit deposits of low-grade uranium ore in the far northwestern part of the country.
According to a study by Michael Eisenstadt of the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, Iraq bought some 250 tons of a uranium-bearing mixture called yellowcake in the late 1970's and early 1980's from Brazil, Portugal and Niger.
Yellowcake must be subjected to a complex series of processes to produce fissionable uranium 235. According to reports from Polish engineers who were briefly held as human shields by Iraq, the first chemical steps of that process are being performed at a large chemical plant at Al Qaim, northwest of Baghdad. The end chemical product in this complex chain is uranium hexafluoride -- a gas needed for the isotope separation process in which bomb fuel is produced. Western analysts can only guess where a full-scale uranium separation plant might eventually be built.
 
The Source of the Supplies
 The Simon Wiesenthal Foundation of Los Angeles has circulated a list of more than 200 companies in Europe, Asia and the United States that have supplied Iraq with materials and technologies potentially needed by a nuclear weapons industry.
Recent intelligence interest has centered on Iraq's efforts to obtain uranium raw stocks and in building a high-technology gas centrifuge plant for separating fissionable uranium 235 from nonfissionable uranium 238. Stymied during the 1970's and 1980's in attempts to buy plutonium, or weapons-grade uranium, from arms smugglers and other foreign sources, Baghdad decided to manufacture its own.
According to some published speculation, Iraq has already obtained enough parts and material to build 26 centrifuges.
But such experts in nuclear weapon technology as Leonard S. Spector, director of the Carnegie Endowment of International Peace, believe that despite this progress Iraq is still years from making weapons. One reason is that centrifuges can produce only tiny quantities of enriched uranium at a time.
In natural uranium, the content of uranium 235 is only 0.71 percent. Each time uranium hexafluoride gas made from natural uranium is passed through one of the huge centrifuges, the "enriched" product contains a slightly larger proportion of uranium 235 -- 0.794 percent -- while the "waste" gas (which is subjected to further processing) contains a slightly smaller proportion -- 0.635 percent.
 
An Elaborate Process
 To obtain significant enrichment of uranium-235 requires many passes through thousands of centrifuges, each one built of costly materials and standing some 20 feet tall. Enriched uranium suitable for most American nuclear power reactors contains only about 3 percent of uranium 235 while uranium fuel for a bomb works best at purities above 90 percent uranium 235.
A leading nuclear analyst, Gary Milhollin, director of the Washington-based Wisconsin Project of Nuclear Arms Control, said that if Iraq had only 26 centrifuges, "we'll all be long dead of old age before they get even one bomb."
A rule of thumb, he said, "is that for every thousand gas centrifuges you have in operation, you can produce enough uranium 235 each year to make between one and one-and-a-half nuclear warheads of about 15 kilotons, roughly equivalent to the explosions that devastated Hiroshima and Nagasaki. You certainly don't acquire a nuclear arsenal overnight."
Gas centrifuges cannot be dispersed because they must be operated in concert in what is called a cascade process. This means that a plant containing at least 1,000 of the big machines would be highly conspicuous, especially since it would require a railroad siding, access roads and other accessories, including a gigantic source of electrical power.
 
Three Research Installations
 Iraq is known to operate nuclear research installations at Erbil, Mosul and Tuwaitha, but no intelligence reports have come to light of any plant construction at these or any other sites that could house a full-scale gas-centrifuge separation plant.
Gas centrifuges are notoriously difficult to build and operate without accident. Their rotors spin at speeds high enough to tear ordinary steel asunder. Experimental centrifuges operated by Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee broke up so frequently that plant workers dubbed them "self-disassembly machines."
Pakistan, an emerging nuclear power that reportedly built some 14,000 gas centrifuges based on European technology, is rarely able to operate more than 1,000 at a time because of breakdowns. Pakistan is believed to have obtained enough material for a nuclear bomb in 1986, and according to the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace is thought to have sufficient fuel today to build fewer than a dozen weapons.
Weapons experts believe that Iraq must surmount another major problem -- the test explosion of a nuclear device.
If Baghdad were to build a simple weapon from its reactor fuel based on the "gun-type system," no test would be needed. The gun-type system, used in the atomic bomb that destroyed Hiroshima, uses a chemical propellant to slam a uranium 235 projectile through a cannon barrel into a target of uranium 235. Combining the two uranium masses suddenly initiates a chain fission reaction and a nuclear explosion.
 
Iraq's Sights Are Higher
 But Baghdad has given many signs that its sights are higher; it clearly hopes to build a more complex implosion bomb similar to the bomb that destroyed Nagasaki. The detonation of such a bomb must be perfectly choreographed in microsecond steps, or the explosion will fizzle.
"I would be very surprised if Iraq were to deploy implosion warheads without testing at least one of them," said Dr. Sidney Drell, a high-energy physicist at the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center who has served on Presidential scientific advisory boards since the 1960's.
Mr. Kerr of the International Institute for Strategic Studies agreed. "They'd have to look for some remote part of the world where they could carry it off without being observed too easily," he said. "Certainly, they have been testing their new missiles in Mauritania. Out in the open Sahara. It may be that their interest in those wide-open spaces in the Mauritanian Sahara also has to do with a nuclear test."
Gen. Yehoshua Saguy, who commanded Israel's military intelligence apparatus until 1987, said in an interview that in his estimation, based on the latest Israeli intelligence, it would take Iraq two years to pose a nuclear menace. "But left to himself," he said, referring to President Saddam Hussein, "Saddam will eventually build a nuclear arsenal, and he will have the means to attack not only Israel but most of Europe. Will the world stand by and let that happen?"

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Drugs in Europe: Signs of a Spreading Plague

BYLINE: By TOM MASHBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STRASBOURG, France, Nov. 17

 BODY:
The 14-hour days spent treating heroin addicts at a clinic in Warsaw leave Helena Baran exhausted. But after spending 10 hours here, listening to grim predictions about crack in Europe, she was alarmed.
"This is all we need," she said as four American mayors finished giving their European counterparts a blunt lesson on drugs and urban decay at a meeting here this week. "We have unemployment, people on the margin. There's already a black market in opium and barbiturates. Now, with the borders open, this drug might well flow in." 
 The American warning, delivered by the Mayors of York, Pa., Colorado Springs, Charlotte, N.C., and San Diego, arrived with a statistical exclamation point: European police officials reported this week that Continent-wide seizures of cocaine had risen sixfold since 1986, from 1.5 tons to nearly 9 tons.
This is tiny by the standards of the United States, but drug-enforcement officials say evidence points to an effort by Latin American cartels to ship cocaine to Europe now that the United States market for crack seems appears saturated.
"There is no doubt that the Colombians are looking at 1992 and Western Europe," a Drug Enforcement Administration official told Reuters, referring to the 1992 integration of the European Community. "But they are also looking at Eastern Europe, which is virgin territory for cocaine."
Noting that crack cases are rare or nonexistent in their cities, European mayors have strongly resisted the idea that the smokable form of cocaine could someday come ashore. The American mayors here said they hoped that their message would be a cold slap in the face to a skeptical audience. "We were surprised by their blase attitude when we met in Montreal last year," said Robert M. Isaac of Colorado Springs, the president of the United States Conference of Mayors, referring to a conference on crime prevention held in October 1989. "We don't want to scare anyone, but in the area of drugs, Europe is where the United States was before crack got big."
Maureen O'Connor, the Mayor of San Diego, was blunter: "They're practicing denial. They don't believe there is a problem. But as we say in the States, 'Government is always the last to know.' "
The Americans were joined by a group of Canadian mayors who said their experiences might more closely mirror those of smaller European cities.
"We don't have the same problems with guns and lack of education that you see in the States, and yet even a small city like Halifax can be home to a crack house," said Mayor John Backhouse of Prince George, British Columbia.
Although the message from North America had a chilling effect, not everyone was sure of its relevance here. "I was astonished to hear about the violence and the enormous criminality in American cities," said Mayor Jorge Sampaio of Lisbon. "But to say there is crack in the big cities of Europe, I simply don't know."
And Patrick Ouart, an aide to Mayor Jacques Chirac of Paris, said, "Are we truly vulnerable to crack? We just can't say."
European health specialists estimate that there are 100,000 cocaine addicts in Europe, and 800,000 heroin addicts, out of a population of 350 million. But 1989 was the first year that Interpol, the European police agency, reported the impounding of more cocaine than heroin, suggesting that the drug is gaining casual users.
"We don't really have hard numbers yet for crack," said Christopher Luckett, a specialist on the drug trade and on money-laundering who works for the Council of Europe, which organized the meeting here. "The Europeans have been free-basing cocaine for 15 years, and where there's coke, there's crack."
Jiri Kos, a police official in Prague who specializes in drug cases, said 7,000 people there have been counted as drug addicts so far this year. "Certainly, crack could arrive," he said. "People feel freer now, and that brings good consequences, and bad ones, too."

HEADLINE: Blacks and the Election: What Was the Message?

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME

 BODY:
In an election that played out in a welter of mixed signals, few signals were so mixed as those coming from black Americans on Nov. 6.
The turnout of black voters in the nation as a whole apparently declined relative to white turnout. But it held steady, or even rose, in states with some of the country's leading contests, as in North Carolina, Texas and California. 
 Several campaigns featured a resurgence of racial politics that was viewed as harmful to Republican efforts to attract blacks. But Election Day polls showed growing black support for Republican Congressional candidates nationally.
And notwithstanding black support that was a factor in some of the Democrats' biggest successes, particularly Ann Richards's triumph in the race for governor of Texas, a number of experts said the party's move toward the political center and away from some of its more outspoken liberal positions could be hampering its ability to turn out black voters.
 
Decline in Electorate Share
 Perhaps the most arresting set of figures about blacks that came out of the balloting were those showing a decline in their share of the electorate. A survey of voters leaving the polling places, performed by Voter Research and Surveys, the new pool effort of the network news organizations, found that blacks made up only 5 percent of the national electorate on Nov. 6. A survey by the Wirthlin Group, which does polling for Republicans, found the same 5 percent share.
That compared with New York Times/CBS News Poll findings of an 8 percent share in the last off-year election, in 1986, and 7 percent in 1982.
But exactly what the decline means, or even whether it has any lasting meaning, is a matter of debate.
Among those who suggest that the Democrats are paying a price in lost black voters because of the party's move toward the center, a shift resulting from decisive defeats in the last three Presidential elections, is Larry J. Sabato, a professor of government at the University of Virginia.
"This is not 1964," he said. "Blacks aren't thrilled to death just because they have the right to vote. They have to have someone to vote for. One cost of moderating the message by Democrats is that they aren't exciting their most loyal voter core."
Ed Brown, executive director of the Atlanta-based Voter Education Project, which seeks to enroll black voters in precincts across the South, said such slippage in their turnout was due in part to a feeling that neither party was adequately addressing their needs. Or, as it was put by Darrin Williams, a 23-year-old unemployed black Atlantan with two years of college education, "What happens at the top doesn't trickle down to the bottom." Mr. Williams counts himself among those who did not vote last week.
 
A Note of Caution
 Curtis Gans, director of the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, a Washington research organization, notes similar slippage in the last Presidential election year. A Census Bureau survey taken shortly after the Presidential election 26 years ago found that 70.7 percent of voting-age whites said they had cast ballots, as against 58.5 percent of voting-age blacks, for a gap of 12.2 percentage points. That gap had narrowed to 5.6 points by 1984, then widened to 7.6 points in 1988.
Mr. Gans attributed the widening of the margin in part to the largely bland nature of the Democratic Presidential campaign and what he called its failure to address civil rights and other issues of concern to blacks. But he cautioned against reading a great deal into the exit-poll figures coming out of the Nov. 6 vote, saying too many factors were at work in an off-year election.
For instance, some analysts noted that there were few competitive elections this year in a number of states with relatively large black populations, like New York and Mississippi, and that as a result the figures on blacks' national share of the electorate might have been artificially depressed.
 
An Opposite Trend
 Indeed, some specialists in black voting patterns said they doubted that the figures indicated any significant trend at all. To the contrary, said David Bositis, a senior associate with the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a Washington research organization specializing in black issues, various statistics point to a long-term trend in which the turnout of blacks relative to that of whites is on the rise. One such set of statistics comes from the Voter Education Project, which found that only four years ago, for the first time in history, blacks' share of the national electorate virtually equaled their share of the voting-age population.
Mr. Bositis said he expected this trend to be sustained in future elections. The number of black elected officials around the country has increased from 1,500 to more than 7,000 during the last two decades, he said, and as they move up to higher offices on the political ladder, they will carry black voters with them.
"I think the critical element is less issues than the role of black elites," Mr. Bositis said. "The movement is up over the past 10 years, and I expect it to continue. You may have episodic downturns, but the long-term movement is there."
 
Disappointment in Chicago
 The most dramatic case of disappointing black turnout last week may have been in Chicago, where it was viewed as a factor in the defeat of Neil F. Hartigan, the Democratic nominee for Illinois governor. An estimated 45 percent of black voting-age Chicagoans went to the polls, a drop of 10 percentage points from 1986, and in some predominantly black wards the figure was as low as 30 percent. One effect was to bring the city's overall rate of turnout down to 53 percent.
Black turnout was disappointing, too, in Louisiana, where in an October election State Representative David Duke, a former leader of the Ku Klux Klan, sought a seat in the United States Senate. Mr. Duke got 44 percent of the vote, and post-election analyses in Louisiana indicated that his showing was so strong because turnout among whites was 15 percentage points higher than among blacks.
But in some other states, particularly those with the most hotly contested, closely watched races, blacks' share of the total vote apparently held steady, or even rose.
In Texas, where Ms. Richards was locked in a bitter campaign against the Republican nominee, Clayton Williams, Voter Research and Surveys found that blacks made up 13 percent of the electorate, a rise of four points from the share found by CBS News in 1986.
In California, the Democratic state chairman, former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., has been under fire in recent days from a number of Democratic politicians who say that the state organization did not do enough to bring out the black and Hispanic vote and that this failure could have been the difference in Dianne Feinstein's unsuccessful campaign for governor against Senator Pete Wilson. But Voter Research and Surveys found that blacks made up 9 percent of California's electorate on Nov. 6, no drop at all from the proportion that CBS News found four years ago.
 
Gains by Republicans
 Some analysts expressed greatest surprise at an Election Day finding by a New York Times/CBS News Poll that Republicans had received 22 percent of the black vote around the country in races for the House of Representatives. That was a seven-point gain over the black vote that the same polling organization found for Republican House candidates in 1988, and double the percentage found in 1982.
Because of sampling error, a shift in black voting between any of those two polls had to be five percentage points or more to be significant. Put another way, that means that the apparent seven-point shift between 1988 and 1990 in blacks voting for Republican candidates might actually have been as little as two points.
 
Race as a Message
 One apparent benefactor of a black shift toward Republicans was Gov. Guy Hunt of Alabama, where the proportion of voting-age blacks who turned out was roughly equal to that of whites who did so. Rebuffing his Democratic challenger, Paul R. Hubbert, Governor Hunt got about a quarter of the black vote even though Democrats had accused him of injecting race into the campaign.
To a number of experts, race provided a most telling message of the election: the degree to which racially charged contests can bring out white voters.
In addition to Mr. Duke's drive in Louisiana, there was the case of North Carolina, where victory by former Mayor Harvey Gantt of Charlotte would have made him the first Southern black elected to the Senate since Reconstruction. The Gantt campaign brought a rise in North Carolina blacks' electoral share, from 16 percent in 1986 to 19 percent this year. But the incumbent, Senator Jesse Helms, whose organization injected racial issues into the campaign in its final days, won a massive white turnout that swamped Mr. Gantt.
"When the central issue of a campaign essentially is race, that's going to propel turnout," Mr. Gans said. "It's one of the fault lines of American politics."

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN EUROPE;
Bush Gives Czechs a Copy of Liberty Bell

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Nov. 17

 BODY:
President Bush rang a replica of the Liberty Bell in the Czechoslovak capital today to mark the first anniversary of this country's democratic revolution, and he evoked the memory of Czechoslovakia's subjugation by Hitler to appeal for support in his fight against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
"There is right and there is wrong. There is good and there is evil. And there are sacrifices worth making," Mr. Bush told an enthusiastic crowd of more than 100,000 people in Wenceslas Square, the symbolic center of the 1989 overthrow of Communist rule here. 
 Mr. Bush drew a cheer from the crowd, the largest he has addressed as President, by associating President Vaclav Havel with the coalition opposing Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. He repeated his vow to drive Mr. Hussein's occupation forces from the Persian Gulf sheikdom.
"The darkness in the desert sky cannot stand against the way of light," Mr. Bush said, drawing on the symbolism of light and darkness embodied in the writing of Thomas Masaryk, the first President of Czechoslovakia, to bolster his message.
 
Vague Promise of Help
 Saying that he expected Czechoslovakia to stand by the United States' side in the Persian Gulf, Mr. Bush promised his listeners that "America will stand with you" as the country grapples with its economic hardships.
This dual theme pervaded both an earlier speech that Mr. Bush delivered to the Federal Assembly here and his words to the crowd in the square. He spoke to the multitude from a bulletproof-glass booth as the early twilight slowly replaced the leaden skies of late afternoon and spotlights illuminated the Czechoslovak and American flags waved by many of those in his audience.
The mixed message seemed to underscore the way Mr. Bush's priorities have changed in the year since the revolution here and elsewhere in Eastern Europe.
He was eager to make a strong gesture of support to Czechoslovakia, to reassure his listeners that the crisis in the Persian Gulf did not mean that the United States had forgotten them, and to participate more personally in events that seemed so far removed from Washington. But Mr. Bush brought little with him in the way of additional financial aid, and his attention focused on the gulf.
 
'Your Bitter Experience'
 "I have this feeling in my heart that no peoples understand better what is at stake in the gulf than Czechs and Slovaks," Mr. Bush told the Federal Assembly, which is still not an elected body.
"You know from your bitter experience that the world cannot turn a blind eye to aggression. You know the futility and vain hope that aggressors can be appeased. You know the tragic consequences when nations confronted with aggression choose to tell themselves it is no concern of theirs."
Mr. Bush will continue to press his case on the gulf as he proceeds on a weeklong trip through Europe and the Middle East that is to culminate in a Thanksgiving Day visit to the troops in Saudi Arabia. In Paris, he is to discuss the gulf crisis on Tuesday morning with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union.
Mr. Bush is the first American President to visit Czechoslovakia while in office. He drew loud cheers from his listeners in the square when he announced that he would return to Prague a 1919 letter from Masaryk to Woodrow Wilson outlining a declaration of independence and a constitution for Czechoslovakia.
That letter has been kept in the Library of Congress, said Mr. Bush, who referred to it as a "declaration of independence." He said, "1989 was the year that freedom came home to Czechoslovakia; 1990 will be the year your declaration of independence came home to the golden city of Prague."
The emotional rally in Wenceslas Square mixed symbols of different cultures, times and countries. In a reminder of the tight security protecting Mr. Bush on this trip, agents in orange vests prowled rooftops behind neon signs advertising the original Budweiser beer and Licensintorg, an agency of the Soviet Union.
 
Symbols of Patriotism
 Mr. Bush spoke from a spot between the statue of King Wenceslas and a memorial central to Czechoslovakia's modern history, the spot where the student Jan Palach immolated himself in 1969 to protest the Soviet-led invasion a year earlier. It is covered with flowers and candles in memory of Palach and that of the student march on Nov. 17, 1989, that was violently suppressed by the police, setting in motion the final stages of the "velvet revolution" that overthrew the Communist leadership.
Mr. Bush's remarks on the future of Czechoslovakia were positive. "There are no leaves on the trees and yet it is Prague Spring," he said in a reference to the reforms of 1968 that were crushed by Soviet tanks.
"A year ago, the world saw you face down totalitarianism," Mr. Bush said. "We saw the peaceful crowds swell day by day in numbers and in resolve. We saw the few candles grow into a blaze. We saw this square become a beacon of hope for an entire nation as it gave birth to your new era of freedom."
Mr. Bush presented a replica of the Liberty Bell to Mr. Havel and rang it three times -- "once for your courage, once for your freedom, and once for your children."
He promised: "We have not forgotten. The world will never forget what happened here in this square where the history of freedom was written."
 
More Praise Than Money
 Mr. Bush had little to offer in the way of concrete assistance. He repeated an earlier pledge to obtain $5 billion in loans from the International Monetary Fund to assist East European countries with rising energy costs as a result of the gulf crisis. But the only initiative he offered was a pledge to ask Congress to create a $60 million fund to assist nascent business enterprises here. This is to be drawn from $370 million already committed to Central and Eastern Europe for the coming year.
Mr. Havel, in his remarks, concentrated on the economic hardships and political divisions in Czechoslovakia.
Noting that a year had passed since the student march on Wenceslas Square, he said: "Today we are standing here somewhat embarrassed. We know very well what we still have to accomplish, and the question springing up to mind is why do we find it so difficult to launch our joint project off the ground."
He said, "Are we really a nation capable of reviving its virtues only once in 20 years' time?"
Mr. Havel also quoted Alexander Hamilton to bolster his effort to unite the country's divided population and counter a separatist movement among some in the Slovak minority. He cited a document in which Hamilton said, "Among the greatest obstacles obstructing the passage of the new constitution, one can easily discern the undisguised interest of a certain group of people in each state to prevent the coming of all changes threatening to restrict their power."

HEADLINE: Cuomo Seeks Big Cuts; 10,000 May Be Laid Off

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Warning that New York State faced "no other choice," Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today proposed layoffs of up to 10,000 state workers and other actions that would ultimately reduce the state government's work force by about 18,000 jobs, or 10 percent.
The Governor's plan, intended to close huge budget shortfalls that have become a near-chronic affliction in Albany, would sharply scale back services at virtually every level of state government and would inflict painful cutbacks on local governments as well. 
 New York City, already overwhelmed with budget gaps of its own, would lose at least $100 million in state aid.
 
Huge Layoffs, Fernandez Warns
Although Cuomo administration officials pledged to work with New York City to minimize the impact of the proposed loss in aid, Mayor David N. Dinkins said he feared even greater cuts and their toll on city services. [Page 42.]
Included in the Governor's $100 million figure was a reduction of $75 million in aid to New York City's schools, a move that Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez has said could force him to lay off thousands of teachers.
Under the proposal, most of which is subject to approval by the Legislature, the state government would immediately cut aid to all school districts by a total of $200 million, and reduce Medicaid and other social programs by an almost equal amount.
 
Even More Cuts Next Year
In addition to closing the $1 billion gap the state faces in its current budget, the plan would start saving at least $1.3 billion in the budget for the fiscal year that begins next April, the Governor said at a press briefing in the Capitol. But even more cuts could be required then. Some state officials, including Comptroller Edward V. Regan, have forecast a budget gap of up to $3 billion for the next fiscal year.
Almost all state employees would have to take five days off without pay over the next few months. It would be the first time in state history that workers would be ordered to take unpaid furloughs.
The proposal would also propel smaller but unusual cutbacks in hundreds of other areas. To save money, New York would bar visitors from state prisons except on weekends. It would also turn off night safety lights along most state parkways in Westchester County and on Long Island.
All told, the Governor's plan would carve about $1 billion out of the $8 billion the state was planning to spend in the rest of the fiscal year that ends in March. The yearly budget was $30 billion, already the most austere of Mr. Cuomo's eight years in office.
 
No Tax Increases
 Mr. Cuomo's plan adheres to his pledge earlier this year not to raise taxes or resort to borrowing to close the gaps. After two years in which the Governor and lawmakers approved the largest tax increases in the state's history, the state could not afford to go that route again, Mr. Cuomo said.
"This plan closes the gap without taxes and without deficit notes," he said. "It does not do it, however, without pain."
Mr. Cuomo and the state's legislative leaders have been roundly criticized over the last few years for dealing with the state's fiscal problems on virtually an ad-hoc basis, and for using fiscal sleight-of-hand that tended to roll one year's problem over to the next.
In issuing his plan today, the Governor was clearly seeking to seize control not only over this year's problem but over next year's deficit as well.
Moreover, although lawmakers will most likely revise facets of the Governor's plan, the basic obligation to cut spending seems unavoidable. Under new strictures that the Legislature imposed on itself last year, its ability to borrow its way out of the problem is sharply curtailed. And both Assembly Speaker Mel Miller and Senate Majority Leader Ralph J. Marino have agreed with the Governor that tax increases should be avoided.
 
Facing the Inevitable
"Our position will be, if you don't like these cuts, then show me what other cuts you have in mind," Mr. Cuomo said. "I frankly don't believe there are a whole lot of other alternatives."
Mr. Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat, said in a statement today that cuts in local assistance were inevitable. He said he had just begun reviewing the Governor's proposals and would reserve further comment.
The economic turmoil New York faces is reflected even more severely in its neighboring states. Both Connecticut and New Jersey are struggling to close gaps that are a larger percentage of their budgets than New York's.
Governor Cuomo's plan to lay off workers as well as to eliminate jobs through attrition and early retirementwould be spread across 26 state agencies over the next 17 months and would purge 18,000 positions from the approximately 180,000 on the state payroll. About 60,000 more workers are paid by New York State from Federal Government funds and other sources.
The plan would eliminate 6,000 state jobs before March 31, about 2,000 of those through layoffs, the Governor's Budget Director, Dall W. Forsythe, said today. In the 1991-92 fiscal year, which begins April 1, 12,000 more positions would be eliminated.
Mr. Forsythe declined to specify how many jobs each agency would lose, saying he preferred to brief union leaders before making that information public. Other Cuomo administration officials said the most serious job cutbacks would occur in mental-health care and in the Corrections Department, where at least 300 prison guards would lose their jobs.
 
Unions to Resist
 Union leaders vowed a bitter fight against both the layoffs and the mandatory furloughs. "Jettisoning thousands of dedicated state employees is not the answer to these fiscal problems," said Rand Condell, president of the 60,000-member New York State Public Employees Federation.
The state's ailing hospital system would lose about $55 million in state funds in the current year, partly through delays in planned Medicaid rate increases. The losses would amount to a partial retreat from a major hospital bailout package passed by the Legislature this summer.
The president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, Kenneth E. Raske, denounced the proposed cutbacks, saying they would have "the potential to wreck the health-care system in New York."
 
'Painful' in New York City
In New York City, the cuts would be felt most keenly in education, hospitals and other social services, said Mayor Dinkins's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael.
"It will be extremely painful, because we have no buffer left," Mr. Michael said in an interview today. "There is only one way to cover the loss, and that is to cut our services. There's nothing left under a rock, or in a reserve fund."
Both Mr. Michael and Mayor Dinkins said they needed more time to review the plan, but their initial assessment was that the city might lose as much as $200 million in state aid over the next few months, or twice the figure provided by the Cuomo administration. Mr. Cuomo's spokeswoman, Anne Crowley, said the Governor had pledged to work with the city to keep the cuts at $100 million.
 
Pressure to Review Teacher Pay
Mr. Dinkins stopped short of vowing to fight the cuts, saying he understood that the state's "long-term fiscal stability" might be at stake. But he said the city's own financial difficulties would require that it receive state relief in some form, possibly through the relaxation of state-imposed mandates or measures to reduce the cost of borrowing.
The cuts in school aid are certain to renew pressure on Mr. Dinkins and other city officials to reconsider the 5.5 percent pay increase recently negotiated with the teachers' union. About $70 million to help cover the increase was to come from state education aid, which is now being cut.
 
Nullify Contract, Stein Says
 The City Council President, Andrew J. Stein, said today that the contract agreement should be nullified and that officials should "substitute an agreement that works in the best interests of everyone."
The Governor said his education cuts had been tailored to be less severe in poor school districts than in wealthy ones.
Implicit in Mr. Cuomo's plan was an attack on "member items," or special funds that lawmakers have created to dole out money to various projects in their districts. These items, denounced for years by the Governor as pork-barrel spending, include grants for everything from local senior citizens' organizations to uniforms for Little League baseball teams.
The Governor's plan would immediately freeze all outstanding member items, saving the state from $40 million to $50 million this year. Repeated attempts by the Governor to do away with the spending have been rejected by the Legislature.
In issuing his plan, the Governor sought to state its impact favorably. "While these cuts are painful," he said, "they must be viewed in the context of the overall generous investments of this administration in education, social services and local aid over the last eight years."
Nevertheless, the immediate protests from union groups, local leaders and others affected by the cuts indicated that when the Legislature reconvenes soon to consider the Governor's plan, there could be a bruising fight.

 
 
THE GOVERNOR'S CUTS

 
Higlights of the plan proposed yesterday by Governor Cuomo:
 
Lay off up to 10,000 state worlers over the next 17 months. 2,000 layoffs would occur by March 31.
 
Eliminate up to 8,000 additional state jobs over the next 17 months through early retirement programs and attrition. 4,000 jobs eliminated by March 31.
 
Require five-day unpaid furloughs for state workers.
 
Cut aid to local school districts by 2.5 percent.
 
Cut revenue-sharing payments to local governments by 10 percent.
 
Cut Medicaid payments and payments to hospitals.
